HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: Digital Commerce;
Concern is growing over people and companies that are stockpiling patents to be used as competitive weapons.

BYLINE: By Denise Caruso 

 BODY:
AS the industrial age gets creakier, the information age is lubricating a new economy with the flow of ideas.
Ideas are given their literal currency through patent and copyright laws, originally intended to stimulate innovation by protecting inventors from idea snatchers and allowing them to profit more easily from their talents. But some experts worry that an increasing number of individuals and companies are perverting that original purpose with increasingly specious claims to ownership, as well as by stockpiling patents into competitive arsenals. 
 Several examples of patent absurdity have been in the news lately. Relatively new on the scene are "method of doing business" patents, otherwise known as "soft" patents because they do not actually cover a physical invention. Such patents, which also included software, were rejected by the United States Patent and Trademark Office as a matter of course until very recently, when courts began overturning the patent office's refusals.
Soft patents are frowned on by many people involved with intellectual property because they often lay claim to some of the most mundane activities of daily life.
Earlier this month, for example, the Internet Patent News Service, an on-line newsletter, bestowed its "Worst Method of Doing Business Patent in 1998" award upon Patent No. 5,851,117, granted to a company for its blindingly original idea of using an illustrated book to teach janitors how to clean a building.
A patent for using a book as a teaching tool? "This claim should never have been written, let alone allowed," Gregory Aharonian, editor of the Internet Patent News Service, wrote in a recent issue of his newsletter.
A similar patent claim is being made against MP3.com (www.mp3.com), the Internet music seller. MP3 has the music industry in a panic because its World Wide Web site allows visitors to download audio files of thousands of copyrighted songs free; it also enables musicians to sell their CD's directly to customers, thus bypassing record labels and pocketing much more profit.
The challenger, Sightsound.com, claimed in a letter to Michael Robertson, president of MP3.com, that it holds patents that control "among other things, the sale of audio or video recordings in download fashion over the Internet."
The letter then asked Mr. Robertson to pay its licensing fee: 1 percent of all revenue that MP3 derives from the sale of downloaded audio files.
Nice work if you can get it. Mr. Robertson, however, who received the letter last week and has posted it on MP3's Web site, notes that MP3 does not sell the music it downloads, but gives it away.
More to the point: a patent for downloading files over the Internet for a fee? Given the fundamental capabilities of networked computers, this sounds remarkably like patenting the combination of a pencil, a piece of paper and a stamp as a method for writing a letter.
"I just have to wonder if the Patent Office has completely lost its mind," Mr. Robertson said.
Such sweeping "method of doing business" patents are only part of the problem. In a recent issue of the venerable high-technology trade journal, Electronic Engineering Times, one of its executive editors, Ron Wilson, wrote in an editorial that "U.S. intellectual property law is rapidly reducing itself to absurdity," adding that the patent process "has turned into a bludgeon to crush competition."
Mr. Wilson cites several examples of how various technology companies, including I.B.M, Intel and Hewlett-Packard, use their vast holdings of patents as competitive weaponry in seeking to disable each other with infringement charges.
In fact, just last week a new arms dealer opened its on-line doors: a company based in Pasadena, Calif., called the Patent and License Exchange (www.pl-x.com), promotes its site as offering an "easy-to-search patent inventory, on-line bid placement, secure chat room negotiation, closing services (escrow) and aftermarket license administration."
Today's relaxed rules for granting patents, and the greater ease with which arsenals can thus be amassed, gives a decided battle advantage to industry heavyweights.
"The big guys couldn't care less about the quality of their patents," Mr. Aharonian said. "They just want as many as possible because they trade them like baseball cards. When you have a thousand patents and your competition has 1,500, you don't care what they are, you just swap them."
It's far easier than hauling one another into court, he said. But small companies, even if they are defending good, solidly researched patents, are seldom taken seriously by big companies, Mr. Aharonian said. He added: "If you're a small company, have you got a million bucks to sue Microsoft over patent infringement? I don't know if these companies realize ahead of time what the game is. A patent is just the first step to spending a lot of money."
Of course, none of this money would be spent without expert counsel. Mr. Wilson recalls attending a conference a year or so ago given by a patent lawyer who was giving instructions on how to build competitive patent bludgeons. "He was describing the strategy they recommended to their clients," Mr. Wilson said, "which was basically a pyramid of patent protection."
Mr. Aharonian sees the wielding of patent portfolios as a form of class warfare, where the lines are drawn between big companies and small, with consolidation and mergers creating a constant tension between the two camps.
"Change is always good, and change usually comes from new people; and if those new start-ups can't get protection, you'll see less change, less innovation, less entrepreneurialism," Mr. Aharonian said. "That's why big companies don't want the system to change -- they'd get a lot less patents."
In today's business environment, in which a company's market value is measured with increasing frequency by the intellectual property it owns, arsenals of patents -- specious or not -- make an unfortunate kind of sense.
"If you're concerned about the planking," Mr. Wilson said, "you don't want someone rocking the boat."

HEADLINE: Last Holdouts Join Other Airlines in Raising Fares

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
United Airlines, Trans World Airlines and U S Airways joined the other large domestic airlines and raised their fares over the weekend, virtually assuring the success of the first industrywide fare increase in more than a year.
Several carriers had been pushing for an increase for months, but their efforts were thwarted by Northwest Airlines, which refused to go along. But on Friday, Northwest followed Delta Air Lines, raising prices 2 percent on last-minute, walk-up fares most often paid by business travelers and 4 percent on advance-purchase tickets aimed at vacationers. 
 Other airlines quickly raised prices, followed by the three holdouts: United, T.W.A. and U S Airways. While Northwest or another airline could still roll back prices, forcing others to follow suit, industry analysts say that is unlikely.
"I think it is safe to say that it will stick," Samuel C. Buttrick, an airline analyst with Paine Webber in New York, said yesterday.
While there has not been an across-the-board increase since 1997, fares have regularly risen on individual routes. Mr. Buttrick said the latest increase would have little effect on consumers who shop for discounts because the airlines would still run sales featuring ticket prices at the current levels or lower. Indeed, United announced a sale on Friday, hours before it adjusted its general fare structure to reflect the new increase.
However, corporations, which have seen business fares rise 34 percent over the last three years, according to the American Express Company, will see another increase. Many companies have started buying restricted leisure fares, preferring to pay the $75 penalty for changing flights because the total cost is still cheaper than the walk-up fare. Others are cutting travel or encouraging alternatives like video conferencing to save money.
Airline executives and industry analysts said that the increase was justified even though inflation was less than 1 percent last year because revenue has been declining. This year, the airlines plan to add about 5 percent more seats, putting further pressure on their profits.
Delta led the fare increase after it failed last week in an attempt to add a $1 surcharge on tickets not booked through its Internet site.
Consumer advocates, corporations and some vocal politicians have complained that air fares are already too high and threaten to strangle economic growth in regions not served by two or more carriers.
"Nobody is going to take away the expectation and the privilege for an industry to raise prices if it can," said Kevin Mitchell, chairman of the Business Travel Coalition, which lobbies on behalf of several large corporations. "The problem is if it is in the absence of competition."
Airline stocks soared on Friday after Northwest matched Delta's increase. But Mr. Buttrick said the price increase was not a panacea for the industry. He estimated that the fare increase would bolster industry revenue by 1.5 percent this year, significantly less than the 4 percent revenue growth he is forecasting.
"It is going to take more than this fare increase to get there, based on recent trends," he said.

HEADLINE: Too Involved In Kosovo

BYLINE: By Lee H. Hamilton; Lee H. Hamilton, the former Democratic chairman of the House International Relations Committee, is director of the Woodrow Wilson Center.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Deploying American and NATO troops in Kosovo may well be necessary in the short term to prevent the outbreak of wider violence and to help carry out a political settlement. Yet, the possibility of this additional obligation of manpower and resources in the former Yugoslavia raises the important question of whether we are overengaged in this relatively small region.
America and Americans are everywhere in the states of the former Yugoslavia. The United States and NATO already have about 800 monitors, of whom about 180 are Americans, on the ground in Kosovo. In addition, the alliance will soon have up to 3,000 troops in neighboring Macedonia. These troops will be deployed in addition to the 32,000 troops -- 6,900 of them Americans -- who remain in Bosnia. The Bosnia deployments, which began three years ago, have cost well over $20 billion. 
 We have not just supplied troops. The United States and its NATO allies have become deeply involved in nearly every aspect of the civilian and humanitarian problems in these regions. We are supplying billions of dollars more to promote reconstruction, political and economic reforms, and humanitarian aid, especially in Bosnia.
American officials are in leadership positions all over the region. We are practically the proconsul of the former Yugoslavia. Americans command the NATO-led peacekeeping force in Bosnia. We have the controlling voice in the fate of Brcko, a pivotal Bosnian town. We are arming and training the forces of the Muslim-Croat Federation. Another American Ambassador commands the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe's unarmed monitoring force in Kosovo.
This is simply too much. It is time to take a step back and put this open-ended commitment into proper perspective. Each peacekeeping mission -- in Bosnia, Kosovo and Macedonia -- taken by itself has been defensible, helpful and important, and I have supported each one, and the Administration has done a good job in responding to these crises. But now it seems we're pushing our commitment too far.
Viewed from the wider perspective, this commitment of time, effort and expense that the United States and its allies have made and will still have to devote to the former Yugoslavia is greatly disproportionate to its relative importance to our national interest. For all their savagery, the conflicts there have been essentially local, the result of unresolved ethnic, religious and power disputes.
It is true that if we took our troops out of Bosnia or our monitors out of Kosovo, violence would break out almost immediately. There will be peace only as long as we stay. There is little chance for self-sustaining peace in either Bosnia or Kosovo in this generation.
So, we are mired. This will cost us many more billions.
It is not at all certain that Congress and the American people -- who have been lukewarm at best about our deep involvement in the Balkans -- will continue to support our enormous commitments indefinitely. We cannot just pull out of the region, but we must seriously begin to look at a gradual "de-Americanization" strategy that allows us to reduce our engagement over time, and not get more deeply involved, as we are doing now in Kosovo.
For this to work, our European allies must take over more responsibility. A good start was the willingness of the French to assume leadership of the NATO troops that protect the monitors in Kosovo. That force includes no American ground troops. The Europeans already have the lead in carrying out the civilian reconstruction in Bosnia. We should also continue to work closely with the Europeans on the future of Kosovo, so that this does not end up as an entirely American affair.
There are greater threats to our national interests than those posed by the problems of the former Yugoslavia. If we don't put the perpetual crisis there into proper perspective, we will be less able to respond to the real threats to our security and national interests.

HEADLINE: Malaysia's Leader Rattles Meeting of Financial Elite

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 31

 BODY:
The world's financial commanders have had no greater nemesis in recent years than Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, who has banned the trading of his country's currency, denounced American economic imperialism and jailed his Finance Minister for daring to challenge his economic prescriptions and his iron-handed rule.
So it came as something of a jolt for the world's most dedicated capitalists, gathering for an annual retreat of financial elite in this Swiss resort, to discover Mr. Mahathir in their midst. 
 He has been everywhere, behind closed doors with bankers, dropping hints that he is thinking of cutting special deals for "responsible" investors who want to move money in and out of his country, declaiming on his theories about the role of Jews in starting the crisis that spread from Asia to Russia to Latin America.
True to form, Mr. Mahathir has been by turns charming and combative -- except on one subject, the ongoing corruption and sexual misconduct trial of his former hand-picked successor, Anwar Ibrahim.
"He thought he could unseat me through street demonstrations, the way Suharto was overthrown by street demonstrations," Mr. Mahathir said over dinner on Saturday night with a group of journalists, referring to the fate of the former President of Indonesia, the most prominent political casualty of the economic crisis. "There are other charges against him that have not yet been proffered," he warned darkly about his one-time protege. "Whether he is acquitted or not, he will have to face more."
In one sense, Mr. Mahathir is lost in the parade of luminaries here, from Nelson Mandela to Yevgeny Primakov to Kofi Annan to the huge delegation of American officials who sometimes cannot help sounding a bit like they are taking a victory lap.
They arrived here just as Washington was announcing another spectacular quarter of growth for the American economy -- 5.6 percent, exceeding all expectations -- that only underscored the sense among the crisis-wracked here that the global financial system is rigged for America's benefit.
And that makes Mr. Mahathir's theories sound a lot less wild to many now than they did 18 months ago. Back then, he was still debating George Soros -- the financier who is also here with a parcel of aides whispering into the tiniest of cell phones -- about the dangers of currency speculators.
In a bitter debate with Mr. Soros at the 1997 meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, Mr. Mahathir called for controls on the free flow of capital around the world, and Mr. Soros called the Prime Minister "a menace to his own country."
Now Mr. Mahathir's favorite hobbyhorse -- controlling capitalism's excesses, keeping small countries from being washed out to sea by the ebb and flow of billions of dollars -- is the subtext of half the seminars here in Davos.
While almost no one has endorsed the Malaysian solution, declaring a nation's currency valueless outside its borders, the 73-year-old Prime Minister has come to seek vindication, and to delight in the fact that the International Monetary Fund and the United States Treasury fear others could follow Mr. Mahathir's path.
"The U.S. must be more tolerant of the stupidity of Malaysia," he said. "Why not leave us to do the wrong things we want to do? What is this talk about freedom and independence if you say I have the power to stop you and I will stop you?"
Actually, the United States has not exactly said that. But Mr. Mahathir was directly challenged on his own turf in November by Vice President Al Gore, who at an Asian economic summit meeting in Kuala Lumpur took up the language of Mr. Anwar and other enemies of Mr. Mahathir's rule, openly calling for "reformasi," or reform.
Mr. Gore's aides are happy that it played well back home, that the Vice President, in the words of one of his advisers, "took on a tin-pot dictator."
Here in Davos, Mr. Mahathir and Mr. Gore steered clear of each other, no small trick in a town this small. But Mr. Mahathir spent a good deal of time repairing relations with investors, who have cut his country off ever since Malaysia declared that any money invested in the country must stay there for at least one year.
Asked over dinner about statements he made to largely Muslim audiences in Malaysia about the role of Jews in causing the global financial crisis, he readily admitted that his people "see a Jewish hand" in the chaos, and he did not appear prepared to challenge that perception.
"They see Mr. Soros, and he is a Jew," Mr. Mahathir said. "He will give the impression that this is a Jewish plot. This is the impression of ordinary people in Malaysia."
When a questioner asked whether Mr. Mahathir agreed with ordinary Malays that a Jewish plot exists, he hesitated a brief second and said, "I do not think there is."

HEADLINE: Americans at U.N. Seek Parity With Foreign Co-Workers

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 29

 BODY:
A group of American citizens working for the United Nations in professional-level jobs are preparing to step up a fight to receive the same education grants for their children that foreign officials get in New York.
Under an agreement more than 50 years old, foreign professionals working at the United Nations headquarters as specialists in a range of fields including economics, political affairs and technical or financial services receive more than $15,500 a year for each child in school in New York. 
 Americans do not get the grants, which were intended to allow foreign families to pay for a private education in the language or culture of their home countries, so that the children could return comfortably to those nations.
"It wouldn't be so bad if it were used for the purpose intended," an American working here said. The reality, this official and others from various countries said, is that the grant buys entry to the best private schools and colleges for children who may have been born in this country, have an American parent or be part of a family settled here. Since 1994, United Nations officials may apply for permanent residency after 15 years of work at the headquarters.
"What makes it so unjust is that many of these children are Americans like our children," an American parent said. The Americans -- about 108 officials with a total of more than 170 children -- want help from United States representatives on the United Nations committee that determines these grants, said Stephen Baldwin, who recently retired as an official in the Department of Economic and Social Affairs.
In 1995, Mr. Baldwin was among a group of Americans who petitioned the United Nations Administrative Tribunal, the organization's highest judicial panel, for equal treatment. They were turned down.
Mr. Baldwin suggested in an interview that the General Assembly, the group of 185 nations that formally sets the grant levels, could freeze increases until the Americans could be brought into the program. This would not add costs to the organization's already hamstrung budget.
The United States, unlike many other nations, is perennially reluctant to become involved in the cases of Americans working for the United Nations, officials say.
"It would be very helpful to us if our own representatives were to take up this case and say this isn't a level playing field," Mr. Baldwin said.
Another parent, who did not want to be identified, said the American Government's attitude "represents the low esteem with which the United Nations is held in Washington."
Some American officials have recommended abolishing the grant entirely, but Mr. Baldwin said that this would be politically unrealistic and "draconian," because many families are involved who do send their children to foreign-language schools and need financial help living in New York. Average salaries for these professional-level jobs hover around $75,000 to $80,000.
The education grant has become an untaxed windfall for foreigners, augmenting their salaries substantially, American professionals say.
The grants apply only to United Nations officials, whose salaries and benefits are set or reviewed by the General Assembly and the International Civil Service Commission. The supplements do not apply to diplomats based in foreign missions in New York, though they may qualify for other programs through their respective governments.
Americans in United Nations service are eligible for the grants when they are sent abroad. But many United Nations officials spend a large part of their careers at the headquarters in New York, where city neighborhood schools may have problems and private education is expensive.
The supplements were originally for children up to the age of 11, who would then return to their home countries for secondary and higher education. They are now being used up through university level.
The grants can easily be misused, United Nations employees say. A Canadian reported cases of children from extended families being brought to New York to raise the number of supplements added to an official salary.
Unmarried employees also say that they watch married colleagues increase their incomes substantially with the education grants as their families grow, while single officials live on flat salaries.

HEADLINE: Essay;
A Russian Feeler

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
With Russian inflation running at 100 percent a year, Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov told a little joke about being forced to accept demands to be disclosed next week by the International Monetary Fund.
"A man is handed a letter from his wife," he said at the World Economic Forum. "He opens it and the page is blank. 'How can that be?' he is asked. 'It's all right,' he replies. 'We don't talk.' " 
 He had begged Al Gore to lean on the I.M.F. for repayment delay and new loans, and was turned down for good reason: the former spymaster has no economic plan to deal with congenital corruption beyond "optimizing the prison population."
But if Russia goes under, 30,000 nuclear missiles and the scientists and engineers behind them go on sale. The nation is not "too big to fail" (its population is smaller than Indonesia's, and is slumping toward half that of the U.S.), but the fallout from its collapse could be dangerous.
The usual cast of pompous Russian reformers and Yeltsin bureaucrats who used to parade around this Alpine conclave is absent. Now, a skeleton crew of Primakov's bankers wring their hands about devaluation and default, in contrast to the single longtime voice of opposition with the plan and self-confidence to turn Russia around -- Grigory Yavlinsky.
The economist and former pugilist, 47, is the last democratic reformer left standing. That's because he ignored Boris Yeltsin's seductive revolving door and instead built a grassroots party. In December's parliamentary elections, his Yabloko Party will grow; and running for President in 2000, Yavlinsky will at least be kingmaker.
Western Kremlinologists no longer hoot in derision when I say that; they saw Yabloko make possible Primakov's temporary ascension. Yavlinsky insists it was the only way to insure free elections after Yeltsin, but power-hungry Primakov may have other ideas.
Yavlinsky preaches the need for "tough love" to top American officials, to get us to assume Russia's I.M.F. repayments without new I.M.F. cash infusions. To regain the confidence of investors, he seeks new ways to reinstill Russian self-confidence.
One way is to break the mold on missile defense. President Clinton, after six years of pooh-poohing a shield against rogue-state missiles, suddenly reversed field lest he be blamed for vulnerability to germ blackmail. But Russians do not want to change the old ABM treaty that kept each superpower defenseless against the other. When I asked Primakov about it, he stayed in the old Communist rut: touch ABM and Start II won't be ratified.
Yavlinsky comes at it creatively: "America has a right to missile defense against terrorism, as does Europe, of which Russia is a part." He proposes a non-strategic missile defense in cooperation with NATO, capable of shooting down fewer than 100 missiles, thereby providing an umbrella against terrorist attack without destabilizing the Russian-American standoff. That would finesse the impasse and ease ratification of Start II's reductions.
Russian pride would thus be salved and money saved, but I see other motives: it would provide paying work for thousands of talented Russian technologists now looking hungrily toward Iran and Iraq, and would lessen the pressure for sales of missile and nuclear plants to states already taking advantage of Russian desperation.
Does Russia have anything to offer in missile defense? Using a handy-dandy cell phone, I called Prof. Andrei Piontkovsky in Moscow, director of the Academy of Science's strategic studies, to ask what Russia had on the shelf to shoot down missiles.
"The S-300," he replied promptly, as if I were a customer, "two years more advanced than your Patriots." That's dubious; he could not point to a single successful test of that missile against missiles. Besides, the S-300 is the weapon Russia peddled to Greek Cypriots until the Turks warned they would take out any such missiles that were delivered.
Still, Russians have long been adept at making long-range nukes and might bring expertise to the anti-missile table. Rather than punish Russia for dealing with Iran, the West, Yavlinsky urges, should cooperate with Russia to keep its scientists, know-how and products at home.
Worth discussing. As Clinton belatedly dumps his resistance to missile defense, we can usefully explore with NATO and Russia ways to stop incoming terrorist missiles. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Mirra Komarovsky, Authority on Women's Studies, Dies at 93

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Mirra Komarovsky, a sociologist who was an innovative authority on gender, family and education, died on Saturday at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 93.
Professor Komarovsky retired in 1970 after 32 years on the faculty of Barnard College. But she returned to Barnard in 1978 and became the chairwoman of its women's studies program for a time. 
 She was an advocate for women who has been credited with having initiated the contemporary analysis of gender roles with her book "Women in the Modern World: Their Education and Their Dilemmas" (1953, Irvington).
In that work she wrote that by making the purposes of women's education clearer, barriers to the attainment of a good life could be removed. As to the respective merits of training for a career and of education meant only for a homemaker, she wrote: "To disagree with the antifeminist does not necessarily make one a feminist. We can reject the antifeminist program without having to embrace the old-fashioned feminism with its militant hostility towards, and its disparagement of, the homemaker."
In 1991, Ellen V. Futter, who was Barnard's president at the time, said Professor Komarovsky's "research has been crucial to our understanding of today's women and the choices they make."
In that year Professor Komarovsky received the Distinguished Career Award of the American Sociological Association. Earlier, in 1973 and 1974, she was the second female president of the association, which was founded in 1905.
In her book "Women in College: Shaping New Feminine Identities" (1985) she described changing views of work, family and men that were held by students in the class of 1983 at Barnard, a women's college.
Reviewing that book in The New York Times Book Review, Adele Simmons, then president of Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., wrote: "The impact of the women's movement on higher education becomes apparent to even the most skeptical reader." She noted that Professor Komarovsky observed bleakly that, as Dr. Simmons put it, "while attitudes have changed, institutions have not. The gains of the last decade, she warns, will only be secure when society develops permanent measures to support women in the workplace as well as in the home."
In researching the book, Professor Komarovsky used interviews, questionnaires and surveys to study the attitudes of more than 200 students in the Barnard class of 1983. Fully two-thirds of those young women were afflicted with what she called "culture shock" that differed from student to student. As Dr. Simmons put it, "Ideas about virginity, femininity, sexual preferences and study habits all came under scrutiny as students' friendships evolved and intellectual challenges arose."
Professor Komarovsky found that 76 percent of the female students planned, at the time they entered Barnard, on combining career, marriage and children in the coming years. And by the time the class graduated, fully 85 percent of its members had come to have that threefold ambition.
Two observations of Professors Komarovsky's that Dr. Simmons found intriguing were her finding that the most highly career-minded students had mothers who had not worked and regretted it -- or mothers who worked and enjoyed it; and her suggestion that the young women sought a mixture of sensitivity, self-awareness and masculinity in men.
Professor Komarovsky also found that most of the women she surveyed found it hard to attain relationships that they considered satisfactory with men, although those women had had chances to interact with men from a variety of backgrounds.
Rather similarly, Professor Komarovsky wrote, on the New York Times Op-Ed page in 1981: "Young women are becoming aware that the call to equal opportunities for women outside the home is an empty slogan as long as the society insists on traditional role segregation within the family. Some women react to this discovery with equanimity, others with frustration, resignation or indignation. But the real touchstone of their aspirations is the longing for a society in which the rhetoric of equality will be realized as fact. There is no denying that this would require major institutional changes."
What to do? "We have much to learn from Sweden," Professor Komarovsky wrote: "Modified work patterns for both sexes, housing patterns permitting more-cooperative ties among child-rearing families, accessible child-care centers of high quality for all economic classes."
Over the years, she also wrote about various aspects of sociology, including theory and methodology.
She was born in Baku, on the Caspian Sea, in what was then Russia, to Mendel Komarovsky and the former Anna Steinberg, and she was raised largely in Baku. When she was 17, she and her family emigrated to the United States. She attended a high school for a year in Wichita, Kan., where some members of her family lived, and went on to receive a bachelor's degree in 1926 from Barnard, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa and was taught by the anthropologists Ruth Benedict and Franz Boas.
Nonetheless, as the book "Women in Sociology" (1991, Greenwood), edited by Mary Jo Deegan, reports: "Komarovsky was puzzled" by Barnard's "extolling intellectual excellence while discouraging women from pursuing careers."
She received a master's degree in 1927 and a doctorate in 1940, both in sociology, and both from Columbia. Her doctoral thesis was published as a book, "The Unemployed Man and His Family" (1940).
Earlier, she was a co-author of the book "Leisure: A Suburban Study" (1934). In addition, before joining the Barnard faculty as an instructor in 1938, she taught at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and was a research assistant at the Yale University Institute of Human Relations, at Columbia, and at the International Institute of Social Research in New York.
She was chairman of the sociology department at Barnard from 1949 to 1968 and was president of the Eastern Sociological Society in 1955 and 1956.
But she recalled years later that in the 1940's and even later, choosing women's issues to do research on was at a cost to her. The field lacked academic glamor and was not likely to further a career.
An early marriage, in 1926, ended in divorce in 1928. In 1940, she married Marcus A. Heyman, who died in 1970.
Her survivors include a sister, Dolly Cheser of Rockville Centre, L.I., and five nieces and one nephew.

HEADLINE: Whitman Breaks Leg While Skiing on Swiss Slope

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey broke her lower leg in two places yesterday when she fell while skiing in Davos, Switzerland, where she is attending the World Economic Forum.
"She was on an intermediate slope and took a turn and a twist and the rest was history," said Jayne O'Connor, a spokeswoman for the Governor. 
 Mrs. Whitman, 52, underwent surgery at a local hospital, Spital Davos, and is expected to remain there until midweek, Ms. O'Connor said. The Governor will probably have to cancel a trip to visit NATO troops in Stuttgart, Germany, tomorrow, another spokesman, Pete McDonough, told the Associated Press. She may delay her return to New Jersey, originally scheduled for Wednesday, Ms. O'Connor said.
Mrs. Whitman is expected to require a cast but not crutches, Mr. McDonough said. It was not clear last night which leg the Governor had broken.
The Governor, an avid skier, cyclist, horseback rider, canoeist and tennis player, was on an outing organized by the economic forum, an annual gathering of political, economic and cultural leaders from many countries. This was the second year that Mrs. Whitman attended the conference, Ms. O'Connor said.
While Mrs. Whitman is out of the country, the State Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, Republican of Scotch Plains, is Acting Governor.
Ms. O'Connor said that she did not know if the Governor would miss any of her state duties when she returns to New Jersey, but she added that Mrs. Whitman has tremendous powers of recuperation.

HEADLINE: CLINTON TO UNVEIL $1.7 TRILLION PLAN FOR U.S. SPENDING

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
President Clinton will release a $1.766 trillion Federal budget blueprint for 2000 on Monday that proposes billions of dollars in new spending while preaching fiscal conservatism.
Mr. Clinton's budget plan will ask Congress for substantial new money for scores of domestic programs popular with liberal and middle-class constituencies, from urban housing vouchers to classroom construction. 
 But Mr. Clinton, taking advantage of surging Federal tax receipts, will also propose large spending increases for cherished Republican priorities: the military, local police and small business.
The President's plan envisions a budget surplus of at least $76 billion for the current fiscal year and much larger surpluses stretching as far into the future as Government forecasters can see.
The health of the American economy and overflowing Federal coffers allow Mr. Clinton the luxury of indulging in large new "investments" in politically popular labor, education, health care and environmental projects while cloaking himself in fiscal prudence by proposing to use budget surpluses to pay down the Federal debt.
But, as has happened so often in the past 12 months of scandal and impeachment, Mr. Clinton will dominate only half of the attention of official Washington and the media on Monday. At the very moment Mr. Clinton is unveiling his budget in an East Room ceremony, Monica S. Lewinsky will be sitting down with a roomful of lawyers, senators and House prosecutors in a hotel suite five blocks away to be deposed in the Senate impeachment trial.
And the prospects for Mr. Clinton's ambitious programs are uncertain given Republican majorities in both houses of Congress and the ill will on both sides as a result of the impeachment battle.
Mr. Clinton's proposal for increased defense spending is likely to win Republican support and in fact it may be increased. His plan to provide tax credits for long-term medical care also has bipartisan support. But many of the other spending programs are unlikely to win Republican backing at a time when limits on Federal spending imposed as a result of the Balanced Budget Agreement of 1997 remain in effect.
While Mr. Clinton proposes to increase overall Government spending by $39 billion over this year's level, Federal outlays as a proportion of the American economy will be at the lowest level since 1973, 19.4 percent.
The plan raises, but does not definitively answer, the overriding economic question now before the Congress and the White House -- how to adjust to a time of surplus after a generation of seemingly intractable Federal budget deficits. The plan, all of which is subject to Congressional approval, is in effect a holding action until a long-term plan is negotiated to shore up Social Security and Medicare, the crown jewels of Democratic progressivism that are projected to run out of money early in the next century.
"This year's budget is truly a historic document," Jack Lew, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, said. "The transition from an era of deficits to an era of surpluses has changed so many of the issues and poses basic, fundamental choices. What do you do in a time of fiscal well-being to insure that you'll have fiscal well-being far into the future?"
To that end, Mr. Clinton has announced a plan to insure the solvency of Social Security and Medicare well into the next century by reserving 77 percent of any budget surpluses to shore up the universal retirement and health care entitlements. An additional 12 percent of the projected surpluses is being set aside under the Administration's plan for a new form of retirement account designed to increase the nation's paltry personal savings rate.
In his State of the Union message, and now with his budget, Mr. Clinton has seized the fiscal and political high ground, moving into a policy vacuum created by a year of scandal and a Republican failure so far to offer a coherent and compelling blueprint for addressing the long-term problems of the nation's costliest domestic programs.
The President's budget -- bound in volumes with black covers symbolizing the ocean of black ink the Administration foresees -- attempts to do large things in relatively small steps. Social Security and Medicare will be rescued from future insolvency without pain to current taxpayers or future beneficiaries in the form of tax increases or reductions in benefits.
A senior Administration economic policymaker said that Mr. Clinton would have preferred much larger increases in programs to help America adapt to the high-technology future. But the fact of a Republican-controlled Congress hungry for tax cuts has limited the President's budgetary freedom of action.
"In a second-best world," said Gene Sperling, the President's chief economic adviser, "the reality of divided Government is that Clinton is able through a combination of hard negotiating and fiscal discipline to achieve targeted increases in these areas while proposing a fiscally disciplined budget."
Mr. Sperling continued, "We've learned there are two ways to score a touchdown -- by throwing the Hail Mary or by throwing six 15-yard passes to move the ball down the field. We've been successful in putting forward an investing-in-people agenda by going in and fighting for these programs one year at a time."
Schools, cities, displaced workers, the environment and the Pentagon will all receive sizable infusions of new money without any broad tax increases. The single largest proposal to raise revenue in the budget takes aim at Washington's favorite pair of deep pockets: cigarette smokers and tobacco companies.
Mr. Clinton is proposing a 55-cents-a-pack increase on cigarettes to raise $8 billion a year for the next five years. The tax increase will be described as an effort to reduce smoking by teen-agers by raising the price of cigarettes to almost $4 a pack, but the revenues are not earmarked for anti-smoking programs or to pay the health care costs of treating smoking-related illnesses.
That projected revenue will cover only a fraction of the $25.6 billion in new spending in the 2000 budget that Mr. Clinton has already announced -- from $12 billion for the Pentagon to $10 million to train Native American teachers to serve in predominantly Indian regions of the West.
Mr. Clinton is also proposing $20.6 billion in limited tax cuts over the next five years to subsidize long-term care for the elderly and disabled, build schoolrooms, develop fuel-efficient cars and promote adult literacy.
The public expresses broad support for such initiatives in White House and public polls, but there is no assurance that any of them will survive the Republican Congress, which is more interested in cutting tax rates across the board than embarking on a New Deal-style spending spree.
"The President has tried to satisfy every special-interest group except the middle-income taxpayer," said Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican who serves on the Senate Budget Committee. "When taxes are as high as they have ever been, it's time to let the taxpayers keep some more of their money."
Mr. Grassley said that initial reaction to the President's State of the Union message on Jan. 19 was favorable, even from many Republicans. But as more details of Mr. Clinton's spending plans have trickled out, a different picture emerges, he said.
"When he gave that speech on Jan. 19, it looked like a pretty middle-of-the-road position," Mr. Grassley said. "But upon reflection, what he's basically doing is just reverting to the classic Democratic policy. Three or four years ago he declared the era of Big Government is over. Well, the era of Big Government is back."

Scientists Solve the Riddle Of the AIDS Virus's Origin
The riddle of the origin of the AIDS virus has apparently been solved, according to an international team of scientists who reported that they had traced its roots to a related virus in a subspecies of chimpanzee in Africa. Because the chimpanzee is able to live with the virus without falling ill, the scientists expressed hope that their discovery would help improve therapies and develop an effective vaccine against the AIDS virus. SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 172 words

HEADLINE: Fed's Policy Is Sound;
What Academics Think

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In arguing that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, should ignore inflation and lower interest rates to reduce unemployment, Robert B. Reich (Op-Ed, Jan. 26) assumes that there is a tradeoff between inflation and unemployment and that the Federal Reserve can choose how much of each it wants by setting interest rates. 
 This idea has been discredited by academic economists. The majority view is that if Mr. Reich's proposals were implemented, the drop in unemployment would be short-lived; lowering interest rates and increasing the money supply would cause a permanent inflation, reducing the efficiency of the economy until inflation was vanquished yet again. To accuse Mr. Greenspan of not caring about the unemployed is disingenuous given that he is doing what he believes is everything in his power to help them, especially since most economists agree with him.
 
RUSSELL DIMOND
Madison, Wis., Jan. 27, 1999
 
The writer is a graduate student in economics, University of Wisconsin.

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
A CROWNING PERFORMANCE

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 31

 BODY:
John Elway would not say it in so many words, but for the Broncos' quarterback, their 34-19 victory in Super Bowl XXXIII tonight was probably his last roundup.
And his best. 
 As the oldest quarterback, at age 38, to start a Super Bowl game, he completed 18 of 29 passes for 336 yards, including an 80-yard touchdown arrow to wide receiver Rod Smith that broke the Atlanta Falcons' wings.
Elway also scored a clinching touchdown on a 3-yard keeper as the Broncos joined the Packers, the Dolphins, the Steelers (twice), the 49ers and the Cowboys as the only teams to win two consecutive Super Bowls.
After being voted the game's most valuable player by a panel from the news media, Elway sidestepped questions about his future.
"I'll cross that bridge later," he said in the interview area. "I don't even want to talk about retirement now."
Mike Shanahan, the Broncos' coach, acknowledged that "there's a good chance" this was Elway's last game, but the coach added that the quarterback's teammates were "talking to him about a three-peat" in the Super Bowl next season. No team has won three straight Super Bowls.
"It throws a kink into my thinking," Elway said of the three-peat possibility.
But without him, the Broncos and even Denver itself would never be quite the same.
Few athletes have ever defined their city or their area the way John Elway has. Until he arrived, Denver was just a mile-high cow town with low esteem in sports. The 1977 Broncos had been to the Super Bowl with their Orange Crush defense, but were crushed. The basketball Nuggets were never much. The baseball Rockies and the hockey Avalanche weren't even there yet.
But almost as soon as Elway started throwing passes in 1983, he usurped Denver's identity. He was bigger than the city itself, bigger than the Rocky Mountains in the distance. Other players didn't talk about playing Denver, they talked about playing Elway.
Other celebrated quarterbacks never upstaged their cities. Joe Montana wasn't San Francisco, the Golden Gate Bridge was. Terry Bradshaw wasn't Pittsburgh, steel was. Bart Starr wasn't Green Bay, bratwurst was. Joe Namath wasn't New York, Broadway and Fifth Avenue were. Johnny Unitas wasn't Baltimore, crab cakes were.
But for 16 seasons, John Elway has been Denver, and Denver was happy to have him, even when the Broncos lost three Super Bowls with him.
He even looked like he belonged there: big shoulders, with a lariat for an arm. And he walked like a cowboy who just got off his horse.
Elway was even part of the Denver economy. His automobile dealerships were so successful, they were sold about a year ago for a reported $82.5 million. Pat Bowlen, the Broncos' owner, has indicated that Elway might even emerge as a part owner of the franchise if he decides not to be a quarterback anymore.
When Elway was told tonight that he would be awarded his choice of either a Ford Mustang or a Ford Expedition as the game's most valuable player, he laughed and said, "That's all I need is some more cars."
Two weeks ago, Elway acted as if he had played his last game in Mile High Stadium. After he rallied the Broncos over the Jets, 23-10, for the American Football Conference title, he stayed on the field and waved goodbye. He told the fans, "I love you." He took a victory lap to "look into" their eyes.
What Elway saw in those eyes was their affection for a quarterback whose numbers as a passer, as dazzling as they were, never were as important to him as the numbers on the scoreboard.
Of all the appreciations of Elway through the years, the Broncos' backup, Bubby Brister, perhaps explained better than anybody else what has made Elway tick since he arrived in Denver after he told the Baltimore Colts, who had drafted him, that he wouldn't play for them.
"All John ever wants to know," Brister said last week, "is what he needs to win, whether it's Ping-Pong, fishing, basketball."
Brister remembered a fishing trip during the off season when Elway asked him the weight of the biggest fish he had ever caught. Brister told him 8 pounds 8 ounces.
"The next day," Brister recalled, laughing, "John caught a 9-pounder."
Another time they were playing a video game. Brister put up 52 points.
"John made 54," Brister said. "He's the most competitive guy I've ever known. And that same attitude made him such a great quarterback. When he was behind in the fourth quarter, all he wanted to know was what he needed to win -- a touchdown or a field goal."
More often than not, Elway generated that winning touchdown or that winning field goal.
In his career as the National Football League's career winningest quarterback, Elway produced a record 47 game-saving drives, including six in the post-season. And when he was asked the other day to rate his best moments other than the Super Bowl upset of the Packers a year ago, he mentioned two drives.
"I think 'the Drive' in Cleveland is the first thing that pops into my mind," he said, referring to winning the 1986 A.F.C. title game. "That kind of put me on the map. And I went 98 yards to kick a field goal to beat Houston in the first round of the playoffs. 'The Drive' in Cleveland was 98 yards, too."
The only reason Elway and anybody else remembers those drives is because the Broncos won those games -- the barometer he used in rating his top three quarterbacks.
"Comparing quarterbacks is like comparing apples and oranges," he said, "because the circumstances that each quarterback has are so different. But I think the bottom line is the guys who can figure out ways to win, no matter what the circumstances or what position they are in.
"You have to look at Dan Marino as being up there with his numbers and what he has done; unfortunately, he never has had a good enough team to go all the way. I think Johnny Unitas kicked everything off, a guy that won championships, and Roger Staubach because he was my idol when I was young."
Now, surely, John Elway is an idol for so many others -- the young who wish they could do what he does and the old who wish they had.
"If there's anything that sums up John's career," Shanahan said Friday, "it's that he puts the team first -- one of the reasons he's not talking about retirement right now. He doesn't want to lose focus of this football game; the game is more important than him and his retirement. He's an unselfish guy that has meant everything to Denver."
Just rename it Elway, Colorado.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
The Cream Still Rises, Even From Barrel Bottom

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
David Greenspan isn't a mere actor. He's an appliance on the fritz. Plug him in and watch the mechanism go haywire: he shakes and rattles, swivels and squeaks so persuasively you half expect smoke to rise from a crack in his forehead.
Onstage, his stock in trade is the alien among us, but not in the vein of Mork from Ork. Mr. Greenspan, an Obie-winning performer and playwright, alights from somewhere beyond the outer limits. Whether he's intimidating the other guests as a particularly spooky Harold in "The Boys in the Band" or waxing oleaginous in an enigmatic Mac Wellman extravaganza, he is always strung out in one way or another, on a supercilious tear or on the brink of total neurological collapse. And that's why he is ideal for "High Life," Lee MacDougall's new lowlife comedy at Primary Stages about a cockeyed gang of junkie grifters who botch an A.T.M. heist and end up killing one of their own. 
 Any week in New York City, you can find two or three new Off Broadway plays that, like "High Life," ruminate about lowlifes. As the nation becomes ever more affluent, it seems, the theater becomes increasingly obsessed with the drunk, the disorderly, the dysfunctional. It's not a return to the 1960's and the theater of social awareness, however; few in this genre are intended as exercises in consciousness-raising.
Rather, many of these plays seek to capitalize on our insatiable need for the goriest details and on our appetite for reminders of what we all might easily become. They are, in their way, extreme reactions to the sanitized domains of television sitcoms, where the people and the apartments almost always are more attractive than the real world.
In "High Life," the diminutive Mr. Greenspan is eminently entertaining as Donnie, the most reptilian and tightly wound of a quartet of sociopathic drug addicts in this only slightly diverting, extended sketch of a play. Like the dramatic situation, Mr. Greenspan's performance ultimately trails off into irrelevance. But before that happens, the actor does something remarkable: he makes the burnt-out ends of drug-filled days seem, well, funny. It's an eccentrically winning embodiment of the effects of mind-altering chemicals, in the tradition of Richard E. Grant's bravura turn as a tanked-up, out-of-work actor in the cult film "Withnail and I."
Mr. Greenspan's impression of a human Osterizer is the best thing about "High Life," because it's so exhaustively resourceful in ways the script does not appear to call for; even in obvious bits, as when Donnie reports on his recent bout of pneumonia while sucking on a cigarette, his work is fresh. Yet despite other assets, including Casey Childs's crisp direction and Isiah Whitlock Jr.'s flash-fire portrayal of one of Donnie's homicidal partners in crime, "High Life" remains long on exposition and short on revelation. In fact, given the plethora of plays these days that sift society's dregs, the details of "High Life" are positively fungible.
Some of the best of these lowlife dramas, with their echoes of older playwrights like Sam Shepard, succeed because of self-consciously withering humor (as in "Killer Joe") or delicately textured atmosphere ("Ecstasy") or devastatingly real characters ("This Is Our Youth"). But many others are simply imitative of better plays. They are flawed works that walk on the dark side chiefly because that's where the theater crowd has taken them.
Three Off and Off Off Broadway productions that opened in recent weeks -- Mr. MacDougall's "High Life," Jessica Goldberg's "Stuck" and George F. Walker's "End of Civilization" -- fall into this latter category. All serve up crime and degradation, but little in the way of elucidation or even cheap thrills.
Ms. Goldberg's play, for instance, produced by Rattlestick Productions at the Theater Off Park, is a Gothic riff on "Thelma and Louise" with a bit of Mr. Shepard's "Buried Child" thrown in. Directed by Abby Epstein, it is the tale of two lost young women working in a video store in "Middletown, U.S.A.," and aching for an escape from a stultifying life of alcoholic parents, predatory men, tabloid-television culture and unwanted children.
The relentlessly depressing outlook of "Stuck" is the opposite of what we've come to accept as the American Dream, that children born into an environment that chokes off hope use the negative energy to their advantage. "Hi, stupid baby! Who's the stupidest baby?" one of the video store women, played by Jenny Maguire, coos nastily to the infant daughter she has carelessly brought into her deadwood world. Ms. Maguire's Margaritah is a former high school prom queen who falls in love with a right-wing Argentine businessman (Michael Irby) whose father has bought the town's pollution-spewing factory; her best friend, Lula (Jennifer Albano) hits the bars and winds up in bed with the father of one of her old school chums.
Playing soul mates in benumbed despair, Ms. Albano and particularly Ms. Maguire are heroically believable, and Ms. Goldberg is skillful at the portrait of rapport. Evidence of a sharp intellect is abundant, but as with "High Life," "Stuck" lacks the forward thrust of compelling theater. Until the horrifying final scene, which only reiterates rather than enlarges the play's themes, the drama lives up to its name. By the time "Stuck" ends, it feels as if the story has only just begun.
Mr. Walker's "End of Civilization" at Raw Space tries to add an air of mystery to the lowlife genre, but all it really adds is confusion. The play, which jumps around so arbitrarily that the only time you can be sure of is the one on your wrist, takes place in that lowlife staple, a tacky motel, where Henry and Lily, a despairing, unemployed man and his dutiful wife, have taken a room while he looks for work. During their short stay, a serial killer starts knocking off job seekers in all the employment offices Henry visits, while Lily takes up life as a hooker.
The play offers some real howlers: "I think Henry is going to kill a lot of people because Henry is feeling very demeaned," Lily helpfully informs the dimwitted detectives on the case. Of course, it all ends with a single gunshot. This production, directed by Randy White, inadvertently poses the question at the heart of all down-and-dirty drama: How low, really, can you go?
The answer is, when the theatrical experience is potent, there is no bottom to the barrel. As demonstrated by Mr. Greenspan's memorable work in "High Life," the creepiest stage behavior, leavened by wit, can make the heart soar.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The Invisible Men

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
U.S. Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers joked the other day that he had a new idea for solving the problem of Brazil's collapsing currency, the real. He suggested the Brazilians rename their currency -- "real.com." Judging from U.S. stock markets, it would double in value every 90 days.
Mr. Summers' joke, though, actually captured the most interesting aspect of this year's Davos World Economic Forum, the annual gathering in the Swiss Alps of world leaders, business executives and bankers. Every year at Davos someone stands out as the trend-setter. This year the stars of Davos were invisible: one was Amazon.com and the others were the leaders from so many developing countries who used to come here regularly, but this year didn't show. And therein lies a story. 
 Every panel discussion here on the Internet economy was sold out, and the panel where experts discussed whether the Internet stocks were "a bubble" about to burst was standing room only. The Princeton University economist Alan Blinder kicked off that discussion by observing that there was probably some bubble quality to the Internet stock craze, or as he put it: "I have a general rule: Whenever something becomes worth more than the whole state of California, sell it."
Interestingly, though, the person who poured the coldest water on the Internet mania was Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, who said, "I find the valuations of high-tech stocks in general surprisingly high." Mr. Gates argued that the high-tech business today is so intense, and companies can be overtaken by competition from so many different directions, that making any assumptions about the future earnings of any high-tech company -- particularly one on the Wild West Internet -- is very risky.
But people are missing the most important point about the Internet stock boom, said Mr. Gates. Whether or not it's a bubble, it is attracting enormous amounts of new venture capital to every imaginable Internet-related company, and this influx of cash is going to drive "the pace of Internet innovation even faster."
For the global business leaders here, nothing could be more exciting. But for the other invisible party -- the leaders of developing countries -- nothing could be more depressing than the thought that the world will be getting faster. There was a time when the head of state of a developing country -- such as Thailand or Mexico -- wouldn't want to miss Davos and the chance to show off for the big multinationals. It was almost as if by simply coming here, you were automatically part of the global economy.
But in the wake of the meltdowns in Mexico, Russia, Southeast Asia and Brazil in recent years, a new sobriety is taking hold in many of these emerging markets. Their leaders are coming to realize that the answers to their problems are not here. They are at home. They are starting to realize that it makes no sense to come to Davos and show off your country if you do not have a financial, legal and regulatory structure able to handle the Electronic Herd of global investors. And the only way to get that structure is to build it yourself from the ground up.
"You cannot wait for Godot," remarked Noordin Sopiee, one of Malaysia's leading strategic thinkers. "We have to solve our problems at the national level. God help those who expect others to help them."
Emad el-Din Adeeb, editor of the Egyptian journal Al Alam Al Youm, concurred: "O.K.," he said to me, "I understand we need to get prepared for this globalization and that is partly our responsibility. There is a train that is leaving and we should have known this and done our homework. But now you should slow the train a bit and give us a chance to jump on."
And that's what is scary about this year's Davos: Just when the developing world is coming to really grasp that it has no choice but to get itself ready to climb aboard this train, Bill Gates is predicting that the train is going to get faster -- not slower -- as the developing world moves toward Internet-based commerce, communication and learning systems. What's worse, no one can slow the train down, because the world economy today is just like that Internet: everybody is connected but nobody is in charge.
As the Deutsche Bank economist Ken Courtis observed: "The developing world has decided to catch the train just as it's being dematerialized and turned into a virtual experience." That's not an easy train to catch.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury PricesDrop Sharply After Positive Economic Reports

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices posted the biggest drop in almost three months as several economic reports pointed to resilience in the United States economy and Brazil's stocks and currency surged, leaving investors little incentive to buy bonds.
"Bonds have very limited upside," said David Jallits, who helps manage $5.5 billion at Strategic Fixed-Income in Arlington, Va. Last year's 3.9 percent growth in the economy, combined with signs the economy is not slowing as expected by many analysts, dims the chance for another Federal Reserve interest rate cut anytime soon, he said. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 18/32, to 101 1/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.18 percent, from 5.08 percent on Friday.
Bonds fell after reports on consumption, manufacturing and construction suggested the economy, which is in its eighth year of expansion, was not losing steam. That means the Federal Reserve will probably not trim its target for overnight lending between banks from the current 4.75 percent when it meets today and tomorrow, analysts said.
The decline in the dollar against the yen also hurt Treasuries, reducing the appeal of United States assets to international investors, traders said. Expected sales of at least $4 billion of new bonds by Pepsi Bottling Holdings and other corporate borrowers also weighed on bonds, as did gains in Brazil's currency, the real, and an 8.8 percent jump in its benchmark Bovespa index.
"There's a little pressure off emerging markets, and perhaps the flight to quality isn't as much of a driving factor," as it was after Brazil devalued its currency last month, said Alan Kral, who helps oversee $1 billion at Trevor Stewart Burton & Jacobsen Inc. in New York.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's index of manufacturing activity rose to 49.5 in January, from 45.3 in December, a sign that manufacturing activity did not slow as quickly in January as it did a month earlier.

HEADLINE: Reports Give Good News On Economy

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Factory production rebounded last month after a four-month slump, and consumer spending and home building accelerated in December, fortifying an economic expansion that shows no signs of quitting.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's production index rose to 53.1 in January, from 46.8 in December, the first increase in four months and the highest level since May. Readings above 50 mean more manufacturers reported expanded production than those that said they were cutting back. 
 Consumer spending rose eight-tenths of a percent in December, fueled by higher auto purchases, after a two-tenths of a percent gain in November, the Commerce Department said. December's five-tenths of a percent rise in personal income also topped the previous month's rise of four-tenths of a percent. And construction spending registered its seventh straight monthly increase in December, paced by gains in home building.
"We have such a virtuous-circle dynamic right now," said John Ryding, a senior economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. "Tight labor markets force people to increase efficiencies, so they invest in these new technologies." Because much of that technology is produced in the United States, that in turn creates jobs, bolsters incomes and fuels consumer spending, he said.
The economy grew at a 5.6 percent annual rate in the final three months of 1998 -- the fastest quarterly pace in two years -- and 3.9 percent for the year, the Government reported on Friday. That growth came with only a 1.0 percent rise in inflation.
The separate construction report from the Commerce Department showed that overall spending rose 1.7 percent in December, topping the 1.0 percent increase a month earlier. All segments showed gains, with residential construction rising by the largest dollar amount.
"Right now, there's nothing in the cards to suggest that consumers won't continue to spend at the rate they have been," said Richard Yamarone, an economist at the Argus Research Corporation in New York. "A fully employed labor force, near-zero inflation and low interest rates have prompted great growth in housing and autos -- two large engines of the economy."
The rebound in the purchasing association's manufacturing report lends credence to analyst and investor expectations that the economic expansion will keep setting records. The current expansion entered its 95th month today, the longest in peacetime and closing in on the record of 106 months set in the 1960's during the Vietnam War.
The association's overall manufacturing activity index rose to 49.5 last month from 45.3 in December -- the first increase in four months and the highest reading since June. "It looks like the manufacturing recession is close to over," said Christopher Low, an economist at First Tennessee Capital Markets in New York.
While the closely watched gauge of United States manufacturing exceeded Wall Street expectations, January marked the eighth straight month the index was below 50, which means the number of manufacturers that said business deteriorated was greater than the number of those saying it improved.

HEADLINE: U.S.-India Talks Gain and Could Lead to Easing of Sanctions

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Feb. 1

 BODY:
American officials said today that momentum was building that could lead to a substantial easing of economic sanctions imposed on India after it conducted nuclear tests in May.
It could also lead to India's signing the test ban treaty, probably by mid-year. 
 The Indians were more cautious in their assessment of the outcome of three days of negotiations that ended Sunday -- the eighth round of talks since the tests. But both Indian and American diplomats were optimistic about resolving their differences.
Officials from both countries said they also hoped more broadly for an improvement in the prickly, mistrustful relations between the United States and India. An Indian official described the tone of conversations between Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and External Affairs Minister Jaswant Singh as "verging on bonhomie."
The United States took a step in this diplomatic tango today by inviting ambassadors from the major industrial democracies and Russia, known as the Group of Eight or G-8, to a luncheon in New Delhi, where Americans broached the resumption of World Bank lending to India for road, power and other development projects. Sanctions have thus far cost India about $1.2 billion in World Bank loans, bank officials say.
"The United States cannot act alone," said a senior Clinton Administration official, who, like all the officials interviewed, refused to be quoted by name. "It must move in tandem with the other G-8 partners."
An Indian official said a decision to allow World Bank lending to resume would be "a small step toward the creation of a positive atmosphere." Another Indian official said there was no explicit agreement that if the United States takes certain specific actions on sanctions, India will sign the test ban treaty.
"That's too mechanical a spin," he said.
In Washington, the State Department said it would soon decide whether and how to reward India for progress on nonproliferation -- specifically, on a decision by India to set a date to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.
"There is encouragement on the part of our negotiators," said James P. Rubin, the department spokesman. "There are some indications that the Indians are going to move in a direction that will allow us to respond with moves of our own."
"We have said all along that our sanctions policy will be adjusted based on progress made in nonproliferation negotiations," he continued. "Progress has been made in these most recent negotiations, and we are consulting with Congress."
While both the Indians and Americans insisted that they have done nothing so crude as horse-trading during eight rounds of talks in eight months, it is clear that each side has certain conditions that must be met before relations improve. India's decision to conduct the underground nuclear tests, which Pakistan immediately followed with its own nuclear tests, brought the relationship to one of its lowest points ever.
The Indian Government, run by a seemingly ever-shakier coalition led by the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, needs something concrete it can claim to have gained for signing the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty by the September deadline for ratification set by a United Nations conference more than two years ago, party leaders have said. The Government cannot be seen as giving in to American pressure without opening itself up to attack from the opposition Congress Party.
The Government badly needs some victories. The Hindu nationalists were routed in state elections in November, in large part because of the rising prices of vegetables, and they have been under attack from some of their allies in recent days for raising the prices of subsidized rice, wheat, sugar and cooking oil to lower the budget deficit.
In a joint statement by India and the United States on Sunday, both said they would "endeavor to create a positive atmosphere for advancing their relations." Indian officials say they will work to build a consensus for signing the test ban treaty when Parliament reconvenes this month.
Mr. Talbott today visited the Congress Party leader, Sonia Gandhi, and has given interviews to Indian journalists in which he stresses his respect for India as a great secular democracy and speaks glowingly of the possibilities of a close relationship between India and the United States.
But Indian officials say the United States has taken steps recently that have soured the atmosphere, for instance backing a resumption of World Bank lending to Pakistan but not to India.
And they have complained frequently about what they see as the American Government's overly broad use of a law that generally bars American businesses from trading with Indian companies and Government agencies that are involved in developing India's nuclear and missile programs. India wants the list of more than 200 Indian institutions affected by the law to be pruned -- a step that the Americans described as being "in play."
The United States -- and President Clinton personally -- first and foremost want India to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. The President called Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee on Friday for the first time since the tests to talk about the treaty and other goals of American policy.
While recognizing that India will not give up developing what it calls a "minimum, credible nuclear deterrent," American officials want it to limit its nuclear program and stop producing weapons-grade nuclear material. They also want it to keep up talks with Pakistan to reduce tensions between the countries.
American officials are to meet with Pakistani diplomats in Pakistan on Tuesday, but declined to discuss the agenda. Their next round of talks with India is expected to take place in the middle of the year.

HEADLINE: 'Question Mark' to Become Venezuela's President Today

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Since his election seven weeks ago, "Hurricane Hugo," as President-elect Hugo Chavez is popularly called, has barnstormed Europe, Latin America and the United States sending mixed signals about how he will govern Venezuela.
On Tuesday he will put on the presidential sash at an inauguration that will launch what promises to be a presidency of surprises. 
 The 44-year-old former lieutenant colonel has promised a revolution to clean up the Government's chronic corruption. He also pledges to break the stranglehold of the two traditional political parties by holding a referendum that would lead to the drafting of a new constitution.
But on other matters, like how he will manage the ailing economy, deal with the United States and Cuba and recalibrate the flow of oil exports, analysts say he remains a question mark.
Mr. Chavez has been an international curiosity since he tried unsuccessfully to overthrow an elected civilian Government with a military coup in 1992. Afterward he was cashiered from the Venezuelan Army and spent two years in jail.
Despite his checkered relations with some in the military, he made the red beret worn by many army units the symbol of his election campaign and proclaimed his admiration for Fidel Castro and the Cuban Revolution.
Since his election he has been wearing well-tailored suits, but Mr. Chavez has basked in his bad-boy image. "I am being compared to Mussolini, Hitler or even the Devil," he told reporters in Paris last month with a characteristic guffaw. "But I am a social fighter and a democrat."
Mr. Chavez's globe-trotting was aimed at polishing his image and calming foreign investors who steadily withdrew money from Venezuela's stock market last year in anticipation of his election.
Here and abroad, he told investors that he would not impose exchange controls or default on the national debt. He said he would defend the Venezuelan currency, the bolivar, even though analysts say it is at least 25 percent overvalued. He also promised to slash the Government's bureaucracy, strengthen central bank automony, raise the sales tax and encourage foreign investment.
With oil prices at a 12-year low and the Government's interest payments on its debt expected to rise to 40 percent of the budget this year, analysts say Mr. Chavez will probably have little room to maneuver if he wishes to avert the kind of currency turbulence now unsettling the Brazilian economy.
On oil policy, Mr. Chavez's aides have said they would support efforts by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to raise the price of crude. But they would not commit themselves to a production cut.
While campaigning Mr. Chavez promised to reverse Venezuela's practice of pumping more than its OPEC quota. Venezuela is the leading source of foreign oil to the United States and is the second-biggest petroleum exporter in the world.
"The cliche is that there are two Chavezes and we don't know which one will be inaugurated tomorrow," said Roberto Bottome, editor of a Venezuelan business journal. "He has moderated his message in tone if not in content."
Still, Mr. Chavez's oratory has remained hard to decipher in recent weeks as he has painted himself as both an economic realist and a left-leaning populist.
Two weeks ago Mr. Chavez told a group of businessmen that he wanted to install a system "where market forces truly work, where the state will be the engine of progress." In Washington last week, Mr. Chavez met with President Clinton for 20 minutes and pledged his commitment to democracy.
But on a visit to Cuba last month, Mr. Chavez embraced President Castro anew.

HEADLINE: Geneva Steel Seeks Bankruptcy Protection

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: VINEYARD, Utah, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The Geneva Steel Company, which had sales of $720 million in its latest fiscal year, sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code today in an effort to work out a plan to refinance its debt.
On Jan. 15 Geneva skipped a $9 million interest payment on its 9.5 percent senior notes, due in 2004, to conserve cash. Today the company said it was negotiating a loan of $125 million to stay in business. It did not name the lender. 
 Geneva Steel blamed "a dramatic surge" in imports for the filing. American steelmakers have been hurt by a record level of steel imports from Asia, Russia and other regions with slowing economies, which has caused a sharp drop in orders and weaker prices. Two United States producers, Acme Metals Inc. and the Laclede Steel Company, filed for Chapter 11 protection last year.
Geneva Steel, which is based in Vineyard, filed its petition in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Salt Lake City. Trading in shares of the company was halted. The shares, which have dropped 74 percent in the last year, rose 6.25 cents, to 56.25 cents, on Friday.
