HEADLINE: Pepsico Says Its Earnings Were Higher Than Predicted

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Pepsico Inc. announced its fourth-quarter earnings after the market closed yesterday, painting a picture that was largely positive for its soft drink, snack food and orange juice businesses. Earnings per diluted share came in at 24 cents for the quarter, a penny higher than analysts had expected.
The company credited momentum in its soft-drink business for much of its success, noting that its North American sales volume had grown 10 percent in the quarter and 6 percent for all of 1998. 
 "Pepsi One, our new one-calorie cola, led the growth in the fourth quarter," the chairman and chief executive of Pepsico, Roger A. Enrico, said in a statement.
Yet that growth may have come at a steep price. Pepsi-Cola's profits in North America fell 21 percent in the quarter, which was the result of intensive advertising and promotional spending, as well as "a very competitive pricing environment," said Richard M. Detwiler Jr., a Pepsico spokesman.
Pepsi and its chief rival, the Coca-Cola Company, have been engaged in a price battle at the supermarket and other retail outlets for most of the last two years.
Pepsico had announced last week that it was taking 17 cents in various one-time charges against earnings to cover losses in business areas like Russia, where the company had an unusual charge of $218 million, and to cover the costs of certain Frito-Lay plant closings in the United States.
Largely because of Russia, though Asia also played a role, international Pepsi-Cola sales fell 12 percent compared with the fourth quarter a year ago. Worldwide operating profits in the soft-drink division were down 33 percent, the company said, attributing that to competitive pricing, higher advertising and marketing expenses, and the unraveling of the Russian economy.
Other areas of concern include Brazil, where sales of Frito-Lay products fell 3 percent, according to the earnings statement. "That's a little disappointing," said Jennifer Solomon, an analyst for Salomon Smith Barney.
Over all, international profits from Frito-Lay, which makes up half of Pepsico's earnings, fell 6 percent in the quarter, while North American profits rose 3 percent. Worldwide, Frito-Lay posted a 1 percent gain in the quarter.
Pepsi reported fourth-quarter sales of $7.19 billion, up 15 percent from $6.26 billion in the fourth quarter of 1997. Net income declined 10 percent, to $361 million, from $401 million in the period a year earlier. The earnings announcement was made after the stock market closed. Earlier, shares of Pepsi fell 87.5 cents, to $38.125.
"One of the critical drivers in 1999 will be the strength in profit growth of the Frito-Lay business," said Andrew M. Conway, an analyst for Morgan Stanley, who estimates that growth at 9 percent.
Worldwide Pepsi-Cola volume grew 7 percent in the quarter, mostly driven by the 10 percent gain in North American volume, the company said.
Along with Pepsi One, the leading brands were Mountain Dew, Pepsi, Lipton Brisk iced tea and Pepsi's bottled water brand, Aquafina.

HEADLINE: Mills Godwin Jr., 84; Ruled Virginia as Democrat and Republican

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
Former Gov. Mills Edwin Godwin Jr. of Virginia, who rose above his segregationist past to become one of his state's most effective chief executives, died on Saturday in Newport News, Va. He was 84 and lived in Suffolk, Va.
Governor Godwin had just been released from Riverside Hospital in Newport News, where he was treated for pneumonia, said the office of Gov. James S. Gilmore 3d in Richmond. 
 Mr. Godwin was the only two-term Governor for the Commonwealth of Virginia since the Civil War, and he served his terms eight years apart -- elected in 1965 as a Democrat and in 1973 as a Republican. He epitomized the end of an era dominated by the Democratic machine of Harry F. Byrd Sr., whose organization ran Virginia politics from the 1920's to the 1960's.
In his first term, Mr. Godwin broke with the policies of the Byrd machine and was able to piece together a mainline conservative coalition that attracted labor leaders and the rank and file, African-Americans and whites, liberals as well as conservatives.
With such broad support he was able to build roads, overhaul the state Constitution and tap a new source of revenue in the form of sales taxes. His legacy was a community college system that gave Virginia an educational basis for economic growth.
Born a farm boy in Chuckatuck, Va., Mills Godwin was a 1938 law graduate of the University of Virginia and practiced law in his home county, Nansemond, until 1960. He was elected to the Virginia House of Delegates in 1947 and to the State Senate in 1952.
It was in the Senate that he became a pillar of his state's policy of "massive resistance" to the racial integration of schools. He vowed that there would be no compromise on the issue. But that intransigence shattered in the late 1950's, and he eventually argued that Virginia just needed time to adjust to the inevitable.
He was elected lieutenant governor in 1961 and governor four years later. He later left the splintering Democratic Party and was elected to a second four-year term as a Republican in 1973.
After his second term, he worked as a business consultant and corporate director.
Mr. Godwin is survived by his wife of 58 years, Katherine Beale Godwin, and a sister, Leah G. Keith of Chesapeake, Va.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

AFRICA
 
GUINEA-BISSAU: THOUSANDS FLEE FIGHTING
Thousands of people scrambled to flee Bissau, the capital, as fighting intensified between loyalist and rebel forces, and the rebels announced "a final assault" on the city. At least 15 people were reported killed. The fighting appeared to signal the end of an accord in November that halted a five-month civil war in the former Portuguese colony. (AP) 

KENYA: STUDENTS PROTEST AGAIN
Clashes be- tween the police and university students continued for a third day in Nairobi over a plan to build luxury housing in a large forest at the edge of the city. The police fired tear gas at the students, who blocked traffic and harassed motorists. Dozens of students and several officers have been injured in the protests. Ian Fisher (NYT)
 
IVORY COAST: U.S. OFFICES CLOSED
The United States Embassy and other American Government offices in Abidjan, the commercial center, shut, reportedly for security reasons. An embassy official would not say what had led to the closings. A number of American embassies have briefly closed since the bombings of American embassies last year in Kenya and Tanzania. (AP)
 
RWANDA: O.A.U. GENOCIDE INVESTIGATION
Nearly five years after at least 500,000 people, mostly Tutsi, were killed, the Organization of African Unity has sent a commission to investigate. The panel will meet Government officials and genocide survivors, who accuse other African countries and the United Nations of not doing enough to prevent the killings. (AP)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: 10 OFFICERS CHARGED WITH MURDER
Ten Mexico City police officers have been charged with murdering a New York University student, Frederick McPhail, in November. The officers are accused of having seized Mr. McPhail, 27, as he withdrew money with his bank card and forcing him to drink large amounts of liquor before letting him go. Mr. McPhail died of alcohol poisoning. Sam Dillon (NYT)
 
CANADA: CHINESE SMUGGLING CASE
A Chinese man who tried to take four Chinese women from Canada to the United States in a false compartment under a truck was arraigned in Buffalo and charged with smuggling. Immigration officials say that as part of a growing trend in which Canada has become a major illegal entry point into the United States, Khung Chang Kang, 54, of Rochester, N.Y., was paid $500 a person to transport the four women from Ontario to New York. Anthony DePalma (NYT)
 
COLOMBIA: REWARD FOR RIGHTIST FUGITIVES
Colombia offered a $31,500 reward for information leading to the capture of suspected right-wing paramilitary fighters who killed two human rights workers, Everardo Puerta and Julio Gonzalez of the Committee of Solidarity With Political Prisoners. The murders, the latest in a string of attacks, led rights groups to accuse the Government of turning a blind eye to paramilitary atrocities. (Reuters)
 
EUROPE
 
NETHERLANDS, GREECE: KURD SEEKS HAVEN
The Kurdish guerrilla leader, Abdullah Ocalan, whose whereabouts have been a mystery since he disappeared last month from Rome, tried to enter the Netherlands, but his private plane was not allowed to land at Rotterdam. Later, Turkish officials said Mr. Ocalan had landed in Greece. Greece denied that. He is Turkey's most wanted fugitive. Stephen Kinzer (NYT)
 
AUSTRIA: BANK SETTLES HOLOCAUST SUIT
A bank accused of profiting from the sale of gold taken from Jewish Holocaust victims will pay $92 million in restitution, an American lawyer for survivors said. The company, the Bank Austria group, also promised to cooperate in similar investigations against German banks, said the lawyer, Ed Fagan. (AP)
 
MOLDOVA: PREMIER QUITS
Prime Minister Ion Ciubuc resigned, saying Parliament and the reformist ruling coalition had failed to support his efforts for market reforms. Mr. Ciubuc had promised to speed changes in the impoverished former Soviet republic, but little changed as Moldova was seriously affected by Russia's economic turmoil. (AP)
 
ASIA
 
CHINA: JIANG BACKS PRIVATE ENTERPRISE
President Jiang Zemin has backed amendments to the Constitution that strengthen support for private enterprise, calling them an aid to market reforms, the official New China News Agency reported. The amendments, the third set since the Constitution was adopted in 1982, recognize the private sector as an "important component" of the state-led economy, the agency said. (AP)
 
INDIA: HARD-LINER SWORN IN
A leader of the hard-line Hindu party, Shiv Sena, Narayan Rane, left, was sworn in as Chief Minister of the State of Maharashtra, whose capital, Bombay, is India's financial center. He took over two days after the head of Shiv Sena, Bal Thackeray, asked Monohar Joshi to resign. Mr. Thackeray, who holds no public office, gave no reason for Mr. Joshi's dismissal. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
INDIA: 10,000 CHRISTIANS PROTEST ATTACKS
At least 10,000 Christians took to the streets in the northeastern State of Mizoram to protest attacks on Christians by Hindu militants. Black flags were hoisted in churches across the state, whose population is 98 percent Christian. The Northeast has been spared the religious violence that has struck other parts of the country. (Agence France-Presse)
 
NORTH KOREA: OVERSEAS MISSIONS TRIMMED
Faced with acute economic difficulties, North Korea closed 14 overseas diplomatic missions, or 21 percent of its foreign operations, last year, South Korean officials said. The closings numbered eight in Africa, four in Europe, and one each in Asia and the Middle East, officials at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade said. (AP)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
CYPRUS: 2 ISRAELIS JAILED
Two Israeli undercover antiterrorism agents were jailed for three years after prosecutors agreed to drop espionage charges and the two pleaded guilty to approaching a restricted military zone. The agents, Igal Damary, 49, and Udi Hargov, 37, who were arrested on Nov. 7, also admitted possessing banned listening equipment. (Reuters)
 
ISRAEL: PALESTINIAN STATE URGED:
A joint appeal was issued by 146 Israeli writers, artists and intellectuals in support of a Palestinian state in all of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Breaking with a broad consensus in Israel about the peace effort, they also called for Jerusalem to be shared, with Palestinians setting up their capital in the eastern part. (Agence France-Presse) Compiled by Terence Neilan

HEADLINE: Rohm & Haas Plans to Buy Morton in $4.5 Billion Deal

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The Rohm & Haas Company agreed today to buy the salt and chemical maker Morton International Inc. for $4.5 billion, a deal that would make the combined business the No. 2 maker of specialty chemicals.
Rohm & Haas, which manufactures chemicals used in products ranging from shampoos to computer equipment, will use cash and stock that values Morton shares at $37.125, a 43 percent premium to Friday's closing price. Rohm & Haas will also assume $268 million in debt from Morton, which makes specialty chemicals used in adhesives, electronics and other products. 
 The move will increase the Philadelphia-based Rohm & Haas's annual sales to $6.5 billion from $3.7 billion. The company expects to cut $200 million a year in costs, which would help it as the industry consolidates amid falling prices and lower demand from Asia.
The Chicago-based Morton is North America's largest maker of salt, and is best known for its Morton Salt girl trademark. The purchase would allow Rohm & Haas to surpass rivals like Rhodia, a subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France, and Ciba Specialty Chemicals A.G. of Switzerland. Clariant A.G., also of Switzerland, is the biggest maker of specialty chemicals, with annual sales of about $6.8 billion.
Rohm & Haas shares rose 75 cents, to $31.75, while Morton jumped $9.75, to $35.625.
Specialty chemicals are typically added to other substances during manufacturing to improve characteristics such as durability, color and flexibility. They are scarcer and sold in smaller volumes than so-called commodity chemicals.
Declining chemical prices and the global expansion of many industrial customers have led to mergers by a number of specialty-chemical producers so they can exploit economies of scale, demand price concessions from suppliers and provide one-stop shopping for customers.
Last year chemical mergers included Hercules Inc.'s agreement to buy BetzDearborn Inc., creating one of the biggest makers of chemicals used in paper production, and PPG Industries' acquisition of an architectural coatings business from Dutch chemical maker Akzo Nobel.
Rohm & Haas expects to pare costs by reducing freight expenses and eliminating corporate and administrative overlap, with about half of the savings coming from job cuts. The combined companies will have about 23,000 employees, and Rohm & Haas said it expects to reduce that by about 5 percent in the next year.

HEADLINE: PC Component Shortages Are Seen in Asia

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 1

 BODY:
Asian companies that make computer components lag behind the United States and Europe on fixing problems related to the Year 2000, which could lead to supply shortages next year, Scott McNealy, chief executive of Sun Microsystems Inc., said today.
"We believe Asia is way, way behind," Mr. McNealy said at a news conference during the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum. "Intel, Sun and Hewlett-Packard have done quite similar surveys of their supply base," he said, adding that Asia was significantly behind in dealing with the problem. This might make it difficult to buy computer hardware in 2000. 
 Mr. McNealy said he thought the Asian financial crisis might have disrupted companies' efforts to update the programming of PC's that might otherwise crash or produce bad data because of Year 2000 problems.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE ASSESSMENT;
Seeking the High Ground On Spending Surpluses

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
It says "Budget of the United States Government" on the cover, but the document that President Clinton sent to Congress today is really a political agenda, in spreadsheet form, for a new fiscal era.
Presidents always use their budget proposals to lay out their wish lists, and Mr. Clinton has been particularly adept at using the annual budget cycle not just to win attention for new and recycled programs but, this year especially, to portray himself as active and engaged. 
 Yet Mr. Clinton also has a more sweeping goal. With Washington still in shock at the speed with which the Federal Government has left behind an era of huge budget deficits and diminished expectations, Mr. Clinton is trying to seize the high ground in a fast-developing and fundamental debate over how the nation should capitalize on its prosperity.
Should the country invest its anticipated fiscal windfall in preparing for the aging of the baby boom generation and the strains that will create on the foundations of the social welfare system, Social Security and Medicare? In Mr. Clinton's view that is the prudent course and one that, after accounting for new spending for the Pentagon and domestic priorities, leaves no money for the sweeping tax cuts that frustrated Republicans have been demanding for years.
"This is not just about saving Social Security and Medicare, although that is terribly important," Mr. Clinton said today.
Fiscal prudence now, he said, will allow succeeding generations to deal with the unforeseen and unknowable challenges of the next century "unburdened by the unfinished business of the 20th century, unshackled by our profligacy in the latter part of this century."
Despite Mr. Clinton's implications to the contrary, Republicans say, they are equally dedicated to shoring up Social Security, and they also believe there should be more money for education and the military. Showing remarkable unanimity for a party that has been riven for the last few years by internal dissent, Republicans are arguing that there is enough money to slash taxes as well, although the budgetary math that leads to such a conclusion is a bit murky.
"We can have it all," said Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee.
The two parties are in at least tacit agreement on a few points. One is not to question too aggressively the assumption that the trillions of dollars in anticipated surpluses will actually materialize. Reaping the windfall requires that the economy and the stock market remain relatively healthy for years. And Republicans and Democrats alike are considering detailed policy proposals that presume long-term budget forecasts from the White House and Congress prove uncharacteristically accurate.
Moreover, the two parties are not far apart on the biggest question before them. Facing the insolvency of what is arguably the most popular and enduring of all Government programs, they agree in general terms that nearly two-thirds of the anticipated budget surpluses should go to dealing with Social Security.
There is little agreement, however, on the best way of using the surplus to shore up the retirement system. And even putting aside Social Security, there is a heated battle shaping up over how to use the money left over once Social Security's future is assured.
The Republican leadership in Congress and Mr. Clinton have powerful reasons to find some accommodation this year and enact legislation on Social Security and dividing up the surplus. But the stakes are so big and the atmosphere so poisonous that resolution of the big questions may have to wait for the 2000 elections.
And even as they debate each other, the two parties are being forced to rethink their own approaches to tax and spending policy as the old rules forged in the austerity of deficit politics give way to a presumed age of fiscal plenty. They even need a new language.
So murky are some of the concepts for using the surplus to shore up Social Security that neither side can fully understand what the other is proposing, leaving budget analysts from both parties scratching their heads. And what, after all, has happened to the deficit hawk now that the deficit is no more?
No longer able to use the specter of endless deficits to impose limits on the growth and power of the Federal Government, Republicans are returning to the approach championed by Ronald Reagan two decades ago: stimulate the economy through big tax cuts, an approach that has the corollary benefit of starving the bureaucracy.
"We count on the American people to handle their own money and solve many of their own problems around their kitchen tables and their front rooms and their businesses," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. "We don't want to invent programs to use the surplus on."
Having tried hard to refashion themselves as the party of fiscal responsibility, the Democrats now have to find a way to promote what Mr. Clinton called today a "prudent but progressive" approach to governing. In other words, can they use Government to address the country's problems without opening the floodgates to new spending?
"This is a budget and an agenda that will not do nearly enough to bridge the broad and growing chasm that divides the wealthy and prosperous from the majority of Americans," said Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota, who said the country has "a great number of critical domestic programs that desperately require real budgetary commitment."
But it was a sign of the Democratic Party's move to center on fiscal issues that his critique was an isolated one and that the official party line of the day was that Democrats stood for a smaller, smarter Government.
"The cry has gone out across this country, 'The Democrats are at it again, the era of big government,' " said Senator Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey, the senior Democrat on the Senate Budget Committee. "The fact of the matter is that we will be spending less as a percentage of the American economy on Government than we have at any time since 1973, and that public debt, looking out 15 years from now, will be at its lowest point since 1917."

HEADLINE: 15 Hospitals Reach Tentative Accord With Nurses

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The union representing 4,300 registered nurses at 15 private hospitals announced a tentative agreement yesterday on a three-year contract that gives nurses a role in deciding patient care policy.
The contract establishes committees at each hospital of equal numbers of nurses and administrators to devise safe ratios between the number of nurses and patients, said Norma Amsterdam, executive vice president of 1199, National Health and Human Service Employees Union. 
 "For us, quality-of-care issues took precedence over economic issues," Ms. Amsterdam said.
Hospitals covered by the agreement include Beth Israel Medical Center and Catholic Medical Center. The contract, to be voted on over the next two weeks, calls for a 3 percent raise retroactive to Nov. 1, a $2,500 lump-sum bonus on July 1 and another 3 percent raise on Nov. 1, 2000.
The union's president, Dennis Rivera, said the agreement was "unique in the United States in addressing quality-of-care issues." He added, "And no other nurses in the country enjoy the employment security guarantees that 1199 R.N.'s have."
The contract guarantees employment for any nurse on the job since December 1994, or about 85 percent of the work force. Those hired after December 1994 who lose their jobs can receive up to 80 percent of their previous net income and full benefits for up to one year while undergoing retraining.
Bruce McIver, president of the League of Voluntary Hospitals, a group of 35 private, nonprofit institutions, said the hospitals involved were pleased with the agreement.

HEADLINE: Tony Blair Rides Triumphant, Either as a Visionary or as a Good Promoter

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 31

 BODY:
He is youthful, articulate and visionary, leader of a nation in dramatic transition, with a compassionate vision and a ruthless dedication to seeing it through. His name is Tony Blair.
He is all style and fluff, a spiffy promoter with a preachy speaking manner and a trendy tendency to put the possessive "people's"' before the mention of any British institution and the verb "modernize" in any sentence about his goals for the country. His name is also Tony Blair. 
 Twenty months after he led Britain's "new" Labor Party to power, it is the first image of Britain's attention-getting 45-year-old Prime Minister that is prevailing -- much to the consternation of his Conservative opponents, who have failed to put across the second.
But while he is the most popular Prime Minister in British history and no one questions his extraordinary public appeal, people are asking what is actually inside the enticingly wrapped package he is offering.
Mr. Blair says he is leading a "radical" 10-year project that will free Britain from the grip of class consciousness, energize the individual parts of the United Kingdom by yielding much of London's authority over them, liberate British business from restrictions that discourage enterprise and punish risk-taking, reduce the poor's dependency on the state and end Britain's estrangement from the Continent and make it a leader in Europe.
Still, the Blair Government's emphasis on presentation, or "spin," has left it vulnerable to criticism that all this may represent slick talk of accomplishment, and not solid accomplishment itself.
"A gravity-defying victory of style over substance," is the verdict of one critic, Boris Johnson, columnist for the conservative Daily Telegraph. Mr. Blair's Government, said Michael Gove, a columnist for The Times of London, "is about entrenching a clique's hold on power, not advancing policies for the nation."
The end-of-year list of achievements put out in December by 10 Downing Street included the peace settlement in Northern Ireland; decisions to move regional power out of the Parliament in London to newly created legislatures in Edinburgh, Cardiff and Belfast; reforming the House of Lords; setting a minimum wage; starting a welfare-to-work program; granting independence to the Bank of England in setting interest rates, and establishing Britain as a more positive presence in Europe while maintaining strong ties to the United States.
With a 179-seat majority in Parliament, ineffective opposition from the Conservatives and only rumblings of discontent from dissidents in his party, Mr. Blair has remarkable freedom of action, and his Presidentialstyle has become the most important factor in New Labor's performance.
As focus groups and opinion research become a growing force in Britain, political muscle is increasingly measured with the tape that shows the public popularity numbers. By this standard, Mr. Blair is an outstanding success: his approval ratings are persisting in mid-60's percentiles, the highest ever for a British Prime Minister and 15 points higher than the ratings for his Government. This is occurring in spite of Cabinet scandals and disarray -- including the resignation of his chief ally, Peter Mandelson -- of the kind that contributed to the overwhelming rejection of his predecessor, John Major, in the 1997 election.
He has the support of 87 percent of the fractious Labor Party, and recent polls indicate that even the Tory rank and file prefer him to their own leader, William Hague. Although Mr. Blair heads the country that Europeans most love to loathe for its reluctance to join in their grand ventures like monetary union, he often comes first even on the Continent in polls measuring the popularity of individual leaders.
He has gained favorable international notice for a formless and airily defined theory about the divisions between individual and state responsibilities called simply the Third Way. It seems to maintain a following chiefly because he is the one who is peddling it.
 
Reforming Labor Party For the Middle Class
At home, his Government's purpose, Mr. Blair said in a recent policy speech, is to serve a "new, larger, more meritocratic middle class." His congeniality goes down easily in today's Britain, where attitudes are shaped more by consumerism than by class.
He put the Labor Party through a force-fed reformation in the 1990's, aimed at shedding the socialist ideology, tax and spending habits and tribal in-fighting that had scared off middle-class voters in past elections and given the Tories their dominance of British politics.
Outwardly, Mr. Blair has a glad-handing appeal. He is a shirt-sleeves boss, trading jocular banter with his aides in his back office at 10 Downing Street. But he is said to be steely when it comes to internal discipline. During the push to transform the party, insiders called his methods "Stalinist."
"The odd thing about him is that no one thinks of him as Machiavellian," said Robert Harris, the novelist, who is a fan of the Government. "I suppose that is what is so Machiavellian about him."
With an information management policy keeping Government spokesmen resolutely "on message," Mr. Blair holds to simple definitions and repeated slogans. One of his favorites is that he is not just running a Government but heading up a "project."
Projects need more than five years to fulfill, he and his ministers stress, and it is an article of faith among the Blairites that this Government must overcome the curse of Labor's nearly 100-year-old history of never having run Britain for two successive full five-year terms. The week after Labor's rout of the Tories on May 1, 1997, members of the new Government were already talking about the urgency of winning the next election.
Labor's preoccupation with becoming consistently electable has led critics to fault the Blair Government for being overly cautious and vague, more eager not to disaffect than to engage and lead.
"This is the first unfrightening Labor administration," said Anthony King, professor of government at Essex University. Past Labor Governments are notorious in Britons' memories for economic mismanagement, convulsive social clashes and internal wrangling. A main reason for the Blair Government's success so far, Mr. King said, is "its conspicuous failure" to make mistakes.
Perhaps Mr. Blair's boldest move was to take on the intractable conflict in Northern Ireland. While Mr. Major lacked the political clout to make much tangible progress, Mr. Blair committed his carefully rationed personal prestige to a successful outcome of the rancorous negotiations by joining the talks himself and staying up all night with the haggling negotiators last April to nail down the final terms.
 
A 'New Deal' to Put Unemployed to Work
Mr. Blair has created a program for getting jobs for youths that has placed 50,000 unemployed in jobs in seven months. But in other areas welfare reform has stalled, and steps to cut benefits for single mothers have caused resentment in a country where "welfare state" is not a pejorative phrase.
In education, Mr. Blair is meeting targets for reducing the class sizes of primary schools, and in health he has succeeded in lowering waiting lines. But he must find money to give teachers and nurses needed raises, and he is continually embarrassed by disclosures of failing schools and shortages of hospital beds.
To keep his erstwhile trade union supporters on board, he pushed through a minimum wage and moved to restore organizing rights, though in both cases the terms were not as generous as the Labor traditionalists had wished. Old Labor stalwarts are constantly unhappy with Mr. Blair, but their power is greatly diminished, and they have no other welcome port on the current map of British politics.
His personal diplomacy has made relations with Europe less frosty, even though Mr. Blair kept Britain out of the introduction of the euro. The Prime Minister stresses at every opportunity that Britain is a European country and increasingly hints that its future destiny is in monetary union.
The delicate task of educating a majority of Britons out of their traditional hostility and suspicion toward Europe has been made easier for him by the absolutist position of the Conservative leader, Mr. Hague. He favors declaring now that Britain will not consider entry into monetary union for at least eight years, a view that Mr. Blair is able to mock without having to make a commitment of his own.
Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, who steers the economy and is the second most powerful man in the Government, is charged with navigating Britain past what currently looks to be the only threat to Mr. Blair's hold on British affections -- a year of limited growth, or even mild recession.
The only bumps in the road that the purring New Labor machine has been gliding along have been in an area of potential vulnerability for this Government -- the ethical conduct of its ministers and the unity of their commitment to the Prime Minister's program. These were two of the principal counts in the electoral indictment of the Conservatives by Mr. Blair.
In the last three months, four principals in his Government have walked the forced resignation plank that was a permanent feature of the Major years. Among them was Mr. Mandelson, Mr. Blair's closest confidant and as central an architect of New Labor as the Prime Minister himself. He quit on Dec. 23 when he was found not to have declared a $625,000 home loan from a colleague who was under investigation by his trade and industry department.
 
Scandal Control: Quick Resignations
The departures and evidence that emerged of feuding within the Government posed a challenge to Mr. Blair's reputation for discipline and control, and the scandal-starved British press gave the subject ample coverage. But showing his bent for damage control, Mr. Blair obtained resignations rapidly, in marked contrast to Mr. Major's lingering response in similar situations.
Most of the criticisms directed at Mr. Blair have been accusations of lapses in style -- that he is a "control freak," that he is surrounded by "cronies," that he is creating a "nanny state." His Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, was portrayed recently as a womanizer and a heavy drinker in a vengeful book by the wife he left for a younger woman in 1997, and newspapers have also raised questions about the number of homosexuals in the Government.
"It's partly to ward off boredom of Labor's unbreakable domination that the politics of the personal holds such sway," commented Hugo Young, columnist for The Guardian.
A Gallup poll published in The Daily Telegraph this month showed what the consequences of personal politics were for Mr. Blair. His approval ratings went up a point to 66.

HEADLINE: It's All Too Few Hands on Deck for the Navy

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: ABOARD U.S.S. HARRY S. TRUMAN, off Florida, Jan. 29

 BODY:
The Navy spent $4.5 billion to build this, the nation's newest aircraft carrier. It has two nuclear reactors, the latest electronic, computer and navigational equipment, and, for the long "cruises" to come, amenities for the crew, like televisions in almost every berth.
What the Navy cannot put aboard the Truman is a full crew. 
 Almost every department on the carrier faces a shortage of sailors, from the engine room to the intelligence division to the mess. The air department should have more than 600 sailors to carry out the choreographic feat of launching and landing warplanes.
Today it mustered 448.
"The people aren't there," Capt. Thomas G. Otterbein said, sitting on the Truman's bridge as pilots practiced takeoffs and landings in roiling seas 100 miles out in the Atlantic Ocean.
The Truman, commissioned by President Clinton last July to join the nation's 11 other aircraft carriers, is not alone. Two weeks ago, the Navy disclosed that it has had as many as 22,000 empty positions, or billets, in an authorized force of about 375,000. The vast majority of those were aboard the Navy's 327 ships, rather than on shore.
The Navy's shortages have a variety of causes, not the least of which is a thriving economy that creates more enticing opportunities for young people than the prospect of long voyages at sea. And the Navy has responded with a variety of programs to counter that hard reality, offering bonuses and championing proposals now before Congress to increase pay and retirement benefits for all military personnel.
The Navy's commanders insist that, for now at least, the shortages have not hurt their primary mission, which is defending the United States. But they concede that the problem is taking a toll on ships like the Truman, where sailors and officers work longer hours to pick up the slack.
And that, in turn, is worsening the problems at the root of the shortages: recruiting new sailors and keeping those who have already joined.
"It sort of feeds on itself," Captain Otterbein said. "The workload still remains pretty high. Now you're laying it on the backs of fewer people."
In Norfolk, Va., home port of the Truman and fulcrum of the Atlantic Fleet, there are shortages on almost every warship, from the frigates to the attack submarines. The aircraft carrier Enterprise, whose warplanes provided much of the punch for the air raids against Iraq in December, left port last fall nearly 400 short of a full crew of more than 5,000.
"I don't have any command out there that isn't saying we're short in one way or another," said Master Chief Jesse J. Elliott, the senior noncommissioned officer for the Atlantic Fleet's carriers and air squadrons.
The Leyte Gulf, a guided-missile cruiser, is scheduled to deploy to the Mediterranean Sea in March but so far has a crew of only 338. It should have 410. Its commander, Capt. Raymond P. Donahue Jr., said he expected to fill at least some of the most important slots before the ship steamed for six months at sea, but only at the last minute and with junior sailors.
"Some of their replacements will walk up the brow a week before they deploy," Captain Donahue said, referring to the ship's gangway. "They haven't trained with us. The continuity isn't there."
The challenges with recruiting and retention have affected the entire military, but the Navy's difficulties have become particularly acute. The Navy, like the other services, has steadily reduced its size since the end of the cold war, but now is struggling to hold to the levels it needs to maintain even a smaller fleet. The Pentagon's most recent survey on attitudes about the military found that only 9 percent of young men between 16 and 21 were likely to consider joining the Navy, the lowest of the four services.
Last year, for the first time since the draft ended in 1973, the Navy fell 7,000 short of its annual recruiting goal. Since new recruits almost always go straight to sea after boot camp, that shortfall is now rippling through the fleet.
At the same time, the Navy is not retaining nearly enough enlisted personnel, particularly those with highly technical skills.
The Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Jay L. Johnson, said in an interview that the shortage was only partly a recruiting and retention problem. The Navy has thousands of unassigned sailors who could, with better management, be reassigned to fill the empty billets, Admiral Johnson said. The answer, he said, is "to put the right people in the right billets at the right time." He said he had set in motion plans to do that.
Even he conceded, however, that the Navy faces challenges far beyond the ability of better management: a declining willingness of young people to serve in the military and a thriving economy that entices those who would or do serve.
Petty Officer Second Class Melissa Teames, an air traffic controller aboard the Truman, plans to leave the Navy on April 7 after five years. Only 24, she is highly trained and disciplined.
But the Federal Aviation Administration is hiring again in the midst of a boom in commercial travel. And, as she explained, the F.A.A. does not send you to sea.
"We're doing the same job here," Ms. Teames said, standing inside the darkened control center beneath the Truman's flight deck, "but under more difficult conditions."
The Navy admits that life at sea is not for everybody, even aboard the big carriers. The Truman has a daily newspaper, a post office, a barber shop, a store and even automatic teller machines.
But as big as it is -- longer than five blocks of Manhattan and, from the waterline to its highest point, 20 stories tall -- the Truman is cramped and crowded. Except for the cavernous hangar bay, its passageways are narrow.
There is very little common space, and even less private. Enlisted sailors sleep in bunks, stacked three deep, a step away from three more. They call them "coffin racks." For those who work deep in the ship's hull, it is possible to pass days at a time without seeing daylight.
At today's muster, the Truman's "ship's crew" totaled 2,543, more than 13 percent below the 2,933 that the Navy considers the full number to operate the ship. The Truman does not yet have a full complement of aircraft squadrons on board, which would bring the total crew to more than 5,000. It is likely that when they do arrive, those units, which normally total 2,300 to 2,400, will also have shortages.
The Truman will not deploy overseas until next year. The ship spent six weeks at sea late last year and has another "cruise" planned in March. It steamed into the Atlantic this week to allow pilots based on shore to perform the takeoffs and landings they need to stay proficient.
While at sea, the shortages are felt in ways large and small. Sailors have to work longer, usually 12-hour shifts, and spend more days in "duty stations," handling watch or otherwise being on call. The ship's mess has half the cooks it needs, and so sailors from other departments also have to fill in.
The Navy is scrambling, on shore and at sea, to address the causes and effects of the personnel shortages.
On the Truman, Captain Otterbein has made an effort to improve the quality of life. While the ship was under construction, he ordered the shipbuilders to install an extra weight room to give sailors a diversion. The ship also has more televisions than the older carriers.
Chief Warrant Officer Leon A. Coles, who runs the mess, said he held the key to keeping sailors in the Navy: better chow. The Truman just won the Navy's award for food service. "It's going to have an impact on whether they stay in the Navy," Mr. Coles said.
On shore, the Navy has taken other more drastic, and controversial, steps. It is adding 700 new recruiters to the 3,800 it had last year and nearly doubling the advertising budget, to $70 million from $45 million. But it is also going to allow in more recruits who have failed to receive a high school diploma, despite experience that has shown they tend to drop out of boot camp more than high school graduates.
The Navy's commanders also hope that President Clinton's proposal to raise military salaries by as much as 9.9 percent and to improve retirement benefits will help. Republicans in Congress have responded by proposing even more, including raises of 10.8 percent.
Today, the lowest-ranking sailor, with less than two years of experience, earns $887 a month; near the top end of the enlisted scale, a master chief petty officer, with 20 years of experience, earns $3,207 a month.
There are also new bonuses for enlisting and bonuses for re-enlisting. In some specialized fields, sailors can receive up to $30,000 to stay.
Another of Admiral Johnson's efforts has been to cut by a quarter the number of inspections and administrative tasks that ships face while in port, burdening sailors with extra work during the time they should be enjoying time off.
A reduction in administrative work appeals to Daniel C. Appold, a machinist mate second class on the Truman. "You put a wrench in my hand and I'm happy," Mr. Appold said as he worked on one of the ship's two backup diesel engines. "Put all that paperwork in front of me . . . ," he started to say, then shrugged. "I'd rather have a wrench."
An 11-year veteran, he is not sure whether to stay when his enlistment comes up next summer, though he heartily welcomed the idea of a raise. He expressed frustration with the crew shortages, but also seemed pleased with the Truman's efforts to improve the amenities, especially the food, which he said far surpassed that aboard his last ship, the carrier Abraham Lincoln.
"Compared to the Lincoln," he said, sweat on his brow, deep inside the Truman's hull, "this is a little slice of paradise."

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1798 words

HEADLINE: Hard Line on Needle Exchanges;
Whitman Says AIDS Program Encourages Drug Use

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.

 BODY:
Heroin addicts are, by definition, creatures of habit. So it seemed odd that the bedraggled young man who ambled up to the needle exchange in New Brunswick was uncertain about what kind of syringe he would prefer. 
 He closely examined several different types of needles. Finally, he selected one, abruptly announced that he was an undercover agent from the Middlesex County Prosecutor's Office and arrested an AIDS-prevention advocate named Diana McCague for violating New Jersey's ban on possessing or distributing syringes.
"I should have known right away he was a cop," said Ms. McCague, who had been distributing clean needles to drug addicts since 1994 and has been arrested twice. "Users are very particular about the kind of works they use -- they don't need to compare them. He seemed a little too clean to be real, too."
Ms. McCague's arrest, in the fall of 1998, forced her organization, the Chai Project (chai is Hebrew for life), the last of New Jersey's organized needle exchange programs, to stop distributing syringes. Volunteers now set up their van twice each week outside a soup kitchen in New Brunswick, distributing condoms, H.I.V.-prevention pamphlets and bleach kits to sterilize needles, but no syringes.
The needle-less campaign, and the unusually aggressive tactic of using sting operations to snare advocates for AIDS victims, has made New Jersey the most active front in the nation's fierce political battle about the merit of needle exchanges. The state's unrelenting opposition to the programs also places Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in the uncharacteristic role of hard-liner.
With her centrist views on social issues like abortion, gay rights and gun control, the Governor has cultivated a national reputation as a leader of the Republican Party's moderate wing. But mention needle exchanges, and the fact that New Jersey has the nation's third-highest rate of intravenous H.I.V. infection, and Governor Whitman can grow heated.
Republican governors in New York, Connecticut and Pennsylvania use state money to pay for the programs, arguing that they save lives and spare taxpayers the high cost of treating AIDS victims, which can top $20,000 per patient per year. Mrs. Whitman lauds the county prosecutor who arrested Ms. McCague for "enforcing the law."
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the National Institutes of Health and the Surgeon General have all released studies concluding that needle exchanges significantly decrease the spread of H.I.V. without increasing drug use. Mrs. Whitman dismisses their research as "dubious, at best."
Her appointed Attorney General, Peter G. Verniero, released a study in 1998 that was critical of needle exchanges. The study cited as one of its sources an article by the right-wing Heritage Foundation, which also advocated conversion to Christianity as a cure for drug addiction.
And when Governor Whitman was asked recently to explain the factual basis for her unflinching belief that needle exchanges send the wrong message to children, she grew frustrated, as if the hypocrisy of the programs were so obvious it needed no explanation.
"As a mother, I know that it sets a bad example," she said during an interview last month. " 'Do as I say, not as I do' is a lousy way to lead, whether you're running a family or running a state."
The fight over needle exchanges began more than a decade ago, and today 113 programs exist in 30 states, and exchange 17.5 million syringes annually, according to a survey by the Centers for Disease Control. About half the programs operate legally, and 16 others are illegal, but tolerated by their local governments. The rest operate underground.
With a few notable exceptions, medical experts from the American Medical Association to the National Academy of Sciences to the United States Department of Health and Human Services view the needle exchanges as a matter of public health and say that the goal of decreasing H.I.V. infection rates far outweighs the drawbacks of providing syringes to drug addicts.
Some law enforcement officials, led by Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House director of drug policy, oppose the programs as a matter of principle: drugs are illegal, they maintain, and government sends the wrong message to children by providing addicts with the means to break the law.
In trying to balance the diametrically opposed priorities of AIDS prevention and substance abuse, some government officials have performed political contortions. New York State finances 14 programs, and in New York City, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani last year argued for the abolition of methadone, 12 needle exchanges are in operation.
But the needle programs in New York took hold only after years of debate and false starts. The first was begun under Mayor Edward I. Koch, but was scrapped by Mayor David N. Dinkins after he took office in 1990. Despite his concern that it would encourage drug use, Mr. Dinkins reversed his position a year later after studies found that the programs slowed the spread of AIDS among drug addicts and their sex partners.
President Clinton acknowledges that needle exchanges reduce H.I.V. infection without fostering drug use. But last year he gave in to pressure from Republicans in Congress and prohibited the use of Federal money to pay for them.
In fighting the needle exchanges, Governor Whitman has encountered an unlikely adversary, David W. Troast, whom she chose in 1996 to head the state's Advisory Commission on AIDS. As a wealthy businessman and an acquaintance in Mrs. Whitman's social circle in well-heeled Somerset County, Mr. Troast was hardly someone who would be expected to side with drug users and radicals.
After taking the job, however, Mr. Troast interviewed dozens of experts in public health, epidemiology and AIDS prevention, and was stunned by the magnitude and severity of New Jersey's AIDS problem.
New Jersey has 26,000 people with AIDS, and the nation's highest rate of H.I.V. infection among women and children. The state also has 9,100 orphans whose mothers have died of AIDS.
Mr. Troast said he was also struck by the overwhelming consensus among health experts that any serious attempt to slow the spread of H.I.V., which now infects 2,100 additional New Jersey residents each year, must include a needle exchange program.
Mrs. Whitman rejected the Commission's proposal, and when Mr. Troast pushed the idea again several months later, she rejected it again. As their wrangling became highly publicized, Mr. Troast began to notice a pattern.
"Whenever my council's actions got the attention of the media, the authorities cracked down on Project Chai, and Diana McCague got locked up," Mr. Troast said. "I feel personally responsible for her plight."
In the fall of 1998, Mrs. Whitman wrote a letter telling the Commission that she would never change her opposition to needle exchanges, and urging them to move on to more productive matters, like developing strategies to cut the infection rates among pregnant women and adolescents. Mr. Troast said the Commission did focus on those problems, but arrived at the same conclusion: that a small needle exchange program could cut the state's number of new H.I.V. infections by as much as 50 percent.
"How do pregnant women get infected with AIDS?" Mr. Troast said. "How do adolescents get it? It keeps coming back to dirty needles. "Two-thirds of the new infections come directly or indirectly from dirty needles, more than any other state in the country."
Governor Whitman appointed two new members to the Commission, both of whom oppose needle exchanges, in the fall of 1998.
Many AIDS prevention advocates, including Mr. Troast, suspect that Mrs. Whitman's intransigence on the issue is a political attempt to appease right-wing conservatives in the Republican party who disagree with her support of abortion rights.
Mrs. Whitman brushes aside those suggestions, and insists that her position is a deeply held conviction, based on common sense and firsthand experience with some of the seriously impaired children born to drug-addicted mothers.
Before her first run for governor in 1993, Mrs. Whitman visited a Newark hospital that treated children born addicted to cocaine, and held some of the children who had been born with profound developmental disabilities because of their mothers' drug use. The experience convinced her that it would be better for society to discourage drug use.
"When you have a newborn infant who is unable to bond, because it's constantly crying, it's in withdrawal, it's addicted to drugs, the psychological and emotional damage can be just devastating," Mrs. Whitman said. "If you get a mother with H.I.V. and convince her to take AZT, you can vastly reduce its chance of passing H.I.V. on to the child. But these low-birth-weight babies, there's almost nothing anyone can do. It's not an either-or situation, and these are terrible choices, but the child born addicted never really has a chance."
Convinced that Mrs. Whitman will not reverse her position, Ms. McCague and other advocates are now concentrating on protests calling for changes in the state's law after the Governor's term expires in 2001.
"It's unfortunate that the Government's own statistics show that four people will be infected by injection-related H.I.V. every day between now and then," Ms. McCague said. "That's 4,400 people between now and the end of her term."
In the meantime, there is one last advocate who is known to operate an underground needle exchange in New Jersey, a Hudson County man who would identify himself only as Frank.
Equipped with syringes donated by advocates in other states, and advice from the Chai Project on how to spot an undercover police officer, he travels quietly each week to street corners and shooting galleries to replace dirty needles with clean ones.
On a Friday night in January, rainy weather and a new shipment of heroin drove most of his usual clients indoors. The one man who showed up to exchange a handful of used syringes, an auto mechanic named Tony, said most users considered the new needles more a matter of convenience than of health. On the black market, new needles cost $5 -- about one-third the price of a bag of heroin -- so many addicts reuse them simply to economize, and are often too distracted or careless to sterilize their syringes with bleach.
With or without the clean needles, Tony said, he would continue shooting heroin twice a day, the same as he has for more than a decade.
"You'd like to have a new needle for every blast, because it gets dull and your arms get sore," he said. "But when you want to get high, that's all you think about. You're going to use whatever's there, clean or not -- whatever."

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Offers His Budget, and the Battle Begins

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
President Clinton, hailing a new era of fiscal abundance, today proposed a budget for 2000 that he called a "progressive but prudent path to our future," but Republicans immediately attacked it as a throwback to an earlier age of liberal largesse.
The President said his $1.77 trillion plan would insure the solvency of Social Security and Medicare for decades while paying for billions of dollars in programs for schools, cities, families, the environment and the military. 
 Before the black ink could dry on Mr. Clinton's budget submission, Republican leaders in Congress complained that the President was shortchanging taxpayers by devoting billions in surplus Government revenues to new programs rather than tax cuts.
Republican leaders signaled a willingness to work with Mr. Clinton to reserve nearly two-thirds of future surpluses to strengthen Social Security. But there agreement ends, as the budget debate in Washington shifts from dealing with deficits to allocating surpluses.
"The President's budget ambitiously spends almost every cent of the surplus not set aside for Social Security reform on more Washington-based programs," said the House Speaker, Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois. "Clearly, the President sees the surplus as an opportunity to expand the power, the influence and the size of the Federal Government."
The President and Republican leaders today staked out their opening positions for the budget process, with its public hearings and backroom deals. In recent years, budgets have been fashioned in a frenzy of last-minute bargaining in the fall that resulted in spending plans that bore little relationship to the proposals introduced nine months earlier.
For Mr. Clinton, the politicking began today in a triumphal East Room ceremony before an audience of White House officials, Cabinet officers and members of Congress. Unveiling his budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, the President painted a vision of a future in which the American economy is insulated against domestic recession or foreign shocks by setting aside a large portion of $4.47 trillion in projected surpluses over the next 15 years to reduce the Federal debt from the current level of 44 percent of gross domestic product to just 7 percent in 2014, the lowest level of public debt since 1917.
"We have a rare opportunity that comes along once in a blue moon to any group of Americans," Mr. Clinton said, a day after an unusual second full moon in the same month. "Fiscal discipline has transformed the vicious cycle of budget deficits and high interest rates into a virtuous cycle of budget surpluses and low interest rates."
The Administration spending plan is the first in more than a generation to be written from the comfort of a fiscal year that just ended in October with a surplus. The plan projects continued low inflation and moderate economic growth over the next five years. The unemployment rate is projected to rise slightly in 1999 and 2000 and remain at 5.3 percent over the following four years. The current jobless rate is 4.3 percent.
Mr. Clinton's budget plan projects Federal tax receipts of $1.88 trillion in 2000 and spending of $1.77 trillion, producing a projected surplus of $117 billion. All of that surplus would be reserved, pending a deal on saving Social Security. The President's plan assumes that a deal will be made in the next year and calls for Social Security to receive 62 percent of the surplus that is projected to steadily grow for 15 years.
The White House projects a surplus of $393 billion in 2009, a remarkable turnaround from the $290 billion deficit that Mr. Clinton inherited when he took office in 1993.
"Our economic house is in order and strong," Mr. Clinton said. "If we manage the surplus right we can uphold our responsibility to future generations. We can do so by dedicating the lion's share of the surplus to saving Social Security and Medicare and paying down the national debt.
"We can," Mr. Clinton continued, "and because we can, we must do it now."
Today's robust economy has brought a flood of tax revenue to Washington, but Mr. Clinton would use none of it in the 2000 fiscal year for new programs. He finds ways to pay for dozens of programs and tax breaks within the constraints of the 1997 Balanced Budget Agreement by proposing to raise billions of dollars through tax increases, mostly on business and tobacco companies.
The President has rejected Republican demands for an across-the-board income tax cut, proposing instead a series of narrowly drawn tax credits for specific policy purposes. Mr. Clinton proposes $4.1 billion in targeted tax relief for 2000 and $32.6 billion in tax reductions over the five years from 2000 to 2004. The proposed tax incentives include new credits for long-term health care, a new subsidy for stay-at-home parents of young children and expanded benefits for other child care expenses, tax breaks for a variety of environmental initiatives, incentives for school construction and new research and development programs.
The President also proposes significant spending increases on education, including $1.4 billion for hiring new teachers and $965 million for job retraining and adult literacy programs. He also calls for $1 billion to buy parkland and reduce traffic congestion and urban sprawl.
To pay for these proposals, Administration officials scoured the tax code to find $33.4 billion in new revenue over the next five years by closing corporate tax loopholes and disallowing various tax shelters, imposing environmental charges on oil and mining concerns, taxing certain life insurance transactions and rewriting sales-tax rules for exporters. Many of these revenue-raising proposals have been rejected by Congress several times.
The Administration also is counting on nearly $54 billion in revenue from smokers and tobacco companies. Part of the money will come from a new 55-cents-a-pack cigarette tax that is expected to raise $34.5 billion over the next five years. The rest will come from a plan to recover $18.9 billion in Medicaid reimbursements to states that are expected to be paid by tobacco companies under legal settlements with the states worth $246 billion.
From 2001 onward, Mr. Clinton would devote 62 percent of future surpluses for Social Security and 15 percent for Medicare. The rest would be used to help middle-income taxpayers save for retirement and to pay for increased spending on the Pentagon and social programs.
Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, said that Mr. Clinton's budget squandered a historic opportunity to reduce taxes for all Americans, rather than for what Mr. Armey termed favored Democratic constituencies and special interests.
"Right now, the tax burden on the American people is at an all-time high -- higher than during World War II," said Mr. Armey, the House Majority Leader. "If we can't cut taxes now, when can we?"
Administration officials acknowledged that the President's budget proposals -- particularly the new spending and tax measures -- were unlikely to survive in anything like their current form.
They also said that Mr. Clinton's plan to reserve 77 percent of future surpluses to shore up Social Security and Medicare until 2055 was subject to negotiation with the Republican majority in Congress.
"First of all, the President has not said that this should be the end of the discussion. This is the beginning of the discussion," said Jack Lew, the White House budget director, offering a pointed challenge to Congress. "If there's an alternative to get to 2055 that is capable of reaching bipartisan support, we would like to see that alternative."
Republicans in Congress were unable to agree last year on competing tax-cut proposals, with the result that no major tax relief was approved. But, for now at least, Republicans in both houses appear united in their determination to pass a big tax-cut bill and send it to Mr. Clinton for his signature.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said he was willing to go along with Mr. Clinton's proposal to reserve 62 percent of future surpluses for Social Security. But while Mr. Clinton wants to use the remaining excess for Medicare, a new form of retirement account for middle-income taxpayers and additional social and military spending, Mr. Domenici wants to return the money to the public in the form of tax cuts.
Mr. Domenici said that he believed that Congress would approve a large, across-the-board tax cut and predicted that Mr. Clinton would sign it. "What's changed," he said, "is we have a bona fide surplus."
Representative John R. Kasich, Republican of Ohio, likened Mr. Clinton to Santa Claus, bringing gifts for every constituency. But Mr. Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee warned Mr. Clinton against surplus-generated generosity.
"We are not going to blow this by spending it on Big Government," Mr. Kasich said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Bond Prices Tumble As Stocks End Mixed
Stock prices finished mixed after investors chose to take some profits in late trading, but bond prices posted the biggest drop in almost three months as several economic reports pointed to resilience in the United States economy, leaving investors little incentive to buy Treasuries.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 13.13 points, or one-tenth of a percent, to 9,345.70. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 6.64 points, or five-tenths of a percent, to 1,273.00, and the Nasdaq composite index closed at 2,510.09, up 4.20, or two-tenths of a percent. In the bond market, the yield on the 30-year issue shot up to 5.18 percent, from 5.08 percent on Friday. Page C12. 

Factory production rebounded last month after a four-month slump, and consumer spending and home building accelerated in December, the latest economic reports showed. C6.
 
Microsoft Appears to Stumble
Microsoft set out in Federal court to demonstrate that computer users gain numerous benefits from the company's decision to integrate a Web browser with the Windows operating system. But that demonstration appeared to have backfired during cross-examination of a senior Microsoft executive in the Government's antitrust case. C2.
 
French Insurer Expands in Britain
AXA Group of France, one of the world's largest insurance and financial services companies, said that it had agreed to buy Guardian Royal Exchange for $5.68 billion, expanding its auto and homeowner business in Britain. C8.
 
Pilots Threaten Work Slowdown
Pilots at American Airlines are threatening a work slowdown if a dispute over American's recent acquisition of Reno Air is not resolved. The pilots contend that the purchase of the carrier violates an agreement that any planes owned by American will be flown by members of the Allied Pilots Association. C2.
 
Brazil Seeks to Bolster Credibility
Contrary to the rumors in Brazil that the Government would curtail access to bank accounts, the Government instead sought to reassure its citizens and investors. A8.
 
Rohm & Haas Agrees to Buy Morton
Rohm & Haas agreed to buy Morton International, which is best known for its Morton Salt girl trademark, for $4.5 billion, a deal that would make the combined business the No. 2 maker of specialty chemicals. Rohm & Haas shares rose 75 cents, to $31.75, while Morton jumped $9.75, to $35.625. C27.
 
Maxim Editor to Take Over Details
Conde Nast has appointed Mark Golin, editor in chief in the United States of Maxim, to be editor in chief of Details. C4.
 
America Online Adding Moviefone
America Online is buying Moviefone, which provides show times and sells tickets, for $388 million. C9.
 
Ford Accident Disrupts Shipments
An explosion at a Ford plant in Michigan may cause parts shortages at 16 of the automaker's other North American plants. A10.
 
Anything but Super for Commercials
Super Sunday was more of a misnomer than usual. Many of the commercials broadcast nationally were dominated by sophomoric slapstick, toilet talk and gratuitous sex and violence. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C10.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE TAXES;
$82 Billion in Increases and $36 Billion in Cuts (Do the Math?)

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1

 BODY:
President Clinton's budget includes a grab bag of small tax cuts for some Americans and small tax increases for others. Many of these tax proposals seem unlikely to get far in the Republican-controlled Congress.
"I've never seen such a kitchen-sink approach to Government," said Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, which takes first crack at tax legislation. 
 Republicans like Mr. Archer prefer an across-the-board reduction in income tax rates for all taxpayers, but it is far from clear that such an approach can be enacted in the face of a likely Presidential veto.
As tallied by Congressional committee staff members, who added all the pluses and minuses in the budget's revenue tables, Mr. Clinton proposed 81 separate tax increases totaling $82 billion over the next five years and 37 tax cuts totaling $36 billion over the same period. By the Administration's calculations, the comparable figures are $87.4 billion in new revenue and $32.6 billion in tax reductions.
The largest amount of new revenue anticipated in the budget would be generated by the President's tobacco policy. Mr. Clinton would raise nearly $35 billion over five years by increasing the Federal tax on cigarettes, now 24 cents a pack, by an additional 55 cents. And he would raise an additional $19 billion by insisting that the Federal Government get a share of the money states will receive from their lawsuits against the cigarette manufacturers.
This revenue may not materialize. Last year, the Senate rejected a proposed increase in cigarette taxes, and the measure never got off the ground in the House. Furthermore, the states have resisted sharing with Washington the proceeds from their lawsuits, and measures are pending in Congress that would block attempts to recoup the money.
A few of the President's tax proposals do stand a fair chance of enactment. For example, Mr. Clinton proposed a tax cut of up to $1,000 to defray some of the cost of long-term care for elderly or disabled dependents. A similar proposal was part of the Contract With America, the platform on which Republicans ran when they won control of the House in 1994.
Under the Clinton proposal, taxpayers could claim this credit if they provided more than half the support of someone in a nursing home or otherwise requiring long-term care. The credit would be reduced for taxpayers with incomes above $75,000, or $110,000 for a couple filing a joint return.
The President's proposal for a tax credit to offset some of the cost of child care might stand a slightly better chance this year because, to appeal to Republicans, the Administration added a modest new benefit for parents who stay home to take care of their own children.
Mr. Clinton recommended increasing to 50 percent from 30 percent the proportion of child-care costs that could be written off by families with annual incomes below $30,000. The credit would be gradually reduced for families with incomes of $30,000 to $59,000 and would be 20 percent of allowable expenses for those with incomes above $59,000.
In addition, the President proposed an extra tax cut of up to $250 for families with infants who have not reached their first birthday. This credit would be available even if the family had no child-care expenses because a parent or unpaid relative watched the infant.
The tax credit for long-term care expenses would cost $5 billion over five years. The expanded child-care credit would cost slightly more than $6 billion over the same period.
Not counting the cigarette tax increase, these are among the largest of the President's tax proposal. In a budget with total five-year revenues of about $10 trillion, they are hardly more than asterisks.
Many of the President's tax proposals have been offered in the past and have been rejected out of hand by Congress. Among these are arcane proposals to change the way airline tickets are taxed, to alter the tax rules on exports by manufacturers and to raise taxes on certain life insurance transactions.
The House Ways and Means Committee staff experts calculated today that 35 of the 81 revenue increases in the budget are essentially repeats of measures that were rejected last year. Of the $82 billion in additional revenue proposed, more than $60 billion would be accounted for by these reprised offerings.
The budget describes many of these proposals as attempts to "eliminate unwarranted benefits." But the beneficiaries obviously do not view them that way, and the Republican Congress has been reluctant to end any but the most indefensible tax breaks.
As a political matter, the battle over taxes this year is not likely to be over whether these small tax breaks are justified, but rather over the broader question of whether part of the budget surplus should be used for an across-the-board tax cut.
Republicans argue that it is much more efficient economically to give everyone a tax reduction than to follow President Clinton's course and give small tax cuts for particular purposes like school construction or promotion of energy efficiency.
Mr. Clinton has threatened to veto an overall tax cut, saying wealthy people would be the big winners.
