LENGTH: 1225 words

HEADLINE: Milosevic Advantage: In Talking Peace He Can Win Big

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Feb. 1

 BODY:
As the deadline approaches for entering peace talks on Kosovo province, with threats of NATO bombs and sharp warnings from the West, Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav President, has much to gain.
The threats by the Clinton Administration and its NATO allies to bomb him into ceding effective control over the separatist province not only make it easier for Mr. Milosevic to justify eventual concessions but also make him indispensable to any settlement. 
 "As much as officials in Washington publicly revile Mr. Milosevic and call him the main problem in the Balkans, he is also the solution," a senior Western diplomat said. "The West needs Milosevic to settle Kosovo, and Milosevic needs the pressure of the West to be able to do it. All the rest is hypocrisy."
Given Kosovo's mythic importance as the birthplace of the Serbian nation, Serbian officials and senior diplomats here say, Mr. Milosevic is bound to take NATO to the brink before agreeing to any political settlement over Kosovo, where an ethnic Albanian majority is fighting for independence.
While the stick of NATO's bombs is a necessary condition for any deal, Mr. Milosevic will also require some "cake," as the new Deputy Prime Minister, Vuk Draskovic, put it -- a partial lifting of the harsh diplomatic and economic isolation that the West imposed on Serbia during the Bosnian war. Mr. Milosevic may also seek a quiet promise that he not be indicted for war crimes.
There is a wide assumption here, based on the tone of the state press, that Mr. Milosevic will send a delegation to the Western-sponsored talks that are scheduled to start on Saturday outside Paris. There has been no official announcement, however.
And there is also a wide expectation that Mr. Milosevic will eventually authorize an interim settlement that leaves Kosovo a vague but largely self-governing entity within the formal sovereignty of Yugoslavia, as the West is demanding.
As he was in Bosnia, Mr. Milosevic would again become a vital guarantor of any settlement, reinforcing his international and domestic stature.
Mr. Milosevic will be able to argue that even the introduction of Western troops into Kosovo will serve to repress the "terrorism" of the Kosovo Liberation Army, to protect Serbs and their holy places and to keep Kosovo from becoming independent.
Already, on state television, Mr. Milosevic is being hailed for demanding that Kosovo must remain "part of our country." While the name of that country -- Yugoslavia or Serbia -- is left deliberately vague, "one can already smell the way a settlement will be spun here," said Bratislav Grubacic, a well-connected editor.
The analytical cliche about Mr. Milosevic is that he survives by creating crises that require national unity and justify the stifling of dissent, and that he is a superb political tactician who does not have a larger strategic vision. But he is also considered a highly rational judge of his own interests, with little emotional attachment to the kind of Serbian nationalism he has manipulated for the last 10 years.
"He doesn't care himself about Kosovo," said Aleksa Djilas, a political scientist here who has written some of the best analyses of Mr. Milosevic. "His enemies are his best friends. He thrives when Serbs feel the world is being biased and unfair to them. At the same time, the West comes to his aid when it treats him respectfully, as someone who has all the cards in his hands."
The opposition has helped Mr. Milosevic, too, Mr. Djilas said. "There was a chance for the opposition to unite and put Milosevic and the Socialists out of power," he said. "But they never did, and now they're joining him."
In November, Mr. Milosevic fired key members of his inner circle, including the long-serving army Chief of Staff, Gen. Momcilo Perisic, and the director of intelligence, Jovica Stanisic, reportedly at the urging of his wife, Mirjana Markovic, whom many here compare to a socialist Lady Macbeth.
At the time, Washington officials saw the purge as an indication of Mr. Milosevic's weakness and the fragility of his rule. Some thought the effective loss of Kosovo would mean the quick downfall of Mr. Milosevic.
But Mr. Perisic has not attracted supporters and Mr. Milosevic's control over the apparatus of both the federal and Serbian authorities seems enhanced, said both Mr. Grubacic and Ljiljana Smajlovic, a Serbian journalist. Ms. Smajlovic said, "Milosevic is in great shape," having co-opted into the governing coalition both the nationalist leader of the Radical Party, Vojislav Sesejl, and the most charismatic leader of the former opposition coalition, Mr. Draskovic, who agreed to enter the federal Government two weeks ago.
"Milosevic can say with some legitimacy that he has a national unity Government, and politically, he controls every institution," Ms. Smajlovic said. "The only people outside his reach are those, like students, journalists and professors, who have no parliamentary seats or institutional authority."
And this more liberal group can hardly attack Mr. Milosevic from the right, for avoiding another war and making concessions on Kosovo.
"Officials here like to say that they don't have enough money to make everyone happy, but they have enough to bribe anyone they need," Mr. Grubacic said. "The country is poorer than before, but passive. Milosevic is the king, untouchable, and underneath him, the factions are fighting."
Even a prominent member of the opposition Democratic Party, its vice president, Slobodan Vuksanovic, says that Mr. Milosevic's position is unchallenged now, and that the opposition has damaged itself badly by its own mistakes and rivalries.
Only two years ago, 200,000 people turned out daily in Belgrade to demonstrate against Mr. Milosevic and in favor of democratic spokesmen like Mr. Draskovic, Zoran Djindjic and Vesna Pesic. Their coalition -- Zajedno, or unity -- won local elections in Belgrade, which represents almost a third of Serbia's population.
But their own disputes destroyed the coalition, and their decision to boycott parliamentary elections left them without any parliamentary votes or a clear program.
"Milosevic didn't do this to us," Mr. Vuksanovic said. "We did this to ourselves. He's still in power because opposition leaders missed so many opportunities."
The opposition could have won up to 100 of the 250 seats in the Serb parliament, Mr. Vuksanovic said, but "in the end we're left with nothing."
While Mr. Draskovic contended in an interview that he has kept his integrity and is fighting for the same democratic goals "from within," Mr. Vuksanovic says Mr. Draskovic is trying to benefit from the perks of power, including wide access to the state-controlled media.
At the same time, he notes, Mr. Draskovic's deal with Mr. Milosevic will deeply disappoint ordinary voters. "They will look at this opposition leader and say, 'He's just like all the rest of them,' " he said.
The ordinary voter is afraid of risk, Mr. Vuksanovic said. "They know Milosevic is a bad guy," he said, "but they see that he's stronger than all the other political leaders put together."
Of course the end will come for Mr. Milosevic, Mr. Grubacic said, but not now. "The challenge will be spontaneous," he said, "caused by a stupid mistake, like the last drop of water that overfills the glass."

HEADLINE: Explosion At Ford Plant Kills Worker

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 1

 BODY:
A thunderous explosion, followed by a fire that burned for several hours, killed one worker and injured at least 30 today at the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge complex, long a symbol of American industrial strength that put the nation on wheels by building the Model T.
The explosion and fire heavily damaged the complex's power plant, which normally produces enough electricity to supply the residential needs of a city the size of Boston. Ford and Rouge Steel, a subsidiary here that Ford sold a decade ago, were forced to close all six factories in the 1,100-acre Rouge complex and send home almost all 10,000 workers until further notice. 
 Art Janes, the Ford site manager here, said late tonight that the company was bringing in generators to reopen a parts factory here quickly, adding that 16 of Ford's 20 North American assembly plants depended on parts from it. Later, a Ford spokesman said four assembly plants elsewhere were scheduled for half-shifts on Tuesday because of a shortage of parts.
The cause of the explosion, which occurred in the power plant at about 1 P.M., was not known.
Charles N. Jeffress, the Assistant Secretary of Labor for occupational safety and health in Washington, said that although industrial accidents involving similar numbers of injuries happen occasionally, it was extremely rare to have such a broad and immediate economic effect from an accident. Michigan is one of 23 states in which state officials instead of Federal ones investigate workplace mishaps, and these state investigators will start as soon as firefighters declare the site safe, Mr. Jeffress said in a telephone interview.
In addition to the dead and injured, one worker was missing tonight and might be the unidentified dead person, the police said. Many of the injured were severely burned and 12 were in critical condition.
Auto industry workers have a rate of injury and work-related illness that is two and a half times that of the average for workers in the private sector, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. But Ford has had a fairly good record until now, maintaining a large staff to investigate ways to improve workplace safety, Mr. Jeffress said.
William Clay Ford Jr., Ford Motor's chairman, arrived at the factory less than two hours after the explosion, as firefighters were still trying to put out the blaze, and said the loss of life and injuries made today "the worst day of my life." A great-grandson of Henry Ford, Mr. Ford, 44, emphasized safety and environmental issues as a member of Ford's board before reasserting the Ford family's control of the company last fall and becoming the chairman at the start of this year.
Ford Motor's headquarters is still situated about three miles from the Rouge complex here in this southwestern suburb of Detroit. Started in 1918, the factory complex employed nearly 100,000 workers at its peak in the late 1940's. The complex took iron ore, timber, rubber and other raw materials and turned them into cars. While Henry Ford perfected assembly-line production and built the first Model T's at another, smaller factory in nearby Highland Park, Mich., it was the Rouge complex that became a symbol of American mass production after World War I.
Subsequent factory complexes were less ambitious, buying more of their parts from outside suppliers. Ford now builds the Mustang and many auto parts here.
Ford officials declined to speculate tonight on when the aging factories here would reopen, saying their first concern was for their workers' safety. The unionized workers here will continue to be paid.
George McPartlin, a Ford employee who used to work inside the plant and stood outside it this afternoon, said the top floor, where the worst fires burned, was where coal dust was fed as fuel into the boilers. He raced to the factory this afternoon to make sure that his brother, Larry, a power plant electrician, was safe.
"He had soot all over his clothes and he was shaking" but was not injured, Mr. McPartlin said, adding that his brother had told him that the explosion occurred in a boiler that had just been repaired and only turned on again on Sunday night.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET PROPOSAL: THE DETAILS -- Freeze on Medicare Money to Hospitals Would Pay for Health Care Initiatives;
Military Spending

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH BECKER 

 BODY:
The budget includes the largest increase in military spending since the cold war buildup under President Ronald Reagan and would give members of the military their biggest raise in a decade.
The President's budget of $267.2 billion includes a $12 billion increase, $4 billion of which is a straight increase and $8 billion of which is financed by savings earned from lower-than-budgeted fuel prices and inflation. 
 The President also asking for the authority to initiate two more rounds of base closings, which would eventually produce $2 billion in annual savings, although that is not reflected in this year's budget.
While Mr. Clinton appears to have included all the money requested by the military to improve pay, benefits and readiness -- including spare parts and training -- he held back on any sharp increase for modernizing the military's weaponry and equipment. He asked for $53 billion for procurements, only $1 billion less than in the earlier budget review. But it was not the larger increase requested by the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
That modernization includes money for a new Virginia-class attack submarine, Navy ships, aircraft for the Air Force and a national missile defense system that the Pentagon is trying to develop.
"This highlights the looming debate over modernization that will probably become part of next year's Presidential campaign," said Michael O'Hanlon of the Brookings Institution. "The question will be whether the cold-war-like agenda for modernization should be reassessed before all that money is spent."
In presenting the budget, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen emphasized the 4.4 percent increase in pay for the troops, the reinstatement of military retirement benefits to 50 percent of base pay after 20 years in service, from 40 percent, as well as special programs to encourage members of the military to stay in the service.
Congress agrees that the military deserves higher pay and, in what may become a bidding war, a Senate committee last week approved a bill that would give the military an even larger raise, 4.8 percent.
Mr. Cohen said today that while the Pentagon welcomed as much money as it could get "for our men and women in uniform," he was worried that the Senate would not be able to come up with the additional $7 billion that its pay proposal would require.
"We do not want to raise expectations and not be able to pay for it," he said.
Immediately, Senate Republicans, who plan to make increasing military pay a major theme of this Congressional session, complained that the Clinton budget for the military was not large enough.
"I am disappointed that the President did not fully heed the requests of his Secretary of Defense and the Joint Chiefs of Staff for a significant defense budget increase," said Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona.
The military budget is aside from $13 billion for the nuclear weapons programs of the Energy Department.
About $29 billion of the Pentagon's budget is for the nation's 13 intelligence services, including the Central Intelligence Agency. The precise amount is classified. ELIZABETH BECKER

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
How an Elusive Essence Turned Into a Blessing

BYLINE: By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:

CINDERELLA & COMPANY
Backstage at the Opera With Cecilia Bartoli
By Manuela Hoelterhoff
Illustrated. 262 pages. Alfred. A. Knopf. $25.
 Manuela Hoelterhoff's backstage look at the Cecilia Bartoli phenomenon and the opera world in general is the most perceptive and hilariously honest book on the making and marketing of opera to come along in some time. 
 But it did not turn out quite the way Ms. Hoelterhoff, a Pulitzer Prize-winning former critic and editor at The Wall Street Journal, intended. The original idea was to provide a behind-the-scenes report on an indisputably excellent singer who had achieved sensational popularity before her 30th birthday. For two years, leading up to a new production of Ms. Bartoli's signature opera, Rossini's "Cenerentola" at the Met in 1997, Ms. Hoelterhoff had enviable access to the singer and her circle: her mother, a former chorus soprano and still Ms. Bartoli's most trusted vocal coach; her worldly Italian boyfriend; her savvy manager, Jack Mastroianni, and a whole cast of recording executives and attendant conductors who pass through the story like comprimario characters in an opera buffa.
 Yet, though Ms. Bartoli was quite cooperative, she proved an exasperating subject. Ultimately the reason this particular Italian mezzo-soprano, gifted as she is, has generated such tenacious loyalty, particularly among her American fans (the Italian public has never been quite as enthralled), is a bit inexplicable, and after a while you sense Ms. Hoelterhoff's frustration.
This is not a typical case of a biographer growing jaded the more she learns about her subject. From the first time Ms. Hoelterhoff encountered Ms. Bartoli's singing, on a recording of Rossini's "Barber of Seville," she was smitten. Here was "a smooth, glimmering truffle of a voice," she writes in "Cinderella & Company," "astonishing in its virtuosity and range."
Still, the Bartoli material must have seemed insufficient for an entire book. So, happily for readers, Ms. Hoelterhoff introduces us to just about everyone operatic she met during those two years, interspersed with collected bits of wisdom and gossip. We read about the great Renata Tebaldi's first visit to the United States in 20 years, opera's self-absorbed new love couple, Roberto Alagna and Angela Gheorghiu, the surreal planning meetings for James Levine's gargantuan 25th-anniversary celebration, Renee Fleming, the new generation and much more. The resulting book is a bit of this, a bit of that. But Ms. Hoelterhoff is such an interesting observer and beguiling writer that you eagerly follow her anywhere.
Her snappy sentences often end with surprise punches: she defines the period of bel canto as a tradition in which "embellishments, fluid scales, interpolations and good taste were expected even of tenors." She has a novelist's ability to capture a person in a few wry phrases. Here she is on Joseph Volpe, the general manager of the Met: "A blunt guy with an opera villain's chin beard and a healthy hunger for prestige, the 55-year-old Volpe had now muscled his way past Levine on the totem pole, acquiring excellent suits and independent taste along the way."
Some critics have found Ms. Hoelterhoff's irreverence overly harsh, as when she writes that the only singer of her knowledge who smokes is the Wagnerian tenor Siegfried Jerusalem, "who puffs like Fafner the dragon and sounds like it too." But, an enduring love for opera and compassion come through in her account. Yes, the coloratura June Anderson is described as "another singer tethered to the ground by a fraying silk thread." But later in the same paragraph, reflecting on why Ms. Anderson seems determined, despite her success, to be miserable, Ms. Hoelterhoff writes: "Of all the artists I have ever met, she made me most aware of how hard it can be for shy singers to come to terms with a mysterious gift that requires them to face several thousand strangers who do not necessarily wish them well."
Knowing of Ms. Hoelterhoff's reputation as an unsparing critic and reporter, it's amazing that so many people in the business talked with her so freely, notably the powerful manager and public relations maestro Herbert Breslin, whom Ms. Hoelterhoff calls a "motor-mouthed, bullet-headed, forever tan egomaniac." Mr. Breslin's soliloquy on how he and his prime client, Luciano Pavarotti, showed everyone how real money could be made in opera is breathtaking in its honesty and shamelessness.
The sections on Ms. Bartoli are the heart of the book. There is ample evidence of her superb musicianship, determination and unconventionally interesting career choices, like that of making her Met debut in Mozart's "Cosi Fan Tutte" in the relatively small role of Despina, the maid. "I want to have some pleasure out of my debut," Ms. Bartoli is quoted as saying, "and maybe change perceptions of what is a debut at the Met."
Fans will gain some perspective on Ms. Bartoli's penchant for missing performances. Several notable cancellations seem to have been genuinely precipitated by illness, travel snafus and even personal tragedy: during the years covered in the book, Ms. Bartoli's beloved younger brother died of a brain tumor.
But sometimes her cancellations are maddening to read about, as when a healthy Ms. Bartoli pulled out of a live Saturday broadcast of "Cosi" because two lead male singers were ill, and Mr. Levine, also ill, was stuck in another city. That millions in the international radio audience were counting on hearing her did not seem to matter. Ms. Hoelterhoff does not disguise her astonishment.
But never the most mellow bunch, opera singers have to put up with pushy managers, clueless directors and drafty rehearsal rooms and still exercise their unearthly voices in the most difficult vocal music ever conceived. If anything, with the current economic squeeze in the recording industry, not to mention instant worldwide communications, there is more pressure than ever.
Ms. Bartoli's career is a juggernaut, and one can only hope she keeps her balance. Ms. Hoelterhoff makes few predictions, either about Ms. Bartoli or the field in general. But it is immensely fun and informative to read her account of the problems.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: British Group Urges Freer Exchange of Actors With U.S.

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
A British arts group has strongly criticized a union agreement that governs the number of British and American theater actors working on opposite sides of the Atlantic, and its report is raising hopes that the restrictions can be ended or loosened.
Under the current rules, a producer who wants to bring a British actor to New York must seek the approval of Actors Equity, the American union, just as British Equity's approval is needed to bring an American actor to London. In theory the two unions try to balance the exchange. But over the years some Britons have charged that provisions for exchange have been unevenly and unfairly applied. 
 Some Americans have said that because so much British theater is Government-subsidized and costs are lower in London than New York, British producers and actors would reduce jobs for Americans in a more open marketplace. It costs roughly $500,000 to mount a play in London, compared with some $2.5 million in New York.
The report from the British Council, the country's main international cultural agency, argues that the current policies mean that audiences in both countries miss seeing a great deal of theater and that many actors lose opportunities to work.
"The importance of this report is that it provides a thorough and systematic analysis of a system that is failing actors on both sides of the Atlantic and ultimately the theatergoing public as well," said Jed Bernstein, executive director of The League of American Theaters and Producers, the national trade organization.
The report for the British Council charges that American Equity's influence in the international exchange of actors "is unquestionably operating in restraint of trade between the two countries." It adds that the American union's rationale for its approach is based on "short-term quasi-economic arguments for which there is little if any justification."
Alan Eisenberg, executive director of Actors Equity, said yesterday that the union was willing to sit down and talk with British Equity, which has requested a meeting because of the report. But he said the trade agreement was still needed to protect American jobs.
"The American actor is underemployed and underpaid," Mr. Eisenberg said. "Frequently, when a production comes in, it takes away a job and a career opportunity from an American actor.
"What we're trying to do in the exchange is deal with the artistic complaint of obstruction," Mr. Eisenberg continued. "Open borders, given the lack of subsidy and support, would work to the detriment of actors in this country."
There are three ways a British actor's move to New York can be approved: if he or she is deemed by Actors Equity to be a star; if the production is mounted by what the union considers a "unit company," one of long standing that performs in repertory, like the Royal Shakespeare Company; or if the actor provides "unique services," like those of the African chanters in "The Lion King."
Otherwise, the only way a British actor can be approved by Equity's Alien Committee is as part of an exchange in which the British producers put up a bond and guarantee that an equal number of American actors will be employed in Britain, at United States wage rates, in commensurate roles.
No equivalent provisions appear in formal agreements between British Equity and the Society of London Theater and Theatrical Management Association, but in practice the same categories of exemption are generally observed.
The curious calculus controlling exchanges, rather than providing clear guidelines, has prompted many emotional arguments about who is a star, what constitutes a unit company and the definition of unique services.
At the end of January, Actors Equity rejected a bid to bring to Broadway the entire British cast of the Royal National Theater's highly praised revival of "Oklahoma!," saying that American actors could fill the roles.
The actors' exchange is "the only situation of its kind in the world, and it's terribly close to artists' hearts," Sally Cowling, head of drama and dance for the British Council, said yesterday in a telephone interview from London. "We're just saying this is not in the artists' best interests.
"My first and most simple objective is to add my voice to the encouraging voices," she said. "There are still a lot of problems. Let's get around the table again. There were a lot of companies and individuals on both sides of the Atlantic who didn't know what the situation was."
The main argument running through the British report is that the two countries have a special relationship, culturally and historically, and that the pattern of cultural exchange generally operates freely in every realm except the theater.
"No one seeks to count Dame Janet Baker's appearances at Carnegie Hall and tally them against Jessye Norman's at the Royal Festival Hall or the Barbican," the report said. "There is no suggestion that because Andre Previn takes charge of the London Symphony Orchestra, a British conductor must be given a reciprocal opportunity in, say, Chicago or Cleveland."
The two actors' unions and the producers' groups from both countries all met for the first time in London in 1997 to hammer out some of the issues. At that time the producers proposed a temporary moratorium, perhaps lasting two or three years, on all union restrictions governing the actors' exchange.
Actors Equity rejected the idea at the time, saying that the flow would be in one direction, to the detriment of American actors. The producers then proposed the idea of some sort of subsidy package to underwrite American productions in London and guarantee some American jobs in Britain.
The issue has become more pressing in recent years as more plays have emigrated to New York from Britain and Ireland, among them "Art," "The Beauty Queen of Leenane" and "The Judas Kiss."
American actors on the London stage in recent months have included Kevin Spacey at the Old Vic as Hickey in a revival of "The Iceman Cometh" and David Dukes, Stacey Keach and George Wendt, who replaced the all-British cast of "Art." There is also an all-American cast in a revival of "Show Boat."
"We certainly hope we can get back round the table," said Rupert Rhymes, the chief executive of the London producers' group. "Obviously what we'd like to see happen, as far as our members are concerned, is there be a free exchange, at least for a trial period."

HEADLINE: THE NEW AMERICAN SERVICE;
Easygoing, Not French And Formal

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
IN one of world's most serious restaurant cities, Daniel Swee qualifies as a heroic diner. He can be found reading a menu up to five nights a week, sometimes for business, more often for pleasure. "I eat out far too often," he said. Over a decade, Mr. Swee, the casting director for Lincoln Center Theater, has felt a change in restaurant service that's a little like a change in the weather. It's nothing specific, it's hard to put your finger on, but it's there, and it has made him happy.
"There's a trend toward restaurants where the food is really fantastic, but the atmosphere is casual, and you are made to feel welcome," he said. "In the past, you felt that dining in a top restaurant was a rare privilege, and you'd better behave. Now, there's a warmth and an interaction that wasn't there before." 
 In a city where intimidation is nine points of the law and one-upmanship is the coin of the realm, pleasing the customer counts as a revolutionary idea. Mr. Swee is not alone in sensing a different tone in restaurant service these days, one that reflects a shift in the way restaurant service is thought of, invested in and delivered in New York and other large cities.
Over the last decade, a distinctly American style of service has been evolving, a relaxed yet professional approach that suits the national character better than the old, formal French-style service. This reinterpretation of restaurant protocol is radical enough to merit a name -- the new American service -- and at fine restaurants, owners and managers spend as much time thinking about it as they do about the food.
And plenty of diners would say it's about time. More than half those who responded in the 1999 Zagat Survey, which covers 45 cities, listed service as their top restaurant complaint, and for all restaurants, service ratings lagged 1.5 points behind food ratings on the survey's 30-point scale. In New York, the city with the highest restaurant prices in the country, 43 percent of respondents nevertheless listed service as their top complaint, and the average service rating was nearly 2 points lower than the average food rating.
The gap reflects a historical lag between food and service that makes perfect sense, given the evolution of American cuisine. In the 1970's and 80's, American restaurants, energized by a fresh American approach to cooking, threw all their energies into the kitchen. In the last decade, however, as food quality rose, and as competition between restaurants heated up, owners and managers began looking at service as a way to set themselves apart. Their efforts have begun to show.
"Service in fine dining is at an all-time high right now," said Elizabeth Ward, a vice president for marketing at Visa, who helps restaurants develop programs to improve service. "Fine-dining restaurants can get highly educated, skilled employees, who know they can make a lot of money serving. Also, the restaurants realize that to charge the prices they do, they have to nail it every time."
Karen MacNeil, a restaurant consultant who lectures on service at the Culinary Institute of America's campus in the Napa Valley in California, went even further. "American service is much better than European service right now," she said. "When I go to Europe, I am shocked, except at three-star restaurants, where it's like an elegant ballet, at how much more professional the American waiters are."
So why all the complaining? Although statistics on the restaurant industry tend to be scanty, the numbers that are out there paint a picture of an America that is rapidly developing two starkly divergent restaurant economies. The mass-taste establishments, which include chains, casual-dining restaurants and fast-food franchises, are indeed in the throes of a service crisis. Like their counterparts in the hotel and retail industries, they have been squeezed by a tight labor market, which has sent them scrambling for employees, who leave almost as soon as they are hired.
"Nationwide, many casual-dining restaurants have more jobs than people to fill them, which depresses standards a bit," said Art Siemering, the editor of Trend/ Wire, an industry newsletter. "Restaurants want to give good service, but the whole labor market works against it."
In an annual survey by the American Society for Quality and the University of Michigan, consumer satisfaction with fast-food restaurants, low to begin with, compared with other service industries, has declined markedly since 1994, the first year the survey was conducted.
"Expectations are higher," said Ron Zemke, the president of Performance Research Associates, a Minneapolis company that evaluates service and training for restaurants. "In part this is because of the better economy, but it's also because of an increased awareness of higher levels of service, much more than five years ago."
At fine restaurants, however, especially in New York, San Francisco and Chicago, where competition among top-dollar spots is ferocious, the picture looks very different. In the last five years, the gap between food and service ratings in the Zagat Survey has shrunk from 2 points to 1.5 points. "That's a significant change when you're talking about the whole range of restaurants covered by the survey," said Tim Zagat, who publishes the survey.
Over the same period, tips, ordinarily regarded as a reward for service, have risen across the country. According to survey data from NPD Group, a market research company in Rosemont, Ill., the average dinner tip nationwide rose from 14.9 percent in 1993 to 16.2 percent in 1997. In Manhattan, the standard tip at a good restaurant is close to 20 percent.
Somebody is doing something right.
The new style of service is still taking shape, the rules are in flux, but restaurant owners and their customers know it or feel it when they meet it.
What it is not is the old-fashioned European-style service, with tuxedoed captains, imposing maitre d'hotels, rigid rules of service and an air of hauteur and intimidation. For generations of American diners, this was the definition of fine dining -- the kind of snooty French joint where Lucy and Ethel made fools of themselves. It became an anachronism as a new generation of chefs and restauarant owners developed a fresh American approach to cuisine over the last 25 years.
At its best, new American service is professional, casual and democratic. It is democratic in two senses. First, diners get equal, or at least more nearly equal, consideration, rather than being divided into nobodies and friends of the house. Second, service duties are shared more equally among staff members, which translates into better, more informed service for diners and, not incidentally, good salaries for waiters at top restaurants. It is not uncommon to earn $50,000 a year waiting tables at a second-level restaurant in New York, while waiters at the city's top restaurants can bring home $80,000. The profession may not have the glamour that attaches to chefs, but the days of "My name is Jason, and I'll be your waiter," and snide remarks about out-of-work actors feel anachronistic these days.
"It's a little more conversational, rather than presentational," Mr. Swee said. "You can have a conversation with the servers and actually learn. At Babbo, one of my current favorites, if the wine steward comes over, it's not an intimidating experience. He's incredibly knowledgeable, but enthusiastic and willing to talk to you, to help."
In recent years, it has become standard practice at fine restaurants for waiters to know the menu from top to bottom, and to be able to answer questions about the ingredients in each dish. Waiters are expected to have a solid understanding of wine.
The new way takes a lot of time and a lot of money. When Picholine changed its format from casual bistro to fine dining, Terrance Brennan, the owner and chef, hired a sommelier and a fromageur, bumped up the number of waiters from five to eight, and added a second runner to carry food from the kitchen. He hired a silver polisher after upgrading from stainless steel. His linen costs doubled, partly because he started using finer cloth and partly because diners who get up from their seats to use the telephone, or to go to the restroom, return to find a new folded napkin at their places. Mr. Brennan hired an extra manager simply to oversee service. "Actually, I think service is a little more important than the food," he said.
The changes cost money. The number of employees rose from 25, when the restaurant opened, to 75 now. Over five years, Mr. Brennan raised prices about 25 percent.
Before Bayard's, a new restaurant on Hanover Square in Manhattan, opened its doors last month, it put the staff through a week of lectures and workshops organized by Eric Weiss, the president of Service Arts, which has worked with about 80 New York restaurants in the last six years.
In addition to hearing notables like Gray Kunz, the former chef at Lespinasse, and Karen Waltuck, an owner of Chanterelle, talk about the subject, staff members at Bayard's went through role-playing exercises. They learned that waiters who are asked where the bathrooms are must walk the customer at least halfway there, instead of pointing. Because many diners are unfamiliar with the Wall Street area, staff members carry a map with instructions on how to get to the restaurant by car, train or subway. The first-floor and second-floor hostesses must know the menu inside out, so that they can field questions about ingredients from callers or potential diners who stop in off the street.
Restaurant Associates, when training the staffs for Cafe Centro, Tropica and its other restaurants, schools them in a 10-part regimen called "Steps of Service." It begins with "First Approach" ("Greet guests with a smile, within two minutes of table being seated") and takes the servers through the entire meal in great detail. "Check Presentation" is divided into three parts.
Technique is only half the battle, and one of the main differences between the old style of service and the new is a characteristically American inclination to put practice ahead of theory. "To break up a conversation simply to be technically correct in serving from the left makes no sense," Mr. Brennan said. "We will bend that rule in the interest of unobtrusive service. We'll serve incorrectly rather than put an elbow in someone's face or intrude on someone's personal space."
In any case, technique is only half the battle. The art of waiting tables rests on intangibles. "The real difference between good service and great service is the ability to read the table," Mr. Weiss said. "You don't treat every table the same. You have to be sensitive to body language, to the things that people say, and serve them accordingly."
A good waiter can sense when diners want to be let alone and when they want attention. He or she can usually tell who is in a hurry and who wants to linger. An even better waiter can draw subtler inferences. Take the diner who asks for "a dry white wine." One who asks for a medium-bodied white wine needs a different response from one who wants to know whether a sauvignon blanc has an assertively grassy character.
A waiter at the top of his game, in Mr. Weiss's view, achieves near-psychoanalytic powers of analysis and receptivity. At any rate, Mr. Weiss spends a lot of time telling his workshop students that many diners they encounter will not be in the restaurant to eat at all, when you look deeply enough. "Many people are at a restaurant because they want recognition, attention or simply to belong to something," he said.
The demanding customer is often sending out a cry for help, in other words. It's not about the underdone fillet, which clearly isn't underdone at all. The perceptive server knows this and takes the appropriate therapeutic measures. The steak goes straight back to the kitchen, no questions asked, and the diner is soothed with apologies and cosseted.
Or not. Last November, when Richard Fischbein led a posse of his fellow lawyers and paralegals from the firm of Fischbein Badillo & Harding into Angelo & Maxie's, a Manhattan steakhouse, he simmered in silence at service that he later called "a disaster." Then he erupted, refusing to pay the mandatory 18 percent service charge levied on large parties.
Angelo & Maxie's, in a move straight out of the old school, detained Mr. Fischbein and summoned the police. The mess was sorted out before both sides got to court, but not before Mr. Fischbein became an instant culture hero.
In the city that invented service with a snarl, there may be a little work still left undone.
 
How Are You Being Served?
 
WHAT is good service? Many diners say they know it when they see it or feel it, but the rules are in flux. Although the new American service continues to evolve, it has its hallmarks -- things a restaurant will do to make customers feel comfortable and welcome. Here is a checklist of some things to look for, provided by restaurateurs and consultants who specialize in service.
Many diners think of service as a product delivered by the waiter. They're wrong. "It's everything that happens to you other than the calories that go into your body," said Karen MacNeil, a consultant. "It begins when you phone to make a reservation."
* Does the reservationist ask if you would mind holding, instead of cutting you off with a quick "Please hold"? Is there an apology when the reservationist gets back on the line? Is there some expression of regret if the restaurant does not have the desired opening?
* When you enter the restaurant, does the person at the reservation book look up and greet you? "The first thing I notice is whether the host seems perplexed by my name," Ms. MacNeil said. "There is no reason for anyone to stare for five minutes at the book. I mean, how many reservations can there be at 8 o'clock? Half a dozen? Part of the job is to memorize the book."
* How does the hostess escort you to the table? If you have to race to keep up, something's wrong. She should walk slightly ahead and slightly turned toward you. A waiter should establish contact almost immediately, diners should be presented with the menus hand to hand, and menus should be open.
* When taking drink orders, the waiter should read the table to determine what kind of interaction diners want and how quickly they want the meal to progress.
* In taking food orders, the waiter should describe, rather than recite, the specials and encourage questions about specials and menu items. In taking the wine order, the waiter should gauge the level of wine sophistication at the table, describe the wines accordingly and suggest pairings of wine and food.
* When serving and clearing, the servers should violate the protocol of serving from the left and clearing from the right if that is more unintrusive. When a problem arises, the waiter should apologize and correct it, without making excuses, challenging the diner or taking a defensive tone. WILLIAM GRIMES

HEADLINE: Home Sales Up by 10.4%, Setting Record During 1998

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Sales of new homes surged to a record last year, fueled by job gains, rising consumer confidence and low interest rates that should carry the economy well into a ninth year of expansion.
Sales totaled 888,000 in 1998, up 10.4 percent from a year earlier and well above the previous high of 819,000 set in 1977, Commerce Department figures showed. In December, new single-family homes sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 978,000 units, the second-highest monthly pace ever, eclipsed only by November's record of 1.015 million homes. The figure was down 3.6 percent in December. 
 In another report, the index of leading economic indicators, intended to project the economy's performance six months out, rose for a third consecutive month in December, the Conference Board said. December's gain of three-tenths of a percent followed increases of half a percent in November and one-tenth of a percent in October.
"If you look at the pillars of this economy, there's really nothing stopping it," Tim O'Neill, the chief economist for Harris Bank and Bank of Montreal in Toronto, said, referring to consumer and business spending, manufacturing and housing.
Sales of all homes, existing and new, rose 13 percent in 1998, to 5.673 million units, a third consecutive annual record, government and industry figures show. Thirty-year mortgage rates below 7 percent contributed to the strength, as did the addition of 2.9 million jobs in 1998 that helped push the unemployment rate to a 28-year low of 4.3 percent.
The figures were released as the Federal Reserve started a two-day policy meeting. With an economy this strong, the Federal Reserve policy makers are not likely to cut interest rates. A survey of 30 primary dealers in Treasury securities found that all expected the Fed's Open Market Committee to leave the overnight bank lending rate target unchanged at 4.75 percent.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Is That a Bubble, or Is the Outlook Fabulous?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Bubble talk is back.
From Davos, where Microsoft's Bill Gates was expressing bewilderment as to why people would pay so much for Internet stocks, to Washington, where Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, questioned overall stock prices but said some Internet companies might be good investments even at current prices, people are talking about investment bubbles that might burst. 
 "Bubble" is a pejorative term for an investment whose price rises and rises, and then collapses. It is widely agreed that just such a thing happened to Japanese stock and real estate prices in the late 1980's, and that Japan has yet to recover.
Unfortunately, talking about bubbles is easier than spotting a real one, and it is even more difficult to know when one will burst.
Charles P. Kindleberger, the economist and author of "Manias, Panics and Crashes," the definitive academic study of such things, thought he saw a bubble in this country's stock market a few years back. "I agreed with Greenspan in 1996 when he talked about irrational exuberance, and the stock market is up 50 percent since then," said Mr. Kindleberger, now retired from M.I.T. "I'm still looking to see what would come up suddenly to keep the lemmings from running. Where is the cliff they will run over?"
Bubble talk now tends to deal with two related but separate phenomena. Has the overall level of American stock prices gotten away from economic reality? Is it possible that Internet companies will someday earn enough to justify the lofty peaks their stocks reached last month?
Some dismiss all such talk as nonsense. Markets are rational, they say, so bubbles cannot exist. Even the Dutch tulip-bulb boom now has academics who argue it was rational.
That argument, however, does not give sufficient weight to the role of psychology in investing. "There is nothing," Mr. Kindleberger has written, "so disturbing to one's well-being and judgment as to see a friend get rich." In any period of speculative excess, those who urge caution are discredited well before the bubble bursts. Many thought Yahoo, the Internet company, was overpriced a year ago. Now it is about 10 times as high as it was then.
In 1720 Sir Isaac Newton, a very smart person, invested in the South Sea Company, whose dreams of profiting from exploration made it into a classic bubble. Realizing prices had gone crazy, he sold at a profit, explaining, "I can calculate the motions of heavenly bodies, but not the madness of people." But prices kept rising, and Newton bought again, at the top. He suffered huge losses.
Peter L. Bernstein, an economic historian and consultant to money managers, is one who thinks that the Internet stocks are in a bubble, but that while the stock market as a whole is overvalued it is well short of one. What's the difference? "A bubble is totally out of touch with reality, where the greater-fool theory is the dominant driving force, where you are totally confident that somebody will be willing to pay higher prices no matter what you pay," he said.
Nonetheless, said Mr. Bernstein, the most remarkable thing about this period is "the really broad acceptance of the idea that nothing bad is going to happen to the U.S. economy. I don't remember people feeling this way even in the late 1960's." The economic expansion that ended in 1969 lasted almost nine years, the only one in American history longer than this one, which began in 1991.
Mr. Greenspan warned last year that the United States could not long remain an island of prosperity, but it has. When he voices concern about stock prices now, there is little market reaction, in contrast to 1996.
If there is a bubble, what will happen when it is pricked? The histories of Japan in the 1990's and the United States in the 1930's argue that bursting bubbles devastate economies.
But it does not have to be that way, particularly if the bubble is confined to the Internet stocks. Mr. Bernstein compared this boom to 1961, when investors flocked to space technology companies amid expectations that space would bring untold riches. Those stocks collapsed with the overall market in 1962, but no recession ensued and most stocks recovered.

HEADLINE: Toy Shipments Unexpectedly Flat for Year

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
True, youngsters sent parents scurrying to the malls last year in search of Rugrats, Blue's Clues and Teletubbies. And who can forget the Furby frenzy?
But even with a strong economy and such must-have hits, the toy industry turned in flat results last year and is projecting only modest gains this year. 
 The mediocre performance for 1998 and cautious forecast for this year reflect the continuing effects of changing consumer trends on the overall toy business. And the shifts -- everything from consumers abandoning traditional toy stores to shop at mass merchandise outlets to the effects of technology on child's play -- are being felt throughout the industry.
For 1998, wholesale shipments of toys were essentially flat, declining by $41 million, to $15.2 billion, according to the trade group Toy Manufacturers of America, which released the figures yesterday in advance of the 96th annual American International Toy Fair, which begins in New York on Monday.
"That's a little worse than I would have expected," said Thomas Graves, an analyst who follows the industry for Standard & Poor's Equity Group.
Of course, it did not help that youngsters yawned last year at some previous hot sellers. Remember Tickle Me Elmo and virtual pets?
Such once wildly popular playthings contributed to a robust 7 percent increase in toy shipments to retailers in 1997. As a result, 1998 "was a pretty tough comparison year," Mr. Graves said.
In fact, the Toy Manufacturers of America initially estimated that the industry would grow by as much as 4 percent in 1998, but later revised its forecast to growth of 2 percent to 3 percent. The industry, with retail sales of about $22 billion, missed even that conservative growth target as strong categories like stuffed animals and toy cars and trucks were offset by slower sellers like action figures and dolls.
Beyond that, the nation's largest toy retailer -- Toys "R" Us -- lost its footing last year, which caused manufacturers to stumble.
Toys "R" Us had a disastrous year, having reporting several quarters of disappointing earnings heading into the all important holiday selling season. For the first nine months of last year, Toys "R" Us lost $442 million. Then, during the holiday season, which should have been its strongest period, Toys "R" Us said sales at its stores open at least a year declined by 7 percent.
The company, after watching shoppers increasingly bypass its parking lots on their way to discount chains like Wal-Mart Stores and Kmart, has been drastically paring its inventory to cut costs and to clear its shelves for new toys it hopes will lure customers back. In doing so, however, Toys "R" Us slashed orders to manufacturers, which were unable to make up the volume elsewhere.
Indeed, Mattel Inc., the world's largest toy maker, said reduced orders for its Barbies, Power Wheels and other toys contributed greatly to its poor performance for the fourth quarter and year. Jill E. Barad, Mattel's chairman and chief executive, said in announcing the company's results yesterday that "unexpected cutbacks by retailers and our further adjustment to a just-in-time shipping pattern negatively impacted our results."
For the fourth quarter, Mattel's net income tumbled 69 percent, to $59.5 million, or 20 cents a diluted share, from $195.1 million, or 64 cents, the company said. Mattel also said it took two charges -- one for $27 million related to a recall of Power Wheels and the other $4 million to settle a lawsuit. Revenues declined to $1.54 billion from $1.61 billion.
For the year, the company earned $332.3 million, or $1.10 a diluted share, compared with $285 million, or 93 cents a diluted share, a year earlier. Revenues fell to $4.78 billion from $4.83 billion.
Despite the bad results, Mattel's stock rose 31.25 cents, to $25.375.
Investors, who had been warned to expect poor results, seem to be satisfied that retailers now have lean inventories and will soon increase orders from the larger manufacturers.
What is more, with its recent acquisition of the Learning Company, a leading software maker, Mattel is likely to benefit from a trend that is challenging many of its competitors -- how to appeal to children who are abandoning traditional toys for the Internet.
"The Internet impacts the toy industry in a number of significant ways," said Peter Eio, chairman of the Toy Manufacturers, who estimated that the toy industry would grow by 2 to 3 percent this year. "First and foremost, it occupies an increasing amount of children's time, and therefore, to a certain extent, displaces time that might otherwise be devoted to play."
To capitalize on the trend, the industry must meet consumers' increasing demand for entertaining and educational interactive play," Mr. Eio said, adding that "the real winners will be those companies who combine new technology with tried and trusted brands."

HEADLINE: The New Surplus Era

 BODY:
Of all the initiatives in President Clinton's proposed budget this week, the most politically significant may turn out to be a simple forecast. The United States, the Administration says, is on the threshold of an era of budget surpluses, nearly $4.5 trillion in the next 15 years. Far from calling for a major redirection of government, Mr. Clinton wants to set aside a mere 11 percent of the surpluses for new spending. Three-quarters would be used to shore up Medicare and Social Security. Embattled by impeachment but enjoying the highest approval ratings of his Presidency, Mr. Clinton has sketched a vision striking for its essential conservatism.
The approach is also sensible and farsighted. Social Security and Medicare face future deficits unless significant changes are made. Instead of proposing bold new programs to serve as his legacy, Mr. Clinton is calling for a major investment in the two programs that are the greatest legacies of the New Deal and the Great Society. Republicans have seized on the dozens of smaller spending and tax-break initiatives to paint Mr. Clinton as an old-style apostle of big government. But under the President's budget plan, overall spending is projected to shrink to 19.4 percent of the nation's economy, the smallest proportion in 25 years. The dreaded label of liberal does not fit. 
 The budget has clearly thrown Republicans onto the defensive. Every poll shows that Americans would rather preserve Social Security and Medicare than enjoy a big new tax cut, as Republican leaders want. It is also questionable how much political support there will be for a tax cut that disproportionately benefits the wealthiest Americans. On the other hand, Republicans are right to note that both Social Security and Medicare will need additional fixes beyond the proposed infusion of surplus money.
The extra attraction of Mr. Clinton's approach is that most of the surpluses would actually go to paying down the publicly held Federal debt, a step widely supported by many Americans and endorsed last month by Alan Greenspan. As the Federal Reserve chairman also warned, the surpluses are only a projection. They may diminish if the economy turns sour or plans for spending cuts do not materialize.
Policy makers in Washington are finding it hard to cope with the new political reality of surpluses. Only two years ago, every new proposal for spending increases or tax cuts was challenged as a threat to fiscal balance. Now the familiar budget debates can take place in a context of at least some extra money becoming available. The surpluses make it possible, at least theoretically, for Congress and the President to agree eventually to some kind of combination of tax cuts, money for Social Security and Medicare, spending increases and paying down of the debt. These issues are taking on greater immediacy as the Senate seems to be moving toward winding up the impeachment trial by the end of next week.

HEADLINE: Gephardt to Set His Sights on Speakership, Not Presidency

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri plans to take himself out of the running for President on Wednesday and devote himself full time to recapturing the House for Democrats in 2000 with the expectation that he will become Speaker.
Friends said Mr. Gephardt had recognized two strong political perceptions: that Vice President Al Gore had already laid a formidable claim to the Democratic Presidential nomination and that House Republicans were vulnerable to a takeover because their impeachment of President Clinton is so unpopular with the public. 
 An associate said Mr. Gephardt did not have the fire in the belly to run for President.
"It's not in his gut," this confidant said, adding that Mr. Gephardt was more drawn by the fight for the House. "We're tantalizingly close. He cares about the House, and he cares about the party."
Mr. Gephardt's departure from the field may entice at least one other Democrat, Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, into the race. So far, only former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey has announced his challenge to Mr. Gore for the nomination. Two other Senators, Bob Kerrey of Nebraska and Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, have backed off.
Mr. Gephardt began telling his Democratic colleagues privately today of his decision, which he is to announce on Wednesday. Friends described him as wistful about forgoing a run for President but confident that he was making the right decision because of Democrats' success in the 1998 elections, when analysts' predictions of a dozen-seat loss turned into a five-seat gain. The party needs a net gain of six seats in 2000 to regain control of the House.
Colleagues said Mr. Gephardt's staying to oversee the House drive would be crucial to that effort, since he is one of the few House Democrats who has a national fund-raising base and who is familiar with almost every district.
"He's the one who delivers our message the best," said Representative Martin Frost, Democrat of Texas and the caucus chairman. "He's a good fund-raiser and a unifying force for the Democratic caucus. This is the best possible scenario for us for retaking the House."
Terry McAuliffe, a top Democratic fund-raiser who is close to both Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Gore, said of Mr. Gephardt's decision: "They are very close to getting the House back, and Dick is the guy to lead that. And he wants the party to be unified. A divisive primary would not be unity."
Recent polls suggest that the public is fed up with Republicans in Congress because it sees them as dragging out the impeachment process. Democrats are identifying Republicans whose pro-impeachment votes are seen as hurting them, and Democratic Party officials say impeachment has prompted bigger financial contributions and earlier interest from potential candidates.
The picture is cloudier for Democrats on the Presidential front. A national poll released on Monday by the Los Angeles Times showed Mr. Gore losing to two Republicans: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, by 18 points, and Elizabeth Dole, former president of the American Red Cross, by 8 points.
One Democratic analyst said these numbers suggested that Mr. Gore was vulnerable, not that no Democratic candidate could win. Still, Mr. Gore's clear-cut advantages as Vice President in delivering Federal largesse and organizing the party apparatus to his liking have discouraged potential rivals.
The most recent polls show Mr. Gore way ahead of other Democrats. Last weekend's Marist College poll, for example, shows 44 percent of Democrats favoring Mr. Gore, 16 percent for Mr. Bradley and 11 percent for the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who has not announced whether he is running. Mr. Gephardt had 7 percent and Mr. Kerry 3 percent.
Mr. Gephardt's supporters said he was fully prepared to challenge Mr. Gore and had built up a national network since his failed Presidential bid in 1988. But others suggested that it might have been hard for Mr. Gephardt to give voice to a positive message that was distinctive enough from Mr. Gore's to capture a national following. Mr. Gephardt's history as an economic populist and strong backer of labor might have cast him as a naysayer at a time when Mr. Gore could boast of a booming economy.
Mr. Gephardt's supporters said he had invested himself so much in the House that his decision was essentially made for him when the Democrats made such a strong comeback in November. Mr. Gephardt's stock rose in the House at the same time, and as he evolved into the role of Mr. Clinton's chief defender, he and Mr. Gore found themselves working toward a common goal that has left the Democrats uncharacteristically united.
Erik Smith, a spokesman for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said the party's prospects for recapturing the House appeared so strong that more potential candidates were expressing an interest in running for Congress than the Democrats had experienced since they lost the House in 1994.
"People don't want to give up a ranking position in a state legislature or a mayorship if they're going to be in the minority," Mr. Smith said. "We're seeing a lot of interest."

HEADLINE: White House Externs;
Two Turns of the Revolving Door

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
It is barely 8 in the morning, and Rahm I. Emanuel, until recently a top adviser to President Clinton, is already in high gear, barking at waiters and looking over his shoulder to inspect others having breakfast at the Royalton Hotel in midtown Manhattan.
"Don't be chintzy with the berries," he warns a waiter walking toward the kitchen to pick up his bowl of granola. Later, Mr. Emanuel groans when asked what five words best describe him. "Oh, please," he said, "I can't handle this much therapy in the morning." 
 In some ways, Mr. Emanuel acts as if he were still in the White House. (He mentions more than once how often he still talks with Mr. Clinton.) But Mr. Emanuel is now in a world outside Washington, one where egos, energy and politics are certainly as prominent, but where they are aimed at a different goal: making money. Last month, he joined the boutique investment banking firm Wasserstein Perella & Company to seek his fortune as a merchant banker and corporate financier in his hometown, Chicago.
For many decades, Washington insiders have been trading in their powerful contacts and considerable back-room negotiating skills for lucrative jobs on Wall Street. Mr. Clinton's team has been no different.
The departure of Mr. Emanuel last fall came at roughly the same time as that of an even bigger White House heavyweight, Erskine B. Bowles. And Mr. Bowles, a confidant of Mr. Clinton who served most recently as White House chief of staff, has just joined the New York buyout firm Forstmann Little & Company as a general partner.
The two Clinton allies are a study in contrasts, and they bring to Wall Street different strengths and personalities.
Mr. Bowles, 53, was already a wealthy and seasoned banker before going to Washington in 1993 to head the Small Business Administration. He had founded an investment bank in North Carolina that specializes in advising midsize companies. The transition to Forstmann Little, Wall Street executives say, should be easy.
Patience has never been his strong suit, Mr. Bowles said. But he is reserved, adept at melding differing viewpoints and, in keeping with his Southern roots, is courteous.
Mr. Emanuel, 39, is a corporate novice. A creature of politics, he is tireless yet brusque. Stories about antics during his younger years abound. He once delivered a rotting fish to a pollster who displeased him. And at a restaurant in Little Rock, Ark., soon after Mr. Clinton was first elected President, Mr. Emanuel, ticking off a list of what he thought were disloyal Democrats and other political enemies, stabbed the table with his knife and screamed, "Dead!" after each name. Mr. Emanuel does not deny that either incident took place, but he declines to discuss them.
Investment bankers, of course, are hardly shrinking violets. Yet rarely are they so theatrical -- at least not in public. Still, if anyone understands how to leverage a strong personality it is Bruce Wasserstein, the takeover strategist and chairman of Wasserstein Perella, who hired Mr. Emanuel after a literary agent suggested that the two men meet.
Mr. Emanuel said he called Mr. Wasserstein after talking to several large investment banks that wanted him to pick a specialty -- asset management or corporate finance -- and move to New York. Mr. Emanuel resisted. "I didn't have a sense that three months later they'd care," he said.
Mr. Emanuel is compact and wiry -- he started taking ballet lessons when he was 15 -- and is a 1981 graduate of Sarah Lawrence College, where he studied philosophy. He received a master's degree in speech and communications from Northwestern University in 1985, and has no formal background in finance.
After graduating, he worked on several election campaigns, taking time out in 1991 to volunteer at an Israeli Army supply base during the Persian Gulf war. That same year, Mr. Emanuel headed to Little Rock to raise money for Mr. Clinton's Presidential bid. After the election, he joined the White House as political director. He soon made powerful friends -- and enemies -- in the media as he championed Mr. Clinton's agenda on the talk show circuit.
Mr. Emanuel shudders at the thought that deal making is any different in Washington than in the corporate suite. He cited his involvement in helping to shuttle the North American Free Trade Agreement, the assault weapons ban and the balanced budget amendment through Congress.
"You ever try to get a Congressman to do what you want?" Mr. Emanuel asked. "I don't think the skill set is so different."
Good negotiating skills alone, however, do not necessarily guarantee a long and happy business career. Some former Washington insiders, like David A. Stockman, the former Reagan Administration budget director who is now a banker at the New York-based Blackstone Group, a buyout firm, mastered the transition and prospered.
For others, Wall Street is just a temporary stomping ground. Richard C. Holbrooke, who joined Credit Suisse First Boston as vice chairman in 1996, is now waiting for his nomination as the chief United States delegate to the United Nations to be sent to the Senate. (His appointment was held up by allegations that he violated Federal lobbying laws; he has agreed to settle the civil charges without admitting wrongdoing, Government officials said yesterday.) Credit Suisse is the second tour of duty on Wall Street for Mr. Holbrooke, the architect of the 1995 peace accord that ended the war in Bosnia. He was a managing director for Lehman Brothers from 1984 to 1993.
The sharpest blow for former Washington insiders is often a loss of prestige. "If you are powerful in government, people come to you," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, who was an aide to former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and was Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs during the Reagan Administration. "Government contacts have a short shelf life. You have to nurture the old relationships and build the new."
And just knowing important people is not enough to merit applause on Wall Street.
"Closing a deal is everything," said Samuel Hayes, a finance professor at the Harvard Business School. "If you can close a deal you are great. If not, you are nothing."
Those who know Mr. Emanuel say he is a creative thinker and extremely loyal, with a keen ability to cut through any bureaucratic tangle. It was those qualities that swayed Mr. Wasserstein.
"To me, you take someone with a lot of intelligence, energy and integrity, and that's attractive to us," Mr. Wasserstein said. "I'm confident in my ability to teach people the technical parts of this business."
Besides, he noted, Mr. Emanuel learned a lesson in humility when he was replaced as White House political director in 1993 after his abrasiveness offended too many people. He was forced to move to the communications department, but he worked his way back into Mr. Clinton's graces and an office next to the President. "He fought, came back and learned to do it right," Mr. Wasserstein said. "I liked that tenacity, to see the iron hardened into steel."
Mr. Emanuel is not worried about his lack of experience in finance. He has been in his job only a month, but has been shuttling between New York and Chicago, meeting with chief executives and business leaders he encountered during his tenure at the White House as well as through personal contacts. He will be responsible in part for developing an investment banking practice in Chicago -- where he and his wife, Amy, and their two children live -- that will include advising companies on mergers and strategic planning.
Mr. Bowles, on the other hand, is an old pro at banking, having begun his career in 1969 at Morgan Stanley. In 1972, he moved to Charlotte, N.C., where he later started his own investment banking firm, Bowles Hollowell Conner & Company. There, he specialized in advising midsize firms on mergers and acquisitions.
Nearly 20 years ago, his firm arranged the sale of Kincaid Furniture, the first company acquired by Forstmann Little, which buys troubled companies, shores them up and then sells them. Since then, Bowles Hollowell has done 25 transactions with Forstmann. Mr. Bowles sold his share in the partnership when he moved to Washington in 1993.
"I like the marketing of a company and closing the transaction," he said. "And I like the money I make."
A graduate of the University of North Carolina with an M.B.A. from Columbia University's Graduate School of Business, Mr. Bowles will bring to Forstmann the same kind of organizational skills he used at the White House. Part of his charge is making sure that the buyout firm's in-house operations and investment evaluation process are more efficient, said Theodore J. Forstmann, the firm's chairman. "Plus, he will be helpful in our new-business effort," Mr. Forstmann said.
Mr. Bowles will also continue to be involved with Carousel Capital, the Charlotte-based merchant bank he helped start in 1996. Forstmann Little is investing $50 million in Carousel, Mr. Bowles said, but the two companies are not likely to compete because Carousel does not do transactions of more than $150 million and Forstmann rarely does a deal that small.
Mr. Bowles acknowledges that he, unlike Mr. Emanuel, never envisioned a life in politics. "People ask me all the time, why aren't you more political?" Mr. Bowles said. "I saw my career in politics as public service." In fact, he didn't know Mr. Clinton until 1992, when they were introduced by a mutual friend who asked Mr. Bowles to hold a fund-raiser in Charlotte for the candidate.
The two became fast friends, taking to golf outings and late-night telephone chats. In 1993, Mr. Clinton asked Mr. Bowles to be director of the Small Business Administration and then, in 1994, to work as deputy White House chief of staff.
After that stint, he returned to North Carolina to be with his wife, Crandall Close Bowles, who, as chief executive of the textile maker Spring Industries, is a powerful executive in her own right. He returned to Washington in 1996, when Mr. Clinton asked him to be chief of staff -- a job he accepted for $1 a year.
Mr. Bowles does not shy away from discussing Mr. Clinton's troubles, although it is clear by the way his relaxed mood turns frosty that he is tired of talking about it. "What he had was a relationship with Monica Lewinsky that was flat wrong," he said.
Mr. Bowles would rather talk about something he accomplished years before he joined the Clinton White House. What best defines him, he said, was finishing the Marine Corps marathon in 1982. "I wanted to prove to myself I could do it," he said.
When asked about their experience together in the White House, Mr. Bowles and Mr. Emanuel positively gush. "Did you tell him I said he had a soft side?" Mr. Bowles asked days after a reporter's breakfast meeting with Mr. Emanuel at the Royalton.
"I love that man," is what Mr. Emanuel said at the breakfast meeting. "Erskine is going to kill me for telling you this. We used to have a 7:30 A.M. meeting and Erskine would sit at one end of the conference table in his office and I would sit at the other. Every now and then, when things got a little tense, I would walk over and give him a little kiss on the forehead." He pointed to a space above his right eyebrow and laughed. "I promised him I'd never do that at the country club in Charlotte."

LENGTH: 830 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil NamesA Soros Ally To Head Bank

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Ravaged by a deepening economic crisis, Brazil replaced its central bank president today for the second time in three weeks and surprised the financial markets with the choice: a disciple of George Soros, the billionaire speculator.
The appointment of Arminio Fraga Neto, who had managed one of Mr. Soros's biggest investment funds, coincided with urgent consultations between Brazilian finance officials and the International Monetary Fund on ways to combat the crisis dragging down Latin America's biggest economy. 
 Government leaders are hoping that the talks with an I.M.F. delegation led by Stanley Fischer, the fund's deputy managing director, will accelerate delivery of a second $9 billion installment of a $41.5 billion loan pledged to Brazil.
But the timing of the central bank shuffle also seemed to reflect the Government's desperation for solutions and left it open to opposition assertions that the I.M.F. had played a role.
Mr. Soros's investment decisions have moved markets and, some contend, played a role in the currency volatility that first dragged down the economies of Southeast Asia 19 months ago.
But the choice of Mr. Fraga to replace Francisco Lopes, who had been confirmed as central bank president only a week ago, drew praise from investors and economists. These people said he would provide practical experience and knowledge of how international investors operated.
The Brazilian currency, the real, rose for the second day, partly reversing a plunge that began on Jan. 13, when the Government allowed the currency, then valued at 1.21 to the dollar, to trade freely in the foreign-exchange markets. The real settled today at 1.80 to the dollar, down from 1.91 late Monday. The benchmark stock index fell 1.8 percent.
In the last month, Brazil has been hit full force by the economic turbulence that earlier shattered economies in Asia and Russia. The crisis exploded here after Itamar Franco, a former president and now governor of Minas Gerais state, declared a moratorium on his big state's debt to the national Government, fueling fears the country could not meet its debts.
The instability in Brazil is slowing economies through Latin America, a region that buys 20 percent of all United States exports. Brazil is also the home of more than $36 billion in accumulated direct foreign investment, much of it by American companies like Ford, General Motors, Whirlpool, Citigroup and Caterpillar.
The appointment of Mr. Fraga appeared to strengthen Finance Minister Pedro Malan, rumored to have been on his way out. In a television interview today, Mr. Malan said he and Mr. Lopes had offered their resignations to President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, but that only Mr. Lopes's was accepted.
"Fraga is the man of the hour to restore the confidence of investors because he's one of them," said David Fleischer, publisher of a Brasilia-based newsletter.
Paulo Ferraz of Banco Bozano Simonsen said Mr. Fraga's appointment was "a confirmation of the Government's willingness to go by the book."
With confidence in the Government at a low, however, many warned that credibility for the new central bank president would not come automatically. Paulo Rabello de Castro, a political consultant here, said Mr. Fraga must announce his stand on exchange- and interest-rate policies, as well as debt management "to build up this credibility."
An I.M.F. negotiating team has been discussing a range of issues with Brazilian officials, including the financial standing of Brazilian states, new rules for Government intervention in currency markets and new targets for inflation and interest rates. The fund has supported high rates, now at 39 percent, to control inflation and draw capital to Brazil, despite a recession that many economists expect will be severe.
Opposition leaders criticized the nomination. "Brazil has just delivered the central bank to one of the biggest speculators in the world," said Jose Dirceu, leader of the Workers Party, a leftist group.
Governor Franco, who has become Mr. Cardoso's adversary, was equally caustic. "Brazil has a new finance minister -- Fischer -- and a new central bank president -- Soros," he told a local news agency. "Now it will be much easier to renegotiate our foreign debt. The only thing left to do is perfect our English."
But a spokesman for Mr. Soros denied rumors that the financier had a role in the appointment. "It was as much of a surprise to Mr. Soros and Soros Fund Management as it was to the market," said Shawn Pattison, the spokesman.
A graduate of Princeton University, Mr. Fraga, 41, has been a manager of the Quantum Emerging Growth Fund since 1993, considered a top performer in its class. Before that, as chief of international operations for the Brazilian central bank, he negotiated with foreign banks to restructure Brazil's debt.
"He worked very effectively to bring Brazil back into contact with the international markets," Mr. Fleischer said.
