HEADLINE: Car Makers Get Strong Start To 1999 Sales

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 2

 BODY:
Ford, DaimlerChrysler, Toyota and other auto makers sold new family vehicles at a blistering pace in January, a sign that the American economy's torrid growth in the fourth quarter is carrying over into the new year.
With gasoline prices continuing to fall, sales of gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans soared in January, rising 19 percent at DaimlerChrysler A.G. from a year earlier, 20 percent at the Ford Motor Company and 32 percent at the Toyota Motor Corporation. But car sales were also brisk after months of weakness, with DaimlerChrysler and Toyota reporting large increases while Ford's car sales dropped only because of a reduction in unprofitable car sales to rental agencies. 
 Auto executives were pleased with the year's strong start. "The sales momentum that closed out 1998 carried over into January," said Robert L. Rewey, Ford's group vice president for marketing, sales and service, who attributed the robust sales to "innovative products and features, low interest rates and fuel prices, and growth in jobs and wages."
Ford could face some temporary difficulties in making enough cars and trucks to keep up with demand, following one of the worst industrial accidents in the auto industry's history. A fatal fire and explosion on Monday shut down production at the company's largest factory complex, which supplies parts to most of Ford's assembly plants in North America.
Nicholas Lobaccaro, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said that the continued rise in sport utility vehicle sales would help the industry's profits, while Ford's ability to reduce sales to rental car agencies was also good news. "You had a huge improvement in mix" of vehicles sold, Mr. Lobaccaro said.
George Pipas, a market analyst at Ford, said that car sales to rental agencies fell more than 30 percent last month while retail car sales rose 1 percent. That produced an overall drop in car sales of 9 percent last month; January is traditionally a big month for rental car sales, as the rental agencies start preparing for the summer season while family buyers stay home. Rental agency sales are seldom profitable because the agencies mainly buy vehicles that are in excess supply and available at deep discounts.
DaimlerChrysler's 18 percent jump in sales of Dodge, Plymouth and Chrysler cars reflected brisk sales of its new large cars, notably the Dodge Intrepid and Chrysler 300M, which were not yet widely available last year. But sales fell for smaller cars like the Dodge Neon, Dodge Stratus and Chrysler Cirrus.
Daimler-Benz A.G. and the Chrysler Corporation merged last November but continue to report their sales separately in the United States. Mercedes-Benz announced today that its car sales rose 6 percent while its sport utility vehicle sales were flat because its factory in Tuscaloosa, Ala., has been operating at full capacity for more than a year.
Volkswagen A.G. reported a 45 percent increase in sales last month from a year earlier, the best January performance for the company since 1986. The New Beetle, a nostalgic tribute to the 1960's, remains popular while customers have also been snapping up Passat sedans.
The General Motors Corporation is not scheduled to report its January sales until Wednesday. But auto analysts predicted that when the final figures are tallied, the industry's sales will be running at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of close to 16 million new vehicles. Sales rates over 15 million vehicles are considered strong and usually profitable.
Ford's overall sales of cars and light trucks were up 8 percent. Toyota's car sales climbed 25 percent and overall sales rose 27 percent. Even struggling Nissan managed an overall sales gain of 4 percent.
John Casesa, an auto analyst at Schroder & Company, said that the vigorous sales reflected consumers' affluence and optimism about the future. "They feel rich and they have the confidence to spend money," he said. "It's remarkable at this stage in the economic cycle."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Technology Stocks Decline As Investors Take Profits
Technology stocks, whose valuations have been pushed into the stratosphere in recent weeks, led equity markets lower as investors and traders decided to take some profits. The selloff was most pronounced among the shares of such marquee names as Microsoft, Intel and Cisco Systems.
 The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index suffered the biggest setback, slumping 46.67 points, or 1.86 percent, to 2,463.42. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 71.58 points, to 9,274.12, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 11.01 points, to 1,261.99. In the bond market, Treasury prices fell sharply as the yield on the 30-year issue rose to 5.24 percent from 5.18 percent. Page C12. 

Goodyear Said to Be in Japan Deal
Goodyear Tire and Rubber is expected to announce today that it has signed a deal with Sumitomo Rubber Industries that will effectively give Goodyear control of most of the debt-laden Japanese company's tire operations. C2.
 
Budget Plan Attacks Tax Shelters
Buried in the budget proposal sent to Congress by President Clinton are dozens of provisions, including a sweeping crackdown on the use of tax shelters, that could have a substantial effect on Wall Street, big industries like insurance and even particular companies. C11.
 
PBS Loses Case Against Ex-Monkee
The Public Broadcasting Service must pay nearly $47 million to Michael Nesmith, a member of the 1960's rock group The Monkees, and his defunct company for defrauding him in a home video deal, a jury decided. C4.
 
Two to Leave Long-Term Capital
Myron S. Scholes and William Krasker, two top partners at Long-Term Capital Management, the hedge fund in Greenwich, Conn., will leave the fund, which was rescued by lenders in September after $4 billion of losses. C6.
 
Results Flat for Toy Industry
Even with a strong economy and must-have hits like Rugrats, Teletubbies and Furbys, the toy industry turned in flat results last year and is projecting only modest gains this year. C2.
 
Home Sales Rose 10.4% in 1998
Sales of new homes surged 10.4 percent last year, to 888,000. And the Conference Board said the index of leading economic indicators, which is intended to project the economy's performance six months out, rose three-tenths of a percent in December. C2.
 
Southwest Expands Into New York
Discount carrier Southwest Airlines is starting a airfare war on the East Coast. It will begin flying to MacArthur Airport on Long Island next month with fares as little as half of the lowest comparable rate. In the last five years, as Southwest has expanded into Baltimore; Providence, R.I.; Manchester, N.H., and several cities in Florida, it has caused fares at those airports and nearby ones to decline sharply. It is expected to do the same in the New York area. A1.
 
Pressure on Rates Worries Japan
As Japan struggles to revive its economy, concern is growing that market pressure to lift interest rates could choke off a recovery just as it is beginning. C8.
 
Arena Name Goes for $180 Million
In the richest arena or stadium-naming rights deal ever, Royal Philips Electronics of the Netherlands will pay an estimated $180 million to emblazon its name on the 20,000-seat arena being built by Time Warner to house its Atlanta Hawks basketball team and new Thrashers hockey club. C6.
 
Profit Increases 33% at Cisco
Cisco Systems, the No. 1 computer-networking company, said its fiscal second-quarter profit rose 33 percent as revenue from Internet providers offset slowing corporate sales. C4.
 
Profits at Sprint rose 13.4 percent for the fourth quarter thanks to heavy long-distance calling. C4.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
An Unlikely Fear for Japan: Stiflingly High Interest Rates

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 2

 BODY:
As Japan struggles to revive its economy, concern is growing that market pressure to lift interest rates could choke off a recovery just as it is beginning.
Government officials are saying that Japan's economy could rebound this summer, but it is around that time that some private economists are saying long-term rates could spike and drain the energy from an incipient revival. 
 Government bond yields, which reflect interest-rate trends, remain low by world standards. But they have more than tripled in day-to-day bond trading since October, from slightly more than seven-tenths of 1 percent. In Tokyo on Wednesday, the benchmark 10-year bond yield reached 2.44 percent, the strongest since June 1997.
Japan is stuck in its worst postwar recession and has been trying to emerge from economic stagnation for eight years, so the pessimists have tended to have prominence. But as Japanese officials voice their views on the economy -- starting with their forecast that it will grow by half a percent in 1999 -- it sometimes seems as though they and private analysts are talking about two different countries.
For starters, some economists worry that with the economy's future uncertain, politicians seem to be sinking into a feeling of complacency, now that they have enacted a huge-scale bank bailout and a $200 billion package of lending and spending to stimulate the economy.
"In Japan, crisis is inevitable because without action, there will be crisis and without crisis, there can be no action," said Andrew Smithers, a longtime analyst of Japan who runs his own economic advisory business. "It's amazing how big a crisis it has to be in Japan."
Even with the bailout and the stimulus packages in place, Japan faces an array of formidable challenges, from a recently strengthened currency -- which makes its exports expensive abroad -- to the need to work off the consequences of an investment boom that has left the economy with far more productive capacity than it can easily use.
If the stronger yen does not stifle growth, then a rise in long-term interest rates, making borrowing more expensive, could. Some economists are forecasting a significant rise in long-term rates, to 3 percent or 4 percent by the end of this year.
Though the Government is beginning to spend its way out of its economic troubles, that comes at a cost. Japan's budget deficit for the next fiscal year is likely to reach 10 percent of output. And as tax revenue falls, the nation's accumulated debt is poised to exceed the size of the entire economy.
By comparison, the annual deficit in the United States reached 6.3 percent of the gross domestic product in 1983, the highest since shortly after the end of World War II. Apart from the war, accumulated Government debt reached a peak in the mid-90's at roughly 70 percent of output.
One problem in Japan is that to finance the huge debt burden, along with the stimulus packages, the Government will have to embark on a large program to raise revenue, about 60 trillion yen, or $535 billion at current exchange rates, in the fiscal year beginning on April 1.
The Government has also acknowledged that it will no longer use the shadow budget, a rich coffer of public funds, to absorb some of the bonds it is offering, meaning that investors will have to buy the bonds on the market. Japanese savers are known for their extraordinarily deep pockets. Still, with other government entities and localities forced to issue debt as well, competition for bond investors could push up long-term interest rates.
The Government must also prepare for the repayment of more than 100 trillion yen -- now almost $900 billion -- in 10-year postal savings deposits that come due in 2000 and 2001.
"To me, this is an onrushing truck," said William D. Campbell, fixed-income strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities Asia, adding that Japanese officials "are terrified they'll be unable to meet the capital outflow from the maturing postal savings."
The amount is far larger than repayment demands in other years. Officials here expect most depositors to roll over much of their money, but even if one-fifth of the funds are withdrawn, the Government will have to turn over nearly $180 billion to pay back depositors.
Mr. Campbell and other analysts say that the trust fund bureau, which manages Tokyo's accounts, would probably have to sell a portion of its holdings in Government bonds. And these actions, they say, could throw the bond market into distress, similar to the rout that occurred late last year when the Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, said that the shadow coffers would no longer absorb Government bonds.
The risk to the economy is that if rates rise significantly, this may choke off economic growth.
But Xinyi Lu, fixed-income strategist at Paribas Capital Markets here, suggested that adverse economic consequences could be avoided if higher rates turned out to be only a temporary spike. If rates rose much higher than 3 percent, he said, investors would probably push them back down by pouring money into higher-yielding instruments.
"The yield would rise and then it would come down," he said. "There will be a shock, but it's not like they will keep rising. They will come down."
Government officials also play down the risks of a big oversupply of bonds. They argue that most Japanese investors do not like risk and will probably roll over their postal savings deposits.
Investors who parked money overseas, they say, were hurt as the yen strengthened, cutting into their returns. To avoid foreign-exchange risks, they should keep more money at home, in safe Government bonds.
Finally, they say, interest rates at 3 to 4 percent may not be so worrisome -- especially if the economy is growing.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1577 words

HEADLINE: Nassau G.O.P. Sees Failed Deal On Insurance Become a Peril

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Feb. 2

 BODY:
From the outset the deal seemed like one of those win-win-win situations that politicians love. Nassau County would save millions in health care costs; a company whose officials were friendly with and supported Republican politicians would get the nearly half-billion-dollar contract, and some well-connected businessmen would profit, too.
Now that dream deal has morphed into a financial nightmare. The county comptroller has found that cost overruns in the health plan exceed $34 million and may reach $50 million by the time all claims are counted. 
 Although those figures are only a fraction of the county's $2 billion annual budget, the financial troubles of the health care plan seem likely to create further headaches in the months to come, possibly jeopardizing its bond rating and complicating negotiations with the New York Islanders over a new hockey arena.
But in the minds of some politicians, there may be a longer lasting consequence. Patronage and insider deals have long been a fixture of Nassau County politics, where Republicans outnumber Democrats 2 to 1. But few of the earlier scandals approach the magnitude of the health plan deal, leading even some Republicans to worry that this time voters may become fed up with the scratch-my-back approach in government.
"It's a disaster," said a ranking Long Island Republican who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Between what's happening in Washington, and the Suffolk County chairman under indictment and now the insurance scandal in Nassau, Long Island Republicans are heading for a meltdown in the 1999 local elections.
"Politicians are viewed as a step below used-car salesman as it stands," he continued. "And now the Republicans have left the door wide open for the Democrats."
Even though a booming stock market and a strong economy have created huge surpluses for governments elsewhere, Nassau County, one of the richest in the United States, with a tax base of more than $95 billion, is running a deficit. Two bond rating agencies are threatening to lower the county's bonds because of years of short-term borrowing and the use of "one shot" revenues like county land sales to balance the county's ledger.
The situation is so bad, said Legislator Lisanne G. Altmann, a Democrat from Great Neck, that the Nassau Legislature is considering asking the State Comptroller to administer the budget or perhaps take the extraordinary step of handing the county's fiscal reins to a control board, like the one that ran New York City's finances for several years in the 1970's.
"No one is taking glee in this whole thing, but it is a chance for the Democrats" to take control away from the Republicans, Ms. Altmann said. "The county is broke. Money has evaporated into someone's pockets."
According to testimony given to the Legislature, documents and officials close to the negotiations, here is how the health care deal happened.
The county decided it could save money if it dropped the health care provider for its 26,000 employees and retirees, which it had been paying $120 million a year in a lump sum, and instead insured the workers out of its own pocket. A Suffolk County company, Benefit Plan Administrators Inc., won the contract in September 1997 to manage the system based on its guarantee that it would save the county $15 million over a 39-month period ending Dec. 31, 2000.
The main architect of the switch was the deputy county executive, Robert J. McDonald, a Republican who headed the commission that recommended the changeover in 1997. Mr. McDonald, who retired from the county government shortly after the deal was signed, has acknowledged in testimony to the Legislature's Rules Committee that he had received $12,500 a month in consulting fees from William M. Blake, Suffolk County's former Republican Party chairman, whose insurance agency underwrote the deal.
Moreover, Albert E. Isernio, then the chairman of Benefit Plan Administrators, has testified that his company paid Mr. Blake a commission of $50,000 a month. Mr. Blake's commission was eventually rolled into a $100,000-a-month consulting fee to DJB Associates, a company run by Mr. Blake's son, David.
County officials could not say this week how much money the men had been paid since the deal was arranged or whether they were still receiving their consulting fees. But the officials said they would ask those questions and many others of Mr. Blake when he testifies on Wednesday in front of a special session of the Legislature.
Another party to the deal was Louis V. Tempera, a former Suffolk County labor commissioner who was convicted of perjury in 1982 for lying to a grand jury when he denied receiving more than $100,000 in kickbacks from companies that had contracts with his department. Mr. Tempera received $30,000 in fees from Benefit Plan Administrators, according to the company's documents.
During his testimony to the Rules Committee, Mr. McDonald said he did not view his dealings as a conflict of interest. Several telephone calls to the homes of Mr. McDonald, Mr. Blake and Mr. Tempera seeking comment have not been answered.
Joseph N. Mondello, the chairman of the Nassau County Republican Party, said the party was beginning to feel the fallout from the consulting payments and the subsequent cost overruns. "The whole thing is harmful to the Republican Party," he said. "This thing has not gone far enough to start criticizing the leadership yet. The problem here is to solve the problem."
Right now, the biggest potential consequence seems to be the effect the health care deal will have on the county's ability to borrow. If bond agencies lower the county's rating, the cost of borrowing money increases, raising the cost of building new roads and schools.
The fiscal disarray could also hurt the county's efforts to negotiate a deal to keep the Islanders hockey team. In recent weeks the on-again, off-again talks about building a new arena for the team have been delayed as team officials wait to see if Nassau will be able to borrow its share of the costs.
"The county promised $100 million toward a new stadium," said a New York Islanders team executive, speaking on condition of anonymity. If the county's credit rating suffers, he said, "I don't know what they are going to do."
Thomas S. Gulotta, the Nassau County Executive and the county's chief budget architect, said little about the health plan problems when they first arose. But he held a news conference on Jan. 25 to announce a lawsuit against Benefit Plan Administrators, charging that the company received kickbacks and misled the county about the true cost of the plan.
"I am the County Executive and ultimately I am responsible for what happens in this county," he said.
He also announced he was returning $20,600 in campaign contributions from Benefit Plan Administrators, Mr. Isernio, Mr. Blake and three agencies related to Mr. Blake.
The County Comptroller, Frederick E. Parola, also said that he had returned a total $6,675 in contributions from the William Blake Agency and Benefit Plan Administrators. "I am not involved directly with fund-raising," Mr. Parola said. "When we found out that there was something possibly inappropriate, we returned the money."
Mayor Thomas R. Suozzi of Glen Cove, a Democrat who is a lawyer and certified public accountant, ridiculed the health plan contract last week as "sickening" and "business as usual in Nassau County."
"These guys are giving contracts to their buddies and cutting deals when no one's looking," Mr. Suozzi said. "The worst part of it is that it's just a stupid contract and the taxpayers have to foot a bill for $50 million."
But officials point out that the contract is hardly the first questionable deal undertaken in Nassau County. For instance, one former Republican Party chairman, Joseph M. Margiotta, was convicted in 1981 of mail fraud and extortion for instructing an insurance broker who had received county contracts to split the commissions with Republicans.
During his 1985 trial, many government workers in Nassau County testified that they were forced to kick back 1 percent of their salaries to the Republican Party to keep their jobs or get promotions.
Even for a place with a long tradition of political scandals that includes sewer contract corruption, police misconduct and allegations of bribery, the last 12 months have been tumultuous.
Less than two weeks ago, John Powell, the Republican leader for Suffolk County and the Town of Brookhaven, resigned to prepare his defense against Federal criminal bribery and truck theft charges. That same day, the Nassau County Democratic leader, Stephen J. Sabbeth, went on trial in Federal District Court, accused of laundering money and using a secret brokerage account to hide $750,000 from creditors when his family lumber business went bankrupt 10 years ago.
Township and legislative elections are just months away, and although some Long Island Republicans said the situation has not yet hit critical mass, they worry that the wheels are starting to fall off their political organization.
"D'Amato's not around anymore," one Republican legislator said of the former United States Senator who began his political career on Long Island. "It's no secret that he was the guy who kept people talking, kept the glue together, and got the problems solved without it blowing up in public. We're lacking his leadership. There's a power vacuum."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
DISCOUNTED FARES ARRIVING IN EAST

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Since discount airlines like People Express collapsed more than a decade ago, air fares on the East Coast have remained stubbornly high even as prices have fallen elsewhere in the country.
But new fare-cutting competition has begun to arrive in the East, led by Southwest Airlines, the country's biggest and most successful discount airline. Next month, Southwest will take on the toughest market in the region but the most lucrative in the nation when it comes to travel dollars: New York. Beginning with flights to four cities from MacArthur Airport on Long Island, Southwest will offer fares that are as little as half of the lowest comparable fares. 
 While some question whether Southwest can draw passengers to an airport 40 miles outside Manhattan, the airline's track record so far on the East Coast suggests that New York air travelers -- no matter which airport they use -- can expect some fares to fall sharply.
In the last five years, Southwest has expanded to Baltimore; Providence, R.I.; Manchester, N.H., and several cities in Florida. At each airport, air fares fell sharply -- even on routes not served by Southwest. Fares also fell at nearby airports.
U S Airways, the largest airline in the region, and Delta Air Lines have responded to the challenge by expanding their new discount subsidiaries, which match Southwest's fares. The airlines have also sought to ward off Southwest by offering cheaper fares in several markets the discounter has yet to enter. Even the nation's biggest airline, United, is considering expanding its own low-cost subsidiary to the East Coast.
"If you look at past history, when Southwest goes into secondary airports near a major metropolitan area the fares in the primary airports almost always go down," said Rono Dutta, the senior vice president for planning at United.
The airlines are eager to battle in the East because the region accounts for about 40 percent of the $52 billion spent on airline tickets annually in the continental United States.
"The East Coast is a very dense, very deep market," said Gary C. Kelly, Southwest's chief financial officer. "There is just a huge pool of customers to access."
And Eastern markets are among the few that are still not dominated by a single major carrier. Over the last five years, the big airlines have solidified their holds on so-called fortress hubs in cities like Denver and Detroit, where they face little or no major competition.
"There is not much left to fight for," Mr. Dutta of United said.
Even after recent across-the-board fare increases by the major airlines, the increased competition along the East Coast is expected to push down prices. That, in turn, will make the region more attractive to businesses and aid economic growth.
In Washington, where Southwest began its Eastern push at Baltimore-Washington International Airport in 1993, the average fares on all airlines were nearly 35 percent less at the end of June then they were before Southwest started flying there, according to BACK Associates, an aviation research firm in New Haven.
The average fare paid on U S Airways for a one-way flight between Providence and Baltimore was $184 before Southwest arrived. By June, that had fallen to $55.70 as U S Airways matched Southwest's prices.
New York in particular is ripe for low-fare competition. Except during the brief life of People Express, air fares on short routes have always been higher than the national average at the city's three airports since the airline industry was deregulated in 1978. But in recent years, as Southwest and other low-fare carriers have expanded in many parts of the country, the gap has widened.
Between 1980 and 1997, ticket prices in cities with low-fare airlines fell, when adjusted for inflation, by 41 percent for flights less than 750 miles, according to Roberts, Roach & Associates, another aviation consultant. But in New York they have risen slightly.
Even before its arrival in New York, Southwest has been a direct threat to both Delta, which has a strong presence in Florida, and U S Airways, which is the largest airline in the East. Both responded by persuading their pilots to accept wage concessions so the airlines could introduce low-cost subsidiaries to match Southwest's low fares and still make a profit.
The U S Airways subsidiary, Metrojet, started flying in June and has already carried more than one million passengers. By May, it will serve 22 cities from Florida to Boston, with 202 daily flights.
"Make no mistake, for the airline to exist over the next 20 years, we would become a shadow of what we are today if we didn't do something like Metrojet," Rakesh Gangwal, U S Airways' chief executive, has said.
Delta's answer to Southwest, Delta Express, grew 50 percent last year. It now serves 22 cities, flying mostly between the Northeast and Florida.
All this competition has prompted some surprising moves. Though Metrojet is taking Southwest head on in Baltimore, U S Airways more recently decided to expand its flights from Dulles International, outside Washington, to include hourly service to LaGuardia, in a move many analysts saw as a way to sidestep Southwest.
The expansion threatened United, which uses Dulles as its only East Coast hub. Rather than cede control of Dulles to U S Airways, United now plans to add 40 daily departures from Dulles to 13 cities, including 7 on the East Coast.
United is also considering bringing in its low-fare service, Shuttle by United, which it created in 1994 to compete with Southwest in California and neighboring states.
And American Airlines is beginning jet service between MacArthur and O'Hare International Airport in Chicago.
But Southwest alone cannot be credited with increasing competition in the region. Flush with cash after four years of robust profits, airlines have been buying new planes and seeking new routes to fly them.
American plans to spend $1 billion building a terminal at John F. Kennedy International Airport. Continental Airlines is close to announcing a $1 billion expansion at Newark International Airport, where it is growing its international service.
Even entrepreneurs are showing more interest in the industry after a dearth of new airlines following the 1996 Valujet crash in Florida. For example, plans for a new, as yet unnamed, discount airline based at Kennedy are moving forward.
At MacArthur, Southwest will begin with 12 flights a day to four cities -- Baltimore, Chicago, Nashville and Tampa, Fla. While those are modest numbers, Southwest's strategy has been to start small and grow methodically.
MacArthur, now largely home to commuter airlines, is in Islip, on the South Shore of Long Island. It is a long drive from Manhattan even when there is no traffic.
But Southwest says that it does not need to draw passengers from the three big New York airports to succeed at Islip. In the beginning, at least, it will focus on wooing Long Island's more than 2.6 million residents. It has begun running ads in newspapers and has billboards at Long Island Rail Road stations.
New Yorkers will have to become accustomed to Southwest's unusual style. The airline flies only narrow-body Boeing 737's and there are no assigned seats. Passengers are given a number at the gate and then are boarded in groups of 30.
In the air, Southwest is famous for its lack of amenities -- "This is what our meals look like," one of its ads declares, showing a bag of peanuts -- as well as its wisecracking pilots and flight attendants. But the airline has one of the best safety records and is highly regarded by business travelers for its strong on-time record.
Southwest, which is based in Dallas, likes secondary airports such as MacArthur, because using them avoids the high fees and delays that are endemic to major gateways like Kennedy, LaGuardia and Newark. Many believe that Southwest ultimately plans to add service from an airport north of New York City, perhaps Stewart International, near Newburgh, N.Y., much as it has bracketed Boston by flying from Rhode Island to the south and Manchester, N.H., to the north. The airline says it has no such plans but does not rule the idea out.
Drawing from large metropolitan areas, Southwest has been able to expand the air-travel market by attracting people who would never have thought of flying.
Consider what happened in the two years since Southwest began flying from T. F. Green Airport in Rhode Island, just south of Providence. Drawn by fares as low as $39 for a one-way ticket to Baltimore, travelers soon began driving to Rhode Island from Massachusetts and Connecticut -- even from as far away as New York and Vermont -- to fly Southwest. Rival airlines increased service and lowered their fares. In the last two years, the annual passenger traffic at the airport has nearly doubled, to 4.6 million people. And the same thing has happened in other cities Southwest serves.
"There are people who fly down to Baltimore and see a Red Sox game for cheaper than if they drove down to Boston," said Alfred Testa Jr., the director of Manchester Airport, which Southwest began serving last year. "It is no longer strange to see people downstairs in the terminal going to Florida for three days."
That kind of attitude is also found among business travelers.
"The joke we have at the office is that we have the Southwest route map, and that is our marketing plan," said Kelly Stewart, the director of sales at Healthstream, a small company based in Nashville that sells computer services to the health care industry.
While low-fare competition has been short-lived in the past as low-cost rivals were driven out of business, this time, some analysts say, there is enough room in the East for all the low-cost competitors.
"Fare wars happen when high-fare carriers try to cut each other's throats," said Kevin C. Murphy, an airline analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York. "What you have here is low-cost service that is good for everybody because it changes consumer behavior."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
FIRSTPLUS SELLS FINANCE UNIT TO THAXTON FOR $51 MILLION

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Firstplus Financial Group Inc., a financial services company struggling with liquidity problems, said yesterday that it had sold its Firstplus Consumer Finance Inc. unit to the Thaxton Investment Corporation for $51 million. The Dallas-based Firstplus is a subprime lender, making loans to consumers of up to 125 percent of their homes' value at high interest rates. The company was badly hurt by the late-summer global credit squeeze that dried up the market for loans it packaged and sold as securities. Thaxton, based in Lancaster, S.C., is an insurer and mortgage lender that had $1.5 million in profits in 1997. Firstplus said it planned to use the proceeds to repay liens encumbering the assets of Firstplus Consumer and to meet other obligations.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (71%);

HEADLINE: Responding to Middle Class, Some Colleges Trim Tuition

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Marlboro College, a small liberal arts campus in Vermont, has just announced an 8 percent cut in tuition and fees and no increase in room and board for freshmen who arrive next fall. The students will pay $26,410 instead of $27,810.
Muskingum College, in New Concord, Ohio, got fed up with doling out more financial aid every time the college raised tuition, and so it slashed tuition by $4,000, a 29 percent drop to $9,850, from $13,850. 
 And although Dartmouth College did not exactly eviscerate tuition, it held the line at an increase of only 3.9 percent for the current academic year, its smallest increase in 32 years.
No, this is not necessarily a trend. The great majority of colleges and universities have been raising their costs even faster than inflation for at least two decades. But a handful of schools say they feel the pain of middle-class and working-class parents and have responded. And some academic officials say it could be a stirring of significance.
Among the leaders of the movement are the state university systems in Massachusetts and California. Virginia is very likely to join them. For three consecutive years, the five-campus University of Massachusetts has scaled back tuition and fees for in-state students, from $4,969 in fiscal 1996 to $4,727 in fiscal 1999.
Since 1997 the nine-campus University of California system has reduced tuition and fees for in-state students to $3,609 from $3,700. Costs at the less expensive California State University were cut 5 percent.
And last December, Gov. Jim Gilmore of Virginia proposed an across-the-board cut of 20 percent in tuition and fees for all in-state students at public colleges and universities. Since the state's economy is booming, the chances of passage by the Virginia General Assembly this session are considered excellent.
"It's too early to say whether it's a trend," said Terry Hartle, a spokesman for the American Council on Education, the Washington lobbying organization. "But any time you get Massachusetts and California involved, you've got some very visible states."
These colleges and universities are reacting as they see some financially hard-pressed parents and their children increasingly shying away from relatively expensive private colleges and instead choosing less expensive public institutions or, in some cases, giving up on higher education altogether.
How do these campuses do it? Aren't they just as financially stressed as the others that keep raising their prices?
Paul LeBlanc, president of Marlboro College, said that two and a half years ago when he was given his job, the trustees instructed him to be "aggressively entrepreneurial," which meant finding things the college could do to generate new sources of revenue in order to hold down or even reduce what students were being charged.
"One of the business ventures we spun off, called the Design Center, which utilized both faculty and students," Mr. LeBlanc said, "won the contract to design the State of Vermont's new Web site for tourism, and that and other similar projects have generated more than $100,000.
"Educational institutions have to learn to do things outside their usual boundaries," Mr. LeBlanc continued. "That's what will enable them to reduce costs."
James Wright, the president of Dartmouth, said he had been able to resist runaway tuition with a series of efforts to "reallocate existing resources."
One of the most successful of these efforts, he said, has been to allow alumni donors to lend their names to scholarships of as little as $1,500.
"We're also using more of our unrestricted endowment for financial aid," he said. "That was one of my first priorities when I became president last August."
Not all of these well-intended efforts are successful. Last fall, Tuition Credit Exchange, a national organization that attempted to resist the relentless rise of college costs by "selling" tuition credits to the parents or friends of even very young college-bound children, closed its doors for lack of support.
Bill Higdon, a former president of Graceland College, in Lamoni, Iowa, who served as an executive of the credit exchange, said: "We stirred up a lot of interest, but ran up against the natural conservatism of people when faced with a totally new concept. But the idea of beginning the family effort to marshal resources for college costs over a period of years instead of in just four years is a good one and has a future."
In the 1970's there was little growth, if any, in college prices beyond the rate of inflation. Since 1980, however, college prices have been soaring at twice and sometimes three times the Consumer Price Index. Over the 10-year period ending in 1998-99, after adjusting for inflation, the average public tuition and fees went up 53 percent at public colleges and 35 percent at private four-year colleges.
Since the 1980-81 school year, both public and private four-year institutions increased at more than twice the rate of inflation, on average.
Private college tuition rose most sharply in the early and mid-1980's, while public tuition increased the most in the late 1980's and early 1990's.
And despite the efforts of places like Marlboro and Muskingum, the pressure to raise costs is still intense, said Jack Joyce, a spokesman for the College Board responsible for the organization's annual survey Trends in College Pricing.
Colleges are hard pressed to keep costs down, he said, because they are faced not only with constant needs, like raising faculty salaries and maintaining aging buildings, laboratories and libraries, but also in recent years have been pressed to meet "student demands and expectations for a wired campus that includes the new technology required for modern communication."

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Education page on Feb. 3 about colleges that are reducing tuition or holding it steady referred incorrectly to the Tuition Credit Exchange, a private organization that allows parents of young children to lock in current rates by prepaying. The exchange is still in business; it has not closed.

HEADLINE: THE ARTS IN: Fairbanks Alaska;
It Takes Creativity to Thaw the Soul

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

DATELINE: FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Feb. 1

 BODY:
The ice was too cold. When the temperature sank under 30 degrees below zero here last week and bottomed out at 47 below zero through the weekend, an icy fog swaddled this city in a glowing soup. And the local sculptors who have dotted the city with angels and polar bears and other crystalline icons had to put away their sanders and their chisels and the water -- "Arctic superglue" in local parlance -- they use to fuse ice limbs to ice torsos and to make repairs.
It was cold even for Fairbanks, where residents routinely use the frozen Chena River for a road; cold enough for a cup of coffee tossed in the air to freeze before the droplets hit the snow; cold enough for automobile tires to square against the ground, and cold enough for heating oil to begin thickening. At such temperatures, blocks of ice simply become too brittle and prone to shatter for the delicate shaving and whittling that a sculptor's work requires. 
 Still, Kathleen Carlo-Kendall gave it a shot. With Anita Tabor, a wood sculptor who moved here from Arkansas 13 years ago, Ms. Carlo-Kendall, an Athabascan Indian and mask maker, spent an hour or so on Saturday in front of the Westmark Hotel downtown, working on two large native-style masks, one traditional, one contemporary. They did not make much progress, but it was a good workout; the two women are half of the first all-female team to enter the International Ice Art Championships ("Frigid Women," they jokingly call themselves) held here each March.
And it was a good excuse to battle the cabin fever that many people say is a winter burden, brought on more by lingering darkness than by the cold. There are but seven hours of dim sunlight a day right now, up from little more than three hours at the winter solstice six weeks ago.
"It's nice to get out of the house," Ms. Carlo-Kendall said. "I haven't been out in three days."
The arts have a tough row to hoe in this part of the world, a place where man's creations pale beside Mother Nature's, and particularly at this time of year when the world is dark, and for many, the spirit is, too. Yet there may be no other place in the country where the arts serve such a practical function as they do in this surprisingly diverse (ethnically and artistically), brutally winterbound and isolated environment.
Even if this not a pretty town -- the blocky, economical architecture is often lamented, with good reason, by the locals -- Fairbanks manifests a persistent and enduring interest in the arts. They not only bring people out into the cold and cheer the bleak landscape, but they are cited by many here, not outlandishly, as a reason to live.
"Suicide during this time of year runs a little high, and the arts have been a comforter," said James C. Hayes, the Mayor. "Without them, I don't know what we'd be."
The state, with its notorious small-government bias, has cut back on arts subsidies in recent years; its support to the Fairbanks Arts Association diminished to just $11,000 this year from more than $65,000 in the early 90's. But the political isn't personal, says June Rogers, the executive director of the association, who notes that many of the budget-slashing legislators contribute generously to the arts from their own pockets. The city supports the arts with a hotel bed tax; its contribution to the association this year was $77,000, 90 percent of which was channeled to local nonprofit groups.
Fairbanks maintains two dance companies, two art galleries, two community theaters (one performs original work, the other Shakespeare), a chorale and a light opera company that often sells out a 1,400-seat hall. The city also has an ambitious amateur symphony whose co-principal violinist also plays the tuba. On Saturday night the symphony's Arctic Chamber Orchestra lured about 300 people out in 30-degrees-below-zero weather for a program that included Bartok's difficult "Divertimento for Strings" and the world premiere of "Sculptured Memories," a dissonant tone poem by Gregory Mertl, 29, of Rochester, his first commissioned work.
Fairbanks has a fair amount of public art, supported by a state levy on builders of 1 percent of the cost of all new buildings. And the city is rife with painters, musicians, writers and photographers, as well as decorative weavers like Marnie Cornwall, who specializes in the delicate wool of the qiviut, or Alaskan musk ox; artists using natural materials (aside from ice) like Penny Wakefield, who works in dried and painted fish skins, and Athabascan skin sewers and beadworkers like Dixie Alexander, whose variations on tribal clothing are in the collections of the Smithsonian Institution and other museums in "the lower 48."
There is a gem of a museum here, on the main campus of the University of Alaska, tiny and crammed with the natural history of the state, along with native artifacts and art objects ranging from 1,500-year-old Eskimo carvings of wood and ivory to contemporary paintings. The university is a focus for the regeneration of native arts, whose connection to tribal life had long been attenuated by the encroachment of modern times.
 
The Old Arts Lost to Television
Ms. Alexander (who also runs an annual fiddling festival where Athabascan elders gather to play the twangy, countrified music brought here by Scottish and French-Canadian traders in the 19th century) spends part of the year in villages around the state, reintroducing the traditional art forms.
"A lot of people still have their elders sewing for them," she said. "What happened to the younger generation? The Alaska Cable Network. Computers. Snowmobiles." She added, "We get a lot of our funding from suicide prevention groups."
On campus there are signs of renewal. Alvin Amanson, who directs the native arts program at the university, is an Aleut painter from Kodiak known for modern expressionist portraits of Alaskan wildlife. (De Kooning is his acknowledged influence.) He has been encouraged, he said, by the skill of his young students, who are beginning to meld the rhythms and skills of their villages with contemporary imagery. One young woodcarver, he said, a Yupik from southeastern Alaska, dazzled him with the masks he made for a university dance troupe.
"The first one was of Bart Simpson," he said, laughing uproariously.
Situated in a broad valley cut by the Tanana River, between the towering Alaska Range to the south and the Brooks Range to the north, Fairbanks is home to 31,000 people, with another 50,000 in the surrounding North Star Borough. It is a small place, but it is nonetheless the state's second-largest city (behind Anchorage, 400 miles south), and the only urban center serving Alaska's interior, a region the size of Texas.
It is a place that must be all things to many people. "We've got more variety of arts per capita than most places our size," said Matt Reckard, a retired civil engineer and part-time actor. "But I don't know that that makes us an arts town. We've got more car dealerships than you'd expect, too."
Founded in 1902, Fairbanks has been an important mining center through most of the century. In recent decades, however, its population and urbanity have been augmented by the presence of Air Force and Army bases and the growth of the state university, whose main campus serves 9,000 students. Construction of the Alaska pipeline brought thousands of laborers in the 1970's; many stayed on after the wild times of the period settled down.
In addition, the outdoors attracted individualists from all over the United States, many of whom decided that the glories of summer (not only hiking and rafting and midnight softball but a two-week summer arts festival) were worth enduring the hostile winters.
The outdoors is alluring to artists as well, of course. They include both lifelong Alaskans like Lisa Rogers, a self-taught painter, sculptor and crafts artist whose work includes imagery from her years of a subsistence life style in Lime Village, a remote northern town with a population of 40; and others, like David Mollett, a landscape painter who was born in Oregon but has lived most of his life here.
"For a landscape painter it's nice that nobody's painted it much," said Mr. Mollett, who has lived and exhibited in New York and Paris. He was among the very first painters to venture into the Brooks Range. In his studio, he keeps a canvas that was shredded by a bear on one of his sojourns there.
As a result of all these influences, the population of Fairbanks is idiosyncratic and tends to be self-selecting. By their own assessment, the city's residents tend to be curious people and readers, even though Alaska is, in the words of Greg Hill, the director of the local library, "book poor."
"All the libraries in the state put together don't have the volumes they have at the University of Washington," Mr. Hill said. "But Alaska has 10 percent higher usage rate than the rest of the country, and Fairbanks has a 10 percent higher rate than the rest of Alaska. We have our kooks and cranks, but they tend to be intelligent here."
The population is also increasingly diverse. This is a city whose best restaurant is arguably a Thai luncheonette, and where last week at the Arctic Bar, a local watering hole, Marc Brown, an Athabascan guitarist, introduced the members of his band, the Blues Crew, by saying, "You probably won't see another blues band with an Indian, an Eskimo, a black guy and a white guy."
 
Where Is It Warm? Inside a Church
And although country music is prevalent in most of the roadhouses, there are places that occasionally feature Celtic music, jazz and even rap. Fifteen percent of Fairbanks residents are black, including Mayor Hayes, who is also the pastor at the Lily of the Valley Church of God in Christ, one of several black churches in the city that nurture a tradition of gospel singing. On Sunday morning the church choir, 20 strong, accompanied by an organist and drummer and singing in a distinctively pop style, stirred a full house of congregants to the extent that the ushers were passing out fans, making it the only overheated place in the city.
The arts are warm, but in Fairbanks in winter, maybe a lonely flame. Drive a short way out of town, and the snowfields and snow-sugared black spruce seem to stretch on forever, an endless abstract in black and white.
"I look at all this grayness, and I think about depression and loneliness and all the things grayness can contribute to," said Ms. Rogers of the arts association. "But you know, it is beautiful. I don't find it depressing. And I think that's what art can do for people here, give them another way to look at things."

TURKEY: CRACKDOWN ON ISLAMISTS ORDERED -- Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, left, announced a nationwide crackdown on Islamist activity, saying he was instructing the police and judiciary to take legal action against any threats to the secular order. Past crackdowns in Turkey have led to prosecution of politicians and journalists deemed to have encouraged religious militancy.

RUSSIA: U.S. HELP SOUGHT ON 'YEAR 2000' -- Russia said it needs up to $3 billion to tackle the Year 2000 computer problem -- six times its original estimate -- and appealed to the United States and NATO to help fix computers that control its nuclear weapons. While an errant missile launch brought on by a computer failure is considered highly unlikely, such snags could sabotage radar and telecommunications networks. (AP)

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 664 words

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Sometimes Folding Is the Better Part of Valor

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
Good legislators generally make bad Presidential candidates, and politicians who try to ignore this rule have a way of winding up unemployed. Yesterday the House minority leader, Richard Gephardt, officially came to grips with both realities by dropping out of contention for the Democratic nomination. That leaves Bill Bradley with the responsibility of giving Democrats someone to turn to in desperation when they experience inevitability panic over the ascendancy of Al Gore.
It may be a sad moment for Mr. Gephardt, one of the many 50-something members of Congress whose political clocks are starting to tick alarmingly. But it made a lot of other people happy. Mr. Gore, who has been relentlessly placating the minority leader for more than a year, was of course relieved. The House Democrats, who are just six seats short of a majority, are delighted that Mr. Gephardt is going to lead their campaign effort in 2000. But Mr. Gephardt's friends and family must be happy as well. You don't want to see a loved one wandering around New Hampshire shopping malls and morphing into Lamar Alexander. 
 Lately, Mr. Gephardt has shown every sign of becoming very good at his current job. During the impeachment debate he rounded up all but five of the Democrats for Bill Clinton, a man who enjoys the personal loyalty of approximately half a dozen members of his party. The recent example of Newt Gingrich has taught Congress that a party is better off if its top Congressional leader does not have a whole lot of personality, and on that count Mr. Gephardt certainly fits the bill.
American history is full of stories about legislative leaders who set their sights on the White House and came to grief, from Henry Clay to Bob Dole. The qualities necessary to pass bills -- attention to detail, love of the artful compromise, the inclination to keep promises -- get in the way during a Presidential campaign. The characteristics that are important in a run for President -- star quality, willingness to abdicate control of your life to handlers, an agile attitude toward facts -- are not much use in Congress.
Given that Al Gore is absorbing campaign contributions the way the Titanic took on water, the news that Mr. Gephardt had decided to pass up the chance to challenge him was not exactly earth-shaking. Still, Mr. Gephardt got a few days' mileage out of the announcement, which proceeded from probably-not to aides-say-not to a speech in the Capitol where he conclusively demonstrated that he had made the right career move. It was a stately march of non-candidacy, much like Colin Powell's, except Mr. Gephardt lacked a book to flog.
There is not much of a history of great declarations of non-candidacy, mainly because the population of people who might conceivably be asked to run consists almost entirely of men and women who have been dying to be President since they were elected to student council in junior high. The big decliners have almost all been generals. William Tecumseh Sherman gave his name to the ultimate refusal when he telegraphed the Republican nominators in 1884 that if nominated he would not run, and if elected he would not serve. (The Republicans went instead with Senator James Blaine, a legislative guy, and lived to regret it.) Until we have another hero-producing war, Colin Powell will probably be the last of the general refusers.
It took a very bad campaign to convince Ted Kennedy that he was actually a legislative guy at heart. The most colorful non-candidate was Mario Cuomo, who let the national press corps sit waiting on the floors of New York State's Capitol as planes revved on the runway to fly him to New Hampshire on the last day of filing. Mr. Cuomo finally emerged from the governor's mansion to announce that he couldn't run for the White House because State Senator Ralph Marino of Muttontown had refused to approve a state budget. It was a psychodrama to remember, but one Mr. Gephardt wisely declined to imitate.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Tire Makers Combine as Mergers Rise in Japan

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 3

 BODY:
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's deal for control of most operations of Sumitomo Rubber Industries Ltd. echoes faintly an earlier American-Japanese marriage in tires. In 1988, amid a wave of high-profile Japanese acquisitions in the United States, Bridgestone bought Firestone of Ohio for $2.6 billion.
Today's agreement comes as Japan undergoes a surge of mergers and acquisitions -- including some involving American companies. But a reversal of the 1980's trend is unlikely, and few here expect the Goodyear deal to herald a new flood of foreign takeovers. 
 "I just can't see it," said Clifford J. Shaw, head of Merrill Lynch Mercury Asset Management Japan Ltd. "I don't think this is the beginning of a major trend."
For one, investment bankers said, the Goodyear-Sumitomo deal was spurred by competitive pressures specific to the tire industry.
More important, the fact that a lingering recession is forcing Japanese companies to seek out deals also means that many assets up for sale may not be at the top of international shopping lists. How many auto companies want to buy a plant and increase capacity? How many foreign companies want to pay for expensive headquarters here? Or the real estate under a department store when renting is markedly cheaper?
Recent purchases by foreigners have largely been in financial services -- deals that are also being driven by the deregulation of Japanese markets. "It's reactive M & A rather than pro-active on the part of the Japanese companies," Craig Chudler, a strategist with Salomon Smith Barney in Tokyo, said.
Still, deals between Japanese companies are breaking fast and furiously. The Toshiba Corporation has been paring its exposure to affiliates and subsidiaries, as has its rival, Hitachi Ltd. The Nippon Oil Company, Japan's largest refiner, is buying the Mitsubishi Oil Company in an effort to consolidate, and the Asahi Chemical Industry Company has agreed to sell its processed foods subsidiary to Japan Tobacco Inc.
Over all, the number of mergers and acquisitions involving Japanese companies rose 35 percent last year, to 908 deals, according to the Nikko Securities Company. Foreign buyers were responsible for 121 deals.
More foreign deals may soon be on the way. The Nissan Motor Company has been talking with foreign auto makers about buying a stake.
In the case of Sumitomo, it is a second-tier tire company staring rapid consolidation in the auto industry in the face and contemplating its prospects, one of its bankers said.
With $2.76 billion of debt, more than three times its equity, striking a deal with Goodyear -- with which is already had a substantial relationship -- was a stroke of good fortune. Goodyear is providing nearly $1 billion in cash, which will help clean up Sumitomo's balance sheet.
Indeed, today's deal is merely part of a global consolidation sweeping the auto business. Japan can produce four million more cars than it can sell, so it is a natural market for such consolidation. Nissan is seeking the same sort of deal that Sumitomo made with Goodyear, and the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation is shopping bits of itself around.
Furthermore, the deal with Goodyear is not a straightforward merger or acquisition. Japanese companies prefer the safety of a joint venture, capital participation or other types of corporate links that allow them to hold hands without quite getting into bed. The six ventures between Goodyear and Sumitomo let Sumitomo maintain a vestige of control and independence, which its bankers say was critical.
"That's the kind of M & A you're most likely to see here," an investment banker said.

HEADLINE: Fed Decides To Maintain Interest Rates

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Trapped between conflicting pressures at home and abroad, the Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, keeping its hands off an economy that is either gratifyingly robust or too strong for its own good.
The decision, almost universally expected by economists and investors, caused barely a ripple on Wall Street. But it highlighted the dilemma facing the central bank just months after it cut rates three times to insure that financial turmoil in much of the rest of the world would not derail the long American expansion. 
 Rather than slowing, the economy grew at a torrid 5.6 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, putting back on the agenda the possibility that inflation, long dormant, could reappear. One faction within the Federal Reserve is also concerned about rapid growth in the money supply, a cause or signal of inflation.
As a result, analysts said, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and his colleagues on the central bank are almost certainly considering whether they will need to reverse course and raise rates later this year if growth does not slow markedly on its own.
Yet the continued fragility of global financial markets, a rapidly expanding trade deficit, concern about causing a big selloff on Wall Street and the almost total absence of any hard evidence of inflation have combined to create a strong case for leaving rates alone or even cutting them further.
"The Fed cannot lower interest rates because of eye-popping economic strength," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist at Wells Fargo in Minneapolis.
"They cannot raise rates because of the stock market bubble and what's going on overseas and because politically it's impossible to raise rates given the very low inflation rate right now," he said. "So the best course for them is to stand pat and see how the U.S. and the global economies unfold."
Today's decision left the benchmark Federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks at 4.75 percent and the discount rate on loans from the Federal Reserve system at 4.5 percent.
The central bank's usual terse announcement this afternoon that the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee had adjourned with nothing to report belied the fundamental nature of the debate that has reemerged within the institution in the last few months: Has the economy entered a new era in which heavy investments in technology allow rapid growth to coexist with low inflation? Or is the United States merely enjoying a remarkable but temporary string of good economic luck that will end with inflationary forces reasserting themselves?
The evidence in favor of a fundamental change includes some of the most recent economic statistics. The fourth-quarter growth rate of 5.6 percent brought growth for all of 1998 to 3.9 percent, the third consecutive year in which the economy has expanded at nearly a 4 percent rate.
Traditional economic theory holds that the economy cannot grow more than about 2.5 percent a year over the long run without igniting inflation. But the broadest measures of price changes suggest that inflation last year was 1 percent or less.
Moreover, the absence of meaningful inflation came despite falling unemployment, which has left the jobless rate, currently 4.3 percent, hovering near 30-year lows. And heavy investments in computers and other cost-saving technology has allowed many companies to improve productivity, setting off a debate about whether the United States has reversed a two-decade-long slide in productivity growth.
"Members of the Fed wake up every morning and look out at a booming economy and ask themselves whether it's a result of computers or of interest rates being low," said Brian S. Wesbury, an economist at Griffin, Kubik, Stephens & Thompson, a Chicago investment firm.
Mr. Wesbury comes down on the side of those who think technology has increased the economy's capacity for noninflationary growth. He said that relative to inflation, the short-term interest rates controlled by the Fed are still high and could be cut to further stimulate growth without any danger of overheating.
Mr. Greenspan has been sympathetic to the argument that productivity growth is accelerating, but he has also warned, as recently as last month, that the recent pace of growth is unsustainable.
Economists who think growth is flirting with danger levels said part of the reason is that the Fed cut rates one too many times last fall in reaction to the global financial turmoil. In their view, inflation could accelerate this year, especially because some factors that tamped it down last year -- particularly falling oil and food prices -- are unlikely to be replicated this year. If money supply growth continues at double-digit rates, they said, the danger will be compounded.
Wherever they come down in the debate, though, most economists think the Fed will hold steady for months unless there is some clear change in the economy's course.
"The Fed's policy debate is rich with crosscurrents and is characterized by uncertainties," said Mickey D. Levy, an economist at Bank of America. "They will remain on hold until something breaks."

HEADLINE: Legislators In Brazil Are Leaving Ruling Party

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

 BODY:
BRASILIA, Feb. 3
A raft of newly elected members of Congress switched parties just before taking office here this week, in a move that appears to signal a more fractious second term for President Fernando Henrique Cardoso as he forges ahead with unfinished changes.
Some deputies who belonged to the evangelical Christian movement dropped the powerful conservative party, which had delivered the votes for their elections, and joined a smaller party in which they could hold more sway. They promised a more critical stance toward Mr. Cardoso's proposals. 
 "What's against the people and against the nation, we're going to fight head on," vowed Marcos Jesus. As did many candidates who ran on evangelical platforms, he switched from the small Liberal Party.
Several legislators from Minas Gerais left Mr. Cardoso's party for the party of Itamar Franco, Governor of their state. Mr. Franco is in the middle of a battle of nerves with Mr. Cardoso: Mr. Franco declared a moratorium on his state's debt to the Federal Government, shattering Brazil's already fragile credibility in world markets and unleashing the latest round of economic turbulence.
Mr. Cardoso is waging an all-out campaign to restore the faltering economy, bolstered by a $41.5 billion standby loan from the United States, the Group of 7 industrialized nations, the International Monetary Fund and others.
Having experienced 39 percent annual interest rates, unemployment at a 15-year high and soaring, and a currency that has been devalued more than 30 percent in the last month, Mr. Cardoso's popularity has fallen to an all-time low, with only 27 percent of 2,000 Brazilians questioned in a survey saying they supported him.
The first deputy managing director of the I.M.F., Stanley Fischer, postponed his return to the United States tonight. Mr. Fischer, along with technical and negotiating teams from the fund, have been combing through accounts and reworking the targets and conditions for aid.
Brazil is eager to speed delivery of the second part of $9 billion in aid.
Although Mr. Cardoso's six-party coalition enjoys a comfortable majority of 380 among the 513 deputies in the House, some important parties in the coalition have disparate factions.
The Brazilian Democratic Movement Party of Mr. Franco, for example, is split between those who support him and those who back Mr. Cardoso. Because of defections this week, Mr. Franco's party swelled, from 83 to 95 seats, the total that Mr. Cardoso's party has in the lower chamber. Mr. Franco is widely seen as a highly likely Presidential contender in four years.
Even Mr. Cardoso's party shows signs that the ready Congressional support for most of his proposals would not last into his next term. The leader of his Brazilian Social Democracy Party in the House, Aecio Neves, told a newspaper that the party "had to act with more liberty, without making so many concessions."
Bishop Carlos Rodrigues of Rio de Janeiro, another member of the evangelical bloc, dropped the Government-allied conservative party that helped him win office in October to switch to an opposition party.
Bishop Rodrigues criticized the Government for raising taxes, saying spending had to be cut. But he said laying off public workers and cutting pension benefits were not the answers. "That doesn't solve anything," the bishop said. "It's only a palliative."
To balance its books, he added, the Government ought to simplify taxes to reduce opportunities for evasion and corruption.
In part, Bishop Rodrigues said he switched parties because of an administration plan to push for laws that would require members of Congress to vote along party lines.
"The President wants party loyalty not for political reasons, but to put a muzzle on the deputies, and I won't accept that," Bishop Rodrigues said. "For that, you don't even need to be here. You could just sit in your house and have the party leader vote for you. Why even be a deputy at all?"
The administration sees a loyalty law as a way to cut pork barrel projects and other concessions that each victory in Congress demands.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Clinton's budget plan on social needs will barely make a dent.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT CLINTON'S budget includes dozens of new spending programs. It also includes dozens of new tax credits and other subsidies. Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, mockingly declares "the era of Big Government is back" three years after Mr. Clinton declared it over.
But charges of extravagance are unconvincing. Even if Congress passed Mr. Clinton's entire plan, the relative size of the Federal Government would continue to shrink, budget analysts point out. Robert Greenstein of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research organization, estimates Government spending, while continuing to grow modestly in absolute dollars, will fall by 2004 to about 18.5 percent of total economic output. That level, down from 19.7 percent today, would be the lowest in 34 years. 
 Nonmilitary discretionary spending -- the part of the budget that excludes Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security but includes nearly everything else outside the Pentagon, from the F.B.I. to basic research -- would fall by 2004 to 3.1 percent of economic output, the lowest level in at least four decades. Besides, the fundamental feature of this budget is its fiscal prudence; it uses trillions of dollars of surplus revenue to drive down Federal debt rather than spend it immediately or give it away in across-the-board tax cuts.
Still, simply because overall spending levels would hardly budge does not mean that Mr. Clinton can so easily escape the serious charge that his shotgun approach to spending and tax incentives is missing the target. The proposed budget sprinkles new spending across a huge array of programs, hardly missing a constituency or Congressional district. Rather than concentrating the scarce funds and doing a few things well, the Administration has chosen instead to do dozens of things on a small scale, says C. Eugene Steuerle of the Urban Institute, in a way that amounts to "budget patches."
Mr. Clinton proposes to spend about $17 billion more next year on discretionary programs than current budget rules anticipate. The litter of initiatives is breathtaking: $600 million on community learning centers and after-school programs here, about $600 million to integrate technology into classrooms there, $2 billion for states to protect water quality, $50 million to demolish blighted buildings, and on and on with a host of undoubtedly worthy projects.
Indeed, some of the initiatives, such as reinstating food-stamp and Medicaid benefits to recent immigrants, are widely praised, especially by Democrats. The National Science Foundation gets a sizable boost, as does an effective tax credit for building housing for low-income families. But Rudolph Penner of the Urban Institute takes a look at the panoply of new spending programs and asks, "Where's the theme?"
Gary Bass of O.M.B. Watch, a liberal advocacy group, would have preferred that Mr. Clinton focus the $17 billion of extra spending on a few programs aimed at the needy. Research shows that the most effective way to prepare workers for the future is to educate them when they are young. Mr. Clinton's Administration understands this, and his budget would put $600 million more into Head Start, the effective preschool program, and other education and training initiatives. But the investments fall far short of enrolling every eligible child.
Imagine a budget that used the $17 billion to tackle two or three pressing needs. For example, there are millions of families qualifying for subsidized rental housing, but there are no vouchers for them. The White House proposes to create another 100,000 vouchers, a large increase by historical standards but not nearly enough to meet the need. Robert Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, supports the fiscal prudence of the overall budget, but would prefer piling up more of the available money for training elementary and secondary teachers.
Critics also accuse the Administration of cluttering the tax code with dozens of new credits and subsidies, declaring an end, if not to Big Government, at least to an era of tax simplification that culminated in the estimable Tax Reform Act of 1986. The White House proposes, among pages upon pages, a $1,000 long-term-care tax credit, a $1,000 credit to offset expenses of disabled workers, a credit for small businesses that join coalitions to purchase health insurance and a credit for parents who stay home to care for a newborn.
Most of these tax credits are too small to do much good. Take the credit for caring for the chronically ill. It almost entirely excludes the poor, who do not pay taxes and cannot take advantage of a tax credit. It provides, compared with the annual costs of $60,000 or more, small relief to middle-class families. Is this the most effective use of the limited money Mr. Clinton carves out for new initiatives?
Besides making the tax code bewilderingly complex, the layering of credits creates other problems. Each credit, to avoid unduly running up costs and benefiting the rich, must be phased out as family incomes rise. So each credit that is phased out amounts to a tax on work.
There are reasons the Administration backed into nit-picking tactics. Congress has imposed tight caps on discretionary spending, virtually forcing Mr. Clinton to tackle problems with tax subsidies. Lacking the will to go after waste that riddles discretionary spending and the political muscle to eliminate the caps and start fresh, Mr. Clinton resorted to doling out spoonfuls of money where shovels were needed.

HEADLINE: U.N. Pulling Its American Employees Out of Iraq

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 3

 BODY:
The United Nations ordered its remaining American staff members in Iraq to leave today after Baghdad warned that it could not guarantee their safety.
The order, in practice, affects only two Americans among 420 non-Iraqis working in the country to provide food and medicines. Another 12 to 15 British and American employees working for the program are affected in principle but are already out of the country. 
 Fred Eckhard, the United Nations spokesman, said he could recall no precedent for such a move in the relief program. He said the decision was made by Benon Sevan, the United Nations Under Secretary General who oversees security and coordinates the Iraq "oil for food" program.
The decision came after sustained American air strikes on Iraq and after a monthlong effort by United Nations officials failed to elicit a pledge from Baghdad to honor its obligation to protect all United Nations personnel, irrespective of nationality. Mr. Sevan recommended the move to Kofi Annan, the Secretary General.
Mr. Sevan's decision contrasts with that of Richard Butler, the beleaguered chairman of the United Nations Special Commission charged with disarming Iraq of weapons of mass destruction. When Iraq threatened to bar entry to American members of inspection teams in 1997, Mr. Butler decided to stop inspections rather than permit Iraq to dictate the composition of the teams. Ultimately Iraq relented until the latest confrontation this year when it refused to accept any inspectors.
The restrictions signal a reluctance by Washington and the United Nations to provoke a confrontation with Iraq on this issue while the United Nations is struggling to achieve a consensus on policy.
Asked why Mr. Sevan did not make a similar decision, Mr. Eckhard said, "I don't want to compare Benon Sevan's judgment with Richard Butler's judgment."
Several United Nations officials, said that the organization sometimes informally refrained from sending staff members of certain nationalities to places where they might in particular be in harm's way, but that they were unhappy about Mr. Sevan's decision, calling it troubling.
At the same time, they added, Mr. Sevan was primarily motivated to help the people of Iraq, one million of whom are said to be suffering from the effects of food shortages and other results of economic sanctions and President Saddam Hussein's reluctance to buy the vital food and medicine he is permitted to import through oil sales.
The two Americans who have been ordered to leave Iraq are the secretary to Prakash Shah, Secretary General Annan's special envoy in Iraq, and the deputy director of the World Food Program, which announced today a $21 million appeal to help the hungry in Iraq.
Iraq had offered to make an exemption for these two Americans, plus a third who was working in Baghdad, but Mr. Sevan did not think that any Americans and British should be singled out to stay.
Both the British Foreign Office and American officials in Washington expressed "regret" about the decision, but added that the safety and security of their citizens required such a move. They blamed the Government of Iraq, saying that its unwillingness to guarantee the employees' safety had "forced" the United Nations to make the decision.
Most of the United Nations employees in the "oil for food" program are in northern Iraq, in three Kurdish provinces not directly under Baghdad's control.
The United Nations distributes food in the north and monitors its distribution by the Iraqi Government in the rest of the country. The program permits Iraq to sell almost $5.3 billion worth of oil every six months to buy food, medicine and basic goods.
The issue has been slowly building. Iraq warned in early January that it might expel American and British relief workers, saying in an unsigned diplomatic note that their safety could not be assured given public anger over air strikes that, Iraq charged and the United States and Britain denied, had "schools, universities, hospitals, grain depots, means of communications and factories" as their targets.
Since then, United Nations officials have tried unsuccessfully to obtain safety guarantees from Baghdad. While all United Nations members are required to assure such protection, there is no automatic penalty in the organization's charter for failing to do so.
But the issue is likely to be raised when the Security Council, deeply divided over the eight-year old economic sanctions against Iraq, discusses policy toward Iraq at future meetings.
