HEADLINE: Suha Arafat: A Militant in a Blue BMW

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: GAZA, Feb. 2

 BODY:
Suha Arafat, the First Lady of the Palestinian territories, maneuvered her blue BMW through the chaotic streets of Gaza City, blond hair flying as she dodged donkeys and peddlers.
Behind and beside her, security cars struggled to keep her covered as Palestinians stopped on the street to stare: a woman driver is a strange enough sight in this poor, Islamic society, but Madame Arafat chauffeuring herself? 
 Sitting in a bodyguard's lap, her daughter, Zahwa, bilingual in French and Arabic, chattered away until they rounded a corner under a giant billboard of Yasir Arafat. "Papa!" she said merrily, looking herself like the image of the Palestinian leader -- if he could be reimagined as a 3-year-old girl with a blue hair ribbon. "She is totally her father," Mrs. Arafat said. "A real authoritarian."
Mrs. Arafat, 35, would seem an unlikely partner for the 69-year-old Palestinian revolutionary, who remains forever wedded to his cause.
She was raised in a well-off home in the West Bank, educated by nuns and refined at the Sorbonne. Her black patent leather high heels clash with his combat boots. And her deep-seated Christian faith and Western assertiveness seem at odds with his world: desperate Gaza with its veiled Muslim women.
But in ideology Mrs. Arafat, whose husband is to meet with President Clinton on Thursday in Washington, is every bit the fiery Palestinian freedom fighter. And if there is such a thing as pillow talk in their modest residence, where the spartan first floor is his and the stately second-floor extension belongs to her, Mr. Arafat surely gets an earful.
Mrs. Arafat is a merciless critic not of her husband but of his government, willing to do battle on Palestinian television with advisers she believes are dragging down Mr. Arafat and the Palestinian people.
"Every beautiful flower ends up surrounded by weeds," she said. "I'm fed up with criticizing them. It doesn't do any good. History will be their judge."
Nonetheless, during a long afternoon in the living room of their home, Mrs. Arafat -- surrounded by images of Jesus Christ, Pope John Paul II and a young Mr. Arafat with lantern and gun -- was scathingly critical of many key ventures of the Palestinian Authority.
She dismissed the new Yasir Arafat International Airport, which operates under strict Israeli security supervision, as "a branch of Ben-Gurion in Gaza," referring to the airport outside Tel Aviv. She ridiculed the thriving Palestinian-run casino in Jericho as "a disgrace."
"I hate it," she said. "It's the most shameful act that the economic counselors of the Palestinian Authority did. Right across from a refugee camp, no less. We have no hospitals, no sewage, sick children, a whole sick society. But, oh, we have gambling. Great."
And she mocked the American-brokered peace agreement signed by her husband and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in October. She did not attend the signing ceremony in Washington, and since the agreement's fulfillment has been frozen for two months, she feels justified.
"Each time we're going to get how many new inches of land, we have to make a celebration?" she said. "It turns out it was only a photo opportunity."
For years after they were secretly married in Tunis almost a decade ago, Mrs. Arafat was dismissed as a "decoration" for the longtime bachelor, particularly by the inner circle of the Palestine Liberation Organization, who could not bear the sight of their fearless leader making goo-goo eyes.
"It was not easy to enter into their world," she said. "It is a man's world, and very closed -- like a family with a lot of intermarriages, and, well, you know the result of that."
But by speaking her mind and by establishing humanitarian institutions in Gaza, Mrs. Arafat has earned a place for herself as a Palestinian leader in her own right.
"She is like a big mother for the people," said Randa Bamia, the director general for international relations at the Palestinian tourism ministry. "She feels a lot for their miseries, and she's very popular because of it. At first they wanted to make her out to be frivolous, but really she lives much more modestly than the wife of most any minister in her husband's government."
In "Arafat, From Defender to Dictator," a new biography of Mr. Arafat published in London by Bloomsbury, Said K. Aburish, a Palestinian-born journalist, said he had tried to but could not find any basis to rumors that Mrs. Arafat took advantage of her role by making business deals.
As she did this past autumn, Mrs. Arafat often spends months at a time abroad, usually in Paris, where her parents keep an apartment. That has fueled other rumors, that she was away on shopping sprees, but she said she spent most of her time there fund-raising for her relief organizations. In her Gaza life style, there is no obvious bounty of any mad spending.
Compared with the villas of some Palestinian officials and business executives, the simple house rented by the Arafats is humdrum and middle-class. Mrs. Arafat said she had to beg her husband for the second-floor addition so she and Zahwa would not have to share the lower floor's two rooms with his security entourage.
When she finally unveiled the tasteful but hardly lavish second floor, Mr. Arafat told her it looked like a cabaret and returned to his monk's quarters downstairs, she said.
When Mrs. Arafat is in town, she visits Gaza's refugee camps regularly, soaking up their tales of hardship and also their complaints about her husband's government, many of which she can't help agreeing with.
Mrs. Arafat endeared herself to many in the camps when she refused on principle to accept a VIP pass from the Israelis that would have allowed her to cross Israeli roadblocks without the hassle that most Palestinians face.
Mrs. Arafat keeps a small office at one of her relief organizations, a foundation for physically disabled children. The center is a bright and modern place, filled with the latest developmental toys, and Mrs. Arafat seems to have a personal relationship with the children.
They stroke her hair, and she hands out chocolates and quizzes the teachers about their progress. Presented with a problem by her staff, she wonders aloud if she can find a donor to solve it, remarking that a French delegation is visiting on Wednesday.
"Some people in the Authority are not very helpful," she said. "They want to talk politics but not humanitarian things. But people are fed up with politics. So what if Netanyahu gives up 30, 40, 60 percent of our land? The people want food on their table, and decent health care."
"The President is doing a lot," she continued, referring to her husband. "Sometimes he screams at me when he comes home. 'Can you imagine today you cost me $100,000, Suha?' But he is very kind this way."
Sipping black coffee spiced with cardamom, Mrs. Arafat spoke of intense pressures on her husband to put off the declaration of a Palestinian state on May 4, the date that the Oslo peace accord set for the conclusion of a final agreement between Israel and the Palestinians.
"I think, as Suha and not as the wife of Arafat, that this date is sacred," she said, "and nobody in the world has the right to make us bargain it away. We can't go on and on in this ambiguous condition."
Depressed about what sees as a failing peace effort and corruption within the Palestinian Authority, Mrs. Arafat said her vision of the future was "black."
Born in Jerusalem, Mrs. Arafat grew up in an affluent and political household, first in Nablus, then Ramallah. Her father was a banker and her mother, Raymonda Tawil, a well-known and provocative journalist who was frequently placed under house arrest by the Israelis. When she met the Palestinian leader, during a trip to Amman, Mrs. Arafat was working as a freelance journalist based in Paris.
Smitten, he hired her to do public relations for the P.L.O. in Tunis, where she nominally converted to Islam before they married.
"I married a myth," she said. "But the marriage helped him step down from his pedestal and become a human being."
More tender than the old guerrilla leader, her husband still lives in a kind of bubble, focused on the struggle, she said. Once he sat next to Catherine Deneuve at a dinner without seeming to notice, and Mrs. Arafat had to educate him about the French actress by using her Paris Match magazines, she said.
But the real instruction comes from Zahwa, who was named for the Palestinian leader's mother. An irrepressible and commanding little girl with a mop of curly hair, she stormed and complained when she did not see her father enough.
Now, when he is in Gaza, his bodyguards pick her up from school and take her to his seaside office. A veteran watcher of CNN on the lap of her mother, Zahwa tells her father about Bill Clinton and Kofi Annan and Monica Lewinsky, all the important TV characters.
"Zahwa softens Arafat," Mrs. Arafat said.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
Irish Struggling With Big Ten Decision

BYLINE: By JOE DRAPE 

 BODY:
Notre Dame Coach Bob Davie knows he has a reliable spiel when he sits in living rooms across the nation with potential recruits and their parents. He tells them about his program's national television contract and how, through 111 years of winning football, the Catholic university has been one of the few and certainly the most famous independent team in the nation.
But on Friday, Davie, along with the rest of the Notre Dame community, will find out how much longer that might be true. The university president, the Rev. Edward A. Malloy, will present a recommendation to the board of trustees on whether Notre Dame should seek an affiliation with the Big Ten Conference. 
 "It's a win-win situation, though I'm glad I'm not making the decision," Davie said. "There is a concern about the unknown. Would Notre Dame remain as unique as Notre Dame is, if it were aligned with a conference? We're in an enviable position as an independent."
The decision to join Penn State, Michigan, Ohio State and eight other Midwest institutions, is as much about academics and the fate of its less-famous sports teams, which are now affiliated with the Big East, as it is about football. The Big Ten has not invited Notre Dame to join, but the conference has engaged in months of what its commissioner, Jim Delany, calls "comprehensive information exchange."
"We think that they would be a great addition to our conference," Delany said, acknowledging that the Big Ten had previously approached the Fighting Irish. "But that's far short of offering an invitation or coming to a membership agreement. We have some heavy lifting to do if they are interested in moving forward."
The Notre Dame community appears split on the decision. Its faculty senate has endorsed the alliance because it would allow Notre Dame to share information and research materials with conference schools, and the University of Chicago.
But students appear less eager, as demonstrated by the chants of "No Big Ten" at basketball games as the board of trustees' meeting draws near. Alumni are concerned that the university might lose its identity as an independent Catholic university.
Currently, Notre Dame keeps its gate receipts from football, its bowl payouts and the $7 million a year from its television contract with NBC, a contract that will reap $8 million annually in the years 2000 to 2005.
If it joined the Big Ten, however, Notre Dame would have to share its gate receipts, television revenue and other earnings with member schools.
This past bowl season, according to Delany, the conference grossed about $25 million, with $19 million divided among 11 members.The other $6 million was shared by the five schools that played in bowl games.
"Our revenues have grown from $18 million 10 years ago to over $70 million today," said Delany, who expects to reach $100 million in the next two years.
Notre Dame's biggest concession would be giving up the independent television contract that has helped spread its mystique and has aided Davie's recruiting pitch. Instead, the team would be included in the Big Ten contract with ABC.
Mike Wadsworth, the Notre Dame athletic director, has said a deal with the Big Ten would be a wash economically because of factors such as reduced travel time. The nearest rival for its teams playing in the Big East Conference is more than 350 miles away.
Michael A. Tranghese, the Big East commissioner, said his office has not been privy to Notre Dame's negotiations, but says his conference would survive if the Fighting Irish defected. "If they think they should go, then they should go," he said.
Davie said talk of joining the Big Ten did not come up among players in the recently concluded recruiting period, but it wasn't far from his mind.
"You like to sit in a young man's home and sell them on the uniqueness we have," he said. "But I understand, it's just not a football question."

HEADLINE: Final Arguments in Gun Suit Turn on Question of Negligence

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
Lawyers for relatives of six people killed with illegally obtained handguns presented closing arguments yesterday in a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, saying that 25 gun manufacturers were liable for the slayings because "negligent marketing" practices "put the guns into the hands of the shooters."
The lawyers held that it did not matter which of the companies actually made the guns used in the killings, because the distribution practices of all the companies fostered widespread illegal trafficking in their products, creating a "toxic waste flow" of illicitly available weapons. 
 But lawyers for the manufacturers presented a sharply different view of the month's worth of testimony in the trial.
"Trying to hold manufacturers of legitimately produced products responsible for the acts of these outlaws" -- those who trafficked illegally in guns and those who pulled the triggers -- is "simply wrong," one of the industry lawyers said.
Contending that the plaintiffs' case was built on "smoke and generalities," the lawyer, James P. Dorr, told the jury that the plaintiffs in the suit had presented "no evidence that negligence by any manufacturer was the proximate cause of these shootings."
He also asserted that their collective liability theory was the equivalent of holding all car makers liable for an injury caused by a drunken driver in one car.
The lawsuit was brought by the slaying victims' relatives and a seventh person who was severely wounded by an illegally obtained handgun.
Legal experts say it is the first suit to come to trial that charged that industrywide negligent distribution by the nation's gun producers made them collectively liable for shootings with guns that they had legally made and sold but that ended up in the hands of criminals, youths and others not authorized to have them.
The jury is expected to begin deliberating today.
The trial is being watched across the country because the plaintiffs' argument is similar to contentions in lawsuits that Chicago and other cities have recently filed, or plan to file, against the gun industry, much as states have sued the tobacco industry.
The seven shootings at issue in the Brooklyn trial took place in the New York City area in 1993 and 1994 and involved robberies, disputes and apparently one accident. A lawyer for the plaintiffs, Denise Dunleavy, suggested varying amounts of damages for the plaintiffs, should the jury find the companies liable. The suggestions ranged from several hundred thousand dollars for the mother of one victim to as much as "7, 8, 10 million" for Steven Fox, a Queens teen-ager who survived the apparently accidental shooting with a bullet still in his brain.
In only one of the seven shootings was a gun recovered, but another plaintiffs' lawyer, Elisa Barnes, told the jurors that "it simply doesn't matter because in this illegal market, all the guns are the same."
She recalled that economic and statistical consultants for her side had testified that 90 percent of handguns used in crimes in New York State in recent years had originally been sold in other states, often Southern states with weaker gun control laws. She held that the manufacturers had regularly oversupplied dealers in the states with weak gun laws and that many of the excess guns ended up in the hands of illegal traffickers, who resold them in states with strong laws, like New York.
In his remarks, Mr. Dorr, the defense lawyer, recalled testimony in which an economist had charged that the oversupply argument was based on flawed statistics. He told the jurors that "there is no oversupply" of guns to various states and that the criminal trafficking across state lines "is not connected to anything in the lawful marketing" by the gun makers.
The companies, he said, cooperate as much as they can with law enforcement agencies in fighting illegal trafficking.
As the lawyers clashed, one of the plaintiffs watching in the gallery, Freddie Hamilton -- whose son, Njuzi Ray, 17, was killed in one of the shootings -- expressed optimism that the jury would see the case the plaintiffs' way. And, alluding to the four years since the suit was filed, the 55-year-old woman said: "I'm glad it's almost over. It's very draining."

HEADLINE: Pataki Retreats on Paying For Early Schooling Plans

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 3

 BODY:
In his State of the State Message a year ago, Gov. George E. Pataki said it was time to "declare, once and for all, what we all know to be the case" -- that prekindergarten programs work. And he promised to increase spending on such programs tenfold by 2001.
But in his budget message last week, the Governor appeared to make a sharp turn in the opposite direction, proposing to eliminate some early-childhood programs and cut back spending on others, including the prekindergarten programs he praised so warmly last year. 
 The new plan has left school districts perplexed and furious, with some scrambling to come up with money they thought had been promised and others wondering whether to abandon the effort entirely.
In New York City, for example, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew today warned that thousands of children might lose out on prekindergarten as a result of the Governor's proposed cuts. Dr. Crew said the city wants to offer the program to 29,000 children next year, up from 14,000 this year, and to all 112,000 of the city's 4-year-olds in four years.
"As far as I am concerned, they are at risk," Dr. Crew said of the universal prekindergarten classes. "They are unfunded mandates at this juncture."
The districts, from New York City to Syracuse to Buffalo, had been counting on hundreds of millions of dollars in additional state aid, based on an agreement that Mr. Pataki and the Legislature reached in 1997 to phase in programs for very young students over the next few years.
The money, which would have totaled about $1.5 billion in the school year beginning in 2001, was intended to help the districts provide prekindergarten classes for all 4-year-olds, smaller class sizes in the early grades and all-day kindergarten for districts that now have either no kindergarten, or only half-day sessions. Some of the money was also earmarked for school construction, textbooks and computers.
But in his budget proposal, Mr. Pataki sought to back away from that agreement. He delivered the promised construction money, but proposed eliminating allocations for prekindergarten, kindergarten, and smaller classes, offering instead to provide school districts with a more modest cash grant that could be used for programs of their choosing.
His aides say that that approach would give districts greater flexibility. But it has also stirred confusion and uncertainty among school districts, particularly those that are already making plans to hire additional teachers and find new classroom space to carry out the programs next year.
Mr. Pataki's proposal would have the greatest impact on New York City, which would receive a $77 million state educational grant in lieu of the $150 million it would have otherwise received for early-childhood programs. The money from the original deal, school officials said, would have enabled the city to hire 600 additional teachers to reduce class size in the first, second and third grades, as well as add 4,000 full-day prekindergarten slots.
But now, those plans are on hold. "We have no rational basis for talking about the next school year," said Steven K. Allinger, a lobbyist for the New York City Board of Education. "We hope we can convince the Governor to restore the funding to these initiatives."
New York City is by no means the only district that has been caught by surprise. In Rochester and Buffalo, for example, school officials had planned to add a combined 1,536 prekindergarten slots for the coming school year. But those plans are suddenly up in the air as a result of Mr. Pataki's proposal, according to the officials.
"You can't wait until August to decide that you're going to expand the program by several hundred slots, particularly in large city schools that have critical classroom space problems," said Georgia M. Asciutto, the executive director for the Conference of Big Five School Districts, which represents the state's five largest urban school districts, including Rochester and Buffalo. "That process has to start much earlier than that."
Over all, the agreement Mr. Pataki reached with the Legislature in 1997 would have provided school districts around the state with $100 million in 1999-2000 for prekindergarten classes, $75 million for class size reduction, $10 million for full-day kindergarten, $50 million for school maintenance, along with several smaller allocations.
The Governor would replace all of those programs, totaling $270 million, with a grant of $200 million. The administration contends that the 1997 deal placed too many restrictions on school districts in return for the financing. Mr. Pataki himself noted that of the 120 school districts that qualified for the additional money last year, only half applied.
But education advocates and school officials say abrogating the 1997 deal would almost certainly mean that districts would abandon the prekindergarten, kindergarten and class size initiatives. If districts are free to spend the proposed grant as they please, officials said, they would have little incentive to use the money for the ambitious programs for young students, particularly if the Governor has his way in giving districts an increase in state aid that is below the rate of inflation.
Beyond that, Mr. Pataki's critics say that the $200 million grant he is proposing is far less money than the state would have spent under the 1997 deal. Mr. Pataki's aides do not dispute that, but note that he intends to supplement the state grant with $100 million in Federal money that has been allocated to help schools reduce class size in the early grades. But his critics maintain that the state should not be reneging on its financial commitment to early-childhood programs just because the Federal Government is now providing money for the same purpose.
The reaction to Mr. Pataki's plan is almost certain to make it the focus of sharp debate in the Legislature, where members of both parties are already under intense pressure from their constituents to preserve financing for the relatively popular early-childhood programs.

HEADLINE: John Service, a Purged 'China Hand,' Dies at 89

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

 BODY:
John S. Service, the first of the "old China hands" purged from the State Department in the McCarthy era, died yesterday in Oakland, Calif. He was 89.
As a young Foreign Service officer in World War II, he filed prescient reports on the rival forces battling the occupying Japanese -- Chiang Kai-shek's nationalists and Mao Zedong's Communists -- and observed the corruption and weakness of the former. 
 But after the war, as what became known as the China Lobby swung American policy strongly behind the failing Chiang Government -- the Communists gained full control of the mainland in 1949, driving the Nationalists to Taiwan -- much of the blame fell on what was said at the time to be a pro-Soviet conspiracy in the State Department.
"Who lost China?" became a major election slogan that shaped American political life for many years. It helped make the careers of Joseph R. McCarthy and Richard M. Nixon and, according to some historians, helped shape American involvement in the Korean and Vietnam wars.
Mr. Service once predicted wryly that although he never used his middle name, only the initial, his obituary would identify him not only as an official once accused of espionage, but as "John Stewart Service."
The accusers of those men spelled out their full names, and so they went down in history: John Stewart Service, John Carter Vincent, John Paton Davies, Oliver Edmund Clubb. All were forced out of the Foreign Service. All were eventually vindicated, but neither they nor, some thought, the Foreign Service itself ever fully recovered.
Their ordeal actually began during World War II in the efforts of an American mission led by Gen. Joseph W. (Vinegar Joe) Stilwell to expand the Chinese war effort against Japan. The China experts, traveling through the areas controlled by various warlords, reported that Chiang's Nationalist Party, the Kuomintang, was dragging its feet, reserving its American-supplied arms for an eventual showdown with the Communists.
The old China hands predicted that in such a fight, the Communists would win. They called instead for American pressure on Chiang to reform his Government and direct his forces against the Japanese, in cooperation with the Communists.
"Selfish and corrupt, incapable and obstructive," were a few of the words Mr. Service used to describe the Chiang Government in a 1944 memo to General Stilwell.
Like many of his generation of China hands, Mr. Service was born in China of missionary parents, on Aug. 8, 1909, in Chengdu, where his parents had founded a branch of the Y.M.C.A.
He grew up in Sichuan province, attended high school in Shanghai and studied art history at Oberlin College in Ohio, where he also was captain of the track team. Returning to China in 1932, he married an Oberlin classmate, Caroline Schulz, the daughter of an Army officer.
After a brief stint in a bank, he joined the Foreign Service, and when the Japanese entered Beijing, he escorted American refugees through the lines to safety.
He was assigned to the new Nationalist capital at Chongqing as a political officer in 1941. His job was to gather information from all factions and parties, including the Communists. As political officers do today, he gave briefings to visiting American journalists, including Theodore H. White and Eric Sevareid. Those activities were later cast in a controversial light.
A lifelong amateur runner, Mr. Service hiked around China with a sleeping bag, eating as well as he could off the land. E. J. Kahn Jr., in his book "The China Hands," quotes a State Department colleague as saying: "Jack had uncanny instincts. He could walk along a Chinese street and by the kind of matches sold or the clothing worn or the food being cooked, could analyze the structure of the local society."
As the war progressed, Mr. Service warned that a civil war was widely regarded as inevitable, under conditions that would lead to an undemocratic, probably pro-Soviet Communist government.
In July 1944, he finally managed to get to Mao's headquarters in Yanan. He wrote that he felt he had "come into a different country," one marked by hard work, cooperation and "the absence of banditry."
Recording his first impressions, he wrote: "There is an absence of show and formality, both in speech and action. Relations of the officials and people toward us, and of the Chinese themselves, are open, direct and friendly. Mao Zedong and other leaders are universally spoken of with respect (amounting in the case of Mao to a kind of veneration)."
This was in sharp contrast to the "crisis" of the Chiang Government he described in a crucial memo to General Stilwell that Oct. 11. "Recent defeats have exposed its military ineffectiveness and will hasten the approaching economic disaster," he wrote.
But the memo was reportedly leaked to the Nationalist Government. The powerful China Lobby back home was furious, and both General Stilwell and Mr. Service were recalled to Washington. President Roosevelt replaced General Stilwell as his personal envoy with Gen. Patrick J. Hurley.
Mr. Service got back to China as an Army adviser, visiting both sides, but was soon in trouble again. He drafted a letter, signed by the rest of the diplomatic staff in the Nationalist capital, Chongqing, urging that the United States provide aid to the Communists in order to reduce casualties in an expected Allied invasion from the sea. General Hurley charged betrayal and got him recalled, this time for good.
Waiting for reassignment in Washington in April 1945, Mr. Service received a phone call from Mark Gayn, a freelance journalist who was at the time working for Amerasia, a tiny left-wing magazine with strong views on China similar to Mr. Service's own.
Mr. Service met several times with Mr. Gayn and Amerasia's editor-publisher, Philip Jaffe, and lent them copies of some of his reports, a few of which he himself had classified as secret. He later agreed with his accusers that this was an indiscretion, but contended that it was common procedure.
Amerasia was under surveillance by the F.B.I., and agents had repeatedly entered its offices and several apartments, and had taken or photographed documents, including those provided by Mr. Service.
A grand jury looking into the question of whether documents had been illegally obtained voted unanimously against indicting Mr. Service. Others were indicted, and as the result of a plea bargain some were fined and one case was dismissed.
The effects of the case endured, however. The Chinese Communists treated it as proof of American hostility. To American supporters of Chiang, it was proof of an anti-Nationalist conspiracy in the State Department. And in the ensuing years, the right would charge that there was a cover-up in the case.
In 1996, a book based on recently released F.B.I. files suggested there had indeed been a fix in the case, but not the kind the right had charged. In "The Amerasia Spy Case" (University of North Carolina Press), Harvey Klehr and Ronald Radosh wrote that Thomas Corcoran, the prominent former New Dealer turned Washington fixer, had a hand in the case, lobbying the Justice Department to go easy on Mr. Service.
One of Mr. Corcoran's clients was Chiang's Government, and he feared that if the Foreign Service officer went on trial, Mr. Service, like-minded State Department advisers and above all General Stilwell -- who was under a Presidential gag order -- would testify about corruption and other failures of the Nationalists.
Cleared by a State Department loyalty board -- by his count he would eventually pass nine such inquiries -- Mr. Service was to go to Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur's headquarters in Tokyo. But as the cold war sharpened and the Chiang Government disintegrated, the search for culprits intensified. Other espionage cases, the Alger Hiss affair, the Soviet explosion of an atom bomb and the Korean war further embittered the dispute.
On the night of Feb. 9, 1950, Senator McCarthy held up a sheaf of paper during a speech in Wheeling, W. Va., and declared, "I have here in my hands a list of 205, known to the Secretary of State as being members of the Communist Party and who nevertheless are still working and shaping the policy of the State Department."
Pressed in Congress, Mr. McCarthy eventually produced 14 names, among them that of Mr. Service, who he charged was a "a known associate and collaborator with Communists."
He was cleared by a Senate committee, which declared that he should not be penalized "by destroying his career and branding him as disloyal for writing what appears to have been the true facts as he saw them."
But on Dec. 13, 1951, a Loyalty Review Board named by President Truman ruled there was "reasonable doubt as to his loyalty." Secretary of State Dean Acheson dismissed him the same day.
He fought the ruling, and in 1956 the Supreme Court ruled 8 to 0 that the Presidential board had no right to review the State Department's findings and that Mr. Acheson had no right to dismiss him. To the surprise of many, he rejoined the State Department and retired from an obscure post in the Liverpool consulate in 1962.
At 53, Mr. Service enrolled in the University of California at Berkeley, received a master's degree and became library curator of its Center for Chinese Studies. With the thaw in Chinese-American relations in the early 1970's, he was able to revisit China several times.
He published several books on China, including a volume of his wartime dispatches, "Last Chance in China" (Random House, 1974).
He is survived by three children, Victoria McCormick of Chevy Chase, Md., Robert Service of Washington, D.C., and Philip Service of Flagstaff, Ariz.; seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Miffed Models: Quit Pouting And Organize

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
NEW YORK fashion models are hurting, and no one feels their pain.
The rage in fashion magazines is for covers featuring actresses and celebrities like Courteney Cox, Michelle Pfeiffer, Oprah Winfrey and Hillary Rodham Clinton. Editors find that these covers sell better than ones featuring models' faces. They also find celebrities, even movie stars, easier to work with than models. 
 So there's mewling on Seventh Avenue ("The Models Are Angry" was one recent headline) as the industry ponders the awful question raised last week by Conor Kennedy, a booker at Company Models: "If magazines are making such an effort to feature Gwyneth Paltrow over and over again, well, what happens to the next generation of Linda Evangelistas?"
The public's answer thus far has been a resounding: Who cares? As victims, miffed supermodels rank on the sympathy scale just above Arab princes whining over low oil prices. Most Americans rejoice at the thought of models forced to wipe the sullen looks off their faces and look for a job.
But with a little effort, the models might be able to win sympathy here on their home turf as they struggle against the competition from Hollywood. Cover girls, after all, are one of New York's major businesses, and the city's politicians have traditionally provided help to any local industry that complains loud enough.
If millionaire stockbrokers and athletes and taxicab-fleet owners are entitled to special treatment, why not supermodels? Workers of Seventh Avenue, unite! You have nothing to lose but your pouts!
Start by forming the S.O.S (Save Our Supermodels) Committee and make enough campaign contributions to get a public hearing in the City Council. Then tearfully tell of your shattered dreams ("I, like, had to finish high school!") and economic hardships ("You know, I had to pay for this dress").
Give testimony about "totally unfair competition" from celebrities, but avoid lines like "Excuse me, Oprah is such a whale" and "That Hillary cover -- hello, total airbrush!" Also to be avoided: "I mean, Courteney Cox, she's got to be 30." While testifying, try not to fling your hair back while staring blankly into the distance.
Hire a consultant to calculate the tens of billions of dollars generated by models for the New York economy. Count not merely the revenues of the modeling agencies but also the money spent on flowers, dinner, nightclubs, jewelry and cars by men pursuing models. Include a generous "multiplier effect" in the calculations -- say, two investment bankers and one real estate developer per model.
DON'T forget to include the revenues of the garment industry, which stands to lose sales because of the ineptness of amateur models. Stress the endless hours of training to acquire the skills needed for a grueling cover shoot. Demonstrate how a veteran runway model can increase sales by knowing how to "work a dress."
Stress the safety risks of using celebrity models. Illustrate how easily an amateur can start a fire by knocking over a photographer's light. Point out that runways are not designed to support the weight of modern-day celebrities (again, do not mention Oprah by name). Sound bite: "Celebrity models are a tragedy waiting to happen."
Demand tax breaks for models, such as exemptions from sales taxes on cigarettes and other professional supplies. Urge the Mayor to reserve curb space downtown for models' Town Cars and to include a fashion stadium in his West Side sports complex. Above all, advocate a new city agency: the Fashion Models Commission.
Like the Taxi and Limousine Commission, the F.M.C. would license all working models and require them to display a special medallion during any photo shoot. The courts might not allow the F.M.C. to ban celebrities from modeling, but it could achieve the same effect by mandating a long apprenticeship and test. (Sample questions: What is the private line for reservations at Balthazar? How often do you need a glycolic facial peel?)
If all this seems too complicated, there is a simpler solution that requires no legislation: join the teamsters. The union could easily negotiate contracts that prevent celebrities from ever posing again, and there would be one fringe benefit. Once New York's fashion editors tried conducting a photo shoot while a veteran shop steward enforced the teamsters' work rules, no one would ever complain again about models being difficult.

HEADLINE: Record for Women in Washington Legislature

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: OLYMPIA, Wash.

 BODY:
In the Democratic Caucus of the Washington State Senate, male legislators, already outnumbered by their female counterparts 18 to 9, have formed a Last Man's Club, betting among themselves, with a touch of nervous bonhomie, on who will be the final one left before all the caucus members are women.
The men also shrug good-naturedly when asked whatever happened to their posh, marble-lined bathroom in the State Capitol. The women took it over last year, and the men were re-assigned to a decidedly less ornate lavatory, with fewer stalls, that had been the ladies' room. 
 "Democracy in action," explained State Senator Harriet Spanel, smiling sweetly.
Truth be told, women have not yet taken over the Legislature here, but they do constitute 40.8 percent of the membership, the highest percentage of women in any state legislature in the nation's history. The women of Olympia are among the more potent symbols of an electoral tide that has brought record numbers of women into public office this year, notably in the increasingly important state legislatures.
Washington is hardly alone. Women make up 36.5 percent of the Nevada Legislature; 35.6 percent of Arizona's; 33 percent of Colorado's and 32.7 percent of Kansas'.
No legislature anywhere mirrors the proportion of women in the general population, 51 percent. And wide disparities exist among the states. Washington's percentage of women in its legislature is far above the national average of 22.3 percent, and much greater than that of the state at the other end of the spectrum, Alabama, where 7.9 percent of state lawmakers are women.
But enough states have a critical mass of women that an old debate has fresh currency: What difference does it make when women are in charge? And that debate has added meaning as states assume power in areas like welfare and health care.
Some academic studies indicate that legislatures with greater numbers of women are more favorably inclined toward measures involving care for children and the elderly and women's health issues, a view with which many lawmakers here and elsewhere heartily concur.
"I think, generally, men like tax-type issues, they like criminal-justice issues," said State Senator Shirley Winsley, a Republican from the Tacoma area, who has served in the Legislature for 22 of the last 26 years. "When you get down to the nitty-gritty issues of dealing with children, aging, long-term care, all those are things that are a natural for women. They're wives, they're mothers, they've been much more active in the schools."
But even many female legislators, noting that women are hardly monolithic in their views, question whether there is a women's agenda to be advanced with their rising numbers.
"I personally sometimes kind of bristle at the idea that there are 'women's issues' for us to carry," said Representative Cheryl Pflug, a Republican in a district outside Seattle who ran on a platform of lowering taxes and tackling traffic congestion and suburban sprawl.
As for the mechanics of political power, some experts note that women have not yet captured their share of the most powerful positions in the legislatures, like House speaker.
Here in Washington, for instance, the picture is mixed. Women do hold 12 of the 15 standing committee chairmanships in the Senate, and 5 of the top 6 Democratic leadership positions in the Senate. On the other hand, the four top leadership positions in the Senate and the House are held by men, and no woman has ever served as speaker.
Still, the raw numbers are striking. In 1969, women held just 4 percent of all state legislative seats in the country, according to statistics compiled by the Center for the American Woman and Politics at the Eagleton Institute at Rutgers University. In every two-year election cycle since then, that percentage has risen -- to 10.3 percent in 1979, 20.5 percent in 1993, and 22.3 percent today.
By comparison, in the United States Congress, 9 women serve in the 100-member Senate and 56 in the House (12.9 percent of the membership there); both numbers are all-time highs, according to the Rutgers institute. The number of women in statewide elective posts is 89, also a record, representing 27.6 percent of the available positions. Female legislators are disproportionately Democratic, while women in executive positions are more evenly divided between the two major parties.
Washington State has long drawn attention for the high numbers of women who hold public office. Even so, the inroads in the Legislature stand out. Twenty-three of the 49 state senators are women, as are 37 of the 98 state representatives.
"I've traveled around the country and spoken with a lot of lawmakers in other states," said State Senator Pat Thibaudeau, a Seattle Democrat. "And I've never seen a woman yet, be she Republican or Democrat, who doesn't get this big smile on her face when I tell her that we're almost half the Legislature."
One question that has been widely explored is just why women seem to hold much larger percentages of legislative seats in Western states than they do in many other parts of the country, especially the South. (By comparison, New York's Legislature is 20.9 percent female, Connecticut's 29.4 percent, and New Jersey's 16.7 percent.) The most widely advanced theory seems to be that the Western states' pioneering traditions created a culture in which it was acceptable and even necessary for women to exert strong leadership roles. Many of these states were also among the first to give women the right to vote.
"A woman had to be able to shoot dinner, chop the wood, harness the horses," said State Senator Valoria Loveland, a Democrat from southeastern Washington. "And I think that's carried over in our history. I was basically raised never to use the word 'can't.' "
But other factors play a role in women's political participation, experts say; for example, women sometimes do better in states with weaker party structures, which tend to be more open to candidates entering politics by untraditional routes.
A larger question is just what difference women make in how government functions and in what kinds of bills get passed. Debbie Walsh, associate director of the Center for the American Woman and Politics, has studied that issue. In particular, Ms. Walsh said, women are generally more likely than men to cite child care (especially as a component of job-training programs), affordable health insurance and long-term care for the elderly as their priority issues, as well as a range of issues dealing with women's rights, including divorce and spousal-abuse laws.
A study by political scientists at the University of Florida, "Impacts of Female Legislators on Policy Making," based on surveys of legislators around the country and released last summer, also found an interesting difference between the sexes: Although Republican women in office express more conservative views than male Democrats on several issues dealing with taxes, finance and business matters, they are still more likely than those Democratic men to sponsor bills in those "women's-policy" areas, even ones that require additional government or industry financing.
And although lawmakers of both sexes listed education as their top priority, they split on their second issue. Women listed health care; men chose taxes.
Among the female legislators here, many seemed leery of the notion that their priorities might be different from men's, a view echoed by Gov. Gary Locke, a Democrat.
"When I was in the Legislature, we had women who were heads of the environment committee, economic development, education, natural resources, the budget, local government," Governor Locke said in an interview. "They were experts in a wide variety of issues."
But many other female lawmakers said it was natural for their priorities to be somewhat different.
"When more women come into the process," said Senator Pat Hale, a Republican from eastern Washington, "I think the debate changes, and that's healthy."

HEADLINE: Museum-Financing Dispute Underscores Giuliani-Pataki Rift

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Plans to announce a long-awaited expansion of New York's Holocaust museum at a ceremony today have been postponed because of a heated dispute over its financing between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki, whose rift appears to widen by the day.
Aides to Mayor Giuliani said yesterday that the city and the state had agreed to chip in $11 million each to help pay for the proposed expansion but that the state had recently reneged on its verbal commitment. 
 The Giuliani administration is determined to come up with more money to cover the state's share, city officials said, but would need the support of Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, who is out of town this week. Therefore, they decided to postpone the announcement until at least next week.
This version of events was described as approaching fiction by various members of the Pataki administration.
Brad Race, Governor Pataki's chief of staff, denied yesterday that the state had agreed to contribute the $11 million; in fact, he said, the state had never even been asked to make such a commitment.
And James F. Gill, whom the Governor appointed as chairman of the Battery Park City Authority -- a state-run agency that controls the land on which the museum sits -- approached apoplexy in disputing the Giuliani administration's version of events.
He said that the agreement had always called for the city to contribute $22 million, while the authority would cede the land on which to build the expansion. "It was always the deal -- it was the deal at the get-go," he insisted. The city's contention, he said, "is made out of whole cloth. It's nonsense. It's garbage. And frankly, I resent it."
To which Randy Levine, the city's Deputy Mayor of Economic Development, said: "If the state had kept its $11 million in, we could have gone forward. I'm telling you, they made the commitment."
Whatever the truth regarding the museum issue, it seemed clear from the nasty charges and countercharges that the awkward detente between the state's two Republican leaders is no more.
It was particularly remarkable that their feud should touch an issue as politically delicate as the Holocaust museum, given that both men will no doubt continue to court Jewish voters and contributors as they pursue possible national ambitions.
Those ambitions could well collide in a party that may be able to handle only one New York Republican at a time. And the men harbor a mutual distrust that dates back to Mr. Giuliani's decision to back Mr. Pataki's opponent and eventual victim, Mario M. Cuomo, in 1994.
Since then, the Governor and the Mayor have professed to enjoy a fruitful relationship, with Mr. Giuliani endorsing Mr. Pataki's re-election last fall.
But in recent weeks, the two camps have appeared to go out of their way to antagonize each other.
Mr. Giuliani, for example, did not check with Mr. Pataki last month before proposing a plan to build a domed football stadium on Manhattan's West Side, even though the Governor controls the land on which it would be built.
And Mr. Pataki surprised Mr. Giuliani by recently announcing plans to investigate the School Construction Authority, even though the Governor's appointee to the authority was at the center of recent charges of mismanagement.
All this behind-the-scenes tension sets the stage for a potential spectacle whenever the two men are expected to appear at the same function, as they were for the planned announcement of the expansion of the Museum of Jewish Heritage -- A Living Memorial to the Holocaust, which opened in 1997 on land at the southern tip of Manhattan.
Two men who were integral in establishing the museum, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, and Howard Rubenstein, the public relations consultant, said yesterday that both Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Pataki have long been supportive of the endeavor to memorialize, through exhibits and recorded testimony, the Holocaust. And they both tried to play down a political fight that threatened to overshadow a proposed expansion that took months of negotiations to put together.
"Our feeling is that both sides have done wonderful things for our museum and we will not get embroiled with any dispute," Mr. Rubenstein said.
A dispute has blossomed nevertheless. City officials said that officials from the Pataki administration committed to providing $11 million shortly before Election Day. When they saw no mention of that commitment in the budget plan that Mr. Pataki presented last week, they called to complain.
But Mr. Race had a somewhat different recollection. "I had a conversation last week with City Hall in which the question was raised with me for the very first time," he said. "I responded that that was never a commitment that was ever requested or agreed to by the state. Nobody ever requested the state to put in capital money into this project. Their response was, 'I guess we'll pick it all up."'
Neither Mr. Morgenthau nor Mr. Rubenstein recalled an arrangement in which the state would provide $11 million to the expansion. And Mr. Gill said that he recalled the only question being whether the city would pay its $22 million contribution from the city treasury, or have it deducted from the surplus that it was entitled to from the rents paid at Battery Park City. He said the answer he received was that the city would cover its obligation with money from the treasury.
The final details centered on the press conference to announce the expansion, with the city bragging about its financial contribution and the state boasting of having provided the land (which the Giuliani administration maintains belongs to the city anyway). "It was going to be a wonderful event," Mr. Gill said. "And now at the 12th hour there's this nonsense."
As the dispute emerged, city officials first said they would move the announcement from the neutral ground of the museum to City Hall, the Mayor's turf -- before finally postponing it altogether.
Mr. Morgenthau said that Mr. Levine called him on Tuesday evening to notify him of the postponement. State officials, meanwhile, learned of the change in plans yesterday afternoon. A high-ranking official in the Giuliani administration justified the postponement this way: "What are we going to have an announcement about? The project's not right."
But it soon will be, according to city officials. Colleen Roche, the Mayor's press secretary, said that Mr. Giuliani had reached Mr. Vallone last night, and that Mr. Vallone's recollection of the agreement with the state was the same as those of the Mayor's aides. She said -- and Carolyn Daly, a spokeswoman for the City Council agreed --- that the city could come up with the $22 million total.
Of course, there still remains the vexing question of how to announce the expansion. Said Mr. Rubenstein, "We're hopeful that the two governmental sides will sit down and work it out."

HEADLINE: The Long-Elusive Lynx Is Returned to Colorado

BYLINE: By MINDY SINK 

DATELINE: SOUTH FORK, Colo., Feb. 3

 BODY:
After a few minutes of terrified hesitation, a lynx, a wildcat not seen in Colorado in more than 25 years, was reintroduced here today.
The wildcat, an 18-pound, 3-year-old female, was the first of two lynxes released in the Weminuche Wilderness area of the San Juan Mountains and the first of about 50 lynxes to be reintroduced this year. 
 "They're back!" hollered Gene Byrne, a wildlife biologist with the Colorado Division of Wildlife, as a second cat darted across the sunlit snow here, 45 miles north of the New Mexico border.
"Never left," another wildlife official, Bill Andree, said quietly.
Whether these elusive wildcats were ever really gone from Colorado has been a subject of much speculation in recent years.
But present or not, the lynx has proven divisive. Last October the Earth Liberation Front, an animal rights group, claimed responsibility for a major fire at a ski resort that the group believed was threatening the animals' habitat.
The last known sighting of a lynx in Colorado was near Vail in 1973. Twenty-two have been reported seen in the last 100 years. But there is no doubt that the animal once roamed this state freely.
"This was a relatively common species in Colorado before the 20th century," said Todd Malmsbury, a spokesman for the Colorado Division of Wildlife. "We can't say if their decline was caused by human settlement and all its impacts -- mining, pollution, agriculture, recreation -- or something else."
The lynx's disappearance may have also been a result of a decline in their primary prey, the snowshoe hare, or of trapping.
The spread of development in the Vail area prevented officials from releasing the wildcats there. Instead, they settled on this site next to the San Juan-Rio Grande National Forest, about 200 miles from the popular ski resort area.
"There are too many people, too many dogs, too many everything up there," Mr. Malmsbury said. "It doesn't mean they can't repopulate there though."
Cal Joyner, a supervisor for the United States Forest Service, said: "This is their entryway into 6,500 square miles of wilderness. We don't anticipate them staying anywhere near where we drop them off."
The lynxes released today, which were brought 1,700 miles from British Columbia last week, are part of a $2 million, five-year program by the Colorado Division of Wildlife.
"The American people expect native species present on their national forest lands," Mr. Joyner said.
The reintroduction provoked an unsuccessful lawsuit by local cattlemen and tour groups anticipating that the animal's presence would bring about restrictions on land use.
Their primary concern is not the lynx, which is not a natural predator of livestock, but the restrictions that may result if the Government decides that the cats are a "threatened" or "endangered" species.
"Once the lynx is here, the Federal Government can impose restrictions on the land, and that may hurt the outfitters and ranchers economically," said William Perry Pendley, president of the Mountain States Legal Foundation, which represented the Cattlemen's Association in the lawsuit.
A decision on whether to include the lynx on the endangered species list is expected by summer. Several states -- Montana, Idaho, Maine and Washington -- are believed to have lynx populations. It is on Colorado's endangered species list.
"We just assumed they were here before, but once they're legally listed, we don't know what falls after that," said Freeman Lester, a 63-year-old rancher and president of the Colorado Cattlemen's Association. Others note that there have already been restrictions related to the lynx, since environmental officials assumed it was still here.

HEADLINE: Rise in Number of Children Born Into Poverty in New York City

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Despite an improving economy in New York, more than half of the city's children are born into poverty, a report released yesterday by a children's advocacy group says.
More than 66,000 of the nearly 127,000 children born in New York City in 1996, or about 52.2 percent, were born to families with incomes under the Federal poverty level of $23,000 a year for a family of three, the 216-page report said. The percentage of children born into poverty was the highest ever, surpassing 51.7 percent in 1994 and 39 percent in 1990, according to the report, which was prepared by the Citizens' Committee for Children of New York. 
 The reasons for the rise were not clear, the group said. But the report noted that there were worsening situations in related areas, which include an increase in the number of homeless children and a decline in the number of children reading at grade level, which point to cutbacks at city agencies like the Department of Homeless Services and the Administration for Children's Services.
"The data paint a very alarming picture," said Gail Nayowith, executive director of the Citizens' Committee. "There's a relationship between government spending and outcomes, whether it's the number of children living in poverty or reading at grade level. You get what you pay for."
The group said that there have been spending cuts in 4 out of 19 city agencies that serve children, including a 16.7 percent drop in spending at the homeless-services department from fiscal 1994 to 1998, to $378 million from $454 million.
Samantha I. Lugo, a spokeswoman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, declined to comment on specific points in the Citizens' Committee report. In a prepared statement, she said: "This administration is proud of its record in regard to children. In funds combined, we have spent more money on children than any other administration in the history of the city." She cited such programs as day care financing and Project Read, an after-school program to improve the reading skills of elementary-school children.
Ms. Nayowith said the rise in the percentage of children born into poverty stemmed mainly from increases among white and Asian families. The percentage of black and Hispanic babies born into poverty stayed roughly the same: about 60 percent of black infants and 75 percent of Hispanic babies. But the percentage of white children born into poverty rose in 1996 to 21.6 percent from 12.8 percent in 1990, and among Asians the percentage went up to 47.7 percent in 1996 from 21.9 in 1990.
"We don't know why this is the case," Ms. Nayowith said, "but it may have something to do with increased immigration and perhaps a mismatch in skills between those in poverty and what the economy demands."
The report cited a large number of what it called "risks to child well-being," including poverty, unemployment, teen-age pregnancies, low birth weight, juvenile arrests, and high-school-dropout rates. The group cited scores of city, state and Federal sources of information.
But the group acknowledged conflicts within the data, including different definitions of poverty in different reports.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Credit Card Survey Finds Climbing Fees

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
With holiday shopping bills coming due, city officials warned yesterday that although interest rates on credit cards have declined slightly since last year, customers who do not pay their bills on time are facing skyrocketing late fees.
In its second annual survey of credit card interest rates and fees, the Department of Consumer Affairs found that for 21 cards with a fixed average annual percentage rate, the interest rate dropped an average of 1 percentage point, from 16.05 percent last year to 14.98 percent this year. For 41 cards with variable rates, the rate dropped from 14.58 percent to 13.91 percent. 
 At the same time, the survey found, monthly late charges -- a recent innovation in the credit card business -- increased 19 percent, to an average of $22. More than half the cards in the survey carried higher late fees this year than last year.
Comparing these late charges to the surcharges on transactions at automatic teller machines, the Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Jules Polonetsky, accused the credit card issuers of "double-dipping" because consumers already pay interest on their credit card balance.
"We found that the exorbitant late charges, which are a relatively new phenomenon, are becoming a new profit center for banks that issue credit cards," Mr. Polonetsky said yesterday at a news conference at the department's offices. Someone who is a day late with a small minimum payment may spend more on a late fee than the amount owed.
A banking industry spokesman acknowledged that credit card issuers were seeking new ways to charge for services, but said late fees were also intended as a protection against bankruptcies. "The first thing to go south in a bankruptcy is the credit card," said Joe D. Belew, a spokesman for the Consumer Bankers Association, which represents 150 large banks. "We need to get the message across that you need to pay on time."
 TERRY PRISTIN

HEADLINE: Nerds In Gilded Cubicles

BYLINE: By GARY ANDREW POOLE 

 BODY:
WHEN Eric Schmidt, chief executive of Novell, joined the company nearly two years ago, he would meet a smart employee and wonder why the person still worked there. Not only had Novell, the world's fifth-largest software maker, missed the Internet phenomenon and been hampered by product delays, but it also had some of the ugliest offices in the area.
In Silicon Valley, where many corporate "campuses" resemble destination resorts, Novell looked like an hourly motel. It was hampering Mr. Schmidt's ability to attract and retain the brightest programmers. Salespeople were embarrassed to bring customers to the office. 
 Mr. Schmidt made the decision to go ahead with a new $130 million campus in San Jose, Calif., with tennis, volleyball and basketball courts, a restaurant, a gym and an espresso bar. "To compete in an extremely tight labor market, our campus had to have at least the quality of our competitors'," Mr. Schmidt said recently as he admired his complex, which opened in December. He is particularly proud of the look of the campus, which was inspired by a trip to Venice. Many of the buildings are made of Olympia cream limestone, a light-colored stone imported from Tunisia, because Mr. Schmidt was awed by the colors of St. Mark's Square.
To lure talent in an industry desperate for it, Mr. Schmidt and other Silicon Valley chief executives have become part-time architects, restaurateurs, fitness gurus and concert promoters. Companies are trying to out-perk one another. Some of the best gyms and restaurants here are not open to the public. As the saying goes: Want a good meal? Go to work.
In Silicon Valley, surly servers in hairnets do not dish out mushy mystery meat. The best meals are served at corporate cafeterias where technology workers choose their own pieces of fish or meat and have the chefs grill them to order. Like hoteliers, chief executives brag to other chief executives about their chefs.
Cooks like Lucent Technology's executive chef, Ronald Sullivan, can write their own meal ticket. "I come in early, I leave early, and I don't work weekends," Mr. Sullivan said, taking a break from preparing a basmati rice salad with currants and mixed nuts, to be sold at the highly subsidized price of $4.35, for employees at Lucent's Coyote Creek Cafe.
Why are technology companies, especially large ones, so enraptured with creating fine eateries and other perks?
"We are living in an economy that is driven by skills, and the skills bucket is close to empty," said Thornton May, vice president for research and education at Cambridge Technology Partners, a consulting firm. "Companies are desperate for skilled workers. They'll do anything to recruit and keep you."
This flies in the face of Silicon Valley's tradition of frugality. After all, this is the business that popularized the cubicle, stock options in lieu of salary, casual Fridays and tilt-ups (a Valley term for cheap office buildings). But as the industry has grown, a quiet revolution has taken place. Companies flush with money are investing not only in in-house restaurants but also in gyms with tae kwan do; spinning and yoga classes; pool and Ping-Pong tables; free soda, juice and fresh popcorn; massage therapists; dry-cleaning services; car detailers; dog walkers, and roving ergonomics experts.
It also doesn't hurt to present Bob Dylan and his son Jakob -- both Grammy winners. Applied Materials paid $500,000 so the Dylans would help the company celebrate its 30th birthday.
Bob Dylan had never played a public show with Jakob Dylan, who headlines the Wallflowers, which meant that the 12,000 people attending the Applied Materials private celebration had a "once in a lifetime experience," said Richard Garwacki, vice president of Bill Graham Special Events, which organized 60 shows last year for companies, most of them in Silicon Valley. He said that "there's a lot of ego involved" as companies tried to outdo one another.
"Silicon Valley companies have sophisticated, young employees," Mr. Garwacki said. Presenting corporate-party regulars like the Temptations, Chicago or the Beach Boys just won't cut it. Young, hip and perhaps spoiled, geeks want bands with current hits. "We get more requests for new bands like the Barenaked Ladies, Matchbox 20, Smashmouth, No Doubt and the Smashing Pumpkins," Mr. Garwacki added.
One of the Valley's largest growth industries is perk subcontractors. Bay Sport, a manager of corporate fitness centers, was co-founded by Linda and Doug Emery in 1984. Today they have 200 employees and 100 corporate clients. Although it costs $940,000 to build an average 7,500-square-foot club and $200,000 to stock it with the latest exercise gadgetry, Mr. Emery said he could barely keep up with demand.
On Sand Hill Road, a thoroughfare famous for its collection of venture capitalists, Fedele R. Bauccio runs Bon Appetit Management Company, one of the largest catering companies in Silicon Valley. Starting in 1986 with a single executive dining room, Mr. Bauccio now has 140 locations, 50 in the Bay Area. Last year his company generated $200 million in revenue.
"We do not use the term cafeteria at this company," Mr. Bauccio said. "Green beans do not sit in water for hours at one of our restaurants. We provide fresh food rivaling any fine restaurant." Every in-company restaurant worth its paprika prepares food reflecting the work force's ethnic diversity, he said, with Indian, Japanese and Chinese foods as musts. The Oracle Corporation, based in Redwood Shores, is a Bon Appetit client that is known to have one of the Valley's best Japanese noodle bars, complete with a baby grand piano.
It is not likely that a genius programmer will go to a company just because of its tasty crab cakes, step-class guru or cool hip-hop concerts, but if a company does not provide the standard perks, it will not get on the brightest recruits' short lists.
Of course, at Sun Microsystems' stately Menlo Park campus, the 4,000 workers can eat at several restaurants, including the upscale Java Java, where you can have a generous portion of porcini mushroom and cheese ravioli for $8.25. Sun's fitness center, Fit@Sun, has the latest crazes in fitness classes, including kick-box aerobics. And to keep employees in good humor, Sun brought in the comedian Dana Carvey to perform at a state-of-the-company meeting.
To set itself apart in the perks war, however, Sun has an on-call lactation consultant. Furthermore, it actively helps people interested in adoption. With a $2,500 adoption stipend, Vicky Yee, Sun's corporate diversity manager, went to Guangzhou, China, to adopt her daughter.
Visit Autodesk's headquarters in San Rafael and you will find dogs -- lots of dogs. Kathy Tom-Engle, a spokeswoman, estimated that 100 people had their pooches sleeping in their cubicles. "On occasion you'll hear a growl when you walk around here, but for the most part, the dogs are lazy," she said.
Another popular, and unusual, perk at Autodesk is prepared dinners. An employee can call Rick Gernetti, a chef lured from the film director George Lucas, and he will prepare a gourmet meal that employees can take home and reheat. The company encourages the practice because it keeps employees at work late. A recent dinner selection: blackened salmon with mango salsa, wild rice and vegetables for $6.25 per person. Mr. Gernetti and his staff bake cookies every day, too.
Despite these inducements, established companies are still at a recruitment disadvantage. Since the biggest perk in Silicon Valley continues to be stock options, start ups have the hiring edge. Having a steady but anonymous job at a stable company is not as valued as getting in on the ground floor of a startup where a person has the chance to become a multimillionaire, even the next Bill Gates.
"The greatest difficulties faced by larger companies include a perceived, and often real, lack of willingness to offer equity options or profit sharing," said Michael R. Forrest, president of Job Options, an on-line recruiting company. "As the employment market continues to tighten, they are faced with having to offer salaries and perks to new hires that exceed what the existing work force receives."
Mr. Schmidt said Novell's new 536,000-square-foot campus had already bolstered morale and given him confidence that he would be able to hire hot recruits. Almost every employee has an office because "programmers hate cubicles," he said. Mr. Schmidt encouraged his architect, Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, to create spaces throughout the building where people could gather and talk -- while not creating so much space that people would never meet.
"The density of space in relationship to people is very important in creating a buzz," said Mr. Schmidt, 43, who was an architecture student in college before realizing that he was "truly terrible" at it.
During the building of Novell's campus, Mr. Schmidt was known to say, "Make it so no one has a reason to leave." That mantra seems to be fulfilled. Eat a plate of pasta with salmon, pesto cream and fresh tomatoes ($4.95) at Novell's @cafe.com, ride a stationary bike, sit in one of the Herman Miller Aeron chairs and have a latte at Java City, Novell's coffee bar, and Mr. Schmidt's intended effect seems plausible. "I wouldn't mind if they were working 24 hours a day, seven days a week," Mr. Schmidt said, half-jokingly.

HEADLINE: Marion Boyars, Publisher Of Eclectic Books, Dies at 71

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 3

 BODY:
Marion Boyars, an independent publisher whose eclectic and internationally minded list of authors included at least four Nobel Prize winners, died on Monday at her home in London. She was 71.
The cause was pancreatic cancer, her family said. 
 In an industry increasingly populated by conglomerates with deep pockets and a penchant for books that appeal to as wide an audience as possible, Mrs. Boyars was rare in her insistence on publishing only what she liked, whether the book was likely to sell or not. "Most of my publishing is out of enthusiasm," she told The New York Times in 1995.
Over the years, often working on a shoestring and struggling to stay afloat, she published some 500 books by such writers as Eudora Welty, Julio Cortazar, Yevgeny Yevtushenko, Georges Bataille, Tim O'Brien, Pauline Kael and Ingmar Bergman, works translated from more than 20 languages. Among the Nobel Prize winners on her list were Heinrich Boll, Elias Canetti, Kenzaburo Oe and Eugenio Montale.
She was born Marion Asmus in New York, and grew up there and in Switzerland. After graduating from Keele University in Staffordshire with a degree in politics, philosophy and economics, she married George Lobbenburg, an American who ran a successful clothing company in Britain. The couple had two daughters.
Divorced in her early 30's, she answered an advertisement in The Bookseller, a London trade magazine, and ended up buying a 50 percent stake in a firm run by the independent publisher John Calder. The two set up business in London under the name Calder & Boyars, publishing works by such authors as Samuel Beckett, Marguerite Duras, Henry Miller, Eugene Ionesco and William S. Burroughs. They also specialized in the writings of modern composers, publishing works by Cage, Ives and Stravinsky, and social commentators including Ivan Illich and Robert Heilbroner.
In an international cause celebre, the company was brought to court here and charged with obscenity in 1966 after publishing "Last Exit to Brooklyn" by Hubert Selby Jr. It lost the original case in the Old Bailey but won on appeal two years later after a successful argument by a young John Mortimer.
But Mrs. Boyars, who by then had married her second husband, Arthur Boyars, fell out with her business partner. Taking along the firm's big money-maker, Ken Kesey's "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," among other things, she eventually set up Marion Boyars Publishers, with offices in London and on East 39th Street in Manhattan.
She published about 25 new books a year, becoming a fixture at the annual Frankfurt Book Fair and mining world literature for anything worthy of publication in English.
Mrs. Boyars formed close friendships with many of her authors. When Michael Ondaatje -- who by then was published by another company -- won the Booker Prize for "The English Patient" in 1992, he publicly thanked her for helping to start his career.
She is survived by Mr. Boyars and her two daughters, Susan Quateman of Beverly, Mass., and Catheryn Kilgarriss of London, who is now managing her publishing house.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: February 11, 1999, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary last Thursday about Marion Boyars, an independent publisher with offices in London and New York, misspelled the surname of her first husband. He was George Lobbenberg, not Lobbenburg. The obituary also misspelled the surname of one of her daughters. She is Catheryn Kilgarriff, not Kilgarriss.
