HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.
 
Now Playing
* "AFFLICTION," starring Nick Nolte, James Coburn, Willem Dafoe, Sissy Spacek and Mary Beth Hurt. Directed by Paul Schrader (R, 114 minutes). Mr. Nolte is devastating in the performance of his career, as Wade Whitehouse, a New Hampshire loner fighting a losing battle with demons from his past. Foremost among them: Mr. Coburn, terrifyingly authentic as the drunken, abusive father who long ago cowed his sons into submission. As directed by Mr. Schrader, this pure, unfettered adaptation of Russell Banks's novel starts on a deceptively ordinary note, then escalates into inexorable fury. Every little detail matters. Ms. Spacek and Ms. Hurt expertly play the women who trigger Wade's crisis (Janet Maslin). 

* "ANOTHER DAY IN PARADISE," starring James Woods and Melanie Griffith. Directed by Larry Clark (R, 101 minutes). From the director of the bruising and ominous "Kids," this vibrant, unapologetically seedy road movie is a virtual day at the beach. Mr. Clark's second feature may not have the sting of his first, but it comes closer to establishing him as William S. Burroughs with a swooping, pivoting movie camera, bringing bizarrely innocent enthusiasm to material that might otherwise ooze druggy shock value, and making decadence as basic as the weather. Mr. Woods, as a junkie, thief and absurdly unlikely father figure, revels in this full-throttle role (Maslin).
 
"AT FIRST SIGHT," starring Val Kilmer and Mira Sorvino. Directed by Irwin Winkler (PG-13, 128 minutes). In this overlong and often desperately banal version of a case study reported by Dr. Oliver Sacks, Mr. Kilmer plays a man whose nearly lifelong blindness was suddenly alleviated by surgery. Ms. Sorvino plays the bright-eyed New York career woman who falls in love with him, then urges him to change his once-peaceful life. But the film brings little more than case-study data to communicating how this man's restored sight affected him, or what made it a mixed blessing. Sample dialogue: "Have you ever listened to the rain? I mean, really listened?" (Maslin).
 
* "CENTRAL STATION," starring Fernanda Montenegro, Vinicius de Oliveira and Marilia Pera. Directed by Walter Salles (R, 115 minutes). In this quiet, luminous Brazilian gem, a joyless older woman crosses paths with an orphaned young boy. There's plenty of room for sentimentality here, but the wonder of Mr. Salles's film is all in the telling. As these characters develop a fractious bond, then embark on a road trip that takes them vividly to Brazil's hinterlands in search of the boy's father, Mr. Salles brings great tenderness and surprise to the events that punctuate their journey. Ms. Montenegro's tough bravura performance was one of last year's very best (Maslin).
 
* "A CIVIL ACTION," starring John Travolta, Robert Duvall and William H. Macy. Directed by Steven Zaillian (PG-13, 120 minutes). This story of a David-Goliath lawsuit against industrial polluters, with Mr. Travolta first-rate as an ambulance chaser who develops a conscience, could have been business as usual in the legal thriller genre. But Mr. Zaillian's keenly observed, beautifully acted film, based on Jonathan Harr's nonfiction best seller about a case in Woburn, Mass., doesn't follow familiar formulas. It follows all the surprises and frustrations of a story that was never black and white and is all the better for its shades of gray. Mr. Duvall is outstanding as a corporate lawyer full of wily tricks (Maslin).
 
* "THE GENERAL," starring Brendan Gleeson and Jon Voight. Directed by John Boorman (not rated, 125 minutes). Mr. Boorman's best and most stylish film in years is the deftly told story of Martin Cahill. Nicknamed the General for his crime-plotting strategies, this Irish gang leader and master thief is played with splendid brio by Mr. Gleeson. Photographed gorgeously in black and white, the film tells of his elaborate art and jewel heists, his unusual domestic arrangement with his wife's sister and his singular difficulties with the I.R.A. and the law. Mr. Voight is outstandingly good as the police detective who knows all of Cahill's tricks (Maslin).
 
* "HILARY AND JACKIE," starring Emily Watson and Rachel Griffiths. Directed by Anand Tucker (R, 121 minutes). The parallel biographies of the brilliant cellist Jacqueline du Pre (Ms. Watson), who contracted multiple sclerosis at the height of her career, and her slightly older sister, Hilary (Ms. Griffiths), a talented flutist who gave up a professional career to marry and be "ordinary," is one of the most insightful studies of sibling rivalry ever filmed. Jacqueline may have won fame and glory, the movie says, but she remained a desperately needy emotional child who had to have everything Hilary had (including Hilary's husband). The film is structured like a concerto, in three movements, the last of which ends with Jackie's harrowing death in her sister's arms. The drama is deepened by a soundtrack that makes expert use of Jacqueline's signature piece, the Elgar Cello Concerto in E minor. Ms. Watson's Jacqueline flames with an almost scary intensity (Stephen Holden).
 
* "MY NAME IS JOE," starring Peter Mullan and Louise Goodall. Directed by Ken Loach (R, 92 minutes). A splendid, feisty performance by Mr. Mullan energizes this film about a recovering alcoholic trying to rebuild his life. With humor and scrappy intensity, Joe throws himself into coaching young athletes and embarking tenuously on a love affair, only to find the expected challenges to his new sobriety everywhere. Mr. Loach's commitment to delineating social issues is accentuated by the way his star breathes life into Joe and makes viewers root for his success. Special bonus: this film breaks the brogue-and-burr barrier by including helpful subtitles for the overlapping, heavily Scottish-accented dialogue (Maslin).
 
"PATCH ADAMS," starring Robin Williams and Monica Potter. Directed by Tom Shadyac (PG-13, 110 minutes). As a maverick doctor intent on making terminal patients laugh, Mr. Williams delivers a little clowning and a lot of maudlin feel-good sentiment, along with vulgarity left over from the filmmaker's "Ace Ventura" days. He also spends a lot of time being congratulated for his good works, as the film's minor players are kept busy marveling at his antics. The real-life story of this doctor may sound like a fine excuse for Mr. Williams to cut loose, but the film version proves narrow and predictable. Ms. Potter, with a nostrilly resemblance to Julia Roberts, figures in a romantic subplot with a bizarre twist (Maslin).
 
* "THE PRINCE OF EGYPT," starring the voices of Val Kilmer, Ralph Fiennes, Sandra Bullock and Michelle Pfeiffer. Directed by Brenda Chapman, Steve Hickner and Simon Wells (PG, 93 minutes). First came the great expectations for this animated magnum opus from Dreamworks. Then came reality, in a film struggling mightily to balance animated whimsy and biblical stature. The upshot is an admirably worthy rendering of the Exodus story, even if Moses must initially be seen as a playful young scamp. Biblical plagues and miracles serve as special inspiration for the animators' reality-bending ingenuity (Maslin).
 
* "RUSHMORE," starring Jason Schwartzman, Bill Murray and Olivia Williams. Directed by Wes Anderson (R, 93 minutes). A dryly hilarious portrait of the mogul as a young man, with Mr. Schwartzman a real find as its perfectly horrid little hero, Max Fischer. Max's prep school, Rushmore Academy, does have a faculty, but none of the grown-ups have anything like Max's natural authority. Mr. Murray is sneakily fine as the steel tycoon and Rushmore benefactor who happens to be on Max's own wavelength as they vie for the same beautiful teacher. A particular treat for its skewed, outrageously funny memories of a cutthroat boyhood (Maslin).
 
* "SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE," starring Joseph Fiennes, Gwyneth Paltrow, Geoffrey Rush, Ben Affleck and Judi Dench. Directed by John Madden (R, 113 minutes). A witty, sexy and merrily literate delight, with an exhilaratingly clever premise that only gets better as the film unfolds. The screenplay, originating as Marc Norman's brainstorm and turned by Tom Stoppard into razor-sharp dialogue reminiscent of his "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," dares to imagine whatever it likes about the link between Shakespeare's artistic passions and his mad yearning for a certain aristocratic beauty. Meanwhile, this tirelessly inventive comedy envisions an Elizabethan theater fraught with the same backbiting and conniving we enjoy today, and has great fun presenting the creation of "Romeo and Juliet," glitches and all. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Paltrow make a fine, tempestuous duo, and she gives the first great, fully realized starring performance of her career (Maslin).
 
* "A SIMPLE PLAN," starring Bill Paxton, Billy Bob Thornton and Bridget Fonda. Directed by Sam Raimi (R, 120 minutes). This onetime cult horror director makes a flawless transition to mainstream storytelling with a quietly devastating thriller. And its fine cast plays out the consequences of a harmless-sounding error in judgment that winds up leveling everything in its path. The catalyst is $4.4 million that literally falls out of the sky, and Scott Smith's story proves how deadly the morality of expediency can become. When you get the shivers watching this wintry tale, which features an especially memorable performance from Mr. Thornton, it won't be from the cold (Maslin).
 
"STEPMOM," starring Susan Sarandon, Julia Roberts and Ed Harris. Directed by Chris Columbus (PG-13, 120 minutes). A man's ex-wife and new girlfriend lock horns over who can be nicer to his two children, in a sudsy story made livelier by its two female stars, both in appealingly high gear. Ms. Roberts plays the nicest person ever to wear black to a downtown photo shoot, while the especially fiery Ms. Sarandon plays the suburban mother as mama lion. Even when the prospect of mortality looms, the story manages to maintain its big, lavish look and peculiar (under the circumstances) sense of fun. As in "Home Alone," Mr. Columbus directs with sunny indifference to reality, medical, economic or otherwise (Maslin).
 
"STILL CRAZY," starring Stephen Rea, Billy Connolly, Bill Nighy, Helena Bergstrom, Juliet Aubrey and Jimmy Nail. Directed by Brian Gibson (R, 96 minutes). Twenty years after they last dropped acid in a Druid circle, the members of an over-the-hill English rock band try to reunite, and the results are meant to be both funny and heartwarming. Not an easy mix, unless Spinal Tap really is your idea of a band that needs a second chance. Despite an extremely likable cast that fits right into the spirit of things, the director of "What's Love Got to Do With It" and the writers of "The Commitments" don't drum up enough drama or sustained humor to make the most of their premise. The cast is cheery and game, the material hit-or-miss (Maslin).
 
"THE THIN RED LINE," starring Jim Caviezel, Ben Chaplin, Nick Nolte, Sean Penn and Woody Harrelson. Directed by Terrence Malick (R, 166 minutes). From the first frame of this huge, drifting war epic loosely derived from James Jones's Guadalcanal novel, it's viscerally clear that Mr. Malick is back. The exquisite, oddly detached visual style that made "Badlands" and "Days of Heaven" the most beautiful films of the 1970's is instantly apparent here, even if the narrative vagueness and brooding voice-overs are also familiar. The film sprawls, gets lost and occasionally delivers visual poetry, the kind that could have been greatly helped by tighter editing. Bottom line: no one who admired Mr. Malick's early work should miss this. But those expecting anything simple will not find it here (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
"JAZZ ON FILM." Coming of age together in the 20th century, jazz and film make an ideal union of artistic mediums. And beginning tomorrow, they will be celebrated at the American Museum of the Moving Image in a festival that ranges over a variety of filmmaking styles and draws on more than 60 years of Hollywood and independent features, documentaries and animated films about jazz. At 2 P.M. tomorrow, the legendary saxophonist Illinois Jacquet will be on hand for the initial screening, "Texas Tenor: The Illinois Jacquet Story" (1992), the fashion photographer Arthur Elgort's collage of tour film, archival material and revealing interviews. At 4:30 P.M., the attraction is Bruce Ricker's "Last of the Blue Devils," built around a Kansas City reunion of great jazz and blues musicians, including Count Basie. Admission to the series, continuing through Feb. 28 at the museum, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue in Astoria, Queens, is $8.50 for adults, $5.50 for people over 65 and students with I.D., $4.50 for children from 5 to 18 and free for children under 4. Information: (718) 784-0077 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Climbed 2.3% in December

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
New orders to American factories rebounded in December but the gain was not enough to prevent 1998 from ending as the weakest year for manufacturing since the recession of 1991.
Orders jumped 2.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $343.5 billion in December, the Commerce Department said today. It was the biggest increase in 13 months. 
 Orders for industrial machinery and equipment rose 7.4 percent; for electronic and electrical equipment, 3.6 percent, and for transportation equipment, 1.8 percent.
New orders to factories for all of 1998 -- $4.03 trillion -- were just 2.1 percent higher than the year before. That compared with a healthy 5.4 percent gain in 1997 and was the weakest year since orders declined 2.3 percent seven years earlier.
But orders for computers and office equipment surged 19.4 percent, the biggest gain in 14 years. And orders for communications equipment jumped 12.1 percent.
Orders for durable goods -- big-ticket items expected to last three or more years -- rose 3.6 percent and orders for nondurable goods rose just two-tenths of 1 percent.
The big increase, over all, for orders in December suggests that the economy carried considerable momentum as it moved into 1999.
In another sign of that, the Labor Department said today that the number of Americans filing first-time applications for unemployment benefits fell by 9,000, to 292,000 last week. The decline, the fourth in five weeks, cut the seasonally adjusted number of jobless claims in the week ended last Saturday to the lowest level since the week ended Dec. 19.

HEADLINE: Fed Takes Steps to Make Its Activities More Open

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve disclosed today that it would be somewhat more open about its secretive policy deliberations, saying it would signal more clearly whether it was leaning toward higher or lower interest rates.
Continuing a glacial drift toward greater disclosure, the central bank's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee said it had made two changes to the way it announced and described actions. 
 The committee decided to drop oblique wording in the policy statement adopted at each meeting about the likelihood of future rate increases or decreases and replace it with a more direct statement.
Instead of forcing readers to discern its leanings from the juxtaposition of the words "would" and "might" in describing the possible course of rate changes -- a code long familiar to Fed watchers -- the central bank today released its policy statement from December, proclaiming its neutrality on future rate changes in something approaching plain English.
"In view of the evidence currently available, the committee believes that prospective developments are equally likely to warrant an increase or decrease" in the Fed's key interest rate, the policy statement said.
The committee also decided that it would from time to time accelerate disclosure of any change in its assessment of the likely direction of rate changes. Rather than disclosing any change in its "bias" toward higher or lower rates only after the following meeting, as is the practice now, the Fed would make the change public immediately on those occasions when it wanted its intentions made clear to the public and the financial markets right away.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has been wrestling for years with questions about the institution's traditional secrecy. He has been seeking to protect the confidentiality of the central bank's policy debates.
Yet he also wants to assuage critics in Congress who feel the Fed should be more accountable and might push for more sweeping changes if the Fed does not act on its own to become more open. And most of all Mr. Greenspan wants to avoid surprising the financial markets, whose ups and downs can have a pronounced effect on the economy.
The last major change in the Fed's disclosure practices was in February 1995, when the central bank began issuing a statement after each policy meeting, indicating whether the committee had made any change in monetary policy. Before that, changes only became apparent as the Fed moved to carry them out the next day by buying or selling Government securities to move rates up or down.
Eager to avoid destabilizing policy surprises, Mr. Greenspan has taken to giving the markets relatively clear warnings of changes in the direction of interest rates. Last September, he first hinted at and then almost flatly promised rate reductions in the weeks before the Fed embarked on three rate cuts.
The latest changes were adopted at the Fed's Dec. 22 meeting and disclosed today in the minutes of that session. The Fed met again on Tuesday and Wednesday but did not announce a change in rates or bias.
The Fed voted unanimously to hold rates steady and maintain a neutral outlook in December, seeing equal possibilities that rates might need to rise or fall in coming months, the minutes showed. Speculation among economists has been that the Fed might have considered adopting a bias toward higher rates this week, given the robust growth of the economy and rising risk of inflation.
That the Fed remained silent this week about its policy bias suggested that it had decided to remain in neutral. But because of the wiggle room the new policy leaves -- it explicitly states that not every change in the bias will be made public -- the markets remained almost as much in the dark as they would have if the new policy had not been adopted.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 383 words

HEADLINE: 'Tobacco Bonds' for Schools

 BODY:
In a city of crumbling bridges, aging water pipes and antique computer systems, there is no more urgent capital priority than building and repairing schools. Last week Mayor Rudolph Giuliani proposed a novel way of tapping an additional $2.5 billion for New York City schools in the next five years. He wants to create an agency that would issue bonds for school construction, paying them off with revenues expected from the settlement of New York State's lawsuit against tobacco companies. Although we were initially skeptical, the idea is worth pursuing if its problems can be resolved.
The need for school expansion and repairs is beyond doubt. The Board of Education has proposed a five-year, $11 billion program to create room for a flood of new students and to upgrade existing facilities. In his latest budget, Mr. Giuliani said the city would supply $6 billion of the funds, with the rest coming from Federal and state sources. But the city faces a problem in finding the money, as it is at the limits of its borrowing capacity. The State Constitution limits debt to a fixed percentage of the value of the city's real property, a ceiling reached a couple of years ago. The State Legislature in 1997 created a new city agency with borrowing authority, but now even this agency is close to its cap. 
 Rather than ask the Legislature to increase the cap for this agency, Mr. Giuliani wants the city to create another new corporation to issue $2.5 billion in bonds, secured by $6.7 billion in revenue from the tobacco settlement over the next two decades. Both the Mayor and the City Comptroller, Alan Hevesi, must investigate potential legal problems, including the current dispute over whether any of the tobacco money might have to be shared with the Federal and state governments. In addition, there is some skepticism in Albany that the city can create a new debt-incurring agency without legislative approval.
Ideally, Mr. Giuliani should have used the city's multibillion-dollar surpluses to pay down debt or pay for capital projects. Some worry that too much of the budget is being siphoned off for debt service. Still, if the legal and financial problems can be cleared up, tapping the tobacco funds seems a prudent step to rebuilding the city's deteriorating school system.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As Euro Falls, Key Interest Rate Doesn't

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Hurt by fears of an economic slowdown across Europe in the face of expansive growth in the United States, the month-old European single currency touched record lows against the dollar today as a series of interest-rate decisions reinforced forecasts that European rates would keep falling.
Resisting political pressures to lower rates, the European Central Bank, custodian of the monetary policy of all 11 member nations in the euro zone, left its key interest rate unchanged today at 3 percent. But there was still widespread expectation that the rate could be lowered a few times in coming months, said Michael Saunders, an economist with Salomon Smith Barney. The anticipation of lower rates was one reason the euro declined against the dollar in European dealings. 
 Outside the euro zone, the Bank of England surprised the markets with a bigger-than-expected cut of half a percentage point in its key short-term lending rate, bringing it to 5.5 percent, the lowest in almost five years. Dealers had expected a quarter-point reduction. The bank's monetary policy committee, which is trying to keep British inflation from exceeding 2.5 percent, said the reduction in the securities repurchase had been dictated by "the prospects for international activity and prices, domestic costs and consumer demand." It was the fifth consecutive reduction, reflecting concerns that Britain's slowing economy could be headed toward recession.
British rates have now fallen by two percentage points since October. The country's economic slowdown has been caused in part by a strong pound, which has diminished exports and reduced consumer spending.
Denmark, another euro outsider, also reduced its discount and repurchase rates by a quarter-point today, though for different reasons.
The Danish currency, the krone, is linked to the euro in an exchange-rate mechanism that is supposed to limit the currency's fluctuations. The Danish central bank said its rate cuts, the seventh round since October, were made because of the krone's growing strength against the euro. The move had been expected.
The European decisions came a day after the Federal Reserve decided to leave rates in the United States unchanged, with data last week showing the strongest American economic growth in two years. By contrast, the European Commission said last month that its earlier forecast of 2.4 percent growth in Continental Europe this year would have to be trimmed back. The commission, the day-to-day executive arm of the European Union, has not yet published a new forecast.
The interest-rate decisions illuminated not just the disparities between American and European growth, but also the distinctions between Britain and Continental Europe that, British officials maintain, preclude participation in the euro currency system for the time being.
While the euro zone's benchmark interest rate remained at 3 percent, British rates are still the highest among the Group of Seven industrial nations. At its trading debut on Jan. 4, the euro sold above $1.18, but today it was driven down in European markets to lows near $1.125 -- a fall around 5 percent from the euphoric first days, when investors seeking to build up euro positions sold dollars to buy the new currency. In New York later today, the euro improved somewhat, settling at $1.1328.
The fall in its exchange value reflected a turnaround from the earlier bets by currency traders that the single currency would strengthen against the dollar.
"Sentiment on the euro has turned very gloomy," said Kit Juckes of NatWest Global Financial Markets.
Despite the drop, traders said there was no indication that the European Central Bank intervened to support the currency by purchasing it, and some analysts suggested that the European monetary authority saw a weaker euro as likely to strengthen economic growth as European exports became less expensive abroad.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Falter, Then Recover a Bit on Fed's Announcement

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Bond prices fell sharply early yesterday and then cut their losses as investors tried to sort out several rumors, deal with new data showing that the economy is still strong and confront growing fears that the next move by the Federal Reserve will be to raise interest rates.
All these concerns mean that today's employment report could have a significant effect on bond trading. If job growth in January turns out to have been a lot stronger than expected, more investors will be convinced that interest rates, despite low inflation, are headed higher. That would touch off further bond selling and probably help push stocks lower. 
 "We are facing a situation where the Fed has threatened to tighten if the economy does not slow down," said Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates.
In late trading yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond fell 17/32 , to 99 15/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, rose to 5.29 percent, from 5.25 percent on Wednesday. In the morning session, the bond was off as much as 1 12/32 , and the yield was up to 5.34 percent.
One reason for the rebound appeared to be the indication that Federal Reserve policy makers, who left interest rates unchanged after their meeting on Wednesday, also did not alter their stance on prospects for future rate moves.
Some analysts had feared that the Fed's stance, which has been neutral, was shifted to suggest that policy makers thought their next move on rates was likely to be an increase.
But the Fed said yesterday that it would announce any important change in the stance right after policy meetings rather than waiting until the release of that meeting's minutes, which are published about six weeks later.
One rumor that set off selling yesterday concerned today's employment report. Traders said the morning featured talk that the Bureau of Labor Statistics had mistakenly printed January's jobs data on its Internet site ahead of today's scheduled release and that the report showed nonfarm payroll jobs jumped by 350,000, well above the 138,000 that Bloomberg News said was the consensus forecast.
A bureau spokeswoman said there had been no premature release of data. In November, the October jobs data were put out a day early on the bureau's Internet site. And last month, the Producer Price Index for December was released a day early.
Another rumor was that Japanese investors were selling Treasury securities, in part to make up for recent losses in Japan's bond market.
A more concrete influence on the market was the economic data, which were all strong and are forcing Wall Street economists to revise their growth forecasts upward for the first half of this year.
Factory orders jumped 2.3 percent in December, to $343.5 billion, a record. Also, retailers reported that sales at chain stores open at least a year climbed 8.3 percent in January, surpassing forecasts by as much as two percentage points.

HEADLINE: Besieged U.N. Commission Chief Will Not Seek Another Term

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Richard Butler, the embattled chairman of the commission charged with disarming Iraq of weapons of mass destruction, said today that he did not expect to seek another term as chairman but that he would strongly resist any effort to oust him.
In an interview today, Mr. Butler coupled his intention to leave when his contract expires in June with strong criticism of Russia, a permanent member of the United Nations Security Council. 
 Sergey Lavrov, Russia's representative, has led a fierce campaign against Mr. Butler and his commission, calling almost daily for his resignation or dismissal, saying he is unprofessional, untrustworthy, biased and impolite.
When asked about Russia's attacks on his integrity, Mr. Butler grew combative. Moscow, he said, was trying to divert attention from Iraq's violations of its disarmament commitments and repeated efforts to conceal information and material from weapons inspectors.
"Senior diplomats are asking: What is going on here?" Mr. Butler said. "Are the Russians really asking us to believe that if Richard Butler went under the guillotine tomorrow, that everything would be hunky-dory in Baghdad and Iraq? Are the Russians really asking serious women and men to believe that?"
Mr. Butler stressed that the true issue was whether Iraq would comply with United Nations resolutions and the pledges it made as a condition of the gulf war cease-fire in 1991. He is primarily concerned, he said, that Unscom, as the United Nations commission is known, return to Iraq to judge whether Iraq is developing nuclear, biological and chemical weapons.
Tension within the Security Council over both Mr. Butler's and the commission's fate has been building since Mr. Butler filed a report in December concluding that Iraq was violating its pledge to Secretary General Kofi Annan to permit unrestricted inspections. The report set off American and British air strikes and inspections were suspended.
At the same time, Russia, France and China, all permanent Security Council members, have been lobbying to remove economic sanctions on Iraq. The United States has become increasingly isolated both in its support for Mr. Butler and in its main priority, the insistence that sanctions be maintained until the Special Commission certifies that Iraq has disarmed.
The Security Council agreed Saturday to set up three panels to evaluate its relationship with Iraq. The United States, Britain and Mr. Butler have insisted that commission experts be part of the panel on disarmament. But Russia and Iraq have refused to work with Mr. Butler, or to accept commission documents as long as he is chairman.
United States officials today seemed intent on countering a growing impression among diplomats here that American support for Mr. Butler and the commission is weakening. James B. Foley, the State Department's deputy spokesman, said that Washington "supports Butler fully and thinks he's done a splendid job as chairman." The decision about his future, Mr. Foley added, "is his, and his alone to make."
Mr. Foley stressed that Washington would continue its air strikes against Iraq rather than permit Mr. Butler's many critics to dilute the commission's authority and create what he called a Potemkin Unscom.
Peter Burleigh, the United States representative, called Mr. Butler and his commission "heroes," adding that Washington is "very glad that Unscom will be actively participating in the disarmament panel."
Mr. Butler said it would be tragic if any future disarmament system failed to use the expertise of the Special Commission's inspectors on Iraq's nuclear, germ and chemical weapons. The commission, established by the Security Council in 1991, has a core group of experts who have been studying Baghdad's weapons programs for the past eight years.
Celso L. N. Amorim, the Brazilian representative on the Council, who will lead all three panels, has not yet selected the members. But diplomats here said they understand that while neither Mr. Butler nor the head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, a United Nations agency monitoring Iraqi compliance on nuclear weapons, would be panel members, the group would include experts and commissioners from the Special Commission.
Mr. Butler said he had informed Secretary General Annan yesterday at a meeting at his request that "my present intention is not to ask for an extension." But he also rejected the criticism of his performance and Russian calls for his resignation or dismissal, saying his removal would imply that he or the Special Commission had "done something wrong, which is absolute nonsense."
"If there were some move to arbitrarily dismiss me, I would be very resistant to this," he declared.
At the same time Mr. Butler, an Australian, said that after 30 years in arms control, his main concern was the disarming of Iraq, and that if new management would help accomplish this when his term ends, he would leave with pride in what he and the commission have accomplished. "No one is indispensable," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Rubin's Remarks Help Lift Japanese Bonds

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Japanese bonds posted their biggest rally in almost five months today, snapping a six-day slide as the highest yields in more than 18 months lured investors.
Bonds gained after United States Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin urged Japan to "look at monetary policy as one of the key tools available" to bolster the faltering economy. His comments spurred speculation that the United States would put pressure on Japan to act to curb the recent rise in long-term interest rates. 
 If not for Mr. Rubin's comments, "bonds could have fallen," said Masahiro Kami, a chief fund manager at SB Investment Management, which oversees 650 billion yen ($5.7 billion) in assets. "We'll keep a stance to buy bonds on dips."
The benchmark No. 203 bond maturing in 2008 rose 1.342, or 671 yen per 50,000-yen bond, to 97.121, the biggest gain since Sept. 10. The yield fell 18 one-hundredths of a percentage point, to 2.17 percent.
Mr. Rubin's remarks followed a jump in the No. 203 bond's yield to 2.44 percent today, highest for any benchmark issue since June 1997.
Mr. Kami, who bought long-term bonds maturing in about seven years over the last two days, said he expected the benchmark yield to range from 1.78 percent to 3 percent through March, when investors report profits and losses.
With the economy mired in its worst recession in more than 50 years and inflation absent, yields greater than 2 percent, about triple what they were just four months ago, could increase demand from investors like life insurance companies. They have to provide a guaranteed return of at least 2.5 percent to their policyholders.
"For us, an institutional investor, higher yields are attractive," said Naoki Matsuyama, a manager in the fixed-income securities investment department at Meiji Life Insurance, which holds 3.5 trillion yen ($30.9 billion) of yen bonds.
Adding to optimism were remarks by Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and the governor of the Bank of Japan, Masaru Hayami, that the central bank would not underwrite new government bonds.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Drop in Computer Issues Hammers Nasdaq for 83.34 Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Computer-related shares fell sharply yesterday, dragging the Nasdaq composite index down 3.3 percent, its biggest loss in more than five months, as Merrill Lynch cut its estimate on Intel's profits for 1999.
The skid in high-technology stocks reverberated elsewhere, but less severely, in a session also marked by frantic activity in the stocks of on-line brokerage houses amid temporary shutdowns for a second day in the processing system at E*Trade, the No. 3 Internet broker. 
 The Nasdaq composite fell 83.34 points, its third-biggest point drop ever, to 2,410.07. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 23.58, or 1.85 percent, to 1,248.49. The Dow Jones industrial average held up relatively better and even nosed briefly into positive ground in the afternoon before slipping 62.31, nearly 0.7 percent, to 9,304.50.
One measure of the wild swings in technology shares was Siebert Financial, a minor player in the on-line brokerage industry, which soared as high as 70 5/8 from Wednesday's close of 49 1/2 and then dived after the Attorney General of New York said he was investigating the ability of on-line brokers to process large numbers of trades. The stock ended with a loss of 6 1/4 at 43 1/4.
Other factors weighed on the market as well. Saying stocks had simply become too expensive, Douglas R. Cliggott, the top United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, recommended lowering holdings in stocks to 50 percent from 60 percent, putting 25 percent in cash and keeping bonds at 25 percent.
"Based on current 30-year Treasury yields and our guess at first-quarter corporate earnings, the S.& P. 500 is now 16 percent rich relative to our fair value measure," Mr. Cliggott said. To justify today's prices, he added, profits would have to rise 12 percent this year and bond yields would need to drift back toward 5 percent. He said such an outcome was not very likely.
Considerable money was also shifting yesterday from technology and other highflying issues into economically sensitive areas like the paper industry. Union Camp rose 3 7/16 , to 67 5/8; Georgia-Pacific was up 3 3/16 , to 69 15/16 , and International Paper, the second-best performer among the Dow industrials, climbed 2 5/8, to 44 3/16 . The best performer was another such stock, Alcoa, which jumped 3 5/8, to 86 11/16 .
"You see profit taking in the recently strong tech stocks, and some money flowing into cyclicals," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers.
Microsoft was the biggest drag on the S.& P. 500, falling 7 3/4, to 159 1/16 . Intel was right behind, falling 8 9/16 , to 130 1/8; followed by Lucent Technologies, down 7 1/8, to 102 7/8; Cisco Systems, off 5 7/8, to 105 1/4; General Electric, down 2 3/4, to 100 1/8, and Dell Computer, off 5 1/2, to 102 3/8.
Internet shares other than brokers were also pummeled, with Ebay slumping 39 1/4, to to 239; Yahoo falling 2 11/16 , to 337, and Amazon.com declining 7 3/4, to 118. "It was a pretty bleak day," said Neil T. Eigen, a managing director at J.& W. Seligman. "A lot of these Internet stocks have paused."
Advanced Micro Devices, Intel's biggest rival in chips, announced that it might report an operating loss for the first quarter after having been expected by Wall Street to earn 13 cents a diluted share. Trading was halted, and the stock fell 2 1/16 , to 18 7/8.
The biggest drag on the Dow, accounting for almost 40 percent of its decline, was I.B.M., which fell 5 11/16 , to 169 9/16 . AT&T lost 3 9/16 , to 91 7/16 , and J. P. Morgan fell 3 3/8, to 100 7/8. Morgan was one of several weak bank issues.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Malaysia Eases Some Foreign Investment Controls

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Feb. 4

 BODY:
In its first tentative step back into the global economy, Malaysia announced today that it would relax some of the sweeping controls on foreign investment that it imposed in September.
Finance Minister Daim Zainuddin said the Government would lift a 12-month moratorium on the withdrawal of foreign capital from the country. But to prevent an outbreak of capital flight, it introduced an exit tax that discourages investors from pulling their money out immediately. 
 The exchange controls on Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, remain in force. The currency cannot be traded outside the country, and its value has been pegged at 3.8 ringgit to the United States dollar. The Government will continue to strictly limit the amount of the currency that residents or visitors can take out.
Still, if Malaysia dug a moat around its economy in September by imposing capital controls, today's action was the equivalent of throwing a drawbridge to investors -- at least those with the right intentions.
"These new measures are aimed to encourage existing portfolio investors to take a longer-term view of their investments in Malaysia and to attract new funds into the country, while at the same time discouraging destabilizing short-term flows," Mr. Daim said in a statement.
Fund managers and analysts greeted the announcement, which had been widely expected, with guarded optimism.
"This is a positive thing, and they should be applauded for it," said Mac Overton, a manager at the MBF Unit Trust in Hong Kong. "But I'm a little skeptical. What's to keep them from doing it again if things don't go their way?"
Malaysia, which had been a magnet for foreign investment, became a pariah in the world economy when it unexpectedly cordoned off its currency and capital markets. Most disturbing to investors was the 12-month ban on withdrawing foreign capital. That decision locked in $3.5 billion to $4 billion in capital held by foreign portfolio investors.
Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said he wanted to curb sudden large flows of capital, which he said had destabilized Malaysia's currency and thrown the country into a recession. Dr. Mahathir cited Western currency traders like George Soros as the primary culprits.
Under the new regulations, investors will be allowed to withdraw money from Malaysia immediately. But they will be taxed according to how quickly they act. Those who withdraw capital that had been in the country for less than seven months will pay a 30 percent tax. The rate gradually drops to zero for investors who leave their money in the country for more than a year.
"When the Government first imposed the controls, everyone was afraid there would be capital flight after one year," said Razak Baginda, executive director of the Malaysian Strategic Research Center in Kuala Lumpur. "This is a mechanism to soften the blow of that one-year milestone."
Analysts said the plan had a good chance of working. P. K. Basu, a senior regional economist with Credit Suisse First Boston in Singapore, estimated that $500 million to $1 billion in foreign capital would be taken out of Malaysia in the next two weeks. But he predicted that it would be more than replaced by fresh capital from investors who had been avoiding Malaysia because of the controls.
Other experts are not so sure. Under the new rules, investors can move money in and out of the country without restrictions, starting on Feb. 15. But the Government will tax investors who withdraw profits. Like the exit tax, it is intended to penalize short-term investors.
"I'm sympathetic to a hot-money tax," Mr. Overton said. "But it still seems like the Government is going to have control over my money."
Malaysian officials have been laying the groundwork for these changes over the last several weeks. Dr. Mahathir met with a group of portfolio managers in Kuala Lumpur two weeks ago to gauge their sentiment about Malaysia. And he assiduously courted world leaders, bankers and journalists at the recent World Economic Forum conference in Davos, Switzerland.
Among the principal arguments Dr. Mahathir made is that the controls had stabilized the economy. By shielding Malaysia from the vagaries of the global market, the Government said, it was able to lower interest rates and revive commercial activity. Indeed, its central bank said today that the official forecast of 1 percent economic growth this year might be exceeded.
Prominent Malaysians acknowledge, however, that the controls hurt the nation's reputation and left it isolated. In part this was because they were imposed at the same time that Dr. Mahathir dismissed his deputy, Anwar Ibrahim. Mr. Anwar is now on trial on corruption charges; he may take the stand next week.
"There was a huge misunderstanding about capital controls," said Francis Yeoh, one of the nation's business magnates. "Investors didn't understand that this was supposed to control currency speculators, not long-term investors."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Mercedes-Benz executives express 'concern' with a longtime agency, Lowe & Partners/SMS.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE once-strong ties between Mercedes-Benz of North America and its agency of more than five years, Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, appear to be fraying after an unusual meeting at which Mercedes-Benz executives were described as having expressed "concern" over "serious" issues affecting their relationship.
The situation is emblematic of the increasingly fragile and volatile nature of agency-client relations as well as the importance of personal relationships between marketers and their agency counterparts. 
 The Mercedes-Benz account, with billings estimated at $125 million, is one of the most prestigious in the competitive North American automotive industry. After suffering declines during the recession of the early 1990's, Mercedes-Benz has bounced back, setting a sales record in 1998. Among Lowe's contributions has been the creation of award-winning campaigns that included an acclaimed commercial featuring the Marlene Dietrich recording of "Falling in Love Again."
But it seems that the client and agency may be falling out of love after a meeting that took place on Wednesday between top executives of Mercedes-Benz, a unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G., and Lowe, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. The meeting was disclosed yesterday in response to inquiries by a reporter checking a tip that Mercedes-Benz had dismissed Lowe, which has handled the account since November 1993.
"We have not dismissed the agency," said Donna Boland, a spokeswoman for Mercedes-Benz in Montvale, N.J.
Rather, she added, Michael Jackson, president and chief executive, and Joe Eberhardt, vice president for marketing, met with Lowe executives on Wednesday to "discuss the seriousness of the situation and express concern about two issues."
"We opened the door to these discussions yesterday," Ms. Boland said, "and there will be further discussions with Lowe next week.
"At that point in time, we probably will have something to tell you one way or the other."
Lee Garfinkel, chairman and chief creative officer at Lowe, confirmed yesterday that a meeting took place at the agency on Wednesday with the Mercedes-Benz executives, but he declined to discuss details.
One issue brought up at the Wednesday meeting, Ms. Boland said, was "whether there is a conflict with the Interpublic global alliance with General Motors after the creation of DaimlerChrysler." Her reference was to the fact that agencies like Ammirati Puris Lintas, Campbell-Ewald and McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising -- which like Lowe are owned by Interpublic -- handle G.M. brands like GMC trucks, Chevrolet and Buick.
The General Motors Corporation is of course a longtime competitor of the Chrysler Corporation, which merged with Daimler-Benz A.G. last year to form DaimlerChrysler. Chrysler agencies include the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group and the Bozell Worldwide unit of True North Communications.
The other issue discussed at the Wednesday meeting, Ms. Boland said, was "the current management situation at Lowe," including "attrition" -- a reference to the abrupt departure last month of Robert A. Kantor, president for United States operations -- and "the absence of Marvin, certainly."
That reference was to Marvin Sloves, who retired on Dec. 31 as co-chairman of Lowe after serving in that post for four years and as a vice chairman for a year before that. Mr. Sloves retired with the expiration of a two-year extension of what had been a three-year contract.
"The bottom line," Ms. Boland said, "is we are concerned about the current management situation" at Lowe.
Speculation about the state of relations between Mercedes-Benz and Lowe intensified with the retirement of Mr. Sloves because he had been particularly close to executives at Mercedes-Benz since his previous agency, Scali, McCabe, Sloves in New York, landed the auto marketer's account in 1992. The account came to Lowe along with Mr. Sloves when Scali, McCabe was acquired and merged into Lowe in 1993.
There has also been speculation in trade publications like The Delaney Report that Mr. Sloves, a hale man who still relishes the business, had sought to stay on beyond Dec. 31. Asked about that in an interview on Dec. 8, Mr. Sloves replied: "No, no, no, I never really thought about it. It was the end of my contract."
Mr. Garfinkel and Mr. Sloves had been co-chairmen at Lowe; with Mr. Sloves's retirement, Mr. Garfinkel became the sole chairman.
Mr. Garfinkel concurred with Ms. Boland about the subjects discussed at the meeting. One was "potential conflicts" related to G.M. and Interpublic, he said, and the other was what he called "management issues at the agency that existed in 1998."
In articles that appeared on Jan. 25, the advertising trade publications Frohlinger's Marketing Report and Adweek reported that Mr. Sloves was discussing with executives at other agencies joining them and bringing the Mercedes-Benz account with him.
"My understanding is that Marvin is not out there on our behalf," Ms. Boland said, adding: "We do not have a contract with him. Our contract is with the agency."
Among the agencies mentioned by Frohlinger's as possible new homes for the Mercedes-Benz account was BBDO New York, a unit of BBDO Worldwide. The trade publication Advertising Age reported this week that Pentacom in Troy, Mich., a unit of BBDO Worldwide, had been named to handle media services for Mercedes-Benz in North America on an interim basis as DaimlerChrysler examines a permanent realignment of media duties after the merger.
Another possible new home for the account cited by Frohlinger's was Foote, Cone & Belding Worldwide, another True North agency.
Asked on Dec. 8 whether the Mercedes-Benz links with Lowe were jeopardized because of his retirement, Mr. Sloves demurred.
"I don't think it's here because of me," he said then.
But now the account, with billings that represent up to 20 percent of Lowe's total of $750 million, may be departing.
The turmoil on the account comes despite the fact that Mercedes-Benz sold a record number of vehicles in the United States in 1998. Sales of cars and sport utility vehicles totaled 213,379, up 55.9 percent from 1997; car sales climbed 39.2 percent, and its sport utility vehicle sales rose 196.1 percent.
Last month, car sales increased 6 percent from January 1998, while factory capacity kept sales of sport utility vehicles even with the month a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Dipping Into the Social Security Bank

BYLINE: By Ernest F. Hollings; Ernest F. Hollings is a Democratic Senator from South Carolina.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Everyone in Washington has been arguing over what to do with the supposed budget surplus. President Clinton is calling for saving Social Security; the Republicans are pushing for a tax cut. Unfortunately, the surplus is a hoax.
The last time the Federal Government had a surplus was under Lyndon Johnson. President Clinton's proposed budget calls for spending $100 billion more than we take in. 
 How can that be? The answer is that the surplus everyone talks about belongs to Social Security already. In 1983 the Greenspan commission (named after its chairman, who is now the Fed chairman) proposed a payroll tax to build up a reserve to take care of the baby boomers when they retired. To make certain this reserve would not be spent, the commission recommended that Social Security be accounted for outside of the annual budget.
Despite current law, Congress has already spent the Social Security reserves for other things. As a result, the Social Security account is $730 billion in the red.
According to the Congressional Budget Office, the Social Security trust fund will grow each year by these amounts:

1999	$126 billion	2000	$137 billion	2001	$144 billion	2002	$153 billion	2003	$161 billion	2004	$171 billion	2005	$183 billion	2006	$193 billion	2007	$204 billion	2008	$212 billion	2009	$217 billion	
We should have a $3.2 trillion reserve in 2012, when payments to retiring baby boomers will start to exceed revenue. But because we will have already spent the money for other things, we will have to raise taxes or cut benefits to pay Social Security recipients.
To save Social Security, we must first stop looting it for spending programs or tax cuts. Last week Alan Greenspan suggested that the "surpluses" should be used to pay down the Federal debt.
The first debt paid should be that of Social Security. Once that is done, then we can legitimately debate the relative merits of keeping a reserve or cutting the payroll tax and putting Social Security on a pay-as-you-go basis.
We should freeze the budget and leave the "surplus" where it belongs. That in itself would help to pay down the debt, which would lower pressure on interest rates, stabilize the capital markets, add to the nation's savings and promote economic growth.

HEADLINE: Strip Club Open to Minors Loses in Reversal by Court

BYLINE: By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
In a victory for the Giuliani administration, the appellate division of the State Supreme Court yesterday overturned a judge's ruling that exempted a Manhattan strip club from the city's new sex-shop zoning law because it admitted minors.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani hailed the ruling yesterday, and the strip club, Ten's World Class Cabaret, at 35 East 21st Street in the Flatiron district, was padlocked by city officials last night. Lawyers for the city said they would go to court within days to close a second strip club, the VIP Club on West 20th Street, which had also stayed open by admitting minors. 
 Mr. Giuliani said yesterday's rulings would bolster the city's efforts to close strip clubs and adult video shops under the new law, which bars sex shops in residential areas or within 500 feet of churches, schools and other sex shops.
In a second ruling, the appellate division upheld the closing of an adult bookstore, Les Hommes, on West 80th Street, whose limited effort to feature pornographic fare in only 40 percent of its store was dismissed as a "superficial" attempt to skirt the new law.
"Both of these decisions are very valuable," the Mayor said. "They should give a lot of momentum to other cases that are going forward."
As the city has gone to court to try to close the adult video stores or strip clubs, lawyers for the sex shops have found legal loopholes that make them exempt from the new law.
But yesterday's rulings were a second day of setbacks for sex-related businesses. On Wednesday, a State Supreme Court Justice in Queens rejected a legal argument that lawyers for strip clubs had hoped would allow clubs with liquor licenses to avoid being closed under the law. Justice Arthur W. Lonschein ruled that state liquor law, which allows topless dancing, does not supersede the new law that regulates the sex shops.
The rulings means that strip clubs in residential areas are left with essentially one survival tactic. Following in the footsteps of adult video stores, they may be able to remain open if they restrict adult entertainment to less than 40 percent of their floor space. Whether the clubs can strictly divide their "adult" and "nonadult" business to the satisfaction of judges, as well as survive the drop in profits that would come with the strategy, remains to be seen.
That tactic is proving problematic for some. Two strip clubs in Rego Park, Queens, have been ordered closed after a judge ruled that they were not strictly abiding by the 40 percent rule. Wiggles, at 96-24 Queens Boulevard, was ordered closed last November after a woman performed a nude dance for an undercover police officer in the "nonadult" portion of the club. Goldfingers, at 92-77 Queens Boulevard, was ordered closed Wednesday in part because its "nonadult" game room was found to be regularly locked and not open to the public.
Some sex shops might also be seeing their profitability suffer.
A lawyer for Show World, the landmark strip club on Eighth Avenue near 42d Street, confirmed yesterday that the club has applied to the city to become a "virtual reality" center that will feature no adult entertainment. Show World has avoided being closed under the law by restricting adult merchandise to only 40 percent of its floor space.
Herald Price Fahringer, Show World's lawyer, said economic pressure was playing a role in the store's decision to change its business.
"The problem with Show World is that it's such a large enterprise that it's more likely to try to find something like that rather than continue operating at 60-40," he said.
Mark J. Alonso, the lawyer for Ten's, said the club would try to reopen by featuring topless dancing on less than 40 percent of its floor space.
Mr. Fahringer, who represents the majority of the 144 sex shops affected by the law, said several of the clubs are successfully operating under the 40 percent rule. "Other clients are surviving," he said.

HEADLINE: As Aid Is Cut, Hospitals Prepare for a Tough Year

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
After two years of cuts in government aid, a sharp increase in uninsured patients and the growing dominance of managed care, hospitals in the New York region are bracing for what many people believe will be one of the most difficult fiscal years ever.
And with recent proposals from Albany and the White House that would squeeze hundreds of millions of dollars more from local medical centers, hospital executives and many health care experts are predicting significant budget cuts and warning of possible hospital closings and an erosion in patient care. 
 Most likely to be hit hard, of course, are the city's public hospitals and others that serve the poor and are most dependent on income from the government health insurance programs, Medicaid and Medicare. Last year, amid rising fiscal problems, the public hospital system laid off more than 900 workers. And the system's president says as many as 1,000 more jobs are likely to be lost in the coming months, at least half to layoffs.
But New York's prestigious private medical centers seem deeply worried as well. Among the many that have already started to make reductions in their new budgets is New York Presbyterian Hospital, where every department has been asked to cut spending by 5 percent.
"I would say without the state cuts we would have had a difficult but manageable year," said Dr. David B. Skinner, the hospital's chief executive. "But with state cuts, there is a serious chance we will have major disruptions in patient care."
Those cuts, proposed last week in Gov. George E. Pataki's budget, would amount to $727 million to $850 million in Medicaid spending in the state. And this week, President Clinton said he wanted to squeeze $400 million more out of the state's share of Medicare.
So far, the dire prognostications from the hospitals are largely lacking in specifics. No hospital administrator who was interviewed was able to cite specific areas of care that would have to be cut, or areas of services that would certainly fall under the ax this year. That may be in part because it is too early to tell, and partly because administrators do not want to scare patients -- much-needed sources of revenues -- away.
In fact, the Pataki administration argues that, in decrying the cuts, the hospitals are once again crying wolf, and that they should be able to weather the latest round of reductions.
"To speculate on what will happen moving forward is difficult," said John Signor, a State Health Department spokesman. "But a lot of what the hospital industry is saying now they have been saying for the past four years."
But an examination of new hospital financial records shows that 1998 left many hospitals in the red or just breaking even. And the likely government cuts and other economic pressures strongly suggest that 1999 is not going to look any better.
While the hospitals are not yet required to close their books on 1998, the Healthcare Association of New York State, a trade group representing hospitals, recently surveyed more than a dozen hospitals and found that for the first nine months of the year, profits for the sample group fell an average of 1.8 percent -- from 2.24 percent of revenues to a razor-thin four-tenths of 1 percent.
Even before Mr. Pataki issued his budget, his administration was arguing that the hospitals were in far better fiscal shape. On Jan. 26, the Health Department issued a report -- based on data from 1997 -- that showed hospitals recording a whopping 42 percent gain in net profits over the previous year. But the report became embroiled in the subsequent, increasingly bitter debate over the Governor's health care plans, with opponents arguing that it was leaked to the press to provide political cover.
But it seems a technical accounting change in the way hospitals recorded income boosted the numbers significantly.
In a nutshell, hospitals were told to include nonoperating cash, which made revenues look fatter than they actually were. For example, it looked as if New York Hospital earned $82.6 million in 1997, but $65 million of that consisted of investment income and contributions from private donors to use for building, and not for use in an operating budget.
"The state used the wrong measure for looking at net income," said William O. Cleverley, president of the Center for Healthcare Industry Performance Studies, a health care data organization in Columbus, Ohio. "They should have looked at revenues made from patients, less expenses."
The hospitals are also at the mercy of large economic forces that go far beyond fine points of accounting.
The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 decreased Medicare revenues for hospitals nationally by $44 billion, or $3 billion for hospitals in New York City. This reduction alone peeled about 4 percent off net profit margins.
Further, New York has a high rate of uninsured patients. The number of uninsured under the age of 65 rose to 19.1 percent in 1997, versus the national average of 17.6 percent, draining many hospitals' profits. What is more, the city has a high percentage of Medicaid recipients, who have never been a great source of profits.
At the same time, managed care has taken over a significantly higher portion of the hospitals' business in the last two years, and many hospitals have seen reimbursement rates come down greatly. And they owe a lot of money -- 37 percent of the money invested in New York hospitals comes from debt, compared with the national average of 27 percent.
There are fears of further bad news from Albany: the Governor has said he wants to use only 30 percent of the state's share of the tobacco settlement for health care. And this spring, legislators will debate the state's continued financial commitment to graduate medical education and the charity pools used to help hospitals deal with the uninsured.
"The key picture was that the 1997 numbers were modestly better but still way below national norms, and secondly, there has been an increasing deterioration in 1998 and so far in 1999," said James R. Tallon Jr., president of the United Hospital Fund, a health care philanthropic group.
Mr. Cleverley's independent report ranked the financial condition of hospitals in New York state the second worst in the nation. And the bond-rating agencies that monitor hospital bonds have offered poor outlooks on several local hospitals in recent months.
Many hospital executives are feeling grim about 1999.
"In 1997, we lost $4 million and in 1998, we will have a loss of at least twice that," said Frank J. Maddalena, the chief executive officer of Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center in Brooklyn. He asked doctors to take a 15 percent pay cut this year, and trimmed staff.
At the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the city's public hospitals, a variety of administrative cuts are under way, said Dr. Luis Marcos, the agency's president. Of the jobs expected to be lost this year -- none of which will involve doctors or nurses -- about 500 will involve layoffs and 300 will come from attrition.
Hospitals serving a more affluent base have similar predictions. At Long Island Jewish Medical Center, "The situation is not good," said Dr. David R. Dantzker, the hospital's chief executive, adding that a reduced budget will probably result in less investment in the latest medical technology.
At New York Presbyterian Hospital, where $30 million worth of budget-cutting is now under way, profit margins fell from six-tenths of 1 percent of revenues in 1997 to one tenth of 1 percent in 1998, Dr. Skinner said.
But experts say there is a limit to how many administrative cuts hospitals can make and still stay in the black. "I think the evidence of the last couple of years is that hospitals have taken significant steps to cut costs," Mr. Tallon said. "But at some point there is a loss of services to people."

HEADLINE: Audit Faults Forest Service on Logging Damage in U.S. Forests

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4

 BODY:
Federal auditors have found that the Forest Service frequently fails to assess, prevent or correct environmental damage from logging on the national forests.
After inspecting 12 timber projects in the field from 1995 to 1998, the Agriculture Department's inspector general found that all were deficient and that "immediate corrective action is needed." 
 A new report on the audits found that the environmental studies required before logging was approved were poorly done, the rules to protect streams and wildlife habitat from undue damage during logging were not followed, and the steps planned to repair some of the harm after logging were not carried out.
The inspector general, Roger C. Viadero, reported on Jan. 15 to Mike Dombeck, chief of the Forest Service, that the review had found "numerous serious deficiencies." Agency officials generally agreed with the report's conclusions and recommendations.
The problems not only cause lasting harm to publicly owned natural resources, the report emphasized, but also cost the taxpayers money because many timber sales are canceled for environmental reasons, and the Government must then pay penalties to the timber companies for breach of contract.
The report put an official imprimatur on the kind of complaints that environmental advocates have lodged with the agency for years, and it was welcomed by groups that are suing the agency in Federal court seeking a complete halt to logging on Federal lands on the ground that it does more environmental harm than economic good.
"This is an extremely damaging report to the Forest Service's case because it shows that Forest Service decisions can be based on inadequate and incomplete research and analysis," said Brian Dunkiel, a lawyer for Friends of the Earth, one of the groups suing the agency.
The Forest Service said it was already moving to correct the problems, ordering every regional forester to send special teams into the woods to make sure its rules were being enforced
"This audit is healthy and it is representative of folks' growing concern about how their forests are managed," said Christopher Wood, the senior policy aide to Mr. Dombeck. "We are stewards of the public's trust as well as their resources, and it is unacceptable when we don't comply with our own environmental regulations."
The audit uncovered many problems in the complex paperwork that accompanies the agency's sales of timber on publicly owned land to private logging companies. The Forest Service prepares at least 2,000 environmental assessments each year, in which it is required to document in detail virtually every possible environmental consequence of each sale. In 1997, the Forest Service sold more than three billion board feet of timber for nearly $500 million.
The report also disclosed problems in how the logging was actually carried out. It documented instances of logging too close to streams, and other cases in which too many trees were felled or proper steps were not taken to prevent soil erosion.
Even as the audit was under way, local officials moved to correct some of the problems the inspectors found, halting several timber sales because surveys of endangered species had not been done and because too many trees were being cut.
That proved costly for the Forest Service, which in one such case had to pay $650,000 to logging companies for breach of contract. Over the years, cancellations due to improper environmental planning have cost the agency tens of millions of dollars.
The report had several examples.
In the Clinch Ranger District in Virginia, where clearcutting was usually prohibited within 50 feet of a stream, agency biologists doubled the buffer strip at one site to protect water quality because there were many species of endangered mussels downstream. But inspectors found a clearcut within 15 feet of a stream, and a survey found that in six of nine spots examined the buffer strips ranged from 13 feet to 85 feet. One result was excessive sediment.
In the Laurentian Ranger District in Minnesota, the agency permitted a 50-acre clearcut even though 30 additional acres were clearcut on adjacent county land. That oversight meant that the assessment of cumulative environmental harm was flawed. Similar flaws were found repeatedly at other locations.
The inspector general's report is available on the Internet at:
www.usda.gov/oig/whatsnew.htm

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
How Utah Committee Tried to Pull Job Strings

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN and JO THOMAS 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 4

 BODY:
For the past two months, senior officials of the Salt Lake City Olympic organizing committee have insisted they knew few details of the assistance and payments provided to International Olympic Committee members and their families. But now documents have come to light that show that two key officials were directly involved in at least one effort to find a job for the husband of a Finnish delegate.
Frank Joklik and James C. Beardall, both members of the board of trustees of the Salt Lake City bid committee, separately wrote letters to the Weyerhaeuser Company in Tacoma, Wash., seeking a forestry job for Bjarne Haeggman. The letters, sent in the summer of 1993 as Salt Lake City was attempting to win the 2002 Winter Games, were retained by the bid committee and made available to The New York Times. 
 In one letter, Beardall wrote that it would be "helpful to our Olympic bid effort" if the company would provide a job to Haeggman.
Joklik and other board members have insisted that they knew nothing about Salt Lake City's aggressive campaign to provide jobs, cash payments, tuition aid and lavish gifts to delegates of the International Olympic Committee whose votes determined where the Games would be played.
Joklik declined to respond when reached by telephone, citing the continuing investigation into the Salt Lake committee bid practices. Beardall, who is president of an Ogden, Utah, lumber company, did not respond to telephone calls seeking comment.
A Weyerhaeuser spokeswoman confirmed that the letters the company sent in return to Joklik and Beardall were authentic, and that Weyerhaeuser records did not show that Haeggman had ever been hired.
"It's extremely disappointing," said Ken Bullock, a member of the board of trustees of the Salt Lake City organizing committee who has been critical of its business practices. "If you have correspondence, clearly you are a participant in it."
Federal authorities are now investigating whether the Salt Lake City effort violated any laws. No one has been accused of wrongdoing. The correspondence between Weyerhaeuser and the committee begins in the summer of 1993.
In a letter dated June 29, Joklik wrote to George Weyerhaeuser, chairman of the board of the Weyerhaeuser Company, saying that he had met Pirjo Haeggman, an I.O.C. member from Finland, while on a visit to the Olympic Museum in Lausanne, Switzerland.
Joklik described Pirjo Haeggman's husband, Bjarne, as an "outstanding forester," and added that he "was wondering whether Weyerhaeuser might have any position for which to consider him." The letter is signed "Frank." It was written on the personal letterhead of Joklik, who was chairman of the board of trustees of the Salt Lake City bid committee.
In a response bearing a Weyerhaeuser letterhead, and dated Aug. 12, 1993, a company official informed Joklik that officials had explored employment opportunities in Russia but that it could not find "an appropriate match" for Bjarne Haeggman's abilities.
Two weeks later, on Aug. 26, 1993, Beardall wrote to Edward P. Rogel, Weyerhaeuser's vice president for human resources, asking whether a job could be found for Haeggman in western Canada. Beardall noted that Finland had 20 percent unemployment, and that "it would be very helpful to our Olympic bid effort if we could help Mr. Haeggman find employment."
After Salt Lake City won the bid, Beardall was appointed to oversee internal auditing for the Olympic organizing committee.
A way was eventually found to help Bjarne Haeggman. Beginning in May 1994, the committee began paying him $3,000 a month, with total payments reaching $30,000 to $35,000, a bid committee official said.
According to an organizing committee official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, the bid committee's files contain a document saying that Haeggman was working for Great Basin Engineering, a company based in Salt Lake City and Ogden.
Jay R. Anderson, president and owner of Great Basin, said he never employed Haeggman. Anderson said he did recall a conversation in 1993 with Thomas K. Welch, the bid committee president and a close friend, who asked if Haeggman could undertake an 18-month study of reforestation in Finland through his company.
Anderson said he sent a memo that same day to David Johnson, the bid committee vice president, setting out what he understood about the proposal, but heard nothing more of Haeggman.
Pirjo Haeggman resigned from the I.O.C. last month after it was revealed that her husband had worked for the Salt Lake City committee and that he had also been hired in a forestry job in Canada, while having his rent paid by the Toronto committee that unsuccessfully bid on the 1996 Summer Games. Attempts to reach the Haeggmans today were unsuccessful.
Joklik, who resigned on Jan. 8 as president of the Salt Lake City committee, has said that he knew nothing of the assistance provided to I.O.C. members and their families.
Previously, Joklik has said through his lawyer that the "details" of the bid work were handled by Welch and Johnson.
Details continued to emerge today that appear to show that gift-giving to I.O.C. members was frequent and out in the open. In July 1990, for instance, while Salt Lake City was unsuccessfully pursuing the 1998 Winter Games, the Mormon capital's first official visit by an I.O.C. member was made by Slobodan Filipovic of Yugoslavia.
The former Utah Lieut. Gov. W. Val Oveson presented a Winchester .30-.30, the rifle that won the West, to Filipovic, who died of cancer on June 15, 1995, a day before Salt Lake City won the right to play host to the 2002 Games.
Oveson said he recalled giving Filipovic a gun, but had no idea what it was worth and had no part in planning the presentation of the gift. During his eight years as Lieutenant Governor, he said, he frequently was the host for Olympic-related events and that gift-giving was part of his duties.
"I never felt anything was excessive," said Oveson, who is now national taxpayer advocate for the Internal Revenue Service.
Gov. Mike Leavitt of Utah, who has been critical of scholarships and cash payments made to I.O.C. members, proposed today a nearly 50 percent expansion in the number of board members on the Salt Lake Organizing Committee for the 2002 Games, saying that the board must be "democratized," by bringing in greater representation from the community.
 Meanwhile, Leavitt said in an interview that he was frequently called upon in Salt Lake City and abroad to present gifts to I.O.C. delegates. Often, he said, he did not know what the gifts were beforehand and was not told what they cost. A Salt Lake City bid official said the Governor gave such gifts as clocks and expensive luggage. I.O.C. members are prohibited from receiving gifts with a value greater than $200. It could not be learned whether the price of the gifts exceeded this amount.
"It's not inconceivable that I gave away luggage," Leavitt said. "I did whatever I was asked to do at the time I was asked to do it. I had no idea what the rules of the I.O.C. were. If there were in fact gifts given in violation of I.O.C. protocol, I would have had no context to know that."
He said he had not personally seen anything involving gifts that appeared to him to be unreasonable.
"I don't see that as being the problem here," Leavitt said. The problem, he said, "are these so-called scholarships and cash payments."
In a trip that was emblematic of the complex mix of interests in Salt Lake City's bid effort, the Governor and his mother, Anne Leavitt, traveled with six other passengers to the 1994 Winter Games in Lillehammer, Norway, on a private jet that the Governor said was owned by Leucadia, a corporation that owns one of the resorts that will be used for Olympic skiing and snowboarding in Park City.
On board the same plane, arranged by the Salt Lake City bid committee, was a cargo of $21,000 in used medical equipment intended for the son of an I.O.C. delegate from Algeria. Leavitt said he knew nothing of the cargo.
A member of the Salt Lake City contingent in Norway said that Leavitt's plane arrived at a small airport 90 minutes from Lillehammer at noon on Feb. 11, 1994, and that the medical equipment was unloaded from the plane in duffel bags.
An invoice included in Salt Lake City bid documents shows that medical instruments valued at $21,725 were transferred from Thomas D. Rosenberg, a prominent Salt Lake City orthopedic surgeon, to the bid committee on Dec. 23, 1993. A flight manifest detailed the same items.
Dr. Rosenberg was a close friend of Welch, the bid committee president.
The Salt Lake City committee files include a letter from Rosenberg to Yacine Zerguini, a surgeon from Algeria, about a possible visit to Utah. Yacine Zerguini is the son of Mohamed Zerguini, an I.O.C. member.
Also today, a Salt Lake City businessman, David Simmons, said he had hired the son of a prominent I.O.C. member from South Korea, Kim Un Yong, in the early 1990's at the behest of the bid committee. The son, known as John Kim, worked in marketing in the New York offices of Keystone Communications, a provider of satellite communications services that the Simmons family has since sold. Kim's employment was first reported by USA Today.
Kim Un Yong remains under investigation by an I.O.C. panel that expelled six members late last month. He is considered a possible successor to Juan Antonio Samaranch as president of the I.O.C.
