HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Computer Shares Decline, Sending Nasdaq Plunging
Shares of computer-related companies fell sharply, sending the Nasdaq composite index down 3.34 percent, its biggest loss in morethan five months. Shares of on-line brokerage firms also plunged after temporary shutdowns for the second consecutive day in the processing system at E*Trade and after the Attorney General of New York said he was investigating the ability of on-line brokers to process large numbers of trades. The Nasdaq lost 83.34 points, its third-biggest point drop ever, closing at 2,410.07. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 23.58 points, or 1.85 percent, to 1,248.49. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 62.31 points, to 9,304.50. Page C7.
 
Bond prices declined as traders awaited today's employment figures. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 5.29 percent, from 5.25 percent on Wednesday. C7.
 
Writers to Share Movie Profits
Columbia Pictures has agreed to share a portion of the profits on successful movies and pay some fees to a group of top screenwriters, a perk generally denied them in the past but given to an elite list of actors, directors and producers. A1.
 
Deutsche Bank Financed Auschwitz
Deutsche Bank, which is negotiating to settle claims with Holocaust survivors to gain regulatory approval to take over Bankers Trust, released documents that showed it had helped finance the building of Auschwitz. It was the first time that the bank has acknowledged a financing role in the death camp. A5.
 
Long-Term Capital Is In the Black
Wall Street firms that rescued the hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management last fall have made a modest profit on their investment, but will not make their money back quickly. C2.
 
Microsoft Plays a New Videotape
David Boies, the Government's chief lawyer in the antitrust lawsuit against Microsoft, has been pointing out technical questions and errors in a videotape presented by the computer software maker. So the company went back to the drawing board and videotaped a new presentation to demonstrate the advantages of integrating a Web browser with Windows. That tape was shown yesterday. C3.
 
Price Rises for America West
Texas Pacific Group, the largest shareholder of America West Airlines, has substantially raised the price for acquiring the airline by saying that it would go along with a sale only if a potential buyer bid for all of America West Holdings, the airline's parent company. C2.
 
Lower Rates Seen in Europe
Britain's central bank cut interest rates by half a percentage point and Denmark reduced rates a quarter-point. Although the European Central Bank left rates unchanged, the euro touched a new low on expectations that rates in Europe will keep falling. C4.
 
The Federal Reserve plans to be more open about its policy deliberations and signal more clearly whether it is leaning toward higher or lower interest rates. C8.
 
Russian G.D.P. Fell 4.6% in 1998
Russia's gross domestic product fell 4.6 percent last year, the worst decline in four years. Industry, construction and farming fell. A14.
 
Strong Yen Squeezes Businesses
Hitachi, the Japanese conglomerate, increased its estimate of its losses for the fiscal year and attributed the rise to the stronger yen. C4.

HEADLINE: Investors Stir Hopes of Revival in Catskills;
Real Estate Bargains and Casino Prospects Attract Buyers of Old Resorts

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
A mere two months after the closing of the Concord Resort Hotel touched off a new wave of obituaries about the Catskills, fire-sale real estate prices and renewed hopes for casino gambling have prompted a surge of investment in the old Borscht Belt.
The Concord has already been bought by an investment group that plans to spend $40 million to convert it into a Sheraton franchise and market it to a clientele more diverse than its traditional base of Jewish vacationers. 
 And yesterday, Grossinger's, the Catskills' fabled grand dowager and the career springboard for entertainers like Milton Berle and Eddie Fisher, was sold at a Federal bankruptcy auction in Manhattan for $6 million to a partnership that includes Louis R. Cappelli, one of the leading builders in Westchester County.
Mr. Cappelli is a major contributor to Republican politicians, most prominently Gov. George E. Pataki, who controls the fate of gambling in the region. Mr. Cappelli's lawyer, Joseph S. Rosenthal, said that the partnership plans to convert Grossinger's into a "five-star golf resort and spa" whose success would not be dependent on gambling but would greatly profit from it.
Much of the region's more upbeat mood stems from the improved prospects for casino gambling. In December, regional officials of the Federal Bureau of Indian Affairs recommended approval of a $500 million casino on land at the Monticello Raceway that would be given in trust to the St. Regis Mohawk Indians.
Although the plan still awaits the endorsement of the Federal Secretary of the Interior and Governor Pataki, this first Federal recommendation has attracted the interest of investors around the country.
"It's like a great stock that has tremendous value but isn't selling for a lot of money," said Alan Gerry, a cable-television entrepreneur who owns the muddy farm in Bethel where the 1969 Woodstock concert was held. "Then one guy recognizes its value and other people start putting in money. That's what's going to happen."
Those who speak of a comeback, however, do so with caution. There has been talk of a rebirth before, but those hopes turned out to be wishful thinking, and the Catskills has more than enough forlorn main streets and dilapidated bungalows to give the skeptics reason to gloat.
And those who know the region well know too that its future will be much different from its past. "It's never going to be the same," said Phil Brown, a sociology professor at Brown University who has recently published a memoir, "Catskill Culture," about growing up in a family that worked in hotels and briefly owned a small one, Brown's Hotel Royal (not the famous Brown's in Loch Sheldrake). "Whatever they can do will be good for this area, but it won't be this Jewish paradise again."
The most concrete evidence of a revival, the old Stevensville Resort Hotel, which closed nine years ago and had been destined for demolition, will reopen in May as the 355-room Swan Lake Golf and Tennis Resort Hotel. Its lobby has been fitted with crystal chandeliers, suits of armor and a 12-foot-long jade boat that make it as opulent as anything Catskills legend ever served up.
The difference is that it also has a nonkosher Korean and Japanese kitchen intended for a more diverse clientele.
In addition, the land once occupied by the sprawling Laurels Country Club was bought last month for $1.05 million by developers who plan to build a Las Vegas-style hotel and entertainment complex.
And in Bethel, Mr. Gerry is hoping to turn the old Woodstock site into a theme park devoted to popular music. Last year the site played host to a concert that drew 70,000 people over three days. This summer Mr. Gerry is hoping to produce four weekends of music.
Although developers are clearly hopeful that the St. Regis Mohawk casino will be approved, they insist that their plans are not dependent on gambling.
"If it happens, it would be frosting on the cake," said James Hoppensteadt, a former Sheraton executive and now vice president of Concord Associates, which bought the Concord in a bankruptcy auction.
In fact, although it may seem paradoxical, officials in Sullivan County believe that the new investment in the Catskills is largely due to the fact that hoteliers have finally stopped waiting for the gambling miracle that would ride to the rescue and revitalize their resorts.
Instead, said Jonathan Drapkin, the Sullivan County manager, developers believe they can succeed by broadening their appeal beyond the working-class and middle-class Jews for whom this area was once a summer paradise.
That is why the Concord's association with Sheraton is considered pivotal. The 1,100-room Concord, built in the late 1930's by a fussy hair-tonic magnate, was snapped up in mid-January for $10.25 million. In addition to qualifying for the Sheraton banner, the developers are making one small, but seismic, change: having the kitchen serve nonkosher as well as kosher food to lure more corporate business, like conventions.
An important catalyst for the recent flurry of activity is that prices for rundown hotels have hit rock bottom -- the Concord's value fell by half in a matter of months -- low enough so that investors can afford to put up the capital needed for extensive renovations.
The fatal flaw of the old Catskills was that it provided a style of vacation that fell out of favor by the late 1960's. The groups from which guests were traditionally drawn grew more educated, cosmopolitan and cholesterol-conscious and more interested in vacations in Tuscany or the Hamptons. They tired of three bloating banquets a day and found the hotel tummlers -- frantic round-the-clock jesters whose ranks once included Danny Kaye and Jerry Lewis -- shopworn and shrill.
But the upstart developers see opportunities in more recent generational shifts. Hotel developers believe the Catskills will have a fresh appeal to working couples who may find it difficult to coordinate three-week vacations to Europe and would like shorter getaways that are only an hour and 45 minutes' drive from Manhattan.
"Whatever worked against the Catskills before can work for it now," said Zev Scharf, a partner in the new ownership of the Laurels, which has only the moldering shell of its swimming pool to suggest its past.
Even before the recent spate of deals, Sullivan County, the heart of the Catskills with 70,000 year-round residents, had been making itself more alluring, promoting the demolition of moribund properties and advertising itself as a playground for fly-fishing, eagle sightings, golf and skiing. Main street storefronts have been restored and 15-year tax abatements provided to developers like those at the Stevensville. "What we're doing is nothing short of a total makeover," Mr. Drapkin said.
In April, Wal-Mart will open one of its largest stores in the Northeast on the fringes of Monticello, and sometime soon, Route 17, the spine of the Catskills, will be rechristened Interstate 86 and improved, giving the road an elevated status that appeals to distribution companies and out-of-state tourists.
Mr. Drapkin contends that these developments have occurred without staking everything on gambling. He said that earlier flirtations with gambling hobbled growth because landowners had insisted on prices higher than their land was worth.
Even so, the region's prospects are rising at the same time that the prospects for casino gambling seem brighter then ever. Governor Pataki's press secretary, Michael F. McKeon, said Mr. Pataki would wait until the final Federal action before announcing a decision on the St. Regis Mohawk casino proposal. But he said that the Governor believed gambling could be "a positive economic tool for traditional resort areas like the Catskills."
Robert A. Berman, a one-third owner of the Monticello Raceway and the chief executive of Hospitality Worldwide Services, a hotel developer that was an unsuccessful bidder for Grossinger's, is more upbeat. "I believe that on its merits the casino project will win approval," he said. "We're hopeful that construction of the casino can begin this year." But Mr. Berman added that he bid for Grossinger's in the hope it could succeed without gambling. "The two are not tied together," he said.
Mark Kutsher, the owner of Kutsher's Country Club, one of the last major hotels still open in the Catskills, has seen the best of times and the worst in the region, and finds himself smitten with optimism over the burst of activity. "We're in the midst of a resurgence," he said. "We're on the move again."

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths
WILLIAMS, EDWARD P.

 BODY:
WILLIAMS-Edward P., 92, of Crosstrees Hill Rd, Essex, CT died Monday, February 1. He was the husband of Linda Perkins Williams. He was born in Cleveland, OH on January 2, 1907, son of the late Edward and Mary (Raymond) Williams, grandson of Edward Porter Williams co-founder of Sherwin Williams. He grew up in Cleveland, OH and attended Univ School in Cleveland, the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, CT, Yale Univ, and then Harvard Business School. He worked at Sherwin Williams from 1932-39 then Prescott Paint Companies in various capacities from 1939-1942. He worked for the War Production Board's Salvage Branch at the outset of W.W. II. During W.W. II he served in Italy as a Lieutenant in the Army Air Corps. 1948-1949 he worked for the National Security Council, then for the International Security Agency Committee (ISAC), a small group within the Economic Cooperation Adm (ECA) charged with administering the Marshall Plan. In the early 1950's he moved to CT. and bought controlling interest in the Conn Water Co, where he served as President and CEO until 1972. In retirement he and his wife became avid world travelers, along with their children when possible. He visited remote parts of Africa on several occasions, Borneo, Australia, the Amazon, Antarctica, and many parts of the U.S. and Europe. He was an enthusiastic cinematographer, who enjoyed making and showing movies of places he had explored. When not traveling, he was active in community affairs in Essex, CT. and summer communities in Gloucester, MA and Blue Hill, ME. He was active in support of many social causes including family planning, reducing world overpopulation, preserving the environment, and encouraging sound budgetary policy. He published his memoirs, "A Varied Career" in 1998. In addition to his many other talents, he was a kind, loving husband, father & friend. He will be deeply missed by all. Besides his wife Linda, he is survived by his son Timothy Williams of Arlington, VA, his daughter Lindy Williams of Ithaca, New York & one grandchild. Memorial on Saturday, February 6, 11:30 AM at Essex Congregational, Prospect Street, Essex, CT. 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 736 words

HEADLINE: Brisk Store Sales Defy Usual January Doldrums

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Perhaps January is not just for clearance sales anymore. Still feeling in a spending mood even after a generous Christmas shopping spree, Americans continued to show interest in both liquidation and full-priced merchandise.
January sales in stores open at least a year, a standard industry measure, jumped an impressive 7.4 percent, according to the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index. That was up from 4.5 percent in January 1998. 
 The increases, which exceeded analysts' expectations by 2 percent to 3 percent, were particularly notable because they occurred across the retail spectrum. Discounters, as usual, led the pack. But everyone (with only a few outstanding exceptions), from specialty apparel stores to the previously beleaguered department stores, shined. "If your numbers weren't good, you stood out like a sore thumb," said Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Trend Report.
Because January is a relatively unimportant month for the retail industry, typically accounting for only about 5 percent of annual sales, the surprisingly buoyant sales were expected to have a positive but minimal impact on earnings.
Still the numbers were good enough that many in the industry believed it indicated that January was evolving into more than just a month to liquidate inventory. Jeffrey Feiner, a senior retail analyst with Lehman Brothers, said, "Up until the last years, January was a clearance month. Now retailers are bringing in spring merchandise earlier and having the month stand on its own instead of just dumping goods."
Continued consumer confidence was the main reason for rising sales. Mary Tolan, a global managing partner for retail with Andersen Consulting, said: "People just have a lot more to spend. Also they are increasingly being paid by variable compensation" -- bonuses, for example -- "that comes late in the year, so that could affect January sales, too."
The arrival of cold winter weather after an unseasonably warm December also played a role in pushing sweaters, snowblowers and other seasonal goods off the shelves. Susan Eich, a spokeswoman for the Dayton Hudson Corporation, said, "There was definitely a pent-up demand for cold weather apparel."
Discounters continued to barrel ahead of the crowd in January. Wal-Mart, the nation's largest retailer, experienced a 10.3 percent jump in sales in stores opened a year. Family Dollar topped that performance with a 13.1 percent gain. And Target, a unit of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, enjoyed a 9.6 percent rise. According to analysts, those gains came from strong sales of regular-price merchandise as well as sale goods.
Specialty stores also continued their run. Sales for the Gap Inc., powered by phenomenal performances at its Old Navy and Banana Republic divisions, rose 15 percent.
Ann Taylor Stores posted 13.3 gains. A spokeswoman, Jill Golden, said the company "was pleased with customer response to both our sale and full-priced lines."
The department stores, which in recent years have suffered by being neither as cheap as the discounters nor as chic as the specialty stores, managed to hold their own last month. Federated Department Stores Inc., which operates both the Macy's and Bloomingdale's chains, had an increase of 7.3 percent. Dayton Hudson department stores even managed to outperform its hot sister division Target with 11.8 percent growth.
Saks Inc., which owns both Saks Fifth Avenue and the Profitt's stores, had an 8 percent increase. A spokeswoman, Jennifer Mann, said that clearances had been carefully controlled. "There were no promotions beyond those scheduled," at the beginning of the fiscal year, she said.
The season's big losers were the familiarly troubled names. J. C. Penney saw sales in stores open a year slide 1.5 percent from last year. The midmarket retailer, suffering from heavy competition from discounters, has been struggling for nearly four years to redefine its niche.
Talbots Inc., whose results declined 13 percent, was also sorely out of line with its competitors.
Richard Baum, senior retail analyst with Goldman, Sachs, said that the most important result of the unusually strong January may be that retailers are well positioned for the next season. "We've learned that the consumer is still alive and well and that most stores have successfully cleared out fall and winter merchandise and are set to be busy this spring," he said.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
In New Jersey, Condos Sprout Along the Hudson

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
While rentals have dominated development along New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront for the last few years, they are being joined by a small, but growing, number of condominium town houses and apartments.
The first project to test the current willingness to buy on the waterfront is Jacobs Ferry, with 258 town houses on 14 acres at the river's edge in West New York in Hudson County. Eight months after construction began, the developer, K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, N.J., has raised prices several times, for an average overall increase of 18 percent, and has sold or is under contract to sell 212 of the two- and three-bedroom units. 
 Sales prices range from $250,000 to slightly more than $1 million, for larger units closer to the water, according to the developer. With all of the lowest-priced units spoken for, prices for the remaining unsold units start at $470,000.
Encouraged by that response, at least two other developers are building, or expect to start building, four more condominium projects in the next nine months. Hovnanian plans to build 187 additional units. Together, they will produce 751 residences, most of them priced from $165,000 to $450,000, though some will cost $675,000 to $1.2 million.
Among the factors contributing to the increase in condominiums is that banks are financing them, though on a limited basis, for the first time since the real estate debacle of the late 80's. That decadelong dry spell in construction has created a pent-up demand for condominiums at the water's edge, developers say.
Another factor favorable to condominiums is that rents along the Hudson's west bank have increased. They average $25 a square foot a year, or $2,150 a month for a typical 1,000-square-foot apartment, according to Robert P. Antonicello, president of the ACI Group, a Jersey City concern that tracks waterfront residential activity.
"With rents at that level and mortgage interest rates reasonable," Mr. Antonicello said, "developers are betting they can convert many renters to owners."
Moreover, people squeezed out of Manhattan, where prices for rentals as well as condominiums and co-ops continue to rise, also have begun looking across the river for less expensive housing.
Waterfront homes can cost 40 percent to 50 percent less than similar size units in Manhattan, Mr. Antonicello said, noting, however, that he is unsure of how the market will receive the higher-priced units.
All those factors played a role in Hovnanian's decision to proceed with Jacobs Ferry.
"The market for this kind of development has been good for some time," Ara Hovnanian, the company's president, said. "But now is a particularly auspicious time to build because the waterfront is successfully riding the tide of Wall Street."
The town houses have 1,240 to just under 3,000 square feet on two or four levels, and each has a one- or two-car garage. They are in 17 four-story buildings on the River Road site, which will also feature two outdoor swimming pools. Monthly maintenance fees are $197.
Mr. Hovnanian said the project has attracted executive couples who work in Manhattan and affluent buyers from the suburbs who are moving into smaller quarters and want to be closer to the city.
He said 22 percent of the buyers were from Manhattan, which is double the number the company anticipated.
Among them is G. Matthew Youngs and his fiancee, Deena Edington, who two weeks ago moved into their Jacobs Ferry home from a 600-square-foot rental on Manhattan's Upper West Side. "We're quadrupling our living space and after taxes are paying about the same per month to own as the $2,700 a month we paid in rent," said Mr. Youngs, 33, director of retail analysis for Ralph Lauren Childrenwear. Ms. Edington, 26, is an account executive at the firm.
In nearby Guttenburg, Hovnanian will start construction this spring on Bulls Ferry, 154 town houses of 1,450 to 2,300 square feet; prices will be comparable to those at Jacobs Ferry. Another 33-unit section of Jacobs Ferry is also planned, which will include 15 homes, with elevators, on a peninsula. Those homes are expected to sell for more than $1 million each.
Elsewhere on the West New York waterfront, the Roseland Property Company of Roseland, N.J., will begin work this fall on 210 condominiums in two buildings, one with 4 stories, the other with 12 stories. Prices for the units, with 1,100 to 1,600 square feet, will range from $295,000 to $444,000. Another 155-unit, 12-story structure is planned.
In neighboring Weehawken, Roseland, in partnership with Arcorp Properties, a Weehawken-based company owned by Arthur E. Imperatore, owner of the New York Waterway ferry company, will also start building 48 town houses of 2,800 to 3,800 square feet in June. The units, each with an elevator, are to sell for $895,000 to $1.2 million.
Both projects are part of larger mixed-use developments that will eventually include 6,000 residences. "We always envisioned for-sale housing as part of the mix, which the market is now ready to absorb," said Marshall B. Tycher, Roseland's president.
In Hoboken, Applied Companies is constructing a 12-story, 172-unit condominium that is part of a project called the Shipyard that will ultimately comprise 1,170 condominium and rental units. In March, the company will also begin work on 134 condominiums, out of an eventual total of 1,290, at its Port Liberte project in Jersey City.
Both projects will have one- to three-bedroom units, with 800 to 2,000 square feet. Prices will range from $175,000 to $450,000 for the Shipyard units and slightly lower for those at Port Liberte. Some of the Port Liberte units will be town houses with 1,900 to 3,000 square feet and sell for $325,000 to $675,000.
"As long as the market continues to be receptive to condominiums, we will continue to build them," said Michael I. Barry, a senior vice president at Applied. "We know there is a demand, but how deep it is is anyone's guess."

HEADLINE: Journal;
The White Panthers

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
Reasonable boomers can always disagree on exactly when the 60's died -- was it the day the Beatles' "Revolution" popped up in a Nike TV ad? -- but there will be no dispute about when the 60's were embalmed. It's happening this weekend on NBC, which has turned the decade into a sweeps-month mini-series that, however earnest, suggests what "Hair" might look like as a Disney theme-park attraction.
You can actually see far more of the 60's, in all their idealism and over-the-top rage, by looking at their legacy in our now waning 90's -- our most contentious decade since. The best of the 60's has been permanently absorbed into the body politic, from the principles of the civil rights movement to the skepticism with which many Americans view ill-defined military action. The worst of the 60's is also still with us, but, in a bizarre ideological role reversal, many of the left's most egregious excesses of 30 years ago have been co-opted by the right in the 90's, even as Bill Clinton sometimes appropriates the conservatism of Richard Nixon. 
 If you're looking for pure hatred of government and the "elites" that run it -- the anger aimed at Robert McNamara and the rest of the Ivy-League-educated Vietnam policy architects of the 60's -- look only as far as the anti-establishment barking of Tom DeLay, Bob Barr and other warriors of the Contract With America Congress that shut down the Government during Newt Gingrich's short-lived "revolution." If you want to find the kind of holier-than-thou scorn that 60's protesters once heaped on what they saw as the immoral "silent majority" who supported the Vietnam War, you can find it, too, on the right; the "death of outrage" amen corner apocalyptically decries the immorality and vulgarity of the current American majority who refuse to support the prosecution of the President. If you want to find a 90's music-and-pantheism be-in to rival Woodstock, seek out the Promise Keepers.
With the exception of the Unabomber, whose cryptic polemics ranged from vaguely leftist to completely nuts, almost all the mad-dog radical violence of the 90's also comes from the right. Weathermen-style 60's terrorism is the model for the Oklahoma City bombing, the Atlanta Olympics park bombing, the bombing of abortion clinics and the murdering of doctors who perform abortions. "Off the pigs" anti-law-enforcement rhetoric is also now a conservative staple, whether it's the N.R.A.'s Waco-inspired campaign to brand Federal agents as "jackbooted government thugs" or Robert Bork's call for elected officials to "simply refuse to comply" with Supreme Court decisions they find reprehensible. Mr. Bork's latent flirtation with civil disobedience evokes nostalgia for the delight with which Abbie Hoffman, Jerry Rubin and the rest of the Chicago 7 so memorably taunted Judge Julius Hoffman.
Conservatives aren't above trashing military leaders of William Westmoreland rank, either -- witness the efforts of Gary Bauer and others to impugn the integrity of Colin Powell when the general toyed with running for President in '96. Nor, like 60's draft resisters, do they believe in the glory of Vietnam combat. Steve Forbes, George W. Bush, Dan Quayle, Rush Limbaugh and Lamar Alexander, among other soldiers of the right, let others fight the war while they helped themselves to deferments or cushy stateside stints in the National Guard.
Despite William Bennett's boast that he once dated Janis Joplin, the radical rightists of the 90's do not mimic their leftist models of the 60's in drugs and rock-and-roll -- though they do seem to pore over the sexual passages of the Starr report as their predecessors once did "Tropic of Cancer" and the Kama Sutra. Nor, generally, do they emulate 60's radicals in championing the poor and demonizing the rich. But this, too, may soon change. Chatting with Larry King to promote his much-awaited new Presidential campaign last month, Dan Quayle talked up the plight of unemployed steelworkers and the hungry while knocking the "real rich" and "fat cats," whom he defined as corporate officers who collect stock options and don't work with their hands.
Who would have guessed that Mr. Quayle would push "power to the people," much as Marxist rebels of sometimes similarly affluent origins did on campus three decades ago? As they might say in the mini-series, maybe he's just on a bad trip.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Technology Issues Lead Market Lower in Volatile Trading

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Technology stocks tumbled yesterday and most of the rest of the stock market followed in a day of volatile trading. For the week, the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index was down 5.3 percent, its worst one-week decline since October.
Bond prices also fell as a stronger-than-expected employment report for January confirmed that the economy is barreling ahead and made it more likely that investors will face an increase in interest rates by the Federal Reserve later this year. 
 The Nasdaq index dropped 36.45 points yesterday, or 1.51 percent, to 2,373.62, and is off 4.85 percent in the last two days. It did trim its worst losses in the afternoon, however, bouncing back from a decline of 63 points, or 2.6 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average rallied at the end to finish off just 0.26 point at 9,304.24, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 9.09 points, or 0.73 percent, to 1,239.40. The Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks fell 5.07 points, or 1.21 percent, to 412.72.
In the bond market, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 30/32, to 98 17/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.35 percent, from 5.29 percent on Thursday.
Leading the decline in technology stocks were Intel, Cisco Systems, Oracle and Dell Computer. Investors seemed to be worrying that a new price war between Advanced Micro Devices, the world's No. 2 chip maker, and the leader, Intel, could cut into technology profits. Advanced Micro warned on Thursday that it might have a first-quarter loss because it had been forced to cut prices to compete with Intel. Its stock has dropped 19.7 percent in the last two days and closed yesterday at 16 13/16.
Cisco fell 4 yesterday, to 101 1/4, while Oracle dropped 2 1/8, to 56 3/16. Dell Computer, which hit a high Tuesday of 108 5/8, slipped to 100 7/16.
Douglas R. Cliggott, the United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, said that the technology sector just "went up too far, too fast, and this is truly a healthy consolidation." Even with this week's decline, he added, the Nasdaq index is up 8.25 percent this year.
E*Trade Group, the on-line brokerage firm whose trading system was down for several hours on Wednesday and Thursday, had a brief shutdown yesterday, from 12:20 P.M. to 12:49 P.M. Its stock fell as low as 45 1/16, and then rallied a little. But it still finished the day lower, down 4 9/16, at 48 15/16.
Judy Balint, the president of E*Trade International, said that fewer than 5 percent of its customers were affected by the trading interruptions. She would not comment on whether E*Trade would compensate investors for any losses. But she said that "from a customer relationship perspective, we will try to do what is right."
The volatility of Internet stocks was also reflected in this week's performance of Siebert Financial, another on-line brokerage firm. A week ago Friday, its stock closed at 12 5/16. Then it zoomed to an intraday high of 70 5/8 Thursday. But it finished the week yesterday at 35 1/8.
The problem for investors and analysts lately has been figuring out whether and when the economy might slow. As 1998 ended, many economists were predicting that economic growth would slow this year from the brisk 3.9 percent pace of the last two years. But in the last several weeks, economists have been revising their moderate growth forecasts upward as data from employment to factory orders indicate that the economy is not slowing yet.
Merrill Lynch has raised its 1999 growth forecast to about 3 percent or 3.5 percent from an estimate of 2 percent just two months ago. And yesterday's jobs data, which showed nonfarm payroll jobs up 245,000, almost twice the forecast, will probably prompt more revisions.
"All the data that has come in has suggested that the economy is more resilient than we had thought," said James E. Glassman, senior United States economist for the Chase Manhattan Bank. But the bank is sticking to its forecast of 1 percent growth for now, he said.
This unexpected economic strength may be positive for the stock market because it could bolster corporate earnings. In raising its economic growth forecast, Merrill Lynch also changed its outlook for earnings for the companies in the S.& P. 500, predicting 3.5 percent growth rather than a 5 percent decline. But much higher interest rates could drag stocks lower.
For bond investors, the threat of a rate increase by the Fed is not a positive. Continued low inflation, more good news on worker productivity and concern about the financial fragility in the rest of the world could keep the central bank on hold for some time, however.
With this week's losses, the stock market is having a more modest beginning to 1999 then it appeared just a couple of weeks ago. The Dow industrial average is now up 1.34 percent for the year and the S.& P. eight-tenths of a percent.
And it seems that investors may have the same feeling. While money is still flowing into stock mutual funds, it came in last month at the slowest pace since 1995, according to AMG Data Services. Net inflows totaled just under $13 billion last month. And in the first week of February, investors withdrew $2.9 billion from equity funds, according to AMG.

HEADLINE: Consumers' Debt Climbed in December

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Borrowing by consumers increased at a faster pace in December, led by demand for auto and credit card loans, Federal Reserve data showed today.
Borrowing rose $7.3 billion, to $1.308 trillion, after increasing an unrevised $3.9 billion in November. Before today's report, analysts had expected an increase of $6.5 billion for December. 
 Revolving loans, which include credit cards, increased $2.2 billion in December, after falling $700 million in November. Auto loans rose $5.9 billion in December, after increasing $4.3 billion. Other types of installment loans fell $800 million in December, after rising $300 million in November.
The pace of consumer credit rose at a 6.7 percent annual rate in December. That is up from the 3.7 percent pace in November.
Consumers are benefiting from low inflation, low oil prices, low interest rates, hefty rises in the stock market and the lowest unemployment rate -- 4.3 percent in December and January -- since 1970.
Economists watch the Fed's credit report to help them gauge consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic output. More people, however, have been borrowing against their homes -- through lower-interest home equity loans -- and the Fed's statistics do not track loans secured by real estate.

HEADLINE: Istanbul Journal;
A New Bridge? Not in My Backyard!

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Stuck in rush-hour traffic at an approach to one of the bridges over the Bosporus on a recent evening, a taxi driver cursed the Government for not building a third bridge.
"Two isn't enough for a city of 10 million people," he fumed. "We not only need a third bridge, but also a fourth and a fifth. Then traffic will run smoothly." 
 The Government may soon seek to oblige that taxi driver and many others who believe that Istanbul urgently needs at least one more Bosporus crossing. But reported plans for a new bridge have set off an outpouring of civic protest that mirrors the battles over urban renewal and highway construction that broke out in many American cities in the 1960's and 70's.
Protest is centered in the waterfront neighborhood of Arnavutkoy, which has evidently been chosen as the European terminus for the bridge. Residents say it would all but destroy their community. They have banded together to hold meetings, put pressure on politicians, print leaflets and even pledge to chain themselves to construction equipment if nothing else works.
Civic protest movements like this one are new in Turkey, where the power of the state has always been strong and all but unquestioned. One of the first emerged two years ago in the farm town of Bergama after a foreign-owned consortium announced plans to dig a gold mine that residents feared would harm the environment.
Since then, civic protests have delayed the construction of power plants in several parts of the country. But the movement in Arnavutkoy may be the first directed against a major public works project.
One difficulty that protesters face is that no plans for the bridge have been officially announced. What information is available has come from leaks and random comments by public officials.
The agency that designs projects like these, the Highway Directorate, is based in Ankara and operates outside the control of the Transport Ministry. It was established in the 1950's with the help of Americans influenced by Robert Moses and other planners whose style was visionary and dictatorial.
"In Turkey, planning big projects like this is always done behind closed doors," said Korhan Gumus, chairman of the Human Settlements Association, a coalition of architects and other specialists that is organizing opposition to the bridge. "The guiding principle is that ordinary people can't see the big picture and don't know what's good for the city or the country, so decisions have to be made for them. We have even internalized this approach and tend to accept it as the only possible way of governing."
Bridging the Bosporus, the narrow waterway that bisects Istanbul and separates Europe from Asia, is an ancient dream. The first to succeed in doing it was Emperor Darius I of Persia, who created a temporary bridge of boats during a military campaign in 512 B.C.
The two modern suspension bridges, one completed in 1973 and the other in 1988, carry a total of 1.1 million vehicles each day. Many of the drivers are residents going from one part of Istanbul to another, but there are also many trucks and cars making long trips between points in Europe and Asia.
Some opponents of the bridge say it will do little to ease traffic congestion because the congestion is caused by poor access roads rather than insufficient capacity on the bridges. They are pushing for a rail tunnel under the Bosporus instead.
Others worry about increased air pollution and damage to the esthetics of the Bosporus, whose beauty has inspired countless artists and poets. But the most intense protests come from Arnavutkoy.
For centuries Arnavutkoy was a multiethnic village where Greeks predominated. Most of the Greeks left under pressure in the 1950's and 60's, but the village retains the feeling of a self-contained community.
Along the narrow streets that wind among wooden Ottoman houses are almost everything one needs to live: fruit and vegetable vendors, butchers, cobblers, fishmongers, barbers, cafes and restaurants, a toy store, a hardware store and even a billiard parlor. Many shops display signs opposing the bridge.
"This village is a very special place, and it allows us to live a special kind of life, a life on the streets where people know and trust each other," said Ozden Danisman, an engineer who lives in a traditional old home overlooking the Bosporus. "These days we don't sleep and we don't eat. We just work against the bridge."
The secrecy in which the Highway Directorate works, coupled with the uncertainty created by changing Governments in Ankara, has made people in Arnavutkoy uncertain whom they are fighting against. No one has publicly defended the project or even officially confirmed that it is under active consideration.
But opponents have obtained what they say are maps showing the exact path the bridge and access roads are to take. Arnavutkoy is awash in rumors and plans.
"Our first idea was to block the bridge by filing lawsuits, but now we see that it is basically a political battle," said Caglar Keyder, a sociology professor who is active in the protest movement. "We won't be able to stop it in court, but if we get enough people on our side, maybe we can win."
The Islamic-oriented Virtue Party, which seeks to portray itself as a defender of ordinary citizens against the political establishment, has joined opponents of the bridge.
"A third bridge will not ease our traffic problem," Mayor Ali Mufit Gurtuna of Istanbul, who is a member of Virtue, asserted recently. "On the contrary, it will cause irreparable damage to Istanbul."
But rather than rejoice at Mr. Gurtuna's support, some in Arnavutkoy worry that it will lead secular politicians, who detest Virtue and fear its agenda, to back the project.
"We don't have a patron, someone on the city council or some big-shot politician, to make our case," lamented Nadir Turkguc, who runs a small photo shop in Arnavutkoy. "I'm afraid that our voices won't be heard and that politics will crush us in the end."

HEADLINE: Oil Industry Sees More Job Losses

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The United States oil industry stands to lose more than 17,000 jobs by this summer if oil prices do not rise above $14 a barrel over the next six months, an industry group reported.
About 24,415 jobs have been lost since the price decline began in November 1997, said the Independent Petroleum Association of America, an industry group based in Washington that represents small and midsized oil producers. 
 Producers are also shutting down wells that cannot be operated profitably, the group said, which could mean oil shortages later. More than half the oil and natural gas wells pumping in the 48 states excluding Alaska and Hawaii could be shut down within six months.
To date, the economic cost of lost production is $25 billion, the group said.
Oil prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange are now at $12.02 a barrel, 43 percent less than on Oct. 31, 1997. Companies like Texaco Inc. and ARCO have cut thousands of jobs to lower costs as oil prices have fallen to the lowest levels since the Great Depression.

HEADLINE: Government Plans to Track Internet Sales

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5

 BODY:
The Commerce Department said today that it would begin tracking sales on the Internet, which it called "a major indicator of the nation's economic health."
But even as the Government pointed to figures showing that consumers spent $9 billion last year on the Internet, it warned that growth of electronic commerce would wane unless shoppers trusted that personal information would be kept private. 
 "I wouldn't want people selling information about which books I buy, or what records I buy," said Robert Pitofsky, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission. "The Internet is probably going to grow, anyway. It's just not going to grow as fast until these concerns are addressed."
"Consumers have to feel as comfortable doing business in cyberspace as they do on Main Street," added Commerce Secretary William M. Daley.
Mr. Daley said his agency would begin tracking sales over the Internet separately from figures for catalogue sales. But he said complete figures for last year and this year would not be available until next summer.
The F.T.C. has criticized the on-line industry for its failure to protect privacy rights.

HEADLINE: Higher, but Hollow, Academic Standards

BYLINE: By Diane Ravitch; Diane Ravitch is a research professor at New York University and a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.

 BODY:
Almost every state is setting higher standards for students, which is a very good idea. Few, however, are doing it right. In New York, the state's Regents have raised the bar without taking the necessary steps to help students reach it.
The Regents approved new standards in every subject, but some were so vague that the State Education Department had to issue voluminous guides to explain them. They endorsed new teaching standards, but their main effect is to pile on more regulations and more courses in pedagogy instead of the subject matter that teachers must teach and students must learn. They redesigned the Regents examinations, which guarantees that teachers no longer know how to prepare students for them. 
 Until now, New York has had a two-tiered graduation system: students could earn the prestigious Regents diploma by passing a set of rigorous Regents examinations, or they could earn a local diploma requiring simpler tests. But this spring all 11th-grade students must take a new Regents examination in English language arts, and by 2003 all students will be required to pass Regents examinations in mathematics, science, American history and global history to receive high school diplomas. Unless dramatic changes occur very soon, there may be some neighborhoods where high school graduates are rare.
New York City students are at greatest risk. Only about 20 percent now pass all the Regents examinations. In some city high schools, less than 5 percent of graduates now earn Regents diplomas.
What will happen if 95 percent of those who complete 12th grade in poor neighborhoods fail to receive high school diplomas? What will happen if more than half of all seniors in the city fail to receive high school diplomas? Will support for higher standards evaporate?
One might suppose the State Board of Regents and its staff would have thought this through. Yet since announcing nearly three years ago that they intended to require all students to pass the Regents examinations, the Regents have done little to prepare students and their teachers for the change. According to the United Federation of Teachers, many teachers have never seen the state's new academic standards, and few have received training to enable them to teach Regents-level courses.
Even teachers who have seen the Regents' new standards are not sure what they mean. Consider the standards for English language arts. As originally issued, they consisted of four vacuous statements: "Students will read, write, listen and speak for information and understanding." "Students will read, write, listen and speak for literary response and expression." "Students will read, write, listen and speak for critical analysis and evaluation." "Students will read, write, listen and speak for social interaction." Although the document offered many examples of these skills, not a single piece of literature was identified as required reading.
When it became obvious that these so-called standards were useless verbiage, the State Education Department generated a 161-page document, which still failed to name any poem, essay, novel, play or short story that all graduates in New York should be expected to have read. Instead, the department supplied a list of hundreds of readings, pointing out that these were suggested but neither required nor even recommended.
In social studies, the great smorgasbord field, the state's new standards were equally hopeless. The standard for American history, for example, was simply, "Students will use a variety of intellectual skills to demonstrate their understanding of major ideas, eras, themes, developments and turning points in the history of the United States and New York."
The standards did not identify which ideas, eras, themes, developments or turning points were most important to study, and the State Education Department again had to publish a voluminous "resource guide" to make sense of the original non-standards.
In social studies, the coverage in every area is so extensive that neither teachers nor students know how to prepare for the Regents examinations. Global history, for example, spans the history, geography, culture and economics of every major civilization in the world. The range across times and cultures is so vast that no one can reasonably expect high school students to learn what the state now requires, nor expect even teachers to master the curriculum.
In all likelihood, to get pass rates up the Regents examinations in American history and global history will probably not ask students to demonstrate any knowledge of history, just as the examination in English language arts will presuppose no prior knowledge of any literature. Instead students will be asked simply to explain the meaning of cartoons, graphs, charts, short readings and documents that refer to history.
The union representing teachers in both the city and the state insists that teachers want a grade-by-grade core curriculum. Teachers want to know what they are expected to teach and what students are expected to learn. The state's learning standards do not supply this.
In contrast, states like Texas and North Carolina have successfully adopted academic standards that identify what is to be taught and tested in each grade, and these states have reported significant achievement gains for white, black and Hispanic students. The state tests are closely aligned to the academic standards. Schools get flexibility about how to meet the standards, and schools with more disadvantaged students get additional resources.

But for thousands of students in New York State, and especially in New York City, time is running out. To pass all the Regents examinations, they need well-qualified teachers in every grade. To know how to prepare their students, teachers need clear standards and a core curriculum. Yet the state has provided neither.
If this mess is not straightened out soon, large numbers of students are likely to pay the price, and the movement to improve academic performance by raising standards will suffer a terrible setback.

HEADLINE: January Gain in Jobs Doubled the Forecast

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Despite freezing weather across much of the nation and a financial meltdown in Brazil, the United States economy barreled ahead last month and created a quarter of a million new jobs.
The gain of 245,000 jobs in January, reported yesterday by the Labor Department, was twice what forecasters had predicted. And even with a heavy influx of workers into the labor force in January, unemployment stayed at 4.3 percent -- the lowest level in 28 years. 
 The Labor Department lowered December's job gain to 298,000 from the 378,000 it had initially reported. Still, nearly a quarter of a million jobs have been added in each of the last 12 months on average, making the labor market look stronger than at any time since the height of the Vietnam War.
That buoyancy has many forecasters, most of whom were predicting a broad slowdown just weeks ago, now saying that 1999 is likely to become the fourth consecutive year that economic growth will be well ahead of the long-term trend of roughly 2 to 2.5 percent a year.
"The American economy is the Energizer Bunny: It just keeps chugging along," said David Wyss, chief economist of Standard & Poor's DRI, who predicts the economy will grow 3.5 percent this year. If that happens, as many forecasters now predict, unemployment will fall even further.
Stock market investors shrugged off the jobs data yesterday, hoping that a strong economy would bolster corporate profits and easily absorb the effects of rising interest rates.
With job losses easing in manufacturing and with hiring robust in construction and services, the portion of Americans with jobs has leaped to a record of 64.5 percent. (In Germany and France, by contrast, the figure is below 50 percent.)
More than half of the new jobs last month were in managerial and professional occupations, leaving just two out of every hundred college graduates out of work -- most of them simply in transit from one job to another.
In parts of the Midwest and South, namely Fargo, S.D., and Raleigh-Durham, N.C., unemployment is close to 1 percent.
On average, the Midwest had the lowest unemployment, 3.5 percent as of December, the latest regional figures available. The West had the highest jobless rate, 5.2 percent in December.
And there are still some pockets of relatively high unemployment. In the New York City area, unemployment has fallen to 6.8 percent, down sharply from the 8 to 9 percent level of just a couple of years ago. Still, its unemployment rate -- along with that of Los Angeles and Miami -- is one of the highest among big cities.
Over all, the chief worry now is that things may be getting too good. Investors saw the specter of higher interest rates in yesterday's report.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned last month that he and his colleagues, who left rates unchanged at their most recent monetary policy meeting, would watch for signs that the tight labor market was fueling wage inflation. And while the broadest, most reliable measures of labor costs have held steady, the report yesterday showed that hourly earnings for production and other rank-and-file workers jumped 6 cents last month, to $13.04. That brings the rise over the last 12 months to 4 percent, well above the 1.6 percent rate of inflation and the strong 2.7 percent gain in productivity.
Executives in most industries are complaining about rising job turnover and the difficulty of finding qualified workers. According to a new survey by the Olsten Corporation, a temporary-help company, 77 percent of employers reported shortages of workers, up from 69 percent in 1998. Hardest to find are computer programmers, accountants and financial professionals, but entry-level sales, telemarketing and medical workers are also scarce.
The shortages help explain why businesses are again spending heavily on new machinery and equipment. Companies are not only substituting technology for bodies, but are also trying to replace skills with software. McDonald's, for example, now has pictures of burgers and shakes, not words, on its cash registers.
But what is a worry for Mr. Greenspan and a headache for employers is a terrific boon to workers, especially those at the bottom of the pay ladder. who have had the most trouble getting and keeping jobs, especially good ones. Unemployment among both black and Hispanic workers, already the lowest in a generation, drifted even lower last month. So did unemployment among workers with only high school degrees.
As it happens, gains for the bottom one-fifth of workers have been occurring for a while now, said Jared Bernstein, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute. He cites as an example young black women with only high school degrees, a group that typically has had extremely high unemployment rates. But the portion with jobs has leaped by 10 percentage points, to 58 percent, in the last four years.
"That increase is historically unprecedented," said Mr. Bernstein, who notes that the hottest topic now among scholars of labor markets is "why this recovery has been so good to folks at the bottom." The gains have come not just in jobs, he points out, but, equally important, in pay and training opportunities.
The sources of the strong labor market are not exactly a mystery. Troubles in the rest of the world may have sliced deeply into exports from the United States and caused job cuts in factories. But they have also indirectly fueled consumer and business spending by pulling inflation and interest rates down. Prices for raw materials and imports generally have fallen, intensifying price competition and prompting foreigners to snap up American stocks and bonds. And all that domestic spending -- on everything from computers and cars to new houses and furniture -- means more jobs.
In January, virtually the only areas with accelerating job losses were the oil patch and the mining industries, battered by the lowest commodity prices since energy prices collapsed in the mid-1980's. Makers of heavy machinery, which depend heavily on foreign markets, cut 9,000 jobs last month. But other manufacturers, namely auto makers and companies that cater to the construction trades, added workers.
Job losses for manufacturing as a whole have slowed sharply. Just 13,000 jobs, on net, disappeared last month, the smallest loss since September. The weaker dollar may be helping. American manufacturers are a lot more competitive at 113 yen to the dollar than they were at 147 yen last summer.
The boom in construction continued despite blizzards, with 15,000 construction jobs added on top of 99,000 jobs in December.
As usual, the mammoth service sector accounted for the biggest share of job gains. "January job gains were led by the services industry, which had above-average growth," said Katherine Abraham, Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which issues the jobs report. Hiring was strong in engineering, management and computer services. Hiring by temporary-help suppliers and health care companies, on the other hand, was sluggish.
As long as the rest of the world's troubles keep inflation low in the United States, the Fed may stand aside as unemployment falls. How low can unemployment go? With the old rules seemingly suspended, the nation may soon find out.

HEADLINE: About New York;
Standing Tall On Behalf Of a Union

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
COMPARED with the Twin Towers, Carlos Guzman and Dominick Bentivegna looked tiny as they approached the entrance of 5 World Trade Center on Thursday. They're the kind of working stiffs New Yorkers notice vaguely, if at all -- Mr. Guzman is a janitor at the World Trade Center while Mr. Bentivegna is a doorman on the Upper East Side. Bit players in the service economy, right?
Not anymore. Last week they agreed to drop a $2.4 million lawsuit against the leadership of Local 32B-32J, the city's maintenance workers union, on the condition that its president, Gus Bevona, resign. Mr. Bevona, one of the nation's highest-paid labor officials at $450,000 a year, had resisted dissident challenges in both courts and elections. The dissidents' most recent lawsuit accused him of misusing union funds to pay his legal and re-election expenses. 
 The dissidents, led by Mr. Guzman and Mr. Bentivegna as co-chairmen of Members for a Better Union, had scored court victories before. They also said they had faced harassment and intimidation from those loyal to Mr. Bevona. At one point, Mr. Guzman lived like Yasir Arafat, nervously sleeping in a different home every night after private detectives hired by the union staked out his apartment.
Now the intifada they waged against the union they thought was supposed to represent them has ended, and the union is being run by a trustee. The dissident duo have gone from being little guys to V.I.P.'s. They were entering a Trade Center building when Paul Vance, a maintenance worker, stopped taping rain mats to the floor, looked up and smiled.
"You're a big shot now," said Mr. Vance, who hugged Mr. Guzman. "Good job, man! It's about time. Maybe now we can get working rights."
The greeting was a simple act of solidarity, a reminder that unions can still mean something more than an automatic payroll deduction. Mr. Guzman's expectation that his dues entitled him to his union's respect and support prompted him to question Mr. Bevona's salary and lavish penthouse headquarters (complete with a bank of televisions that monitored other offices) and especially the union's reluctance to defend its members. "The union did nothing," said Mr. Guzman, 51. "The majority of people in this industry come from other countries. The only thing they have is this job and they have to support a family with it. The employers know that and abuse them."
Mr. Guzman's decision to go after the union's leadership was not out of character, even for a janitor who was more used to working in empty offices. He was politicized in his native Ecuador, where a military junta ruled the country during the early 1960's. "When I was 15, we were fighting dictators over there," he said. "The soldiers had guns and bullets; we just had stones to throw at them. We'd go to City Hall and protest. Somebody would die. Then we'd go to the cemetery and protest again. I grew up fighting injustice."
Mr. Bentivegna, 38, grew up in Bensonhurst looking forward to getting a union card the way others anticipate getting into the right club. "All the jobs I ever had, I always wanted to get into 'The Union,' " he said. "Any union. You'd see the papers and you'd see how the union did this and the union did that. If you had a problem, you'd call the union. It was larger than life. I'd like to see that come back to 32B, that if you call the union, the boss is going to worry."
HE had joined Mr. Guzman in 1993 when the union did little about his complaints that his supervisor used racial slurs against his Latino and black colleagues. Since then, the two of them have shared a bond that offers some hope for the city's future: an Italian-American doorman joining forces with a Ecuadorean janitor in a union filled with immigrants and minorities.
"I was raised to respect people," Mr. Bentivegna said. "There is no why. It's like asking why do you want to be a good person?"
Mr. Guzman interrupted. "It was assigned to you," Mr. Guzman joked. "Like Moses. This is your calling. Free your people."
Mr. Bentivegna continued. "I look at everybody in this union and I see only two things," he said. "You're either good or bad."
And involved.
"It's the people who make the people who govern you," said Mr. Guzman, who mastered this bit of practical democracy. "If the people don't participate, no matter who governs, you're always going to risk an abuse of power. Without participation, nothing is accomplished."
With it, everybody's a big shot.

HEADLINE: Jordan King's Heir Reaffirms Stand for Peace and U.S. Ties

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 5

 BODY:
Jordan's next Government will remain committed to peace in the Middle East and close relations with Washington, but wary of both Iran and Iraq, Crown Prince Abdullah said in his first interview since he was designated successor to his father, King Hussein.
"I am an extension of His Majesty's outlook and His Majesty's beliefs," the 37-year-old brigadier general said, in speech that was British in tone but American in rhythm and vernacular. 
 The interview with several visiting foreign reporters took place on Thursday in Raghadan Palace, on an off-the-record basis. Tonight, as King Hussein's death appeared increasingly imminent, the Prince's aides authorized publication of the wide-ranging conversation, which they said was intended in part to set the record straight on the circumstances of his selection two weeks ago to replace his uncle as Crown Prince.
In the interview, Crown Prince Abdullah discussed his nuanced views of other regional diplomatic challenges, his strained relationship with his uncle, former Crown Prince Hassan, and his vision of the future of the Jordanian monarchy.
His greatest immediate internal concern, it seems, is to close family ranks behind him as he prepares to take the throne just weeks after his father unceremoniously deposed Prince Hassan after 34 years as the King's designated successor.
Prince Abdullah said he learned of his father's decision just one day before it was announced last month and the King left Jordan for a second bone marrow transplant in the United States.
He denied published reports that he flew secretly to Minnesota last fall, during the King's previous stay there, to complain to his father about Hassan, who was then Crown Prince. All the King's 12 children visited him during the six months he was being treated abroad, he said, and he had stayed for a few days at the end of September and early October.
Prince Abdullah said he greatly admired Prince Hassan, had often turned to him for counsel, and was confident that his uncle would play a senior advisory role in the new government.
"This was an issue between two brothers," said Prince Abdullah, the King's eldest son. King Hussein wanted "to have the legitimacy go back into his line," he said.
 Shortly after Prince Abdullah returned from his visit to his father at the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota, he gave a rare interview to an Arab-language weekly saying that he had been Crown Prince himself until he was 3 and that there was nothing to prevent reverting to the traditional line of succession -- the first indication to palace-watchers here that such a change was contemplated.
And in the interview on Thursday, Prince Abdullah made it clear that he too thought Prince Hassan had recently been too much the acting king, and not enough the loyal deputy. "The role of a crown prince should be to keep a low profile," he said.
He was quick to refer to his family's dynasty, saying, "The Hashemites are the unifying factor of Jordan."
"That is what binds us together, Palestinians and Bedouins and everyone else," he said, sitting next to his half brother, the 23-year-old Prince Ali, who was once seen as his father's most likely successor.
The man who will be King of Jordan is a personable career military officer with his father's quick smile and unfeigned modesty. He shares as well his father's deep distrust of Shiite radicalism, unfettered democracy and other perceived threats to the stability of Jordan and the survival of the dynasty.
Yet he is quite unlike King Hussein, he acknowledged, in the circumstances of his ascension to the throne, and in his relationships with his peers in the region, whose fathers were in many cases mortal enemies.
Externally, he wants above all to reassure the world that the succession in Amman will not change the foreign policy built up so carefully by King Hussein. Jordan's desire for a permanent peace between "our friends in Israel and our friends in the P.N.A.," the Palestinian National Authority, will remain its chief diplomatic priority, he said.
He emphasized the importance of the perception and reality of Jordanian neutrality in the current Israeli election campaign, joking that he had declined to take calls of congratulation in recent days from Israeli "friends" who were once active-duty generals but who are now actively engaged in politics.
But when discussing the delicately balanced Jordanian policy toward Iraq, Prince Abdullah seemed somewhat closer to the American position.His father was compelled to support Jordan's neighbor and major trading partner when other nations were arrayed against Iraq during the Persian Gulf war in 1991, and has since been a critic of United Nations sanctions that have caused suffering among the Iraqi people.
 The Prince said President Saddam Hussein of Iraq still posed a threat to Kuwait and that Jordan would support a "change" in Iraq's Government. He said he agreed with American policymakers that there "no hope" that President Hussein would voluntarily change his policies.
"We are on the same sheet of music, so to speak," he said, referring to his discussions on Iraq here last week with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.
Yet Iran poses an ultimately more serious destabilizing threat to the region, he said, warning that the liberalizing forces represented by President Mohammad Khatami remain very much a minority.
Belying his image as a sheltered political novice, he spoke knowledgeably of the diverse pressures facing his country and its neighbors, and used candor and charm to challenge the widespread notion that his sudden ascension has strained relations within the royal family.
He also sought to emphasize the practical utility to a future monarch of his army career, which began with eight years in desert bases "in the middle of nowhere," but more recently made him the country's chief military envoy. He is comfortable with ordinary Jordanians, he said, because he has lived like an ordinary Jordanian soldier. And he has developed a close circle of professional friends in the armies of Israel, the Persian Gulf states and the United States, he said.
Prince Abdullah spoke especially warmly of his friendships in other royal families in the Arab world, and sympathetically of their desires to fight Islamic fundamentalism and retain some of their dynastic privileges.
Many of them shared American educations and an American belief in free-market economics, he said.
"We went to the same schools," said the Prince, who attended high school at the exclusive Deerfield Academy in Massachusetts and went on to study at Sandhurst, the elite British military college. "We ate in the same restaurants. We like the same movies. We have a lot in common, and we have all become very good friends."
His wife, Princess Rania, is a Palestinian whom he married in 1993, and they have a son, Prince Hussein, and a daughter, Princess Iman.
Presenting himself as a modern monarch-in-waiting whose goal is liberalize the economy and open up the political system, Prince Abdullah demurred when asked if the dynasty might, under his reign, subordinate its near-feudal power to a constitutionally protected Parliament.
"Democracy is not something that can be done overnight," he said. "It is a learning experience. It is also a discipline. Because we have a democracy, it doesn't mean that people can take things into their own hands."

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
For many people, the depth of religious divisions among Jews was captured this week in the image of Orthodox yeshiva students screaming insults at American Reform rabbis praying, with men and women together, at the Western Wall in Jerusalem.
That image, however dramatic, misses some other deep divisions existing, not between Orthodox and non-Orthodox expressions of Judaism, but in the heart of Orthodoxy itself. These divisions, which have potentially far-reaching consequences for Judaism and resemble parallel conflicts in other religious traditions, will draw 500 to 1,000 participants to the Grand Hyatt Hotel in New York City for an international conference next weekend. 
 Entitled "Orthodoxy Encounters a Changing World," the Feb. 14-15 conference is the work of Edah (Hebrew for "community"), a relatively new and, to be sure, immediately controversial group. The "changing world" of the title is the world of women's rights and Middle East peace negotiations, but it is even more specifically the changing world of Orthodox Judaism.
That world has always had its internal camps. Outsiders are vaguely aware that Hasidic Jews constitute a distinct group within the Orthodox and are in turn split into various differing allegiances, Lubavitchers and Satmars and so on.
But the most important division has probably been between "modern Orthodox," as they have termed themselves, who believe that a strict observance of Jewish law is compatible with an extensive involvement in the social, intellectual and professional life of contemporary America, and a more separatist, inward strand of Orthodoxy that rejects modernity in a much more sweeping fashion as incompatible with Jewish values.
The two groups split sharply in their attitudes toward secular education. The modern Orthodox have valued the study of Western science, literature and art and have enthusiastically entered the professions. Yeshiva University has been their flagship institution in trying this synthesis between modern culture and traditional observance.
The separatists, now labeled ultra-Orthodox by critics or, more neutrally, "haredim" ("those who tremble" in fear of the Lord), have always rejected such secular pursuits as distractions. Most secular schooling should be limited to what is needed for young people to support a family and devote themselves wholeheartedly to religious study and practice.
So what about this bifurcated Orthodox world has changed? Primarily, three things.
The modern Orthodox have increasingly felt the pressure of demands for new roles for women not simply in organizational leadership but in areas of religious life where any reinterpretation of Jewish law is sure to be controversial.
Orthodox leaders of all stripes have always insisted that the Reform and Conservative movements (to which the vast majority of American Jews adhere) are deviations from authentic Judaism. But recent developments -- the Conservative and Reform ordination of female rabbis, for instance, or the Reform movement's new acceptance of intermarriage and homosexuality, or the effort of both movements to get a legal foothold in Israel's religious life -- have turned the border between the Orthodox and non-Orthodox into a virtual free-fire zone. Anyone daring to reach across it, as some modern Orthodox have done, is in peril.
Third, and most important, the "haredim" have increasingly become the dominant force in Orthodoxy. The causes and consequences of this "turn to the right," as it has often been called, are brilliantly sketched by Jack Wertheimer, a professor of American Jewish history and the provost at Jewish Theological Seminary, in the February issue of Commentary magazine.
Young people from modern Orthodox backgrounds, for example, now often spend a year or two in Israel, pursuing religious studies in settings where haredi influence is strong. Orthodox day schools, summer camps and youth programs are disproportionately staffed by haredi educators who choose that calling over secular professions.
The consequences include a shift in authority from practical-minded congregational rabbis to the virtuoso talmudic scholars who head haredi yeshivas and who favor an escalating standard of ritual stringency.
The modern Orthodox in sum, are on the defensive. Some of their most esteemed figures are regularly having their religious credentials called into question. Indeed, Professor Wertheimer uses terms like "vilified" for the treatment meted out to these rabbis and scholars.
And the modern Orthodox themselves, Rabbi Berman said, often have "a sense that the haredim really represent true Orthodoxy and modern Orthodoxy is a movement of convenience."
He said he hoped the conference would send a different message: "that it is really possible to relate to modernity in a relatively open fashion while maintaining a passionate commitment to Torah."
He would consider the gathering a success if, on issues like attitudes toward the non-Orthodox, women's roles in Orthodox Judaism, and rabbinic authority over individuals' spiritual lives, there were simply a recognition of "a greater degree of legitimate diversity."
Even within modern Orthodoxy, however, this initiative has stirred fierce reactions. In the latest issue of The Jewish Week, Rabbi Moshe Tendler, a leading figure in the rabbinical seminary of Yeshiva University, denounced Edah as "outside the pale of Judaism"
Speaking from a separatist perspective, Rabbi Avi Shafran, director of public affairs at Agudath Israel, was comparatively detached. Modern Judaism's effort to be in the contemporary world and yet strictly faithful to traditional Judaism had merely reflected the economic insecurity of Orthodox Jews decades ago, Rabbi Shafran argued.
"Edah pines for those days," he said. "It is trying to make a compromise born of necessity into a high ideal."
Yet Edah's conference addresses a perennial choice facing any religious group "encountering a changing world": build bridges or patrol borders. There is a time and a place for both, of course, and only wisdom instructs one in where and when and how.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

30-Year Bond Yield Rises As Stocks Continue to Fall
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond rose after the Labor Department reported that the unemployment rate in January remained unchanged from December at 4.3 percent, the lowest level in 28 years. The bond's yield climbed to 5.35 percent from 5.29 percent. 
 The Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with technology stocks, suffered its worst one-week decline since October, dropping 5.3 percent. The Nasdaq index closed lower by 36.45 points, or 1.51 percent, to 2,373.62, The Dow Jones industrial average rallied at the end of the day to drop just 0.26 point, to 9,304.24, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks declined 9.09 points, to 1,239.40. The Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks fell 5.07 points, to 412.72. Page C3.
 
With the economy rolling along strongly, consumers continued to borrow for car and credit card loans in December. Borrowing rose $7.3 billion, to $1.308 trillion. C14.
 
Economic Crisis in Brazil Intensifies
Brazil's stocks, currency and bonds fell, closing out a tumultuous week that began with hopes that a new central banker could halt a free fall in the currency. The week ended with concern that rising interest rates would sink the economy, causing debt to balloon. The value of the currency, the real, fell 1 percent, to 1.82 to the dollar from 1.805. C15.
 
Airport Landing Changes Seen
The Clinton Administration wants to end limits on how many planes an hour can land at Kennedy, La Guardia and O'Hare airports, people who have been briefed on the plan said. The change, to be proposed on Monday, would make it easier for start-up airlines to challenge established carriers, at a time when the Transportation Department is looking for ways to stimulate airline competition. A12.
 
Big Donations by Gates and Wife
William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, and his wife, Melinda, have given $3 billion to their two foundations, the president of one of the foundations said. The gifts bring the assets of both foundations to nearly $5.5 billion. Mr. Gates has given away more money than any other living American philanthropist. A12.
 
Japan Tries to Halt Rate Surge
Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan indicated that he wanted the nation's central bank to buy Government bonds and sell bills to help halt a surge in long-term interest rates. Yields on Japanese 10-year bonds tripled in the last four months as investors braced for a flood of debt sales by the Government to finance tax cuts and public works spending. The rising yields drove up interest rates on a variety of things, ranging from corporate bonds to mortgages. C15.
 
Weir Rejects Bid From Flowserve
Weir Group rejected an unsolicited takeover bid from Flowserve, a maker of pumping equipment valves and seals, that valued Weir at nearly $1 billion. C3.
 
CBS Reports an Operating Profit
CBS had an operating profit in the fourth quarter as its radio stations and the return to the television network of National Football League broadcasts led to increased advertising revenue. C3.
 
Boeing Seen Vulnerable to Takeover
Boeing's chairman warned managers last month that the leading aerospace company could become a takeover target because of its depressed stock price. But analysts called any takeover attempt highly unlikely. C4.
 
More Oil Industry Jobs May Be Cut
A trade group said the nation's oil industry stands to lose 17,000 jobs by this summer if oil prices do not rise above $14 a barrel by then. About 24,415 jobs have been lost since the price decline began in November 1997. C2.
