SECTION: Section 6; Page 30; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 995 words

HEADLINE: WORD & IMAGE;
Steam For Sale

BYLINE: By MAX FRANKEL 

 BODY:
The enduring mystery of the Lewinsky affair is why the public has been so forgiving of conduct we all so recently assumed to be unforgivable. Bill Clinton exploited that tolerance shamelessly, and his pursuers ignored it dangerously. But we all struggled to explain the phenomenon satisfactorily. Why did this sexual escapade shock so little and entertain so much?
 Questions about "skeletons" in the closet were always the first ones put to any political candidate -- and female skeletons were always the first to disqualify. Bill Clinton himself reaffirmed that sturdy standard when he greeted the appearance of Gennifer Flowers as a mortal threat to his candidacy in 1992. And when the Lewinsky dalliance leaked just a year ago, the President understandably doubted the public's tolerance for bawdy sex -- as, of course, did Judge Starr and his avenging angels. 
 Some say the explanation for public tolerance lies in the economy, the American people's sense of well-being. But peace and prosperity have never shielded politicians from scandal. Something more profound has been shaping the public's attitude. And suddenly, in a flash, at my neighborhood newsstand the other day, I found the answer.
 Virtually nothing about sex is any longer private or shocking. Sex not only sells, the racks were shouting, it sells unblushingly. Open Sex, Openly Arrived At! Seduction on Demand! Orgasms for All! The very same polls and focus groups that were sustaining Bill Clinton were inspiring the cover come-ons of all these respectable journals. The magazines peddling fashion, beauty and life-style fantasies were shouting slogans of obvious political relevance:
"BE THE BEST SEX OF HIS LIFE: How to Tease Him Mercilessly, Seduce Him Slowly and Then Rock His World in Ways He's Only Dreamed About."
"LIBIDO 101: Read him these sizzling scenes from sexy page-turners and you're guaranteed to scorch the sheets. We even found the exact page numbers so you can skip right to the good stuff."
 Was Larry Flynt intruding further into our mainstream politics? Not at all. His Hustler, and also Penthouse and Playboy, were safely segregated over yonder with the other rawhide rags. I was being brazenly wooed right out front, just beside Time, Newsweek, and The Financial Times, by the perfumed pages of nice-girl and goo1d-guy romance.
 Cosmopolitan: "Give Him the Best Sex of His Life. . . . What Does It Take to Be a Sexually Enthralling Do-Me-or-Die-Me Diva Who Men Never Forget? . . . Are You More Buddy Than Bedmate? Bust Your Lame-Lover Label Before It Sticks. . . . New Ways to Get a Lust-Worthy Bust: Whether you want to fill out that twinset or flaunt touch-me-now cleavage, we have a booty of boob boosters that'll make the most of your bust fund."
 New Woman: "Love It Up! 6 Stay-Hot, Stay-Happy Secrets. . . . 7 Signs He Still Thinks You're Sexy."
 Marie Claire: "Sex Secrets You're Entitled to Know."
 Glamour: "Is He Your Secret Sexual Soulmate? How to Meet or Make Your Man the Lover of Your Steamiest Dreams. . . . His Sex Secrets: Should You Go There? . . . Q: We're planning a romantic fling in my car. What's the best way to do it? A: Wear loose-fitting clothes . . . load up on pillows . . . watch out for the gearshift."
 All this steam, mind you, appeared in a single month, generated by advertisers whose lust for the 20-39 singles crowd obviously makes them equal-opportunity hucksters -- as hot for women as, in more traditional ways, for men.
 An obviously desperate Esquire heaved a top-heavy Pamela Anderson at me across its cover and proclaimed physiological solidarity with the girlie gazettes: "BREASTS! The Triumph of Cleavage Culture. . . . Everywhere you look, another perfect pair. Padded, enhanced, augmented. Empowered. A living, breathing symbol of our whole big, fat falsie world."
 And from Details came: "BODY HEAT! The First Annual Lingerie Issue . . . Whether it's stalwart boxers or a thrilling thong, it says a lot. It says from here on it's serious. . . . If it does its job well, you're not gonna have it on for very long anyway."
 Given how this stuff sells -- and a dozen journals of this genre seem to find 50-60 million readers every month -- how could Bill and Monica fail to sell? They have obviously invaded our minds, lived our fantasies, made themselves into us and us into them.
 Why, then, was the public's comfort with all this surging sex so surprising? Was it not the healthy culmination of our era's triumph over uptight puritans? Those of us who grew up searching for naughty words in the dictionary and tracing over Esquire's Varga girls have witnessed such startling change -- from the mere hint of nakedness in "I Am Curious Yellow" to "The Full Monty" -- that we should have known a President's dalliance and an intern's intoxication would play out mainly as late-night comedy.
 Moreover, we should celebrate our passage. Open sex is clearly healthier than sex repressed. Coping with human longings, loves and fantasies is hard enough when they can be acknowledged and confronted. Treating them as dirty and shameful obstructs human relationships.
 But open is not the synonym of honest. The steamy literature on my neighborhood rack is not romance. The emotions on display in our gamy President and prurient publications are equally cynical and synthetic quests for gratification, typical of our time perhaps but hardly edifying.
 As The Times's Ben Brantley has observed, the most open display of sexuality on Broadway this season was Nicole Kidman's famously perfect body in various states of partial and briefly total undress. But our critic found "The Blue Room," David Hare's reworking of Arthur Schnitzler's "La Ronde," to be "ice-cold" -- "a joyless cycle of users and the used," registering no more pain and passion than "the lurid neon lighting in which it is bathed."
 A joyless cycle of users and used. We know the plot. We voted for it. We'll buy it every time.

HEADLINE: A Promising Youngster Called Photonics

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
PHOTONICS became a buzzword for robust economic times ahead during last fall's gubernatorial elections. But for Chandra Sekhar Roychoudhuri, a researcher and professor at the University of Connecticut, the word's meaning runs deeper.
The science of light-wave manipulation, photonics has been with us as far back as the days of the flashbulb. But its applications now are nothing short of revolutionary. Photonics has become an integral part of everyday life, whether it be in microsurgery, compact disk players or in running shoes that blink at night. 
 For Mr. Roychoudhuri, head of UConn's new Photonics Research Center in Mansfield, the word prompts consideration about the next phase of human evolution.
"It all started with the Big Bang," he said. " 'In the beginning there was light.' Every serious religion talks of light being the first thing in the universe. Now humans have learned to control and manipulate this light."
Yet Mr. Roychoudhuri is frustrated. The state, he says, is behind the curve when it comes to making itself hospitable to the emerging photonics industry. While photonics has been identified by Gov. John G. Rowland as one of three new technologies Connecticut will focus on in the future, Mr. Roychoudhuri characterizes state support for his center as underwhelming -- less than $3 million in the past three years.
There is no research laboratory in Connecticut to compare with those at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology or Stanford University in California. UConn has the state's only engineering school and one of just two photonics programs in Connecticut. (The other is at Three Rivers Community-Technical College in Norwich.) Compared to freer spending competitors like Florida and Arizona, Connecticut is losing ground as the industry begins to define itself, Mr. Roychoudhuri said.
"You cannot spawn new technologies without knowledge creation," he said. "States that don't invest heavily now in growing fields of knowledge like photonics run the risk of being left behind. Connecticut in the next five years will find that out."
The Northeast is home to more than a third of the nation's more than 3,000 photonics companies.
Connecticut, seeking industrial growth since the recession of the early 1990's, had been connected to photonics long before the term found currency. In 1960, the Perkin-Elmer Corporation (then based in Norwalk) built the world's first commercial laser. Back then the field of light-wave manipulation was known as optics, and efforts by the military to harness the laser brought other Connecticut science-based companies like the United Technologies Corporation into the field.
Today photonics encompasses far more than the laser and there are more than 150 photonics-centered companies in Connecticut, employing 18,000 people. Yet few of these companies are major players.
"We are absolutely perfectly positioned to be a powerhouse, but companies based in Connecticut tend to be on the small side," said Wayne Burwell, acting executive director of the Connecticut Photonics Cluster, an informal collective.
Connecticut's most commonly cited success story is that of Uniphase Telecommunications Products, based in Bloomfield. Since being spun off by United Technologies and sold to San Francisco-based Uniphase in 1995, U.T.P. has been a beneficiary of the Internet revolution, producing lithium niobate optical modulators, which are used to modify light as it is transmitted through wires to communicate information.
Used in connection with the state-of-the-art wavelength division multiplexing system developed by the Ciena Corporation in Baltimore, these modulators can transmit as much as 10 billion bits of information a second. (A complete set of the Encyclopedia Britannica comprises 1 billion bits of information.)
In 1995, when the company was known as United Technology Photonics, 55 people worked for what was then a break-even business catering to the cable television industry, U.T.P.'s founder Fred J. Leonberger recalled. Today U.T.P. employs nearly 400 people. Monthly production has gone from 50 modulators to more than 1,000. That helped Uniphase sales jump from $12 million in 1995 to $50 million in 1998. "The Internet is the primary driver of our business today," he said.
A soft-spoken scientist who laughed and shook his head when asked if he ever took a business class in college, Mr. Leonberger now finds himself the chief technology officer for a worldwide corporation, juggling conference calls and trans-Atlantic flights in addition to overseeing operations in Bloomfield.
At the Photonics Research Center at UConn, one current project deals with the possibility of creating fiber-optic amplifiers, which would allow telephone lines to stretch hundreds of miles without a single repeater. Another goal is to create a device that would allow telephone switching entirely by photonics, speeding up the connection process exponentially. Mr. Roychoudhuri calls that the "Holy Grail of photonics research."
Not all Connecticut photonics businesses focus on telecommunications. In Willimantic, Structural Integrity Monitoring Systems is developing sensoring equipment for bridge safety checks. The Zygo Corporation in Middlefield makes instrumentation for measuring manufacturing procedures to less than a millionth of an inch. DeMaria ElectroOptics Systems in Bloomfield is concentrating on laser printing, "the lowest cost per watt of any laser on the market," said the founder, Anthony DeMaria.
Mr. DeMaria, a former assistant director at the United Technologies Research Center, focused on cultivating scientists like Mr. Leonberger, who would later start out on their own. "He hired a lot of us," said Walter Glomb, another DeMaria protege now the chief operating officer of Heliometrics, which is developing laser measurement devices in Ellington.
The merging of business and high-tech science has been one constant of the photonics boom. Small-scale enterprises, fueled by venture capital and based on patents owned by the company's founders, are springing up across the state.
"There's great engineering talent here in Connecticut," said Kevin Didden, president of the CiDra Corporation in Wallingford, which produces sensoring equipment for oil wells. "Where they used to be paid a straight salary, now they get stock options as well. Now when you talk to technical people, they understand what a stock option is."
But Connecticut's paucity of photonics educational centers is a sore point with some business leaders in the state. "Virtually 100 percent of our talent is hired from out-of-state," said Paul G. Suchoski, U.T.P.'s general manager.
One reason for the company being based in Bloomfield was its proximity to Springfield Technical-Community College, just over the state line in Massachusetts. While the programs at UConn and Three Rivers are noted, Mr. Suchoski said, "It could be 10 to 15 years before they have a world-class operation in Connecticut."
The state has been supporting its photonics industry in other ways. Connecticut Innovations Inc., a publicly chartered corporation based in Rocky Hill initially funded by state bond proceeds, is investing in high-tech Connecticut-based businesses.
Its president, Victor Budnick, says that among its successes is a $1.75 million investment to CiDra in early 1997, which, buttressed by private financing, has thus far created around $20 million in total capital.
But CiDra is the only photonics company that Connecticut Innovations is actively invested in, representing 8.9 percent of its total investment portfolio, just one of the 53 companies it has helped.
The state is also working with photonics firms on the research end. At UConn, both the Photonic Research Center and the Department of Material Sciences are working with Stratford-based E-Lite to create ultra-thin computer displays.
"There's a limit to how much the state can spend," said Robert V. Smith, dean of UConn's graduate school. "The good news is we're doing it to some degree. The bad news is we'd like to do more."
Connecticut has done as well as it has in photonics because of state-based pioneers like Perkin-Elmer and United Technologies, from which came many present-day companies, and to neighbors like American Optical in Sturbridge, Mass.
Zygo, for example, was formed by three former Perkin-Elmer employees in 1970. Today it manufactures light-sensitive measuring equipment. Paul F. Forman, one of the founders and now chairman emeritus, said one reason Zygo stayed in Connecticut was the state's quality of life.
"It's a good place to live, but if I wasn't living in Connecticut when we started the company, we would not have come to Connecticut," he said. "The locations which have a world-class research university that truly builds collaboration with industry gives start-ups a real advantage. In photonics, Connecticut hasn't arrived yet."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: A New 90-Page Booklet;
Help for Tenants And Landlords

 BODY:
The title is "What Every Landlord and Tenant Should Know," but if New York City's landlords and tenants were told they had to know everything that's in the new booklet, they might go into shock.
Better to browse through this 90-page handbook, the seventh edition in a series put out by the Citizens Housing and Planning Council, plucking out nuggets of information. 
 It was written by Jane Dickler Lebow, who has edited previous editions, including the sixth, which appeared in 1991. Because of legislative action in 1997 there is much new material.
Browsers will learn what the mechanisms are that bring about the decontrol of both vacant and occupied apartments (page 23); what one's relationship must be to a tenant of record if one is living in an apartment and expects to succeed to the tenant's rights some day (page 11); what the rules say about subletting an apartment (page 30).
And they will get some advice. Tenants are advised, for example, that they should not ignore landlords' requests for information or other official mail regarding high-income deregulation. And landlords will find that they are required to warn new tenants of possible lead-paint risks in their buildings.
The Citizens Housing and Planning Council is a 62-year-old organization of professionals in the housing, planning and economic-development fields, mainly lawyers, architects, planners, private and nonprofit owners and former public officials.
Single copies of the handbook cost $5 and are available from the council at 50 East 42d Street, Suite 407, New York N.Y. 10017-5405.
Telephone: (212) 286-9211.

LENGTH: 1392 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property / 450 West 33d Street;
From Skating on the Ice to Logging On to the Web

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
THIS space is going to scream 'new media,' " said Kevin O'Connor, the chairman and chief executive of Doubleclick Inc.
The space he was referring to is the 16th floor of the building at 450 West 33d Street at 10th Avenue. For years it was better known as Sky Rink, one of the few places in midtown where skaters and ice hockey players could practice their skills. (The rink has since moved to Chelsea Piers.) 
 Now the 50,000-square-foot, column-free space is to be converted into the headquarters of Doubleclick, a company that acts as a broker for advertising on the World Wide Web and measures the efficiency of the ads. The company is one of the fastest growing of the computer-based communications companies in the city's so-called Silicon Alley, hiring on average of a person a day during the last year.
The company is also leasing 100,000 square feet on the 12th floor of the 33d Street building so it can consolidate all its operations under one roof.
Doubleclick is the first company of its kind to secure economic incentives from New York City and State to expand its operations locally, rather than keep a headquarters in the city and shift back office-type jobs to other locations. The company will receive a total of $5.1 million if it stays in place and meets job growth targets.
Rents in the building, which is owned by the John Hancock insurance company, have recently ranged from the low to mid-20's per square foot annually.
In addition to being long and wide, the 16th floor space has volume, with 26 feet between the floor and the bottom of the steel trusses that support the roof. According to Frederic M. Strauss, an architect with the Phillips Group, this layout permits the construction of mezzanines totaling about 11,000 square feet under city zoning rules.
Rather then place the mezzanine around the periphery of the space, as is most common, Mr. Strauss has proposed building two-story-high structures within the confines of the former ice rink space. The two-story enclosed structures would be used largely as meeting rooms and would stand out against the backdrop of low-level cubicles that will probably occupy the rest of the floor.
To further add dramatic impact to the space, the mezzanine-level rooms will be linked by a second-level catwalk stretching diagonally almost completely across the rink space.
In addition to the interior space, the 16th floor also includes two sizable deck areas totaling about 20,000 square feet, in the front overlooking 10th Avenue and in the back facing the General Post Office building. Those decks will be used to provide amenities such as a basketball court, a running track and a shaded dining area to the mostly young staff members, who are expected to work long hours. (A rock climbing wall has also been discussed, but does not appear on current renderings of the project.)
"People spend so much time at work that you need a place where people want to be," Mr. O'Connor said. He said the market for technically qualified employees was so competitive in New York that pleasant working conditions are an important consideration for young people deciding on which of several job offers to accept.
Other new-media companies have equipped their work spaces with exercise rooms, pool tables and ping-pong tables.
A little over three years ago Doubleclick was two people, Mr. O'Connor and his co-founder, Dwight Merriman, working in a basement in Atlanta trying to cook up an Internet-based business. Today the company has 500 employees worldwide (375 in New York), operates in a dozen countries and is publicly traded, having sold an initial public offering in February 1997.
The company's first 3.5 million shares were offered at $17 a share, but jumped to $26.75 at the close of the first day of trading. The stock has been extremely volatile since then, trading as low as $13.50 and as high as $114.62 and recently has been trading at about $100 a share.
The company name derives from the two quick strokes of a button on a computer's mouse control needed to make changes on a screen.
Mr. O'Connor said the company had the choice of relocating to the West Coast, famously the home of technology-based start-up companies, or New York. "We decided to come to New York because New York is the advertising capital of the country and this is where our customers are," he said.
HAVING a base of operations in New York was also a help in the company's international expansion. "Being from New York gives you a lot of credibility overseas," he said. "The attitude is that anyone who can build a business in New York is real."
This rapid growth has helped keep the company on the forefront of technical development but has presented practical difficulties. "My biggest challenge has been real estate," Mr. O'Connor said.
Currently, Doubleclick people are spread over six different floors of two buildings, one at 41 Madison Avenue, at 26th Street, the other at 245 Fifth Avenue, at 28th Street. "Sky Rink gets us together again," he said, using the old name of the 16th floor as shorthand for both floors in the 33d Street building.
He seemed to find that attractive, but he said that without the financial incentives, the company might have looked elsewhere. "We would have always kept a core sales group in New York, but there are a lot of people in the back office and engineering who do not have to be there," he said.
Under the deal with the city's Economic Development Corporation, Doubleclick get $1 million to keep its operations in the city and will get $3 million more if the number of jobs in the city grows to 756. The Empire State Development Corporation contributed $900,000.
Doubleclick officials said the space being rented on 33d Street can accommodate as many as 1,000 people, which gives some indication of of their expectations for growth.
Charles Millard, president of the E.D.C., said the city had targeted new media as an engine for economic growth. "The Giuliani administration is committed to the growth of Silicon Alley," he said, using another term for the concentration of computer-based companies in Manhattan. "And we want to send a message to the rest of the country that New York is behind this industry."
Developing the industry locally while it is in its infancy is important, he said, because of the jobs it is likely to generate as it grows. To the extent that new-media companies prosper in New York, they would help moderate the influence of financial services firms that now dominate the economy and extract huge incentives from the city by threatening to move.
The Web is the first new type of media to be introduced since the widespread distribution of television half a century ago, according to Wenda Harris Millard, who is executive vice president for marketing and sales at Doubleclick and no relation to the E.D.C. president. "Cable was not really a new medium," she added, "it was just a different means of distribution."
Doubleclick executives first looked at the space on 33d Street last summer, but it took until just last month to conclude a deal, in part because the company's requirements kept changing. "This is the only deal I've ever been involved in where the amount of space tripled during the negotiation," said Scott Schneider, a lawyer with Loeb & Loeb who advised on the transaction.
Because of the nature of its business, Doubleclick operates around the clock and on all days of the week -- in industry parlance, "24/7." As a result it arranged for exclusive use of two ground-floor loading bays and two freight elevators in the onetime warehouse building to move equipment in and out as needed.
Because it once housed a major bank's computer center it is well equipped with electrical power and telecommunications equipment, brokers said.
"We needed space like this," said Mr. O'Connor. "The buildings we are in now close at 6 P.M."
With the 10-year agreements now signed, Mr. Strauss said he will go into more detailed design than was possible when it was not clear exactly what would be included in the lease. Doubleclick officials said they hoped to move into the building in November.
The massive 1.6 million-square-foot building, which occupies two blocks along 10th Avenue, is also home to WNET, the public television station better known as Channel 13, and The Daily News.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 8; Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1207 words

HEADLINE: Trees to Harvest, at Work in the Woods

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA 

 BODY:
JOAN NICHOLS had marked some 50 trees in a Lebanon woodlot. Now her husband, Scott, was cutting them down, one by one. "This operation -- one fellow with a chain saw dropping trees, a skidder pulling them out -- is fairly typical of Connecticut," she said.
Her husband neatly dropped a 90-foot oak; his helper, Rick Connolly, readied the skidder. Watching it all was Bill Jahoda, whose family has long owned the woodlot. "This is being done for a family sugarbush," explained Mr. Jahoda, a retired science professor. He'd helped select the oaks and other trees being removed to make more room for sugar maples.
 Mrs. Nichols is a forester; her husband is a "supervising forest products harvester," a logger. They began Nichols Forestry and Logging in Lebanon in 1990, the year they got married. They said they didn't know of any other couple in Connecticut working as such a team.
 She said she grew up on Long Island, and had not expected to take up logging. She did love her family's vacation trips to Maine and to the Adirondacks, however. "I always liked the woods," she said. "I didn't like being in the city." She said she considered a career in environmental education until her studies at SUNY's College of Environmental Science and Forestry at Syracuse set her to thinking along other lines. "We require wood products," she said. "The more I learned about cutting trees, I thought, 'If we're going to do it, we should do it right.' " 
 After graduation, she worked for the United States Forest Service in Montana for two years before settling in Connecticut, where she worked for a sawmill -- and eventually met Scott, a contract logger who had briefly attended the University of Maine before deciding he'd rather go to work. "We met in the woods," she said. The Nichols, both 39, have two daughters, 2 and 4. And while they may be unusual as a working couple, their activities are not at all unusual in the business of logging -- a dangerous, demanding business worth some $414 million annually to the state's economy.
 Douglas Emmerthal, of the Connecticut D.E.P.'s Division of Forestry, said that logging has high rates of injury, and fatality rates higher than those of firefighting or police work. "It's a high-overhead business," he added. "Insurance -- liability and workman's compensation -- is a huge expense." Equipment is costly, with $800 chain saws just the beginning. A few years ago, the Nichols paid $83,000 for a new skidder and $90,000 for a used tri-axle logging truck. Each would cost more today, and Mr. Emmerthal noted that the latest, most sophisticated models are expensive indeed. "It's not hard to spend $250,000," he said.
 Logging has become increasingly professional in recent years. To remain certified as a "wood products harvester" or a "supervising wood products harvester," a logger must attend programs on topics like safety and environmentally sound practices. "It's not just a bunch of guys with chain saws," said Mrs. Nichols. "Loggers need to do a good job -- leave the woods in good shape, but also supply specific products." That means thorough planning and careful work. "When I meet with landowners," she said, "I try to get an idea of their objectives. I do an inventory, and I try to give them as much information as possible."
A logger also needs information. Where and how will this timber be used? Generally, said Mr. Nichols, "You need to know before you lay it on the ground." Every mill has specific requirements, for specific products, and those often change, Mr. Emmerthal pointed out. "You have to do a lot of homework, make a lot of phone calls," he said. "Say you cut a tree into 9-foot, 6-inch lengths. Maybe you'll find a market tomorrow that would have paid a third more for 9-foot, 8-inch lengths."
 Timber from Connecticut is marketed widely and winds up in all kinds of products.
Mrs. Nichols eyed the Jahodas' logs. "Better logs are going to a mill in Quebec. Lower grade material is going to local mills for railroad ties and pallet material," she said. The Jahodas' best logs would go to a veneer mill in northern Vermont. On a recent day Mrs. Nichols met in the Jahodas' driveway with Pierre Lambert, a mill owner from Quebec who had come to Connecticut to buy timber.
Loggers and landowners are always looking for good markets, affordable trucking has made longer hauls feasible, and new projects keep coming along. Mr. Connelly, the skidder operator, recently bought a sawmill and has been working with Mr. Nichols to learn more about wood and woodcutting. He hopes to sell manufactured post-and-beam house packages.
Almost 60 percent of Connecticut is forested, with about 90 percent of the forested land privately owned. "I don't worry about running out of timber," said Mrs. Nichols. "More is coming of age."
But there are concerns like the increasing fragmentation of woodlands. "Woodlots are getting smaller," she said, as owners divide their land among younger family members. Some people haven't the means or interest to keep a wooded parcel. Many owners just want to get their land cleared; they tell her they need the money.
Said Mrs. Nichols: "I tell them, 'I can do that. I can pay for your timber -- but you can't cut timber like that again for 40 years. It's not going to look pretty, and it's definitely not in the best interest of the resource'."
Sometimes, of course, land is simply cleared for new development. With rising land values, she noted, "The development pressure on woodlots are severe."
Mr. Nichols added that he has to make a living. If a landowner decides to clear everything, that's what he does. "I'd rather do lots like this," he said, looking over the Jahodas' carefully managed land. "Scott is a highly skilled logger; he handles his chain saw fast, but carefully," said Mr. Jahoda. "Joan has deep environmental concerns. She'll say, 'I don't think you should cut this,' even though it could be money in her pocket."
Mr. Jahoda has found that landowners are becoming more interested in management plans that not only produce timber but also provide other benefits, like improved wildlife habitat. "We've had a forestry plan here since 1980," he said. The family land -- which includes trails and a pond -- was named a model tree farm, or managed woodlot, in 1985.
 Trees kept falling. "I hate to see them come down," he said. "They're old friends -- but they're crowding the sugar maples. My son has about 350 taps here in the spring." He set off to show Mrs. Nichols the sugar house, where his son boils sap to make syrup. Meanwhile they talked. Oak growth is down, they noted, because so many deer and turkeys are devouring acorns.
Recent research suggests that acid rain is leeching calcium from the soil. "That's frightening," said Mr. Jahoda. But mostly they talked about their fondness for the woods. "This isn't just a paycheck," said Mrs. Nichols. "It gets under your skin." She belongs to logging and forestry organizations and is Lebanon's tree warden.
 Still, she chuckled when asked what she and her husband plan for their own woodlot -- 74 acres they just purchased in Lebanon. "Nothing right now," she said. "I'd like to walk the woods and not worry about working it."

HEADLINE: The View From/Larchmont;
Teaching Respect With a Drumbeat

BYLINE: By LYNNE AMES 

DATELINE: LARCHMONT

 BODY:
KENNETH LITTLE HAWK was beating the drum. Fast, fast, faster, until the children seated around him oohed and aahed. "Now," he said slowly, drawing out the word, "What drumbeat is that?" A little girl cried out, "Indian!" Mr. Little Hawk shook his head. "No, that's Hollywood. Indians do not play drums like that except in movies, when the director wanted to indicate that one of these red savages was lurking behind a rock or was going to drop out of the sky."
Then he smiled. "I'll show you how Indians really play drums." With hands on the skin of the drum he made a steady, vaguely familiar rhythm. "This is the beat of the heart, the beat of the human heart." 
 Mr. Little Hawk, 64, a Micmac Indian, was at the LIFE Center, a nonprofit environmental education organization on Weaver Street here. LIFE -- the letters stand for Local Involvement for Environment -- has been offering classes and workshops for 29 years. A few months ago it set up headquarters in a small house near the Larchmont Reservoir. The space enables them to hold more programs with special guests. Mr. Little Hawk was one of them.
"We want activities that can excite people from age 2 to 82," Suzanne Bartash, an administrator, said. Debbie Lazarus, chairwoman of family events, added: "We like to have as a guest someone who teaches respect for animals, plants and everything in nature. Certainly Mr. Little Hawk fit that bill. A striking, charismatic man with sculptured cheekbones and long silvery hair, he spoke of the Indian's reverence for the earth, saying, "All must work together to mend the global hoop that encompasses all two-legged, four-legged and winged ones and plant life."
He showed the 50 children and adults in his audience rattles made of gourds, drums made of turtle shells and a horn fashioned from a conch shell, telling them that Indians do not like waste and believe there is a use for everything. In a slow, sonorous voice he told tales of his people.
But there is more than myth and romance to Kenneth Little Hawk. He is a sophisticated person who has worked a wide variety of jobs before settling into his current identity, 15 years ago, as performer and spokesman. He has acted on stage and in film, taught economics at the college level and held a secret government engineering job. He grew up in Orange, N.J. -- he still lives in that state, in Whiting in the Pine Barrens -- but he has traveled throughout the United States and beyond.
"At one point, in the early 1980's I decided to track down my grandmother's people," he recalled. "I went to Nova Scotia and found people who knew my family. On the way back I stopped in reservations in Canada and America. I met Indians who were alcoholics, drug addicts, people in sad situations, people in trouble, who were no longer interested in the old ways, in the old people and what they had to offer. So I decided to do this, to give talks and performances to as many as who would listen, to get the message across."
That message begins as soon as one looks at Mr. Little Hawk. On this evening he was wearing black fringed pants and jacket, moccasins, a breastplate and many necklaces. Audience members asked about those, and he described them: a choker made of abalone shell by a Lakota friend, an oyster shell with the meat still fossilized inside "gifted to me" by a fellow actor in a California production of the play "Black Elk Speaks," a little leather medicine pouch filled with herbs, roots, bark and leaves, "some known, some unknown."
He also showed the children and their parents (and a few adults who had come without youngsters) how to make use of everyday objects. "Before the Europeans brought iron to this country, our pots were made of tightly woven straw and grass or of skins," he said. "But you could not just put that on the fire, it would burn. So when we wanted to heat water, for example, we had to heat the stones and then, when they were very hot, put them in the water.
"One day my grandmother said to me, 'Do you know what else you can do with stones? You can hold them in your hand and drum with them.' " He demonstrated with two small, smooth rocks, creating sounds both resonantly hollow and clicking and flat by shifting the weight and position of his fingers. "So you can play drums with stones, but you must never, never throw stones at people or at animals. The animals are people, too."
Next came a demonstration of a rattling musical instrument made of nutshells. "When you have a bowl of fruit and nuts, you probably eat the nuts and throw out the shells. But Indians do not. We tie them to a string and make a nutshell rattle." He shook it loudly and the room grew hushed. "See, you don't have to go to Toys "R" Us for everything."
This mix of reverence and humor was typical. Mr. Little Hawk would weave a spell with his words, play a haunting little melody on a bamboo flute or cast an intense look at the audience. And then he would deliberately break the mood with a modern reference, reminding people that, after all, he was not only an Indian with knowledge of the old lore but also a regular late-20th-century guy.
The combination intrigued his audience, but there were a few who seemed uncomfortable. Michael Glotzer, 62, a retired retailer, said to Mr. Little Hawk: "I heard you call yourself an Indian. I thought that wasn't politically correct. Why don't you say Native American?"
Mr. Little Hawk looked torn between a frown and a laugh, but chose to smile and said: "I'm not about political correctness. I was an Indian way before political correctness. My brother once said to me, 'Indian is a good thing. When Columbus first came to these shores, he spoke Spanish. In Spanish, "in" means "of." "Dios" means God. So, to the Spanish, we are "Indios," people of God. I'm O.K. being an Indian."

HEADLINE: In the Region / New Jersey;
State Program Primes Distressed-Area Projects

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
AFTER more than 15 years of abandonment and neglect the nearly nine-acre site in the southern half of Woodbury -- mostly rundown buildings, including a 19th century factory that once was an industrial engine for the southern New Jersey city -- was a shambles.
Now the site, comprising seven separate but contiguous parcels along Green Avenue within a city-designated redevelopment area, will be transformed into a residential enclave for the elderly. 
 Woodbury MewsSenior Campus, as the project is known, is expected to include 290 independent and assisted-living rental units -- some with meals and support services for low- and moderate-income elderly tenants -- in two new buildings and the old factory, which will be rehabilitated and expanded.
There will also be two other new buildings and one renovated building to house, among other things, medical offices, recreation space and an adult day-care center.
The project will be built in phases over the next two years, with the renovation and expansion of the factory to begin this spring. The entire project is being developed by International Senior Development L.L.C. of Jenkintown, Pa., at an estimated cost of $34 million.
Woodbury Mews is moving forward thanks to a new $425-million state program called New Jersey Urban Site Acquisition, or NJ-USA. It provides interim loans for the acquisition of distressed or abandoned properties that are part of viable redevelopment plans as well as further financial assistance in redeveloping the sites. The aim is to spur or enhance a revival in the surrounding neighborhood.
Thomas B. Bowe, the City Administrator of Woodbury, said that the Woodbury Mewes project would not only turn around a "financial albatross and community eyesore," but cause a domino effect in the rest of the 15-block redevelopment area where the city plans to rehabilitate low- and moderate-income houses.
The NJ-USA program, begun last summer, is the latest in an ongoing effort to make redevelopment easier in the state's urban centers.
"Too many buildings we see boarded up stay that way for an eternity," Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said in her inaugural address a year ago, referring to the need for the NJ-USA initiative. "But cities find it too difficult to take action and so they sit there ugly and unprofitable. This program will enable cities to acquire and redevelop these properties that stand in the way of redevelopment efforts."
The New Jersey Legislature last July appropriated $25 million in general state revenue to create a revolving fund for the program to provide short-term loans to local governments, nonprofit groups or private developers to buy such properties. The loans, which are offered at below-market rates, generally are expected to run six to 18 months and are usually secured by the property.
Because distressed or abandoned properties often come with tax liens the loans will, if necessary, also cover the cost of obtaining clear title to them. Other state sources will be available to overcome other impediments to redevelopment often associated with sites, such as environmental cleanup costs.
The significance of the fund, state officials said, is that no other state program offers short-term loans for acquiring properties, especially in urban areas where redevelopment is difficult even in the best of circumstances. Groups borrowing from the fund might not be able to get loans from conventional sources because of the risks involved with projects at this early stage of development.
"Yes, there is more of a risk with these projects, but sometimes the state has to take the risk," said Jane M. Kenny, commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs, which oversees the NJ-USA program. "This is one of our most important tools because it helps make problem properties shovel-ready."
"The state," she added, "is not so much interested in the redevelopment of one boarded-up building, but rather to direct its resources to projects that will help rebuild whole neighborhoods."
To be eligible for the NJ-USA loans projects must be part of a larger municipal redevelopment plan for the area and be in one of the 67 urban-aid municipalities in the state. There are no maximum loan amounts.
While the state money doesn't represent the major portion of redevelopment financing it helps "fill in the financial gaps," said William Best, executive director of the New Jersey Redevelopment Authority, which manages the NJ-USA program.
"It is a way to prime the pump because it provides the risk capital needed to spur redevelopment efforts in cities," he added. The authority, an independent agency within the state's Department of Community Affairs, was created two years ago to invest in projects in the state's urban-aid municipalities.
IN Woodbury, International Senior Development received a $1.4 million loan to buy the seven Green Avenue parcels. It is the first of eight loans approved under the program to close. Of the other seven approved loans, together totaling some $7.4 million, the largest is a $4 million loan to the Housing Authority of the City of Elizabeth.
The housing authority will use the money to purchase land in the Elizabethport section to build 115 rental units for low- and moderate-income tenants. That project is part of a larger plan to replace two timeworn public housing complexes in the area, together totaling 655 rental units in 20 buildings, with 608 new residences, some on scattered sites elsewhere in the Elizabethport section.
Projects approved under the program will also be able to take advantage of an additional $400 million in financial assistance available through the New Jersey Housing Mortgage Finance Agency and the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, also within the state's Department of Community Affairs. Those agencies, respectively, will issue $100 million and $300 million in bonds to provide financial assistance. The assistance will include construction loans, at below-market rates, as well as permanent mortgages, depending on the site's planned commercial or residential reuse.
For the developer of the housing project for the elderly in Woodbury, the $1.4 million received from the NJ-USA program "expedited the project by months, if not years," said Garry R. Hoffarth, a principal at International Senior Development.
"Typically, conventional lenders are reluctant to put that amount of money into projects that are in the planning stage," Mr. Hoffarth said. Gaining control early of the site, he added, gives the project a sense of reality, which will make a difference when trying to attract other financing from the state as well as private lenders.
The first phase of the project includes the development of 112 rental units -- with meals, recreation and personal care as options -- for moderate-income tenants 70 and older with an annual income of no more than $22,000 for a single person or $35,000 for a couple.
The units will be in the 1830's factory, a local landmark where pharmaceuticals were once manufactured, which will be renovated and expanded by 80,000 square feet to 100,000 square feet, Mr. Hoffarth said. Monthly rents for studios or one-bedroom units are expected to range from $1,000 to $2,500, he said, depending on the size of the apartment and the services elected.
As now envisioned, later phases of the project will include a two-building, 178-unit assisted-living complex and a 10,000-square-foot building containing medical offices and an adult day-care center. In addition, there will be a recreation center in a renovated barn and a separate, newly constructed day-care center for children, the sizes of which have yet to be determined. Mr. Hoffarth said Hospicomm of Philadelphia would manage the housing component for the elderly and provide the personal care.
The site was purchased from the City of Woodbury, which owned the factory parcel after taking it back through foreclosure a decade earlier. The city, using its condemnation powers under the state's redevelopment laws, purchased the remaining parcels, one of which had a $60,000 tax lien.
Mr. Bowe, the city administrator, said the sale of the property, "enhances the tax base of the city" since part of the site was not generating tax revenue for the last decade. And after reimbursing the existing property owners the city has some $500,000 "to fold into its housing program," for the area, he said, noting that without the state money "we would still be knocking on doors."
The city plans to buy and rehabilitate low- and moderate-income residences on blocks adjacent to Woodbury Mews after relocating the present tenants. The houses, many now rundown and owned by absentee landlords, will then be sold to individuals, rather than as a package to investors. Though that money is not sufficient to redevelop the up to 90 residences initially included in the plan the hope is that the activity taking place in the area will draw private investors elsewhere in the redevelopment neighborhood, Mr. Bowe said.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 1; Column 2; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1384 words

HEADLINE: In School, Summer and Saturdays, Too

BYLINE: By FRANCES CHAMBERLAIN 

 BODY:
EDUCATORS note with alarm the growing discrepancy between test scores in city schools, where crowded classrooms, poverty and limited resources depress test results, and in more affluent suburban schools.
So some Connecticut school districts are making a concerted effort to even the score by requiring that students in academic jeopardy attend Saturday morning classes or summer school. 
 New Haven schools initiated changes last year, when letters went to the parents of 2,000 children who were advised to attend summer school. Enrollment jumped from 810 in 1997 to 1,239 in 1998 after the notification.
This year, there won't be much choice. Any child in third grade who has not mastered the basics of reading and writing will be required to attend summer classes, or repeat third grade.
Children who do attend will be assessed at the end of the summer, and if they test more than a grade below where they should be in reading proficiency, will spend another year in third grade, in addition to attending after school and Saturday classes.
"We needed to do something to raise the consciousness of parents," explained Dr. Reginald Mayo, New Haven's Superintendent of Schools. "A drastic promotion/retention policy will get their attention."
Dr. Mayo's plan did get attention; many parents are enthusiastic and have volunteered to help on Saturday mornings. "I've been applauded for this more than anything I've ever done," he said. "People want their kids to learn. The overwhelming majority realize that we're trying to help, not hurt."
Waterbury's schoolchildren face a similar program with a recently approved Saturday Academy, scheduled to begin March 6, a proposal for mandatory summer school and the eradication of social promotion. This traditional practice involved moving students on to the next grade regardless of whether or not they had acquired the appropriate skills.
The shift in educational policy comes about, in part, because of the discrepancy between Connecticut Mastery Test scores in urban and rural areas. "We started to cast about for an economical solution for the short term," explained the Waterbury Superintendent, Dr. Roger Damerow. "All of this is an attempt to deal with test scores."
The initiatives are being supported by a $20 million state grant, approved by Gov. John G. Rowland and the state legislature, to improve reading literacy in 14 cities. "The funding comes from the state," explained Tom Murphy, a spokesman for the State Board of Education, "but the program designs are local."
While New Haven and Waterbury chose the Saturday academy and summer school model, "In Hartford they decided to hire a reading specialist for every school. They will evaluate every student and work with them to improve literacy," Mr. Murphy said. "There isn't any 'one size fits all' to this. The funds were designed to help districts expand programs. There are 14 different designs for this state initiative. We'll see how it turns out and learn from each district."
Young students in the city are up against special challenges, Dr. Damerow said. "In a suburban school, the students all come in on the same footing," he explained. "Here, they come with no English skills or no toilet training, while others have parents who take them to the museum every day. There is no baseline from which you can teach."
Mastery tests have been used to assess progress since 1993, Mr. Murphy said, and the state average has risen consistently.
"However the cities all lag far below the state average and quite far below the more affluent suburbs. The urban areas are 20 to 30 points below," he said. "These are very important numbers and we do regard this type of targeted grant with contributing to closing that gap. This is designed to help all students develop a command of reading by the end of third grade so they can read to learn."
Dr. Damerow added, "We want to do a better job with a really diverse population." About 600 to 650 children, grades kindergarten through third, will be recommended for the Saturday Academy.
"Our test scores aren't bad among other Connecticut cities, but they are poor in terms of other schools in the state," Dr. Damerow said. "The kids vary in ability, but it's not their fault. The parents are sometimes preoccupied with their own survival."
At one Waterbury elementary school, Dr. Damerow explained, children have more to deal with than they should. "There were murders in the neighborhood and people were breaking into the building to steal kids' clothes, gloves and boots to sell them. Can you imagine then what the kids are like? I was a mentor for one boy who moved five or six times in 1 1/2 years. The family had nothing and the little boy was left to fend for himself. These are scenarios that don't play out in the suburban or small town places. I'm not trying to paint the city as a bleak, awful place; it's not. But each city child is more of a story than the average suburban child. The variables are daunting."
Joseph Nolan, a third grade teacher and vice principal at Barnard School, said, "Children need to find success, and if they find success at an early age it could pay rewards. Waterbury has a fairly high drop-out rate. Maybe the academy will turn kids on to school. There will be 10 kids in a class, with teachers who want to be there. It should be positive."
Dr. Anne Wigg, who teaches a preschool program at Driggs Elementary, said, "People are tired of talking about what's wrong. They want to create effective change." Dr. Wigg, who spends her after-school hours as a volunteer tutor for about 12 students, added, "This wide spectrum has a lot to do with home environments. I have three children in my class whose fathers have been killed this school year."
Both teachers, however, argue that rather than limiting their classrooms, the cultural diversity of the city adds richness. "We have an incredible mix of kids here," Mr. Nolan added.
Dr. Paul Sequeira, Waterbury's assistant superintendent, has been responsible for many of the logistics of organizing the Saturday Academy. "There is tremendous need here," he said. "Kids must meet exit criteria and master competencies. Saturday academies identify kids who are at risk, pull them out now, work with them and meet their deficits."
The academy will be held for three-hour periods on 22 Saturdays, he explained. "It's like regular school, but with a different approach. We have a good cadre of people to make it work. This forces us all to think differently, be creative, and address the needs of the client -- the parent and child."
He added, "If we've identified the child as needing help and the parents refuse, we ask them to sign a waiver. What has been done here before hasn't worked. There is a recognition from the staff that we need this."
In New Haven, Dr. Mayo has identified two basic goals. "We want to see a 5 percent increase in reading, writing and math scores on the Connecticut Mastery Tests, and we want kids to be reading on grade level in third grade by the year 2001," he said. "Youngsters who move on, past grade four, without these skills, usually don't do well in the rest of their academic careers. Right now, this is our benchmark."
The Saturday Academy in his city is open to second, third and fourth grade students at six elementary school sites. They will have 45-minute classes in reading, math and writing, based on Connecticut Mastery Test strategies, plus one recreation class in gym, music or art. There are 650 children enrolled to date.
The Stamford School District is also considering a Saturday Academy, according to Tom Murphy at the State Board of Education.
And what do the students themselves think of such programs?
Mr. Nolan, at Waterbury's Barnard School, asked his class about the value of Saturday morning classes.
One third grader thought the whole plan was simply no good: "I think Saturday morning school is a bad idea. Because some people might not want to go, that's why. I'm not going to Saturday morning school. I just need to know my math and I just don't really care."
But others were for the plan. "I think Saturday School is good," replied one student. "Because some of us learn more. It might be fun and exciting. We might like it. We just might have fun."

HEADLINE: Businesses in Pursuit Of an Elusive Labor Pool

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
WHEN Leo James Dufour Jr. advertised for assemblers and cabinet makers for his business, Connecticut Carpentry in Meriden, he said he got a few responses, but most of them weren't qualified to work at his 14-year-old company.
"Our ads say you have to have five years' experience, and the only guys we get in the door have barely been behind a table saw," Mr. Dufour said. "I employ seven people now, but that's only because that's all I can find. I've got a lot of work booked for 1999, but the problem is finding good, skilled employees." 
 Wilson Morin, president of Capital Erectors in Southington, which puts up steel frames for buildings, had much the same lament: "As long as people have some basic skills," he said, "we can train them. But the last ad I ran for welders, I got a dozen responses -- one was a piano player, one was a painter and a couple of them were factory workers.
"It's hard to find any qualified help," Mr. Morin said. "And to make it worse, people are stealing each others' employees. You take the time and spend the money to train someone and the next thing you know someone is hiring them away."
In fact, help-wanted signs were more common than sidewalk Santas in most Connecticut cities over the holidays, and they are one sign that hasn't come down. Most economists say the most serious problem facing the state's economy in 1999 is a shortage of workers to fill the jobs that have been created in an expansion that began seven years ago.
Dr. William McEachern, an economist at the University of Connecticut in Storrs and editor of a quarterly digest on the state's economy, said Connecticut added about 20,000 jobs last year, and he expected it would grow by about 15,000 jobs this year.
"The reason job growth is going to slow is not that the jobs aren't there, just that the bodies aren't there to fill them," Dr. McEachern said. "If you go look in the technical schools in the state right now, anybody who's graduating in June already has a job lined up."
The United States Labor Department estimates that over the last six years, the number of jobs in the state has increased by 130,000, while the labor force has shrunk by 100,000, Dr. McEachern said. While he thinks those statistics might be exaggerated, "There's no question that the job situation is very, very tight."
Tim Phelan, president of the Connecticut Retail Merchants Association, said retailers have mixed feelings about the labor situation in Connecticut.
"When the economy is strong most folks aren't looking for part-time work to supplement their income, so retailers have a little trouble filling jobs," Mr. Phelan said. "On the other hand, that usually means most people are working full-time, and they have more money to spend, and that's good for retailers."
But experts say all employers could be squeezed as the labor situation tightens further. Todd Martin, an economist with People's Bank in Bridgeport, said there has been a 2 percent increase in jobs every year for the last few years, while population has been growing at less than half that rate. The unemployment rate in the state is just 3.4 percent, generally much lower than the national rate, and in some areas it dips even lower, such as Stamford's 2 percent.
"With a labor market that is that tight, you would expect that companies are going to compete very heavily for skilled workers, and we're seeing that in some sectors, such as computer programmers, companies are bidding very high for the best workers," Mr. Martin said.
The result is twofold, Mr. Martin said. First, companies unable to find employees will either rein in their expansion plans, or create jobs in a state where the labor market is not quite so restrictive. Or, companies will spend more money training unskilled workers who are still available in the state, raising their cost of doing business and making them less competitive at a national level.
Either strategy is likely to rein in the state's economic recovery, he said.
Peter Gioia, an economist with the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, said, "We've done three surveys on the business climate in the last six months, and what has come through in all of them is that companies are having a difficult time finding employees, particularly at a high skill level, but even at the entry level. Availability of workers is something that has popped up very strongly on our radar screen, where in past years it wasn't there at all."
A financial services company in the same building where the association is headquartered recently had its first job fair to attract potential employees, and it is offering existing employees a bonus if they recruit a new employee.
"Companies are doing a lot of things differently these days -- using more temporary help, making more use of overtime, using the Internet to find workers out of state," Mr. Gioia said. He said the problem could grow particularly acute in the coming year, as the economy continues its long recovery. One recent survey of association members who employ 25 or more people found that 40 percent said they planned to create more than 10 new jobs in the next two years, and almost half of those said the number would exceed 25.
Dr. Edward J. Deak, a professor at Fairfield University and head of the New England Economics Project, said it seems inconsistent to have a labor shortage when so many of the state's largest employers, particularly in the military and insurance industries, are laying off workers.
"The problem is, are they going to match up their skills with another job?" Dr. Deak said. "If people are laid off in financial services, are they going to try to find a job in retail trade, where there are openings?"
Larry Davidson, president of Weathervane, the New Britain-based clothing retailer that has 54 stores stretching as far west as Ohio, said he has managed to fill most of the sales openings in his Connecticut stores with part-time high school and college students. His problem is filling jobs back at headquarters, the accountants and other specialists who keep the enterprise on track. The labor situation in Connecticut is one of the worst he faces, particularly for the kind of people he needs to hire, he said.
"The problem is the applicant pool of people from post-college to their early 30's is smaller here," Mr. Davidson said. "We don't have as big a pool of college graduates to pick from as other states. It's a demographic issue. I think many people don't perceive Connecticut as a vibrant place for young, single professionals, so they're going somewhere else."
Eric C. Allen, vice president for human resources at Greenwich Hospital, which employs about 1,300 people, said in today's labor market, any large employer has a continuous recruiting program underway.
"We've seen a steady tightening in the job market the last few years, but particularly in the last year," Mr. Allen said. "In certain of our professional and technical areas, it's very difficult to find someone. Radiation therapists, computerized tomography technicians, intensive care and operating room nurses -- any of the serious technical areas, those jobs are very difficult to fill.
"But whatever you're looking for, it's a tough environment," Mr. Allen said. "You have to look longer and see more people, which increases your recruiting time, and costs."
