HEADLINE: White Elephants, Big and Empty, Await Their Fates

BYLINE: By SUSAN E. KONIG

 BODY:
THE lights are finally being turned out at the 1.5 million-square-foot Lockheed Martin building in Lake Success. The 58-year-old structure, which served as United Nations headquarters from 1946 until 1951, will be empty by mid-month as the last of the plant's 500 employees move to a new, more modest building in Uniondale.
Developers are full of ideas about how to redevelop the 93-acre property. But until a plan is adopted, the Lake Success site will join the list of Long Island white elephants, the large buildings and properties that sit empty while their owners consider what to do with them, often disagreeing with their neighbors and local governments on issues like taxes, pollution and the impact of redevelopment on traffic and surrounding property values. 
 Easily the most notorious of these properties is the mothballed Shoreham nuclear power plant in Wading River. But the Island's economic shifts and changing values in health care and education have produced a sizable herd of white elephants, ranging from sprawling complexes like the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in Brentwood to relatively cozy properties like St. Paul's School in Garden City.
Some properties are coming off the white-elephant list. Grumman's old sites in Bethpage and Calverton are being put to new commercial uses. Stephen Jones, Suffolk County's director of planning, is optimistic that the list may soon be further reduced.
"The nation's economy is great," he said, "and being so close to New York City, the financial center of the world, Long Island feels the waves of growth pretty quickly. This kind of growth has been happening at about 10-year intervals, and it's happening now. Yes, changing economic tides have left quite a few properties empty. But new growth spurts are touching them and making them ripe for redevelopment, particularly the vacant military-industrial sites and state hospitals."
No single redevelopment plan could work at such disparate sites as Lake Success, Garden City, Brentwood and Calverton, and all the plans are still in preliminary stages. But they have this much in common: a desire to develop for a variety of uses. The emphasis on mixed use reflects a change in the Island's economy, Mr. Jones said.
"In the 80's, the Reagan years, our growth was still largely based on defense buildup," he said. "Now our economy is much more diversified. We need space for computer and information systems, service-oriented businesses and offices. There are also markets for housing, retail and recreational space -- not the heavy industry the Island once had to support."
But even in a boom, redevelopment doesn't happen overnight. Plans must be drawn, financing arranged and permits secured. The process can be halted at any stage by community opposition. Negotiations can take months, or years.
When visions of these properties range from parks to shopping malls, disagreements are inevitable. For example, Wilbur Breslin, president of Breslin Realty Development Corporation in Garden City, said that if the existing buildings are demolished, Lockheed Martin, Pilgrim and even St. Paul's could succeed as retail sites.
"Each of these properties has tremendous potential value for commercial use like shopping centers," said Mr. Breslin, whose specialty is shopping centers. "Many of the Island's strip malls, which were built in the 1970's and 80's, have high vacancy rates -- about 30 percent -- because they were poorly designed and offer little parking. But these huge sites could be redeveloped into enormously successful retail areas."
Such statements do not sit well with Lee Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board. "I think Long Island has peaked out in terms of major shopping centers," he said. "Many of the major malls, like Walt Whitman and Roosevelt Field, have been expanded in recent years.
"At this point," he said, "more major retail centers are the last thing Long Island needs."
 
LOCKHEED MARTIN
From Manufacturing To Hotels and Gyms
Lockheed Martin is the last of several military contractors to occupy the Lake Success property. Its original tenant was Sperry Gyroscope, which made bomb sights and other precision equipment during and after World War II. Its 20,000 workers made it one of the largest employment sites in Long Island history.
Sperry Gyroscope (later Sperry Rand) leased the property from the Federal Government before buying it in 1951. In 1986, Sperry merged with the Burroughs electronics company to form Unisys. The Loral Corporation acquired the complex when it bought Unisys's defense electronics division in 1995, and Lockheed Martin acquired Loral in 1996.
Kendl Philbrick, a Lockheed Martin spokesman, said that downsizing of its Long Island operations rendered the Lake Success site too large for the company's needs and made it too expensive to maintain.
Lockheed could sell the building "as is" to another user or it could sell off parcels to developers. But North American Realty Advisory Services, a real estate consulting company in Manhattan that has been retained by Lockheed Martin to help create a redevelopment plan, favors keeping the property and tearing the place down. Theodore Pugh, the consultants' senior vice president, stressed that a plan for multiple uses would be based on demolishing the building and starting from scratch.
"People are looking for more open space and less traffic," Mr. Pugh said. "We are proposing mixed uses as the best way to accommodate that."
In September, a 13-member task force representing Lockheed Martin, the Town of North Hempstead, the Village of Lake Success and local business and civic groups began meeting to monitor proposals and make a recommendation. The consensus thus far is that the land should be developed under a master plan, rather than subdivided and developed piecemeal, Mr. Pugh said. Other community concerns include traffic, maintaining the tax base, creating jobs and making certain that groundwater contamination from years of military manufacturing is remedied.
The latest proposal, developed by Mr. Pugh, involves demolishing the existing building and erecting a 300-room hotel with conference center, 300 housing units for the elderly, a 150-bed geriatric center, a 60,000-square-foot sports and fitness center, 530,000 square feet of office space and another 72,000 square feet of retail stores and restaurants. A new road would be built between Marcus Avenue and Union Turnpike to help ease traffic. Five thousand parking spaces could be added while still turning more than 35 acres of building and parking lots into green space.
"I believe this mixed-use plan will have the least amount of negative impact over time," Mr. Pugh said. "Nassau County has gotten much more congested since that building was first built. Because of increased downsizing at the site, there have been fewer and fewer people coming and going. But if another industrial firm comes in, the area will be very overcrowded and have a tough time supporting the flow of traffic."
Not everyone is pleased with the proposal. Marietta DiCamillo, a 17-year resident of New Hyde Park and a task force member, said she was concerned the plan was "too dense" and would add too much traffic to the area. Ms. DiCamillo said that she and other neighbors would like to see "more housing on the property and not so much commercial activity."
"This community recognizes that redeveloping the site is inevitable," she said. "But we want to see reasonable, rational growth. If the proposed plan were to go forth as it is, people who live south of this property would face endless hours of traffic jams, noise, air pollution and, frankly, far too many cars. We're entitled to the suburban life style that New Hyde Park and Long Island represent, and we hope a mutually agreeable conclusion can be met."
Mr. Pugh said that once a plan is agreed on, "the entire approval process could take as long as 18 months, after which the individual buildings must be approved before any construction could begin."
 
ST. PAUL'S SCHOOL
Historic Landmark May House Elderly
St. Paul's School, in the heart of Garden City on Stewart Avenue, is an architectural masterpiece listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Victorian Gothic structure was part of an elaborate Episcopal Church complex built as a memorial to Alexander Turney Stewart, Garden City's founder, by his wife, Cornelia, after Mr. Stewart's death in 1876. St. Paul's, a boys' school, was completed in 1883, the Episcopal Cathedral in 1885 and St. Mary's, a girls' school, in 1892.
St. Paul's eventually merged with St. Mary's, but the village historian, John Ellis Kordes, said that by the end, enrollment had declined by about 75 percent from a peak in the 1950's and 1960's. The school was closed after graduating a class of 28 in 1991, and the site was offered for sale the following year.
The diocese was unable to find a buyer, according to Robert Schoelle, the Village Administrator, so in 1993, the village purchased the 48-acre site for an appraised price of $7.2 million, with a notion of making it the village government offices.
The two largest outbuildings, a field house and gymnasium holding five basketball courts, were quickly put to use as a recreational center. But the Village Hall idea soon foundered -- the village had bought the building without performing sufficient structural analysis.
"We thought about moving our Village Hall there, which is greatly in need of upgrading," Mr. Schoelle said. "But a structural engineering firm determined that while the building was basically sound, it would need more than $18 million in rehabilitation, and that was simply too prohibitive."
Six years after the sale, the main building and its library sit idle.
A committee of Garden City residents and village officials was formed to investigate other uses. "We spent a couple of years looking at proposals from private schools, as well as from the Board of Education for a public high school," Mr. Schoelle said, "but again, the cost was prohibitive."
After 111 public meetings, including 15 with the Board of Trustees, 25 presentations to the village's property owners' associations, 18 interviews with development consultants and 19 with potential buyers, the committee released its recommendations in December 1996:
The village would keep 38 acres of fields for use as a park or for athletic activities; the gymnasium and field house would be used for cultural, social and athletic activities; the library, as well as eight modest cottages on the premises, would be razed, and the main building would be leased to a developer for a living facility for the elderly.
The committee is now negotiating with Carematrix, a Massachusetts concern, for a 148-unit geriatric housing facility. Fifty-seven units would be in the old main building; the remainder would be in a 66,000-square-foot wing the company plans to add to the back of the structure.
Mr. Schoelle's office said that Carematrix's latest offer includes payments of nearly $3.8 million over a lease lasting at least 40 years. The payments would cover barely half of Garden City's investment. Officials noted that Carematrix would also be making additional annual payments in lieu of village taxes, but the amount was not specified.
The deal would preserve the old building, however -- no small consideration in a village that in 1973 allowed the Stanford White-designed Garden City Hotel to be torn down to make room for a more modern but far less attractive structure.
Carematrix's renovations and new construction would take about two years, Mr. Schoelle said, cautioning that "everything is still being negotiated. There's no formal deal as yet."
"In making our decision, we were looking for a demand-driven enterprise," Mr. Schoelle said. "Senior assisted living is an industry which is growing at a tremendous rate."
It also offers the "quietest use of the building," Mr. Schoelle added, "without increasing traffic in the area."
Mr. Kordes said he supported the assisted-living plan.
"St. Paul's is an architectural gem and a local landmark, and I think the village trustees are doing the right thing, trying to find life for it in the 21st century," Mr. Kordes said. "By leasing it to Carematrix, it will get the rehabilitation it needs, and we don't lose control of it. I don't know of any better alternative."
Not everyone agrees. James and Barbara Kenny and Lawrence and Barbara Rafferty, longtime residents of Garden City, filed suit in December 1997 to stop the lease of St. Paul's to Carematrix. Mr. Kenny said the lease would be "an illegal alienation of public-trust property, since the village acquired the property with the promise that it would be used as a public space."
Mr. Kenny maintains it would take a state legislative act to legalize private use of this public space.
"We voted on the property with the understanding that the main building would be used as a town hall," he said. "Now the village says the cost of rehabilitation is $18 million and too prohibitive. I don't believe that's so. I think it could be restored for a lot less."
"I'm not opposed to having the historic main building used for senior housing," he added. "What I am opposed to is the addition of 66,000 square feet and the razing of the chapel. That's not preservation."
The case is pending in state court, with arguments scheduled for March 22.
 
PILGRIM STATE
A Development Plan Is Kept Vague
Once listed by the Guinness Book of World Records as the largest psychiatric hospital in the Western world, the 70-year-old Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center includes 69 buildings on 820 acres of property in Brentwood. In the 1950's, the center accommodated 16,000 psychiatric patients in its 4.3 million square feet. Today, however, the number of patients is down to just over 1,000, and after a short stint housing a 1,000-inmate prison (closed because of local opposition), most of the buildings are vacant, costing the state about $2.5 million a year to maintain.
Two years ago, Governor Pataki announced plans to sell surplus land at 12 psychiatric hospitals in New York State. In a sealed-bid process, more than 1,100 acres at three centers in Suffolk County were finally sold last November: 44 acres at the former Central Islip Psychiatric Center; 408 acres at the Long Island Development Center in Melville, and 655 acres at Pilgrim State. Some 20 buildings on 165 acres at Pilgrim will be kept by the state Office of Mental Health and other organizations to accommodate psychiatric patients, said James Morgo, president of The Long Island Housing Partnership in Hauppauge, a nonprofit agency dedicated to establishing affordable housing on the Island.
The Melville-based Reckson Associates Realty Corporation won the 655-acre Pilgrim State property with a bid of $32 million.
Three years ago, a task force of community members and state and town officials was formed to oversee plans for the property's redevelopment. Thus far, a master plan recommends that one million square feet be devoted to recreational and athletic activities, 500,000 square feet for office space, 300,000 for industrial uses and 90,000 for commercial use, and that up to 500 housing units be built on 100 acres of land.
Reckson Associates must meet various specifications before getting final approval to redevelop the site. The existing buildings, most of which contain asbestos, must be demolished and rainwater catch basins must be cleaned up, according to Empire State Redevelopment Corporation in Manhattan, the state's economic development agency, which, along with the task force, will negotiate and finalize the sale.
Mr. Koppelman, the Planning Board director, warned that too much retail development at the site would "dry up Brentwood's central business district."
The people at Reckson remain tight-lipped about their exact plans for the property, until they meet task force approval. Gregg Rechler, Reckson's executive vice president, said its plan would involve "a mixed-use approach, as the task force and community have recommended," but that he could not be more specific. "It's difficult to say at this time exactly what our master plan will be, because we're working with these other people," he said.
But at least one member of the task force wants Reckson to make the first move. The Rev. Gerald Twomey of St. Anne's Catholic Church in Brentwood said he was waiting to see a master plan proposal.
"Still," he said, "the proposed senior housing is very important. Islip Township has the largest percentage of seniors of any township in the country, so affordable senior housing is very much needed here. Also, Brentwood is something of a poverty pocket on Long Island, so I think any development that brings new jobs and tax abatement is a definite plus for us."
 
NORTHROP-GRUMMAN
Military Complex To 'Enterprise Park'
It has been nearly three years since Northrop-Grumman closed its operations at the 5,900-acre, federally owned Naval Weapons Industrial Reserve Plant in Calverton, eliminating not just hundreds of high-paying jobs but also about $1 million a year the military contractor had been paying the Town of Riverhead in lieu of taxes. Last month, however, the property regained a pulse when 1,625 acres were approved for sale by the Town of Riverhead to three developers for $36 million in cash.
The Federal Government gave Riverhead 2,900 acres of the Calverton site, which Grumman had rented from the Navy for 40 years, just six months ago, and handed the remaining 3,000 acres to the state Department of Environmental Conservation as a nature preserve.
About the same time, the state made Riverhead's property -- which it calls the Enterprise Park at Calverton -- more attractive for investors by designating 1,248 acres as an economic development zone, giving owners and tenants a variety of tax- and cost-cutting incentives, including lower utility rates, tax credits for job creation and sales tax exemptions on construction materials.
Lazarus Burman Associates, a Syosset development group, was one of the three companies that have risen to the bait. Andrea H. Lohneiss, the head of Riverhead's Community Development Agency, said Lazarus Burman had offered Riverhead $17 million for the property's 525-acre industrial section, which includes 1.1 million square feet of industrial and office space as well as a 10,000-foot runway. The company could build up to two million additional square feet of office space, Ms. Lohneiss said, and the runway would be used by industrial tenants, rather than for commercial use.
Landmark National, a developer of golf communities based in New Albany, Ohio, has offered $13.6 million for 800 acres, Ms. Lohneiss said, and would build two 18-hole golf courses at an estimated cost of over $30 million, a 300-room hotel and conference center, and up to 300 single-family homes that would surround the golf courses. Landmark was the developer of several renowned golf courses, including Palm Beach Polo in Palm Beach, Fla., and P.G.A. West in Palm Springs, Calif.
A third major buyer would be N.H.L. Skate, an affiliate of the Manhattan-based Mentmore Holdings Corp., which has offered $5.4 million for 300 acres, where it plans to build a baseball stadium, a sports complex and a family entertainment center.
Of the remaining 1,275 acres owned by Riverhead, 410 acres of pine barrens have been designated for preservation and can never be developed. Some of the rest will be dedicated to green space, some may be used for a sewage treatment plant, and only 200 acres are not spoken for, Ms. Lohneiss said.
Ms. Lohneiss's agency, which includes town residents and business leaders experienced in real estate development, will draw up and finalize the sales contracts. She predicted that environmental impact studies and zoning changes should not be stumbling blocks at this point, noting that the Navy completed an environmental review of the site before Riverhead took possession. A rezoning plan to accommodate the proposed uses is also already under way, she added, and could be in place as early as April.
Community reaction seems uniformly positive, presaging little of the rancor that has infected the planning for other white-elephant sites. Harvey Hellering, a retired telecommunications executive who has lived in Riverhead for 13 years, called the plans ideal.
"We don't want an enormous development here, because it's where we live," he said. "But the Calverton site is very out of the way. You don't pass it as you drive along the main highways. It's a beautiful development which is completely infrastructured and doesn't need much work. Yet it's been just sitting there. The Town of Riverhead has so much tax-free government land that we really don't have a good tax base, and we lost about $1 million a year when Grumman left. Now we have the chance to regain that money."
He also noted that the redevelopment would create badly needed new jobs. "We lost 3,000 to 4,000 jobs over the years as Grumman left," he said.
Ms. Lohneiss said the town's consultants had projected that "within five years 2,200 new jobs with an annual payroll of $26 million will be created and property taxes should reach about $1.7 million."
"We believe the impact of these sales will be wonderful, not only for the town of Riverhead but for all of Suffolk County," Ms. Lohneiss said.

HEADLINE: IN MY . . . PURSE/KAREN HIMLE

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT 

 BODY:
As senior vice president for corporate affairs at the St. Paul Companies, an insurance conglomerate in Minnesota, Karen Himle totes the predictable accouterments of her trade, from pens to legal documents. But the other contents of her Louis Vuitton purse say almost as much about the local climate as they do about her job.
Inside are two tubes of hand cream, six tubes of lipstick and two containers of lip balm. "Winter is very dry," she says. 
 The bag was a Christmas gift she requested for its ample interior; her old one couldn't handle all the stuff she likes to have on hand for her two daughters, Lauren, 9, and Kirsten, 5. On this day, out tumbled a grape Juicy-Juice box drink, a lollipop and a canister of undeveloped film from a snowmobile vacation and Lauren's birthday party.
The purse also holds many business cards, which she keeps not only as a record of whom she has met but also for scrap paper. "I always take notes on the back," she said.
It is clear that Ms. Himle, 43, wasn't prepared for the recent increase in stamp prices. The bag contains a variety of unpaid bills, each awaiting an extra penny of postage.
 ROY FURCHGOTT

HEADLINE: Westchester Guide

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

Restorer From Monticello
Peter Hatch, director of gardens and grounds at Monticello, will talk about his 22 years of restoring, maintaining and writing books on the subject on Wednesday at 10 A.M. at Phillipsburg Manor in Sleepy Hollow. 
 His illustrated lecture, "Thomas Jefferson, Gardener," will explore the passion for gardening that led Jefferson to plant 113 species of ornamental trees, 65 varieties of shrubs, more than 100 herbaceous plants in the flower gardens and 450 varieties of 95 species of fruits, vegetables, nuts and herbs.
After his death in 1826, the gardens fell into ruin, but thanks to his record keeping and Mr. Hatch and his associates, they have been restored.
Washington's home will be the subject of a program on March 10 at 11 A.M. at the same site. Dennis Pogue, director of restoration at Mount Vernon, will talk about "Reconstructing George Washington's Pioneer Farm." In a departure from the traditional focus on Washington and the house where he spent many years and died, Mr. Pogue will describe the 5-year, $3 million project in which a new agricultural exhibition was created on the grounds, defining Washington's place in agricultural history and the slave-based economy under which his farm thrived. The restoration includes the re-creation of Washington's barns and outbuildings.
The fee for each lecture is $10 by advance registration. Both programs were organized by Lyndhurst in Tarrytown, a property of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, and Historic Hudson Valley. For reservations, call 631-4481.
 
Lithographer at Purchase
Ed Colker, whose woodcuts, lithographs, etchings and limited editions may be seen at the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College through April 25, will lead an informal gallery tour of his work during the Art Sandwiched-In program on Wednesday at noon.
"Five Decades in Print: Ed Colker," a traveling exhibition organized by the University of Arizona Museum of Art in Tucson, is meant to show that the artist is an illuminator, rather than an illustrator.
He received classical training as a designer, etcher and engraver at the Philadelphia Museum School. During his long career he has been a dean and department head at the University of Illinois in Chicago and at Cornell University. He served as dean of visual arts at Purchase College from 1980 to 1985 and recently retired as provost of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn.
Admission to the Neubergeris by donation of $4, $2 for people older than 64 and students. Children younger than 13are admitted free. For more information, call 251-6100.
 
Evening on Haiti
An evening of Haitian music, dancing, readings of prose and poetry and impromptu dialogue begins today at 5 P.M. in the living room of the Edward Hopper House in Nyack. It is the first in a series of programs related to the current exhibition of Haitian art from the private collection of the filmmaker Jonathan Demme.
Steve Deats of the Rockland Conservatory of Music will provide the beat for the dancing of Rose Deats. Mr. Deats is the Haitian drummer featured on the soundtrack of Mr. Demme's film "Beloved." Cheri Perkins-Raglan will read from her poems, and a reception will follow the performance.
Hopper House Art Center is at 82 North Broadway. Admission is by donation of $3. For more information, call 358-0774.
 
Dance Performance
"See the Music, Hear the Dance," a program performed by members of the Westchester Philharmonic Orchestra and the Mid-Westchester Y Dance School in New Rochelle, is meant to involve children from 6 through 12 years in the creation of a dance performance through the collaboration of composer, musician, choreographer, dancer and conductor.
The program, to be presented today at 1 and 2:30 P.M. at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College, is one of the orchestra's informal Sunday afternoon concerts aimed at introducing children to classical music. The program will include works by Glazunov, Offenbach and Scott Joplin.
A concert on March 14 in the same spot at 1 and 2:30 P.M. will be narrated by the actress Lucie Arnaz. The story, written by Sharon Dennis Wyeth with music by Brad Ross, is from "A Family for Baby Grand." It follows the piano on its travels from the protection of its concert grand mother to a store window and eventually to the concert stage where the baby grand becomes part of a new family of violins, tubas, piccolos, trombones and bassoons.
The price of both concerts is $30, $20 for children. Single tickets are $17.50 and $12.50.. Call 682-3707, extension 10, for reservations or more information.
 
Looking at Women in Art
"Salome: Images of Women in Contemporary Art" opens today at the Castle Gallery of the College of New Rochelle, remaining through April 9. The exhibition presents an overview of the way women are represented in art at the close of the millennium.
"We can no longer take images of women at face value," Katherine Gass, guest curator of the exhibition, said. "A wide range of subtexts have emerged that challenge us to look with harder intensity and greater intellectual consideration."
The use of Salome as a metaphor for the complexity of a woman is based on interpretations of power, seduction, loyalty and revenge, which motivated her demand for the head of John the Baptist as quid pro quo for dancing for King Herod.
A reception will be held today from 2 to 4 P.M. for the painters, sculptors, photographers and video artists who contributed to the show. They include John Ahearn, Chuck Agro, Maureen Connor, John Currin, Barbara Ess, Jenny Gage, Dana Hoey, Catherine Howe, Richard Kern, Kellie O'Bosky, Tony Oursler and Hannah Wilke.
A panel discussion among the artists, Ms. Gass and Dr. Susan Channing, chairwoman of the Arts and Sciences Department at the college, will take place on March 3 in the auditorium.
Admission to the exhibition and the panel discussion is free. Call 654-5423 for more information. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: The Fight to Restore the Hudson's Beauty;
River of Dreams: Clean Up the Waterfront and the Tourists Will Come

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
ONCE so pristine it fired the passions of an entire school of painters, the Hudson River waterfront has become littered with the remnants of industrial development. While environmentalists, developers and city planners grow frustrated with the landscape of deteriorating bulkheads and abandoned factory buildings, they are also thwarted by a fickle marketplace, the cost of removing chemical contamination and political infighting.
In the more than decadelong struggle to rehabilitate the property between the train tracks and the water, those groups have logged few gains. From Yonkers to Peekskill, officials continue to seek solutions while enticing real estate speculators to the river's edge and trying to pacify an electorate eager to eliminate pollution. 
 Officials are also wrestling with these questions:
*In seeking profits, will waterfront developers build so densely that they obscure views of the Hudson and bar access to the public?
*What mix of residential, commercial and recreational development is appropriate?
*When housing is built, what balance should be struck between market-rate units and affordable ones?
Such problems are not unique to the Hudson waterfront. "We're seeing the same phenomenon around the globe," said Dick Rigby, co-director of the Waterfront Center in Washington, a 17-year-old nonprofit consulting organization.
"In a word, the problem is de-industrialization," Mr. Rigby said. "That has left a lot of abandoned territory, but it also spells opportunity, although there are often many issues to sort out first."
For the 10 communities along the 49 miles of Hudson River in Westchester, there have been shared dilemmas like housing projects that have fallen through and special problems in deciding what to do with property when a major corporation leaves town.
In Hastings-on-Hudson, for example, a series of optimistic waterfront development proposals in the late 1980's and early 1990's finally gave way to an economic recession and then to the discovery last year of polychlorinated biphenyls buried along the waterfront. Concentrations of underground PCB's at a former industrial site in the village measured as high as 381,000 parts per million, the State Department of Environmental Conservation reported. The state standard for PCB's below the surface is 10 parts per million.
The Hastings riverfront has the highest concentration of PCB's of any site in the state, and it is believed that the contaminants are flushing into the main waterway with each tide. PCB's used at the former Anaconda Cable and Wire factory have been shown to cause cancer in laboratory animals and is linked to learning problems in children exposed even to small amounts before birth.
Worried Hastings residents -- who several years ago fought against growing piles of garbage illegally dumped on their docks -- marched on Albany last week demanding an immediate cleanup of the latest threat to their quality of life.
"We're taking the bull by the horns in this matter to get a cleanup going," said Jean Zimmerman, chairwoman of the Hastings Waterfront Watch citizens group, who said she was angry and frustrated. "And we're going to keep fighting until that happens."
In Tarrytown, efforts to transform an aging industrial site to a park have also been thwarted in part by pollution (coal tar deposits from industrial uses) but mostly by what Mayor Eileen Pilla describes as "politics, pure and simple politics."
Members of the Board of Trustees have failed to agree on what constitutes proper development for the village -- and as a result, in the last three years residents have seen only limited revitalization of their 22-acre waterfront. "They just don't get it," Mayor Pilla, a Democrat, said last week of Trustees who oppose her plans for housing and a supermarket at the river's edge. "What they forget is that our waterfront is a contaminated site, and a redevelopment company is willing to come in and clean it up and invest millions of dollars in projects that would in turn contribute to our tax base."
The bulk of the resistance to Mayor Pilla's plans has come from Trustee Paul Janos Jr., a Republican and restaurateur who is running for Mayor. The fight with the current Democratic administration is not about whether to clean up and develop the waterfront, Mr. Janos said, but how best to accomplish those goals. (Mrs. Pilla announced recently that she would not seek re-election.) With the remark "Let's do our homework first," Mr. Janos said that the 400 housing units proposed by the Mayor would increase the village's population "by 10 percent overnight" and would put stress on Tarrytown's road system.
A less contentious scenario is taking place in the village of Ossining, where Cappelli Enterprises of Valhalla has an agreement with the village to develop residential units, an amphitheater, a restaurant and a health and fitness club on 10.5 miles of the village's waterfront.
Ossining's redevelopment plans have been unusual in Westchester in that they have taken only three years to evolve -- "and with no hassles," said Michael D. Zarin, a White Plains lawyer and land-use expert representing the village.
"There will be some affordable housing and also housing for the affluent," Mr. Zarin said. "Ossining is a diverse community, and the waterfront will reflect that."
He observed that the ease with which the redevelopment project has been accepted reflects "a somewhat apolitical Village Board that has not infused politics into this."
Just south of Ossining in the village of Sleepy Hollow, dissension over the waterfront has come not from within but from an increasingly strained relationship between village officials and the major corporation, General Motors, which dominated the waterfront there for almost a century. Villagers are now witnessing the dismantling of the General Motors plant, which was closed about two years ago.
Mayor Sean Treacy said last week that he is worried that G.M. will redevelop its 100-acre scenic property near the Tappan Zee Bridge with scant regard for the present needs of the village. G.M. had employed generations of Tarrytown residents at its Westchester plant since the early 1900's, and the village is now struggling to shift its economy and carry on, the Mayor said.
While he said he is hopeful that a potential developer -- Donald Trump is reportedly among them -- will envision a bold future for the property, Mayor Treacy said he wants it to have a variety of uses and remain accessible to the public for boating and hiking.
Up and down the river there is also talk of attracting tourist dollars.
"But none of us really believes that our waterfronts are going to become a Disney World on the Hudson," Mayor Treacy said.
Mayor Robert W. Elliott in Croton-on-Hudson agreed. "It will be as much or as little as each community wants," he said, observing also that most tourists would be attracted to the cultural and scenic attributes of the river and not to large commercial ventures along it. He predicted, however, that some day ferries would busily crisscross the river again, as they did earlier in the century.
New York Waterway operates a seasonal tourist ferry from Manhattan to Tarrytown and plans to begin another this spring to carry commuters back and forth from Haverstraw in Rockland County to Ossining, where they can board trains to New York City.
Mayor Elliott, also president of Historic Rivertowns of Westchester, an alliance concerned with future uses of the river, said all but a small section of Croton-on-Hudson's waterfront is owned by either the village or the county. The village's plans are to maintain a large part of its nine miles of waterfront as open space for recreational use -- and not to develop it commercially.
Nearby Cortlandt has the longest waterfront in the county -- 11 miles -- and has decided to keep almost half of it as open space.
In Yonkers, which has 5.3 miles of waterfront, many proposals for redevelopment have failed over the years, apparently because of poor planning and changing economics.
Most notably, a plan announced in 1979 for a 1,850-unit condominium project, Pierpointe on the Hudson, was barely under way before it collapsed under financial pressure. Less than 10 percent of the units were eventually developed, and the rest of the plan was abandoned.
"In the past, the city has left the details and responsibility of the waterfront to private developers," James Surdoval, Director of Downtown and Waterfront Development, said. "Now we're working in partnership with the private sector."
Mr. Surdoval said the developer for the current proposal, Collins Enterprises of Old Greenwich, will build market-rate rental housing, along with office and retail space. In addition, a public park and an esplanade are planned for the first phase, to be completed in two years. The property is to be developed with a combination of Federal, state, county, city and private funds, Mr. Surdoval said.
In part, an unpredictable economy also foiled earlier plans for development of the waterfront in Dobbs Ferry. In the late 1980's, a bankrupt developer walked away from a proposed 140-unit housing project, leaving behind unfinished model homes and construction debris near a steep hill leading to the Hudson.
The project became the subject of a lawsuit prosecuted by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., senior lawyer for the Riverkeeper Fund and a professor at the Environmental Litigation Clinic of Pace University's School of Law. The successful citizens' suit, which was filed in Federal District Court in White Plains, cited sections of the Clean Water Act and said the crumbling development posed a threat to populations of fresh water fish and blue crabs in nearby Wicker's Creek.
Now, 90 duplex town houses are being proposed for the site, although those plans are encountering roadblocks. This time, a citizens group and others are objecting to the project because it would be near an American Indian archeological site and shell midden where thousands of artifacts like knives, hunting tools and pottery have been unearthed.
Some progress is being made through the efforts of land trust groups. In Irvington, the nonprofit Scenic Hudson Land Trust stepped in last spring to help transform 12 acres of industrial waterfront to a park, buying two parcels on the waterfront. That project also marked the state's first expenditure of $175,000 in Clean Water/Clean Air Bond Act funds to clean up contaminated sites. In the case of Irvington, the contaminants are lead and small amounts of petroleum hydrocarbons. In Peekskill the land trust recently helped buy 8.1 acres on the river with matching city funds. The plans call for cleaning up a former industrial site for recreational use.
Observers like Jeffrey Anzevino, a waterfront specialist and planner for Scenic Hudson in Poughkeepsie, said that for many communities the question is, Will proposals become a reality or will they become casualties of a changing economy and conflicting political goals?
Another uncertainty ahead for Westchester's waterfront involves the pockets of riverside contamination and who will bear responsibility for undoing past land-use mistakes: the municipalities, the state, the present owners or a combination of those? Will the worries of the people who live along the river and visit it be heard?
"Often when a highly toxic site is discovered, the community doesn't have the courage to resist, but we're determined to get officials to listen to us," Mrs. Zimmerman in Hastings said.

HEADLINE: In the Region / Connecticut;
Developer Uses State Law to Fight Local Resistance

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
LATE last month displeasure with Connecticut's Affordable Housing Law led Darien to follow a path blazed in New Canaan two years ago by condemning an approved residential complex that would have had a 25 percent component of units for moderate-income tenants. Plans to purchase the Darien property by eminent domain for municipal purposes are under way.
Also last month, a referendum in the affluent community of Orange in New Haven County approved, by a vote of 1,523 to 326, condemnation of a 10-acre parcel that was under purchase contract for development as rental apartments. 
 In all three communities the developer whose projects were the target of municipal takeover was Avalon Bay Communities of Alexandria, Va.
All three projects are typical of Avalon's design for luxury -- low-rise rental-apartment communities built in New England architectural style and offering residents pools, clubhouses, concierge services, gyms and other amenities.
And all three projects were also typical of another Avalon strategy -- using Connecticut's Affordable Housing Law as a way to overcome local opposition in upscale residential towns where rental apartments are perceived as serving an undesirable transient market. Under the state law's provisions, local authorities who reject projects with moderate-rent components cannot prohibit their construction unless they can prove to the court's satisfaction that the plans threaten the community's welfare.
The law was adopted in 1989 in an effort to increase the state's stock of housing with moderate rents or prices to 10 percent of dwellings in every town. Most Fairfield County communities fall well below that goal.
Developers who provide the 25 percent component are granted extra density for their projects. The income of tenants for the below-market-rate rental units may not exceed 80 percent of the state's or area's median income, whichever is lower. Qualified applicants are selected on a first-come, first-served basis. In a high-income area such as lower Fairfield County, 80 percent of the state median income of about $54,000 would apply in determining below-market rents.
Avalon has contracted to buy the 32 acres on which to build 189 apartments in 24 buildings in Darien from the D'Addario family. The only access to the property is through a 3.7-acre parcel owned by David Duhaime, a New York City developer, whose application to build 148 apartments in an adjacent parcel was rejected. The Selectmen have resolved to condemn his project as well.
"This has become a common tactic in Fairfield County," said Ridgely Brown, Mr. Duhaime's lawyer. "The town uses condemnation to make things negotiable."
During the law's decade of existence Avalon has been successful in using the law to build apartments in Trumbull, where resistance was severe, and in Wilton, where it was less severe.
In New Canaan, mediation ended in an agreement whereby the town deeded a 9.1-acre site to Avalon elsewhere in the municipality in return for the 3.64-acre downtown site owned by the developer. Avalon then signed a 99-year lease for 10,000 square feet of the property to build a 15,000-square-foot office building.
Unlike New Canaan, Darien has no alternate sites to offer. "We are completely built out," said First Selectman Robert F. Harrel, Jr. "When we add onto a school we have to take land from athletic fields or open space. I don't think people were put off by the affordable housing component. What Avalon charges for affordables is a reasonably healthy rental."
Timothy Hollister, a Hartford lawyer who specializes in affordable housing cases, is handling the Darien and Orange disputes for Avalon. The company is a defendant with Darien in a lawsuit brought by Mr. Duhaime appealing the approval of Avalon's application for 189 apartments next door to his rejected project.
"The law is successful but agonizingly slow," said Mr. Hollister. According to a survey he conducted two years ago, 1,500 units around the state received zoning approval in housing courts set up to hear cases related to the law. "That's about 2 percent of the building permits issued for housing."
BEFORE Darien's condemnation resolution becomes a reality, an appraisal of the property must be made for the town, and a vote on appropriating funds to acquire the property by eminent domain must be taken by Darien's Board of Finance and Representative Town Meeting.
In the meantime, Samuel B. Fuller, regional vice president of Avalon Bay Communities, said, "Darien's decision doesn't change our position. We will go ahead expeditiously to begin development. Condemnation will cost them north of $20 million. That's the value for which we have an appraisal based on the highest and best use of the land."
Darien and Orange have contended that there are pressing needs for the parcels in question. In Darien, Mr. Harrel said, "municipal uses have not been totally defined, but we need a senior center, athletic facilities, a community center, and child care."
Orange held two referendums on borrowing $1.5 million to purchase Avalon's optioned 10 acres. The first failed. The second won after Robert C. Sousa, the First Selectman, convinced the town that 200 acres south of Route 1, including the Avalon parcel, would be ideal for a technology park.
"We are not worried about affordable housing," he said. "We have 13,000 people in 4,000 homes. Avalon wants 168 apartments, or 4 percent of the town's housing. We are concerned about the size."
A 40-acre parcel behind Route 1 was offered by the town as an alternate site and rejected by Avalon because it determined that 35 acres are wetlands.
Shortly after Avalon submitted its application to Orange in 1997 the zoning was changed to eliminate residential and retail uses on the entire 200 acres, retaining only industrial use. A 50-acre parcel next to Avalon's, owned by Stew Leonard's supermarkets since 1996, was also rendered useless and is subject to condemnation.
"We're still shaking our heads, wondering what they want," said Stew Leonard Jr., president of the firm. A Marriott Hotel, Christmas Tree Shop, and two restaurants have recently been built adjacent to his land. "We're just going to sit on it, plant corn for a few years," Mr. Leonard added.
Ernest Cuzzocreo, owner of 70 of the 200 acres, including the optioned Avalon parcel, is skeptical about prospects for a technology park. "I've had the land for sale for many years with different brokers, and there has been no activity whatsoever," he said. "In the past four years the town's Economic Development Commission has not brought a single prospect to look at the property."
Nor is he pleased with the town's offer of $1.5 million when Avalon has appraised it at $6.5 million.
In three towns where affordable housing is in good supply Avalon is building market-rate apartments. Avalon Valley with 268 apartments, and Avalon Lake with 135, are rising in Danbury and open for leasing. Occupancy is scheduled for early spring. Avalon Haven in North Haven received a required zone change and construction will start on 128 apartments this summer.
The remaining four of Avalon's eight Connecticut projects are in Stamford, one of the few Fairfield towns that exceeds the 10 percent affordable housing goal. As a result, said Robin Stein, Stamford's director of land use planning, "they don't need to use the affordable units as a club to get in here."
Three of the Stamford complexes will be rented at market rates, the fourth, on the former Burdick Elementary School site owned by the city, must have 15 percent of the 300 units offered at affordable rates under the city's own ruling.
Avalon Grove and Avalon Glen, built in downtown Stamford during the 90's with a total of 638 apartments, charge from $1,300 to $3,200 a month for one- to three-bedroom units; occupancy is 95 percent. "They are obviously serving an important niche in the market," said Mr. Stein.
Pent-up demand that Avalon and other builders are fulfilling could be intensified, he said, when construction of three or four approved office buildings is no longer delayed by lack of financing due to a dearth of preleasing commitments.
Avalon's success nationwide is grounded in its policy of building the kind of luxury rental apartment communities that attract young professionals on their way up to home ownership and older empty-nesters scaling down from a large house. The company targets attractive towns close to major cities, towns where incomes are relatively high.
Rents have escalated with inflation, a robust economy, and luxurious extras in amenities and architectural features, leading to questions in a heterogeneous city like Stamford about Avalon's selective use of the affordable housing law, and an appearance of elitism.
"They tend to build gated communities," said Mr. Stein. "We don't see as many of the people who live in Avalon Grove walking around downtown as we had hoped. They drive in and drive out -- like people do at the mall."
"Part of Avalon's success is price," he acknowledged, "but given the legitimate concern about affordable housing here we would like to explore with them ways to get more of it."

HEADLINE: WORKING;
How to Break The Chains

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:

Q. I work for a lawyer who has become very abusive. He tells clients that I am messing up their cases and losing paperwork. He alternately curses me and calls me "dear." At the same time, he is constantly giving mesmall gifts. I am seeking other employment, but he has tried to stop me. Now he insists that we walk out of the office together so that other lawyers in the building can see that he, in his words, owns me. His best effort at flattery was to tell me jokingly that if I left, he would die. I know he has behaved this way toward former female employees, but since he is a sole practitioner and I am the only employee, there's no way for me to go over his head. Any advice?
 
A. Get out. Your boss sounds not just abusive, but downright creepy. Even if his more bizarre statements are in jest, his fixation on you seems decidedly unhealthy. 
 "Some of the things he's doing come close to being physically dangerous -- walking her out and making subtle threats," said Cindia Cameron, organizing director of 9 to 5, National Association of Working Women, which is based in Milwaukee. You should check the hours that your building has a security guard on duty, Ms. Cameron suggested.
In finding a new job -- and in surviving in the meantime when there are only two of you -- you face an especially sticky situation. First, make sure you have calmly told your boss exactly what behavior you find so objectionable. Then, if you still have to, put your points in writing and present them to him.
Ms. Cameron advises being as specific as possible. "There's no point in saying, 'Your behavior is making me crazy,' " she said. Instead, ask your boss to refrain from giving you presents, calling you "dear" and criticizing you in front of clients.
Save a copy of your note at home. If the situation worsens and you resign before finding other work, the documentation could help you collect unemployment insurance benefits. "She would have a viable argument that she didn't quit per se, but was really forced to quit in terms of how he treated her," said Doris Ng, a lawyer for Equal Rights Advocates, an advice and counseling organization based in San Francisco.
Because your boss seems intent on sabotaging your job search, try to keep him in the dark as to where you're looking. Should potential employers ask for references, simply explain that you can't list your current boss because he does not want you to leave, Ms. Cameron advised.
As for your rights, legal action doesn't sound like a choice at this point. "There's no law against being a jerky boss," she said.
Although your workplace certainly sounds hostile, whether your boss's behavior rises to the level of sexual harassment is open to question, Ms. Ng explained. "There doesn't seem to be any quid pro quo involved," she said.
Rather than prolonging the fight with your boss, better to simply end it. And, after you escape to a new job, just make sure you don't leave him a forwarding address.
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she responds to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

HEADLINE: Filling in the Blanks At Battery Park City

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
"I GET a headache if I don't hear the sound of piledrivers," said James F. Gill, the chairman of the Battery Park City Authority.
Hold the aspirin. 
 So many projects are under way at Battery Park City that the 92-acre landfill along the Hudson River, a once-blank slate on which politicians and planners have been writing for four decades, is actually running out of room.
"We're going like the hammers of hell," Mr. Gill said. Two thousand apartments in eight buildings, a Ritz-Carlton and an Embassy Suites hotel, an addition to the Museum of Jewish Heritage-A Living Memorial to the Holocaust and a home for the Skyscraper Museum, two public schools, four ferry slips and a 15-screen multiplex are newly finished, in construction or being designed. If Mr. Gill had his way, the recently merged National Association of Securities Dealers and American Stock Exchange would be in the mix, too.
All told, the current boom involves 10 of the remaining 18 undeveloped parcels. And Mr. Gill said he has "every intention" of allocating the rest of the available lots on his watch. "Battery Park City sat doing nothing for a long time," he said. "I want to get as much built as is humanly possible while the market continues."
John La Mura, the president and chief executive of the authority, underscored a "need to reflect carefully" on what comes next. "If commercial buildings in lower Manhattan are becoming residential," he said, "where do people recreate? If the residents who live here say, 'We enjoy this ratio of open space,' with each new apartment building, that ratio diminishes."
Although she does not always see eye-to-eye with the authority, Anne Compoccia, the chairwoman of Community Board 1 in lower Manhattan, agrees that things are advancing quickly at Battery Park City -- too quickly. "They should slow down and think about what they're doing," she said.
Of course, growth always induces growing pains, and Battery Park City is not immune. The loss of open space has meant the eviction of Cirque du Soleil, which pitched its tent for 10 years on the landfill. A six-year struggle has yet to be resolved between the authority and the unit owners in the Hudson View West condominium over the ground rent and payments in lieu of real estate taxes. And the expansion plans at the Holocaust memorial have been postponed for the moment by a dispute over financing between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki.
There is also much tension between Mr. Gill and Mr. La Mura, both appointees of Mr. Pataki, although they insist it has not hampered significant decisions.
More substantively, the authority is torn between its fiduciary responsibility to get top dollar for development sites, its municipal responsibility to make Battery Park City a lively citywide attraction and its social responsibility to insure that neighborhoods are diverse and desirable.
A tug-of-war between the community and the authority over an "interim" ballfield, for example, was only partly resolved by the authority's assurance that the field will be made permanent. The question now is what happens to the development potential -- 870,000 square feet, roughly 870 apartments -- represented by the baseball diamonds, tennis and basketball courts. Mr. Gill said the total value of the land if fully developed would be $100 million. Were the authority to forgo that revenue, he said, it would amount to "the most expensive Little League field in the world." What the authority will do instead is shift most of the unused development rights -- perhaps 700,000 square feet -- to other parcels in the north neighborhood, which will yield larger buildings on those sites than were called for in the master plan.
"The more we develop," Mr. Gill said, "the more revenue we generate."
The authority estimates it will turn over $44 million to New York City this year, after operating expenses of $21 million and debt service of $65 million on $1 billion in bonds. Total revenues are $131 million, of which $119 million comes from ground rents and payments in lieu of real estate taxes. The authority owns the land and leases it to developers until the year 2069.
One-quarter of the operating budget goes to maintain the generously landscaped parkland, which is the prime attraction of Battery Park City to many New Yorkers -- and a lure for development. "I look at it as leveraged money," said Robert M. Serpico, the authority's chief financial officer. "You're spending money to make money."
Thirty percent of the space at Battery Park City was set aside for parks, plazas and esplanades under the 1979 master plan by the architects Alexander Cooper and Stanton Eckstut, during the chairmanship of Richard A. Kahan. The plan called for 14,000 housing units (4,550 have been built and 2,000 are in the pipeline) and 6 million square feet of commercial space, a goal that was met by the World Financial Center and exceeded with the construction two years ago of the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The original plan of 1969 envisioned a population of 50,000 -- two-thirds of them middle- and low-income families -- and employment for 35,000.
Today, some 40,000 people work in the World Financial Center, including the Mercantile Exchange and its Commodity Exchange division. About 8,000 people live in Battery Park City, but it is a far less diverse population than was envisioned. "We've got too many yuppies," Mr. Gill said. "I mean, we like yuppies. But enough already."
"I don't want Battery Park City to be an elitist community," he said. "I don't think that's healthy for any community."
To broaden the age mix, the authority has awarded a development site in the north neighborhood to Brookdale Living Communities of Chicago, a national builder of high-end, independent-living quarters for the elderly. Its 14-story, 220-unit building, the Hallmark, was designed by Lucien Lagrange and Schuman Lichtenstein Claman Efron. The $50 million project is to open next year.
Residents will have to be at least 62 years old. Fees are to run from $3,400 a month for a studio apartment to $8,500 for a two-bedroom unit with a den, which is to include daily breakfasts and 20 dinners, housekeeping and linen service, some utilities, a health clinic in the building and other features.
"With the amenities that Battery Park City has to offer as it gets built up, it's a great place to retire and grow old," said Mark J. Schulte, president and chief executive of Brookdale.
At the same time, the authority is encouraging more families with children to settle in Battery Park City through the construction of larger apartments.
"When we started to develop the north, we put an emphasis on family-sized apartments," said Enid K. Feist, vice president for policy and operations at the authority.
In Tribeca Bridge Tower, which the authority developed itself and now plans to sell, there are no studio apartments and only 21 one-bedroom units. But there are 128 two- and three-bedroom units. Depending on size and location, a three-bedroom apartment rents for $4,500 to $6,000 a month. The authority set aside 30 apartments for families who cannot afford those rents but earn too much to qualify for the "80-20" program. The architects were Costas Kondylis, John R. Menz & Richard Cook and Pasanella & Klein Stolzman & Berg.
At the base of the tower is Public School-Intermediate School 89, with room for 850 students, which opened in September. "If you live in our building, you can send your kid down the hall to school," Mr. Gill said. "If the kid is smart enough when he gets to high school level, he can go to Stuyvesant" -- right across Chambers Street.
Another step toward economic integration is "80-20" housing, in which 80 percent of the apartments are rented at market rates and 20 percent are subsidized and made available to those earning 50 percent or less of the median income for New York City. In return, developers obtain real-estate tax abatements and lower-interest financing through tax-exempt bonds.
Ms. Compoccia said that was far from a panacea. "I'm middle-class," she said. "For argument's sake, give me the opportunity to live in a place like that."
FOUR new buildings at Battery Park City are in the "80-20" program:
* River Watch, a 9-story building with 209 units, developed by the Brodsky Organization and designed by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates and Schuman Lichtenstein. Occupancy is expected in June.
* A 9-story building (yet to be named) with 208 units, developed by the DeMatteis Organization and designed by the same team as River Walk. Occupancy is expected late this year or early in 2000.
* Tribeca Park, a 27-story building with 395 units, developed by the Related Companies and designed by Robert A. M. Stern and Mr. Kondylis. It is to open in May.
* Tribeca Pointe, a 43-story tower with 340 units, by the Rockrose Development Corporation. Tenants have begun moving in.
Tribeca Pointe dramatically illustrates the impact of the "80-20" program. Two-bedroom apartments rent on the market for $3,285 to $4,760 a month. But a family of four with a total annual income between $19,090 and $25,100 could have qualified for a two-bedroom apartment at $525 a month.
"It's truly like winning the lottery," said Kevin P. Singleton, vice president and general manager of Rockrose Development. Chance does figure into it, since priority is determined by numbers assigned to the applications as they are randomly pulled from mail bags. There were more than 3,000 applicants for 70 apartments at Tribeca Pointe, said Sofia Estevez of Rockrose.
Last month, Rockrose was designated the developer of a site at 21 River Terrace in the north end. Designed by Gruzen Samton, the 27-story building will have 300 to 330 units. None will be subsidized. And Rockrose will pay the equivalent of full real-estate taxes.
A significant footnote at 21 River Terrace is that one of the bidders was Avalon Bay Communities, a real-estate investment trust based in Alexandria, Va.
"The most important thing that has changed recently is that national real estate companies are responding to the authority's R.F.P.'s," said Jon McMillan, vice president of the Landmark America development concern in Portland, Me., and former planning director at Battery Park City.
Other national companies arriving at Battery Park City include the Promus Hotel Corporation of Memphis, Tenn., which is allied with Forest City Ratner Companies in the construction of a $163 million, 14-story mixed-use project on Vesey Street, which is to be completed in 2000.
Bisected by a 140-foot-high, art-filled public atrium, the building will contain a 4,000-seat multiplex operated by Regal Cinemas of Knoxville, Tenn., which calls itself the largest motion picture exhibitor in the world; a 463-room Embassy Suites Hotel and a New York Sports Club. The architects are Perkins Eastman, with interiors designed by Alexandra Champalimaud.
The next hotel at Battery Park City, opening in 2001, is to be a 250-room Ritz-Carlton, which will occupy the lower floors of a 38-story tower planned by Millennium Partners on the southernmost parcel. The deluxe hotel chain, based in Atlanta, has not been in New York for two years.
The $175 million project includes a permanent, rent-free home for the Skyscraper Museum, which has wandered from space to space since its founding three years ago. On the 14th floor will be a restaurant with an outdoor terrace overlooking the harbor. Above that will be 150 condominiums. The architects are Gary Edward Handel & Associates and the Polshek Partnership.
In designing the tower, the architects attempted to move beyond the existing esthetic in the residential neighborhoods, where guidelines carefully specify traditional-looking brick and masonry buildings.
While the north side of the Ritz-Carlton Downtown will hew to that, the south and west facades will have a 35-story curtain wall of glass, representing a "more progressive esthetic," said Todd H. Schliemann, a partner in the Polshek firm.
"Lighthouse" was a word used both by Mr. Schliemann and by Scott P. Keller, a partner in Gruzen Samton, which designed Tribeca Pointe at the opposite end of Battery Park City, also with a broad expanse of glass in its upper floors.
"It's like a beacon for the whole of Battery Park City," Mr. Keller said. "As such, it should reflect not only the residential buildings but the office buildings."
With the two critical end sites accounted for, the authority is focusing on a huge parcel in the middle, Site 26, north of the World Financial Center. Officials estimate it could accommodate 1.4 million square feet of commercial development. It was in play last year as a possible site for the New York Stock Exchange.
World Financial Properties, the successor to Olympia & York, which owns and manages the World Financial Center, has proposed building a new home for the National Association of Securities Dealers and American Stock Exchange on Site 26.
Michael Jones, the chief administrative officer of the N.A.S.D., said last week that Battery Park City "certainly could be" a site but that no decision had been made yet.
"We'd love to see Nasdaq-Amex decide to stay downtown," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York. "And certainly one of the most attractive sites downtown is Battery Park City."
Daniel Rappaport, chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange, believes it might be especially fruitful if Nasdaq and Amex were only a block away.
"Having them as neighbors would lead us perhaps to becoming more involved in joint ventures." Mr. Rappaport said.
The exchange is one of the most surprising features of Battery Park City, in that nothing about its restrained, gray-flannel facade betrays the sheer pandemonium within, where two 25,000-square-foot trading floors seethe with hundreds of brokers and traders swarming around circular pits.
Clad in the eye-popping colors of a medieval pageant, shouting and gesturing wildly, they buy and sell futures and options in crude oil, heating oil, gasoline, natural gas, platinum, copper, silver and gold.
Mark Shearman, a natural gas trader, said he liked the extra room in the ring, better places to eat and a gym in the building. But the biggest change in his routine since the exchange moved from the World Trade Center is that he commutes by ferry. "It's a nice little ride across the river," he said, "and I'm right at the building."
MR. SHEARMAN is in good company. About 13,000 passengers a day use the small, floating ferry terminal. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is planning a permanent new one, doubling its capacity to four slips. The $24 million project is to open in 2001.
Crossing West Street to Battery Park City sometimes seems like more of a challenge than crossing the Hudson, especially for children, the elderly or disabled. There are three pedestrian bridges over the roadway but the elevators are not yet working at the bridge that joins the north end to TriBeCa. The authority is considering a fourth bridge, around Morris Street, Mr. La Mura said, as a link the burgeoning south neighborhood.
With the perspective of 20 years and 20-20 hindsight, Mr. Eckstut said one problem with the 1979 plan was the necessary assumption that the Westway highway would be built along the Hudson River, affecting the orientation of Battery Park City.
"The project essentially turns its back to the city," said Mr. Eckstut, now a principal in Ehrenkrantz, Eckstut & Kuhn. While he sees things in need of "tweaking" -- the listless retail space in the World Financial Center, the lack of meaningful waterfront activity -- Mr. Eckstut sounded generally satisfied with the plan as it evolved. "It really feels and looks like New York, which was our goal," Mr. Eckstut said. Where development has veered from the plan, he finds it is usually positive. For instance, he said, "There's a whole emerging cultural district that we never anticipated."
That district is anchored by the Museum of Jewish Heritage and Holocaust memorial, completed in 1997 to designs by Kevin Roche, with interiors by Patrick Gallagher.
The museum is planning a $44 million east wing, containing an auditorium, galleries and viewing rooms for the archives of Steven Spielberg's Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation. Mr. Roche and Mr. Gallagher would collaborate again.
New York museums are typically knit to the surrounding urban fabric but a visit to the Museum of Jewish Heritage helps dispel the sense of incongruity in its isolated location at Manhattan's tip.
After circling the windowless first-floor galleries on Jewish life a century ago, then the windowless second-floor galleries on the Holocaust, a visitor arrives at a hexagonal rotunda on the third floor, with a tall glass case enclosing a Torah scroll that was to have been exhibited in a museum of the "extinct Jewish race" in Prague.
Beyond that case is a row of windows. And out the windows are Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 12; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: SENIORITY;
Why Roll theDice?

BYLINE: By FRED BROCK; Fred Brock is an editor at The Times. His column on the approach to and arrival at retirement will appear the first Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to fbrock@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AS the politicians and lobbyists in Washington strive to score political or ideological points in the Social Security debate, they should be aware that people like Edith Chvala are watching them. Like some economists, she questions the wisdom of staking Social Security funds on the stock market.
Ms. Chvala, 75, lives alone in a mobile home seven miles southeast of Silver City, N.M., on $703 a month -- $542 from Social Security and $161 from a pension. 
 She jokes about being poor, but is quick to point out that she is blessed with good health. Many older people are in worse financial shape, she says, often because they are faced with large prescription bills not covered by Medicare.
As she watches the struggle over Social Security, Ms. Chvala has come to at least one conclusion: She is not excited about proposals that would put a portion of the funds, now invested in Treasury securities, into the stock market -- whether it's President Clinton's plan for the Government to invest the money or the Republicans' notion of allowing individuals to invest part of their Social Security tax payments themselves.
"I'm not a gambler," she said. "It seems like they want to gamble with our retirement money."
If Ms. Chvala is cool to the ideas, so is L. Douglas Lee, chief economist at HSBC Securities in Washington. Unlike many of his Wall Street brethren, he has reservations about privatization, despite the billions of dollars it would pump into the stock market. And he is one of a number of economists who believes that low-ball economic projections and assumptions have led to erroneous conclusions that the Social Security system must be "saved" or "fixed."
Mr. Lee, who is 51, has nothing per se against investing retirement funds in the stock market. But he points out that the Social Security system is more than a retirement program, with features like benefits for the disabled or for dependent children after the death of their working parent. "I think the Government should fund the social welfare aspects of Social Security," he said.
Privatizing Social Security, he said, won't increase the overall resources of the economy, but merely shift them around. And it could drive up interest rates by decreasing the money available to the Treasury, forcing it to borrow more in the private sector.
Mr. Lee says the conventional wisdom that the current system faces bankruptcy is "a little silly."
"Economic forecasts are wrong a large part of the time," he said. "We have to be very careful about making major policy decisions based on projections, especially when other projections, which are very reasonable, show a very different outcome."
But he said that putting part of the budget surplus into Social Security, in effect reducing the Federal debt, as President Clinton has proposed, would build the nation's resources. That would likely bring economic growth, which would increase payments into the Social Security fund, he said. He thinks the Republican plan to cut taxes would only encourage consumption.
"The one thing we can point to over the last few years that has had a positive effect on savings has been to reduce the Federal deficit and move into surplus," he said. "This produces growth, and that's what's going to be needed in order to meet the promises that have been made to future retirees."
IN the end, decisions about Social Security will have direct effects on real lives of real people -- like Ms. Chvala.
A native of Germany, she came to the United States in 1930, when she was 7. She grew up in New York, living in Queens and then Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn.
She married in 1945 and followed her husband, a construction worker, around the Northeast. In 1970, they moved to Buffalo, where she worked as a nurse's aide for 20 years. That job was the source of her small pension. The couple divorced in 1973.
At the urging of a son, she moved to New Mexico in 1990, when she was 67. She used her savings to buy a mobile home and parked it rent-free on her son's property. The son later divorced and moved to Arizona, but his former wife allowed Ms. Chvala to stay.
Four times a week, Ms. Chvala drives her 1985 Chevy Blazer to Western New Mexico University in Silver City, where she swims and is a volunteer at the school's museum.
She thinks she might qualify for some sort of welfare, but would rather get by without it, as Social Security lets her do.
"I like my independence," she said. "I don't want to ever have to live with my children. I am so thankful for my health. My plan is to just drop dead" -- when the time comes. And she would rather that politicians keep their hands off Social Security in the meantime.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 19; Column 6; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 236 words

HEADLINE: Don't Give Public Land To Private Golf Course

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The sign pictured in your article on a golf course developer that wants to annex part of Liberty State Park speaks volumes, or at least more audibly and true than the comments in support of the idea: "Notice: Golfers Only Beyond This Point." 
 While the developer and his political allies want to convey that this is a "public" course that will somehow benefit children, African-Americans, and the local economy, I believe the only people who will benefit are the privileged few who can afford the fees, equipment, and time off required to get in 18 holes. Maybe there will be free rounds for kids and the economically underprivileged, and maybe the owners will continue to allow Fourth of July picnics on what will be the 17th and 18th holes. Then again, I think not.
The article attempts to minimize the issue by calling the land in question a "sliver" and "spit." If this is true, why can't the developer subdivide his current 16 holes?
In any case, land was set aside for Liberty State Park to be used by all people. Since when do we hand over any amount of public park land to a private developer? I voted for a ballot question in November, which was passed by a majority vote, providing for purchase by the state of open space to be saved from development. An excellent idea, I thought. But the golf proposal would be giving away land we already have.
 
JIM DONOHUE
