HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Saturn SC2;
Finding a Jackpot Behind Door No. 3

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
NECESSITY is the mother of invention, and for the Saturn Corporation of General Motors, a rather simple invention is generating a much-needed lift in sales of its aging car line.
Saturn's coupe, sedan and wagon, developed in the 1980's and introduced in 1990 -- with few significant changes since -- compete in an ice-cold part of the market. Small-car sales have dropped nearly 10 percent over two years -- Saturn's sales plunged 17 percent -- as buyers shifted to sport utilities, midsize sedans and more luxurious cars. A midsize Saturn, the L-Series, comes this summer, and another freshening of the small cars is due. Still, existing models will not be replaced until the 2003 model year. 
 Against that backdrop, Saturn executives and a group of dealers held a brainstorming session on what they could do to bolster sales while waiting for new products. One suggestion came from Stuart Lasser, who owns three Saturn franchises in New Jersey. His son Hal, then 8, had complained about how hard it was to climb into the rear seat of the two-door model. Mr. Lasser's idea: Why not add a third door?
About that time, minivans were arriving with four doors, and extra doors were being added to extended-cab pickups. At auto shows, design studies like the Pontiac Rageous and Mercury MC4 -- both of them ostensibly coupes -- had small back doors aimed at making them somewhat practical.
Within six weeks of Mr. Lasser's suggestion, Saturn had engineered a prototype of a three-door coupe. The model scored well in consumer clinics, and Saturn decided to put it into production. As of November, all Saturn coupes have been built with a small, rear-hinged door behind the driver's door.
A month later, Saturn reported a spurt in sales, its first year-to-year increase since April and one of the few positive notes in the small-car market. The gains continued in January, with coupe sales up 28 percent.
After a recent test-drive of a Saturn SC2, I was not surprised that the new coupe was doing so well. Even with the third door, which is nearly invisible when the doors are closed, the car has the sporty look that coupe buyers like. Yet the third door opens new markets: Most Saturn coupe owners are single, but the three-door may prove attractive to parents with small children, who like the look but need more practicality.
From the outside, one cannot immediately detect the third door. Last summer Saturn invited some journalists to a preview of future products. Unable to ascertain what was different about the coupe on display, reporters walked around it muttering "What's the big deal?" under their breath.
Then a Saturn executive opened the driver's door and popped open the small door behind it. The innovation was suddenly so obvious. "Why didn't anyone think of that before?" I blurted out -- a line that Saturn executives seized on to use in advertising.
On close inspection, the outline is evident, but doesn't detract from the car's swoopy look. The door has no handle, inside or out; it can be opened only by grasping a small lever exposed when the front door is opened. The latch is not particularly convenient for rear-seat passengers, but that small seat isn't suited for adults anyway.
The extra door -- its window is fixed in place -- is ideal for tossing in a gym bag, a briefcase or a couple sacks of groceries. It allows children to scurry in without having to tip the front seats forward, and it lets parents buckle in their charges without straining their backs. It is ideal for a driver with a wheelchair, who can swing the chair in behind the driver's seat after he or she is positioned at the wheel. With no center pillar, there are no obstacles for loading or unloading the wheelchair.
One suggestion, though: Saturn should consider lighting the area around the latch, which I fumbled for in the dark when assisting my children.
Because the third door is so useful, one may wonder why Saturn didn't add another to the other side. The main reason is the expense, in a market segment highly sensitive to price, but Saturn officials say that consumers who want four doors will buy four-door models -- that is, sedans.
Despite adding the third door, Saturn has lowered prices slightly for 1999. The SC1 now starts at $12,885; the SC2, with a bigger engine and nicer trim, opens at $15,445.
Because adding the door meant eliminating the center pillar, the driver's shoulder belt was moved from the pillar to the side of the seat. That works fine as long as the belt remains in the loop that serves as its guide. But on my test drive, the belt popped out often and pressed against my throat.
Beyond the third door, little has changed on the plastic-bodied, front-drive, four-passenger coupe. Despite continual efforts to muffle the engine, including yet another try this year, the Saturn remains noisy, especially compared with competitors like the Toyota Corolla. "This car is loud," a 10-year-old passenger -- my daughter -- observed. And aside from the engine roar, at 8 miles an hour an aggravating groan came from underneath. After hearing this on two test cars, I asked Saturn officials if there was a problem. They assured me that the abnormal noise was normal, a routine function involving the anti-lock brakes.
The SC1 base model continues to be powered by a single-overhead-cam four-cylinder engine. Displacing 1.9 liters, it is rated at 100 horsepower. The more expensive SC2 comes with a dual-overhead-cam engine that produces 124 horsepower. A five-speed manual transmission is standard; a four-speed automatic is optional.
Saturn was among the first small-car makers to offer traction control, which helps to keep wheels from spinning on slippery surfaces, and it is still one of the few with this feature. (It is included with anti-lock brakes.) Having just come through one of Michigan's snowiest Januarys on record, I greatly appreciated the traction control, which turned the coupe into a sport utility on my unplowed street.
Saturn's hallmarks are economy and reliability rather than quiet, comfort and performance. The handling is nothing special, and acceleration is only adequate.
But dealers do, generally speaking, coddle their customers, who get royal treatment on par with that accorded Lexus owners (who spend far more). Plus, Saturn stores offer something one can't find anywhere else: a two-door car that has three doors.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
In Euroland, Deal Makers Shun the Partner Next Door

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
WHEN Europe's single currency hit the markets just over a month ago, one of the prophecies was that it would lead to a wave of mergers across the Continent's suddenly invisible financial frontiers. Those deals may yet be brewing. But with merger frenzy in the corporate air, they haven't happened quite so rapidly as forecast.
Last week's announcement of plans for a $17 billion takeover of Paribas by Societe Generale, for example, reflected a belated French move to pursue the sort of consolidation of banking and financial services already familiar in Switzerland and some other countries in Europe. But, like a notable nonbank merger announced last month, the acquisition of Marconi Electronics by British Aerospace, it is a move within national borders. 
 Certainly, the pace of mergers and the pressure to make them have accelerated in the 11-nation euro zone since it began phasing in the new currency. But European deal makers have continued to plow familiar furrows.
The announced takeover of Britain's Guardian Royal Exchange by the giant French insurer AXA brings together one company inside the euro zone and one outside it. (Britain is not a member of the currency union.) The pharmaceutical merger that will create the giant AstraZeneca combines companies in two non-euro nations, Sweden and Britain.
Meanwhile, other big deals, like the planned acquisition of Volvo A.B.'s car division by the Ford Motor Company, the DaimlerChrysler merger and Deutsche Bank's deal to acquire Bankers Trust, have crossed the Atlantic.
Many people argue that the logic of a euro zone -- a huge single market of 290 million people, underpinned by a common currency and free of the risks of currency exchanges -- will inevitably press companies to fuse across its internal frontiers for economies of scale, market dominance and cost savings. Some saw the start of that process with the announcement in December of a partial merger deal between two pharmaceutical giants, Hoechst of Germany and Rhone-Poulenc of France.
But one view among corporate leaders who spoke and mingled at the World Economic Forum here, a gathering of the business and policy-shaping elite, is that cross-border mergers within the euro zone face an array of obstacles.
The barriers are rooted not just in national sentiment but also in the politics of unemployment, the slow pace of deregulation in some industries, the hesitancy of some companies to move toward public ownership and, not least, the tough competition rules of the European Union itself.
Consider the view of Gerard Mestrallet, head of the huge French-Belgian corporation Suez-Lyonnaise des Eaux, the fruit of a merger of three companies to create a combine of energy, water supply, waste services and communications businesses.
"Equity nationalism," Mr. Mestrallet said, makes institutional investors in continental Europe wary of the stock of companies in one another's nations, impeding cross-border deals. "We are going to have to find greater acceptance by institutions of the paper of other countries," he said.
ACCORDING to Paul Gibbs, a merger and acquisition analyst at J. P. Morgan in London, cross-border mergers among the 11 euro nations totaled $73 billion last year as the debut of the euro approached, versus $21 billion in 1996. But, significantly, that figure was still less than one-tenth of the record $842 billion of all merger activity involving European businesses last year.
Many forces are at play. A large number of the small- to medium-sized companies that power the German economy are only now preparing themselves for the capital markets after decades of private ownership and bank financing, said Wilhelm Haarmann, a German acquisitions lawyer here. And longstanding efforts to create a pan-European military industry are thwarted because of political sensitivities toward industries like military equipment and aerospace that retain strong government ties, particularly in France.
Regulation is strict, too, within the euro zone. The European Commission, said Fields Wicker-Miurin, an investment banker at A. Kearney Ltd. in London, "has a great deal to say about which deals are acceptable and which are not."
In a continent where unemployment is more than 10 percent, and much higher among young people, any big cross-border merger would immediately raise political hackles over the single issue of downsizing.
"When you lay off people there is a lot of fear, and the unemployment issue is a public issue, especially in Europe," said Daniel Vasella, president of Novartis, the Swiss drug company.
But without the efficiencies that are supposed to wring profitability from the merged companies, jobs are likely to be destroyed eventually anyway, a point that is sometimes lost on the populist strain of merger opponents.
"Only a profitable company can be a social company and create jobs," said Jurgen E. Schrempp, co-chairman of DaimlerChrysler.
Still, corporate bosses see growth in the populists' following.
Rolf-Ernst Breuer, the head of Deutsche Bank, complained in Davos that public sentiment may be swinging against megamergers. The media, he said, have taken to depicting corporate leaders like him as megalomaniacs. And politicians, he said, complain: " 'Look what these managers do: They buy and sell companies like used cars.' "
So, Mr. Breuer warned, "I think we have to be aware that the climate will change rather soon."
Whether such concerns will blunt corporate appetites is another matter. "We have a strategy, and the strategy has not come to an end with Bankers Trust," Mr. Breuer said. "We have to be ready to grab opportunities that offer themselves."

Against expectations, the flurry of mergers and takeovers in Europe since the euro's birth on Jan. 1 has involved few cross-border deals within the 11-nation euro zone; deals within countries or with companies in countries outside the zone have been much more common.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;
Who'll Fill Two Spaces At Big Mall?

BYLINE: By MARCIA BIEDERMAN 

 BODY:
When it opened in November 1996, Atlantic Center, the enclosed mall at the corner of Flatbush and Atlantic Avenues, was considered by some to be a beacon to retailers reluctant to venture into parts of the city outside Manhattan. Now, however, with the impending departure of two large stores, a big chunk of the mall is scheduled to go dark, and it remains to be seen whether other retailers will keep the flame going.
Caldor Corporation, a discount chain based in Norwalk, Conn., which announced plans to liquidate two weeks ago, will close its 130,000-square-foot store at the mall in May, said Joyce Baumgarten, a spokeswoman for Forest City Ratner, owner of the mall. Last Wednesday Kohl's Corporation reached an agreement to buy 32 Caldor locations in the New York region but none in the city itself, said Gary Vasques, a spokesman for Kohl's. 
 Even before the Caldor news, going-out-of-business signs were up at the mall's 44,000-square-foot Sports Authority, part of a chain based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., which has closed a number of stores. Calls to the company were not returned.
Together, the two retailers occupy about 40 percent of the three-story structure. Other major tenants are Old Navy, Office Max and Pathmark.
The developer is "talking to a lot of people" about filling the spaces, Ms. Baumgarten said. Overall, Atlantic Center is "doing well," she said. She would not provide sales figures.
But an author of a new study of retailing in low-income urban areas said there were only a few retailers likely to take over the space. "There aren't a lot of Caldors out there," said Carl E. Steidtmann, director of the retail industry group at Pricewaterhouse Coopers, the accounting firm. Atlantic Center needs to find tenants quickly, he said, because "dark space doesn't send a very good message to the consumer."
The study, conducted by Pricewaterhouse Coopers and the Initiative for a Competitive Inner City, a nonprofit group, found that in a nation saturated with suburban stores, economically disadvantaged urban areas can offer retailers significant untapped profits. Yet, Dr. Steidtmann said, many chains considered such areas unattractive. "Retailers want to open stores where they have opened stores before," he said.
Both he and Murray Forseter, the editor of Chain Store Age, a trade publication, named Kmart as a likely candidate to take Caldor's place at Atlantic Center. But Stephen Pagnani, a spokesman for the discount chain, based in Troy, Mich., said, "We have nothing on our agenda currently for New York, period."
Dr. Steidtmann mentioned Target, a chain operated by the Dayton Hudson Corporation of Minneapolis, as another possible Caldor replacement, but Mr. Forseter disagreed.
Joe Enos, a spokesman for the Old Navy division of Gap Inc., in San Francisco, said Old Navy was "pleased with the traffic at Atlantic Center." And the Pathmark "has exceeded expectations," said Rich Savner, a spokesman for Pathmark Stores Inc. of Carteret, N.J. Neither would provide details. MARCIA BIEDERMAN

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Why Couldn't Anyone Keep Brazil From Burning?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: DAVOS, Switzerland

 BODY:
WHEN Russia's troubles seemed about to send Wall Street and the world over a cliff last fall, President Clinton announced a new strategy in the war against economic contagion.
No longer would the International Monetary Fund and Washington wait for countries to get into deep trouble before coming to their aid. Instead, they would act ahead of disaster, stepping in with precautionary loans for fundamentally healthy economies. Brazil would provide the first test of the new strategy. 
 It all sounded extremely sensible. President Clinton's aides compared the strategy to a grand immunization program. Others conjured up images of alert firefighters spraying water on the roof of an intact house in a burning neighborhood.
Scarcely three months later, the I.M.F.'s $42 billion preventive package for Brazil -- including a $5 billion commitment from the Treasury -- looks like another failed effort to stop the global economic crisis. Why did the $42 billion defensive line crumble so fast? And, assuming Brazil is not the last domino to fall, what do the events there portend for the coming year?
"The Brazilian experience raises as a question whether it is feasible for the I.M.F. to act in a preventative mode," said Jeffrey R. Shafer, the former Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs and an architect of the 1995 Mexico bailout. "Perhaps all they can be is an ambulance corps."
At the heart of the failure was a bet that turned bad. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and his deputy, Lawrence H. Summers, signed on to the deal because they were relatively confident that the Government of Fernando Henrique Cardoso had the clout to execute the economic changes it promised in return for the aid. "These are all probabilistic decisions," Mr. Rubin said recently. "You make the best decisions you can based on the information you have at the time. You can't judge these things by how they turned out, post facto."
In short, Mr. Rubin places his bets the way he did during a 26-year career on Wall Street, with the understanding that a certain percentage will go bad.
But Washington operates on different rules, and already there is sniping on Capitol Hill that Mr. Rubin placed too much confidence in Mr. Cardoso, much as the Treasury bet too readily last summer that President Boris N. Yeltsin would execute economic changes in Russia.
Both bets went wrong for essentially the same reason. Mr. Rubin and Mr. Summers negotiated with their counterparts, but the Russian Duma, and then the Brazilian Congress, failed to deliver. The budget cuts and other austerity measures were just too hard for politicians to swallow. It was the classic clash between the demands of the markets and the demands of populist politics.
Needless to say, the workings of the Brazilian Congress and the Russian Duma are as different as the February weather in Brasilia and Moscow. But no doubt it was the experience of being seared in both legislatures that led Mr. Rubin, in a speech to the World Economic Forum here, to say that when it comes to saving nations from economic implosion, "I have come to believe that the ultimate key is not economics or finance, but politics -- the art of developing support for strong policy, especially for the hard decisions that involve present sacrifice for future benefit."
THE problem with precautionary programs like the one the Treasury and the I.M.F. tried in Brazil is that they can relieve the pressure on politicians to make those hard decisions.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Rubin hoped that the announcement of the huge package would give Mr. Cardoso the breathing room to bring a reluctant and famously free-spending Congress into line. It had the opposite effect. With the $42 billion package in place, Congress concluded that the economy was insulated from disaster, even if it dragged its feet on unpopular votes.
"In retrospect, we took the heat off the Brazilians just when they needed to get energized," one senior Administration official said recently. The only benefit, others in the Administration say, is that the meltdown was postponed until January -- when it did less damage to the rest of the world than it might have in October.
The Brazil experience, though, is worth remembering when judging some of the other ideas floating around about how to stabilize the world financial system. One is to "prequalify" countries for aid in the event of a crisis. The country in question would demonstrate to the I.M.F. that it practiced safe economics -- no wild spending, a minimum of crony capitalism and corruption, real oversight of its banking system. In return, the I.M.F. would promise to come to its aid if the markets ever staged a run on the country.
What would happen, though, if the country fell off the wagon? Announcing that its government no longer qualified for protection would be the equivalent of throwing the nation to the sharks. Even without such a declaration, investors would sniff any failure to act, and race for the exits. Just ask Mr. Cardoso, who will now spend the rest of the year trying to rebuild the confidence he lost by waiting too long. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Mark L. Yockey;
Artisan International Fund

BYLINE: By WILLIAM R. LONG 

 BODY:
THE financial crisis in Asia and Latin America has been a good reason for Mark L. Yockey, manager of the Artisan International fund, to favor European stocks. But it is not the only one. He follows a bottom-up approach to picking stocks, looking for focused, fast-growing companies run by progressive managers -- and he is finding more and more of them in Europe.
"In Europe, you've had a sea change in the last five years in the quality of the management," he said. "A whole new wave of management came in, and they really were more focused on profitability." 
 Harnessing that kind of management awareness for his fund has helped Mr. Yockey earn an average annualized return of 21.4 percent from Artisan International's inception in December 1995 though January of this year, versus just 8.3 percent for the average foreign stock fund, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher.
Lanky, with salt-and-pepper hair, Mr. Yockey, 42, works in a 29th floor office in San Francisco with three analysts. The four travel the world, sizing up companies that have caught their interest.
One of their rules of thumb is that a company's forward price-to-earnings ratio should be no greater than its three-year forward earnings growth rate, a variation of the common price-earnings-growth, or P.E.G., ratio, which compares a stock's p/e with its one-year earnings growth rate. Mr. Yockey looks for big profit margins and cash flows, but also for management that zeroes in on its best business. "We love focused managements," he said. "If you try to do one thing, you can probably do it pretty well. But you try to do six different things, and you know what? It just doesn't work."
Not that his tenure has been without bumps. In 1997, 13 percent of the fund's assets were in Latin America and 8 percent in Hong Kong. Downturns in those markets resulted in a return of just 3.5 percent that year versus an average of 5.1 percent for its peers.
Deregulation is another theme, especially in telecommunications -- and not just for European companies. Metronet Communications of Calgary, Alberta, is taking advantage of deregulation to provide voice and data services to business customers. It is the fund's biggest holding, at 4.5 percent of assets.
The chief executive of the company is Craig Young, who headed Brooks Fiber Properties, a local telecommunications services company bought by MCI Worldcom last year. "He successfully built one company and sold it," Mr. Yockey said.
Metronet is building broad-band fiber optic networks for high-speed communications in major Canadian cities. Mr. Yockey expects company sales to grow from $200 million this year to $500 million or $600 million in 2001, in Canadian dollars. "We think in 2001 they'll become profitable," he said, versus the losses he expects them to post for both 1999 and 2000 due to capital expenditures.
Artisan International first bought class B shares of Metronet at the initial public offering price of $16.23 (United States) in December 1997. The shares closed on Friday at $38.50. Mr. Yockey's target price for January 2000 is $60.
The hot product of another pick, Finland's Nokia, is the little wireless phone that also keeps an electronic list of names and numbers and receives E-mail messages. "Nokia is driving the cellular phone business on a global basis," Mr. Yockey said.
He first invested in Nokia in the fall of 1997, at the outset of the Asian financial crisis, when the price of A.D.R.'s was down to $37, from about $50. "The stock had been creamed because people were saying that the sales in Asia were going to be poor," he recalled.
But the company's earnings grew by more than 60 percent in 1998, and the A.D.R.'s have shot up to $130.375; his target in 12 months is $175. He estimates Nokia's average annual earnings growth at 30 percent, and its 1999 price-earnings multiple is 28.
Nokia management has done a brilliant job, Mr. Yockey said: "Ten years ago they were a little company up in Finland that nobody had ever heard of, and today they are one of the global leaders in the cellular communications market."
Health care companies are another favorite. He invested in Roche Holding A.G., the Swiss drug giant, in October at about 16,000 Swiss francs and has a target price of 22,000 francs for January 2000. It closed on Friday at 18,250 francs.
Mr. Yockey calculates Roche's three-year earnings growth rate at 23 percent, below its 1999 price-earnings multiple of 26. He said he made an exception to his usual stock-selection rules because Roche was "one of the best companies in the world" and because he expected a big acquisition soon, which would bolster its earnings. He said he was upbeat about new Roche drugs, including Xenical, for obesity; GS4104 for influenza, and several for cancer.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Electronic Middleman for Mortgages

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
NEVER before had William Ikley enjoyed much leverage when applying for a loan, especially a mortgage.
But this time, Mr. Ikley, 36, a butcher who lives in Eldersburg, Md., had a firm deal just one business day after logging on to the Priceline.com Web site. And he, not a lender, was in charge. "It's been a real easy experience," he said. "There wasn't any pressure, doing it from home." 
 In fact, he applied while in his pajamas. And he expects to have a check in hand tomorrow, 10 days after initiating the name-your-price mortgage.
Priceline.com made its name by letting consumers offer bids on airline tickets -- then hotels and, in New York City, cars. The vendors can then accept or reject the offers. Now the company has extended this method for more complex transactions: mortgages.
The new program might not be such a smooth process for everyone. Mr. Ikley needed only a small second mortgage, a $5,000, five-year home equity loan. He was knowledgeable enough to do without the guidance provided by mortgage brokers, who stand to lose business to this potentially less expensive electronic middleman. And as Mr. Ikley learned, Priceline's lenders are not exactly giving money away. He will be paying 8.17 percent rather than the 6.9 percent he had optimistically proposed.
Still, his transaction represents another stage in the evolution of what Priceline calls buyer-driven commerce, which harnesses the Internet's speed and vast scope.
The Tower Group, a consulting firm in Needham, Mass., estimates that by 2001, 10 percent of first mortgages in a $1 trillion-a-year market will involve the Internet. Many Web sites and institutions already match borrowers and lenders, but Priceline's is the first program that lets the consumer initiate the terms.
"We put the customer more in control," said Richard S. Braddock, a former senior executive at Citicorp who is now chairman of Priceline.
THE mortgage process, conducted in partnership with Lendingtree, an on-line loan originator, is fairly straightforward. A loan seeker can apply to finance a particular house, condominium or co-op or to qualify before choosing a property. The borrower visits www.priceline.com and specifies a type of financing (like 15- or 30-year, fixed rate or adjustable), an interest rate, points and a desired closing date. A monthly payment may also be proposed.
The applicant also supplies income and other information that a lender can use to evaluate creditworthiness. A $200 deposit is charged to a credit card. Any response from among Lendingtree's 15 lenders, including the Dime Savings Bank of New York, Greenpoint Financial and the Money Store, must arrive within two business days.
If a lender accepts, the deal is struck and the deposit is applied to the usual fees, like the appraisal. Or the lenders can submit counteroffers. If the borrower rejects them, the application dies and the $200 charge is erased. The charge is not refunded if the customer walks away from an accepted bid.
Unlike Priceline's other businesses, its mortgage service relies on applicants who have already done enough homework to know what they want and what terms they can reasonably expect.
At Priceline.com, borrowers cannot browse through an array of rates and terms without risking a commitment. "It doesn't really allow for shopping," said James P. Punishill, an analyst at Forrester Research of Cambridge, Mass.
Other on-line services -- Web sites of individual lenders or the dozens of so-called aggregators like E-Loan or Quicken or Lendingtree itself -- do allow borrowers to survey the financial landscape.
Armed with information, though, Priceline customers will gain great flexibility, according to Theodore Iacobuzio of the Tower Group. They will probably save money, too, unless they can strike a deal with, for example, a local bank that throws in a free checking account or other services.
Brokers, for their part, are taking this new mortgage-market refinement in stride, said A. W. Pickel 3d of Lenexa, Kan., co-chairman of the technology panel of the National Association of Mortgage Brokers.
"There's definitely a place for it," he said, but he contended that he and his colleagues, many of whom have Web sites of their own, would not suffer much, because consumers need the hand-holding that brokers provide.
Priceline is not as free of added costs as borrowers might think, Mr. Pickel said, because lenders must add to their rates or points the fees they pay to Priceline but which the service does not disclose. Mortgage brokers collect fees in similar ways.
Though Mr. Iacobuzio thinks the on-line mortgage business has "a very big future," he said it would be many years before paperwork disappears and transactions can be conducted electronically end to end.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
For New Orleans, Mardi Gras Is Becoming an All-Year Cash Cow

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
THE calendar says Mardi Gras season lasts seven weeks this year, from King's Day (Jan. 6) to the climactic Fat Tuesday (Feb. 16).
But for the industry behind "laissez les bon temps rouler," Mardi Gras has become a rapidly growing year-round business with global exports. 
 "Economically, it is by far the single-largest special event," says Marc Morial, the Mayor of New Orleans. "It's bigger than Jazz Fest, it's bigger than the Sugar Bowl, it's bigger than the Super Bowl." An annual study by James J. McLain, an economics professor at the University of New Orleans, shows that Mardi Gras spending in the New Orleans area alone has more than tripled in 12 years, to $840 million in 1998 from $240 million in 1986.
To see that growth in tangible form, look no further than the bead- and trinket-strewn racks of Accent Attic, which takes in more than $6 million a year by supplying members of krewes -- the clubs that sponsor and ride on Mardi Gras parade floats -- with the so-called throws they shower on revelers.
"Mardi Gras is over 100 years old, but it has made tremendous growth in the last 15 years," said Accent Attic's owner, Dom Corlone, a former jewelry salesman who went into the Mardi Gras business in 1980. "Fashion jewelry was difficult because if you didn't sell it right away, it was out of style. Mardi Gras, what you buy won't go stale. It looked like a safe business to go into."
But growth has also attracted competitors who underpriced some of Mr. Corlone's products, so lately he has emphasized catering to the krewes' desire for exclusive trinkets. On his annual buying trip to Asia, Mr. Corlone designed a special necklace for Le Krewe d'Etat, which he has since kept under wraps lest other krewes rush to competitors for copies. The secret: "For the night parade, glow-in-the-dark beads," he said, and a battery-powered flashing-eye medallion.
In the 11 Accent Attic stores, bead prices range from less than 2 cents a strand for 18 inches of plastic beads to $1.16 for an 8-foot-long string of fake pearls. There are also bracelets, hair ties, surgical scrubs, hats, banners, stuffed toys, women's underwear and all manner of beverage containers in the official Mardi Gras colors of purple, green and gold.
According to Dr. McLain's report, the average krewe member will toss $540 of this stuff to the crowd, and it's not uncommon for a float rider to go through $1,000 worth or more. In all, Dr. McLain estimates that more than $9.1 million in throws were tossed last year.
THROWS are a visible but small part of the industry that has grown up around the 60 separate Mardi Gras parades in New Orleans each year. There is bigger money in building parade floats, a market dominated by three specialist companies. The largest is Kern Studio, parent of several family-run concerns, which gets $20 million in annual revenue from outfitting 33 of the parades, according to Barry Kern, the company's president. Mr. Kern and his siblings, Brian, Blaine Jr., Blainey and Thais, run the 52-year-old company with their father, Blaine Sr., the founder.
Kern maintains more than 300 floats and thousands of ornamental props, which are often recycled: This year, a giant bust of John Wayne was altered to become Freddy Kruger's scarred visage. The company is now building its largest float, the 240-foot-long "S.S. Endymion," with a million feet of optical-fiber lighting effects powered by a generator "which we believe could light up a minor league baseball park," said Ed Muniz, captain of the Endymion krewe. Dues from Endymion's roughly 2,000 members underwrite the $2 million cost.
Once a seasonal business, Kern is now busy year-round, and not just because it is already designing floats for 2000 before the 1999 models have rolled. The company runs tours of its float factory and rents its warehouses for parties. Mr. Kern said the company's facilities, known as Mardi Gras World, are host to about 125 parties a year averaging 650 guests each. "It's a cash cow," he said.
But it is still not the whole cow. Kern gets 20 to 30 percent of its revenue by using its Mardi Gras skills in other businesses, like building facades, decorations and rides for theme parks and running parades in places from Philadelphia to France to Japan.
Demand for Mardi Gras products is increasing outside of New Orleans as seasonal celebrations grow in cities like Galveston, Tex., and Shreveport, La., and in Mobile, Ala., where a parading tradition predates that of New Orleans. Accent Attic makes 15 percent of its sales out of state, from Italy to Guam and even the Asian countries where the beads are made. "We ship it right back to Hong Kong, because you can't find it there," Mr. Corlone said.
Other businesses get in on les bon temps, too. Bakeries across Louisiana add extra shifts to crank out a Mardi Gras tradition, king cakes -- brioche dough circles filled with spice, fruit or cheese and dusted with green, yellow and purple sugar with a small plastic baby doll baked inside. The cake is served at the beginning of the season -- the feast of the Epiphany; whoever is served the slice with the doll buys the next year's cake.
Gambino's, one of the larger bakers, has a separate plant that cranks up in late December to turn out up to 5,000 king cakes a day, about half shipped to out-of-town customers in a $25 to $50 Mardi Gras kit with paraphernalia like beads, cups and a CD of suitable music. Two weeks before Mardi Gras, one day's orders from Gambino's included shipments to Britain, Norway, Spain Switzerland, Belgium, Japan, Taiwan and Venezuela.
The Mardi Gras bonanza even reaches neighborhood concerns. Small hardware stores do a brisk business in a peculiar product: folding wooden ladders with a seat attached and wheels on two of the legs. Children sit on top to watch the parades, and afterward the ladder is collapsed and used as a rolling carrier for ice chests, sleepy kids and Mardi Gras booty. Philip Deutch, owner of four Ace Hardware stores, said the contraptions bolster what are otherwise the slowest months for hardware retailing: Mardi Gras season accounts for more than half the ladders his stores sell.
The ladder-seats typically cost about $60, but ladder shoppers also commonly buy spray paint, staple guns and glue guns to decorate the ladders. The city's famous termites help assure that customers come back year after year.
Though the city goes to some lengths to stave off direct commercial tie-ins with parades, commercialism occasionally creeps in anyway, especially in the suburbs. The Popeye's restaurant chain gives krewes "doubloons" to throw that can be redeemed for a discount on a chicken dinner. A local potato chip company, Zapp's, makes Mardi Gras-colored bags of chips for use as throws. And Anheuser Busch has sent the Budweiser Clydesdales every year since 1964.
But there will be no Nike or Nokia Mardi Gras. "We are opposed to commercial involvement in the parading events," Mayor Morial said. "It doesn't need to be changed. Why overanalyze something that is so successful?"

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
The Profit Picture: A Rosy Tinge for '99

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
NOW that fourth-quarter earnings are mostly in the books, it is clear that the worst fears about last summer's emerging-markets panic did not pan out. Indeed, it suddenly seems that many naysaying forecasters are painting a far brighter earnings landscape for 1999.
At Merrill Lynch, economists recently raised their forecast for earnings growth of the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to 3.5 percent in 1999, up from a previous prediction, in mid-December, of a 5 percent drop. That's an 8.5-percentage point swing in less than two months. 
 The change resulted from "continued strength in the economy and less pressure on profit margins, which is the result of continued restructuring," said Gerald D. Cohen, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch.
Merrill is far from alone in its optimism. "I'm very bullish on corporate earnings," said Byron Wien, United States strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The economy has a lot of momentum, and I'm optimistic earnings are going to exceed expectations."
Among strategists, the average estimate for that growth is 4.1 percent for companies in the S.& P. 500, versus two-tenths of 1 percent in 1998. according to I.B.E.S. International, a research firm. And among the industries in the index, the engines are likely to be technology, health care and perhaps energy -- a huge 1998 loser that most analysts see stabilizing in 1999.
That is good news for investors, especially with the stock market at record levels and valuations. In the absence of lower interest rates, better profits are probably the best catalyst for more market gains.
Indeed, some strategists suggest that the factors that dampened earnings in last year's third quarter -- the first time in seven years that profits declined for American corporations -- have proved extremely short-lived. Edward Kerschner, a Paine Webber strategist who expects profit growth of 5 to 8 percent in 1999, contends that the poor third quarter resulted from several coincidental factors, including the market plunge in August, the General Motors strike and a steep drop in oil earnings.
Yes, emerging markets still gyrate. But in the case of G.M., the company has already stunned industry analysts by suggesting last month that its earnings could top $10 a share in 1999 if the company meets aggressive financial and production targets. And many analysts do not think oil prices can fall much below their current $12 level.
Meanwhile, Wall Street analysts, who estimate profits for individual companies and tend to be far more optimistic than the strategists, are forecasting aggregate profit growth of 17.2 percent for the companies in the S.& P. 500, versus the strategists' estimate of 4.1 percent, according to I.B.E.S. The gap between the two groups' forecasts is generally far less.
But analysts are already starting to scale back their estimates, as has often been the case in the past. The analysts tracked by I.B.E.S. lowered their first-quarter profit-growth forecasts for S.& P. 500 companies to 4.4 percent as of Jan. 28, down from 5.5 percent a week earlier. Even given the customary volatility of such forecasts, the change represented a surprisingly large reduction in such a short time, said Joseph Abbott, an equity strategist at I.B.E.S.
WHY are analysts optimistic?
In technology, they see continuing strong sales of personal computers, software and semiconductors -- and they know that slack overseas demand in 1998 could make this year's numbers look that much better. I.B.E.S. estimates are for white-hot earnings growth of 35.6 percent for the industry.
Health care is getting help from continued good results at pharmaceutical companies, which have been coming up with an array of new drugs. I.B.E.S. expects 15.9 percent earnings growth for the year.
One big turnaround sector is likely to be financial companies, with expected earnings growth of 17.7 percent -- although the gain would be from last year's disappointing numbers, which were dragged down by third-quarter disasters in emerging markets and hedge funds.
While oil prices could fall again, further depressing energy stocks, some analysts think the industry may have bottomed. Mr. Kerschner calculates that if earnings in the industry had been flat in the fourth quarter, instead of declining over 63 percent as analysts estimate they did, total domestic corporate profit growth would have been about twice as high for the period.
Still, strategists predict that several sectors could be disappointments this year, particularly two that can suffer in periods of slow growth: basic materials and commodity companies and capital equipment suppliers like the Case Corporation, Deere & Company and Caterpillar Inc. "That's where the real vulnerability is," said Chuck Hill, director of research at First Call in Boston.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
An Investor Who Shops for Spunk

BYLINE: By GEANNE ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
AS investment pundits warn about an Internet bubble and Bill Gates of Microsoft wonders where the mania for Internet stocks will end, Michael S. Egan is quietly keeping his chips on the virtual table.
Mr. Egan, 58, knows something about building companies. He made a fortune by turning around the Alamo rental-car company and selling it to Republic Industries in 1997 for $625 million, with his stake worth about $587 million. Then he started an investment company, Dancing Bear Investments, and looked for promising businesses. 
 About that time, he was becoming infatuated with cyberspace. "I started doing a lot of business electronically with the airline reservation systems and the Internet," he said in an interview. "It was quite apparent that it was going to be the major economic revolution of the world since maybe the printing press or currency."
But Mr. Egan wasn't about to invest in a company just because it had dot-com in its name. He was looking for a startup nobody else had heard of and true grit in the people in charge. "They had to have a high, high work ethic," he said. "They had to be able to suffer a blow."
Mr. Egan, an alumnus of Cornell University, mentioned to the university's president one day that he was looking for a "media play on the Net." Perhaps, he was told, he should check out a company called Theglobe.com that a couple of recent graduates, Todd Krizelman and Stephan Paternot, had started while still in college.
Theglobe.com calls itself an Internet "community" that offers its users entertainment, information and shopping opportunities. Mr. Egan liked the concept and flew to Ithaca, N.Y., to have lunch with the two men. After five hours, he made it clear he wanted to buy into their venture.
In February 1997, he dispatched Edward Cespedes, a Dancing Bear executive, for follow-up talks. "Ed was told that he couldn't leave the office until the negotiation was done," said Mr. Krizelman, now 25, one year older than his partner. "He lived on our couches in the office and shared meal after meal of Chinese food with us." Six months later, Mr. Egan paid $20 million for a 51 percent stake in the company.
The payoff came last Nov. 13. In its first day of trading, the stock of Theglobe.com rocketed 606 percent, from $9 to $63.50, the biggest first-day run-up of any initial public offering. "It was an adrenaline day if there ever was one," Mr. Egan said. His stake of roughly six million shares is now worth $382 million.
Mr. Egan has made other smart investments, most notably a controlling stake in Nantucket Nectars, a Massachusetts juice maker, that he sold last year to Ocean Spray for an undisclosed profit. Even for this low-tech venture, his enthusiasm was boundless. Tom First, one of the founders, recalled a conversation on a private jet: "He starts talking about how the company would be a $200 million company within five years while I'm concerned that on our one van in Boston the shocks were blown out."
Mr. Egan has used some of his wealth to lead the life of a country squire, building a $12 million mansion in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., for temporary shelter while he renovated his main spread nearby, and assembling a Nantucket vacation compound of 15 houses, a dining hall, a movie house and a baseball diamond for a family that includes five children and three grandchildren.
But his fears after selling Alamo -- that he would "dry up and blow away" -- proved groundless. As he looked for investment leads, he says, he heeded a lesson he learned when he was 15 and was helping to build a family amusement park in his native Wisconsin. He was having trouble managing a work crew of a dozen Native Americans and hired a middle-aged chief named White Cloud as his assistant. White Cloud got instant results, making him realize that "it's the people around you who get the job done for you."
As a young man, Mr. Egan at first pursued a career in tourism. But a "humbling" job in food service, followed by a low-paying stint in academia, cooled that ambition, and he jumped at the chance to run an old friend's family business.
Sitting in the cluttered Silicon Alley office of Theglobe.com recently, he looked more like an artist than an investor with his snowy white hair, black pullover sweater and black trousers. But he talked like an investor as he dismissed fears about an Internet stock bubble. "There's a very good reason a lot of capital is pouring into the Internet," he said. "Fifty million or 100 million data bases being joined with three billion users."
In other recent deals, Mr. Egan bought and sold AutobyInternet Inc. and bought a majority stake in Inteletravel, a privately held Internet travel company. He plans to take public his own start-up, Certified Vacations, a travel company, at the end of this year. Last Monday, Theglobe.com announced its first acquisition, the expected purchase of Azazz.com, an Internet retailer.
What drives Mr. Egan? He says he wants to help young entrepreneurs make their way. The other day, he says, he had breakfast with the two founders of Nantucket Nectars, both in their early 30's. "You see the enthusiasm for life in their eyes and hear it in their voices," he said. "Maybe I'm trying to recapture my youth."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 5; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Wall Street Likes What It Sees In Detroit

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
THESE are fat times for American auto makers. Adjusted for inflation, gasoline prices are as low as they have been in decades, and interest rates are down, too. Perhaps most important, the economy keeps chugging along, keeping sales buoyant.
So, many companies are awash in cash. Some money is being spent: Ford Motor paid $6.5 billion last month to buy Volvo's auto operations. Daimler used $33 billion worth of stock to buy cash-rich Chrysler. But a lot of money is being held as a cushion against the next prolonged drop in sales. 
 At the moment, Wall Street seems to like what it sees. Maryann N. Keller, a managing director at ING Baring Furman Selz, has been following autos for a quarter-century. Last week, she spent some time talking about developments in the business.
 
Q. For much of your career, Detroit has turned out products that many consumers considered inferior to Japanese automobiles. Now, things appear different. Is that the way you see it?
 
A. I am encouraged on two fronts. First, the relative competitive balance between the United States and Japan is as good as it has been in 30 years. The gap has been closed in many areas, from quality to cost to engineering. In some areas you could say American companies are in the lead.
There are some very good Japanese auto makers, with Honda and Toyota head and shoulders above the rest. But Mitsubishi and Nissan are in big trouble.
The second thing is that American companies are beginning to identify themselves differently. It used to be that they had to control all areas of production. Now, they are looking at defining what the strategic competencies they need to have really are, and are seeing their responsibility as defining the vehicle and then developing the brand, marketing and distributing it.
 
Q. Is General Motors' decision to spin out Delphi Automotive an example of this new way of thinking?
 
A. I think the separation of G.M. and Delphi is a significant positive for General Motors. In the past, G.M. always argued that its inferior profit margins, compared with a company like Chrysler, were a result of the fact that G.M. made more of its own stuff. With the spin-out, G.M. will have the chance to have a different kind of cost-of-capital structure. Once it is finished, G.M.'s liquidity, or working capital, will increase by about $2.7 billion.
 
Q. What do you think of Ford's acquisition of Volvo's auto business?
 
A. As far as I'm concerned, that is an acquisition which doesn't solve Ford's problems. Volvo preferred to be bought by Ford because Ford is demonstrably a very good parent. It has been very, very careful in nurturing Jaguar, for example.
But from a financial standpoint, Volvo won't add much to Ford's earnings. There is nothing wrong with Volvo; in fact, it's a company that is without a lot of problems and has real expertise in safety engineering. So if Ford had to buy something, it is as good an acquisition as Ford could have made.
 
Q. What are Ford's problems?
 
A. Ford's issues are cars in North America, and its international operations.
In North America, Ford derives a very high percentage of its sales from car rental companies like Hertz. The average private consumer loves Ford trucks. But Ford has not been able to make much headway in heightening consumer perception of its cars. It needs to be able to tackle this because eventually the pot of gold it has in pickups may go away.
Internationally, Ford has struggled in the 1990's and has lost market share. It has not come up with an effective product response to reverse that.
 
Q. The conventional argument for mergers is global overcapacity. Do you buy that?
 
A. I am perhaps the only person on the planet who doesn't see massive consolidation ahead in the auto industry.
Excess capacity has been a problem for the last 25 years. The fact is, auto companies will build factories whenever they feel they can get an advantage. They did some pretty stupid things in the 1990's.
So I don't think excess capacity is going away. You can't prevent auto company managements from thinking they will have a more strategic reason for investing in a part of the world where they think they can do a better job than the competition. But the U.S. market is where the bulk of the earnings come for the Germans, for Toyota and Honda and for the American manufacturers. This is it.
 
Q. Do you see anyone willing to acquire a Japanese company?
 
A. I don't think any Japanese manufacturers will be taken over. Japanese companies are complicated, Japanese accounting is not transparent and a lot of losses are hidden. Japan is not going to be an engine of growth for a while.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Can Harlem's Heritage Be Saved?;
Many Jewels of Its Vibrant Past Are Gone. Now Some Residents Are Fighting to Landmark the Rest.

BYLINE: BY NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
IN 1976, Josephine E. Jones set eyes on stained-glass windows, carved cherry bannisters and Minton tiles in a Queen Anne-style row house at 137 West 122d Street in Harlem, and she knew it was the home she had dreamed of owning. The detailing was a signature of Francis H. Kimball, one of New York's leading turn-of-the-century architects, and the street was once known locally as Doctors' Row.
Mrs. Jones had made her way north from Greenville, S.C., where her father, a cotton sharecropper, worked for a white landowner with an expansive Victorian estate. Though Mrs. Jones's family had lived in a tiny shack without running water, she remembered playing in the Victorian house and fantasizing about owning one as grand. 
 On 122d Street, Mrs. Jones discovered that treasure, but hardly anyone else recognized it. The neighborhood had been neglected for 30 years, and there were more abandoned buildings on the street than inhabited ones. Thieves had filched many gargoyles, gables and other ornamental details from the row houses, and one historic brownstone had been painted bright orange.
None of that fazed Mrs. Jones, who bought the house for $15,000. In 1992, she asked the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission to designate her home, and the row houses adjoining hers, as official landmarks. She was not the only one. Middle-class and professional African-Americans were increasingly drawn to Harlem, attracted by relatively inexpensive real estate prices, dropping crime rates and signs of economic renewal. They, too, wanted their historic homes and Harlem's other jewels to gain landmark status, which they hoped would help their preservation efforts.
Too many markers of their heritage, they say, have already been destroyed. The famed Cotton Club is gone, as is the Audubon Ballroom, where Malcolm X was killed. So are the Lafayette Theater, where Orson Welles staged the first all-black production of "Macbeth," and the Harlem Opera House, which Oscar Hammerstein opened in 1889. Other important cultural moorings have deteriorated or been partly dismantled, like the Renaissance Ballroom and Theater, Minton's Playhouse and Small's Paradise, where many jazz legends took the stage.
Preservationists argue that many cultural touchstones remain, and can be saved if the Landmarks Preservation Commission acts quickly. They point out that the city's landmarks law lets owners of historic properties qualify for special grants and low-interest loans for restoration work. And the law carries penalties for alterations that compromise a building's historic integrity.
But the landmarking process is never easy, and it is complicated by Harlem's own economic and social dynamics. Some community developers, for example, argue that landmarking brings bureaucratic restraints and higher expenses that make it more difficult to renovate old buildings. Others say that poverty and other social problems make it harder for neighborhood activists to focus on preservation efforts.
Nevertheless, in the last several years, people like Mrs. Jones have formed local advocacy groups to pressure the city and the commission to recognize historic sites in Harlem. In 1991 the city landmarks agency issued a list of 25 sites it promised to place at the top of its agenda. But some residents say the process has stagnated, and neighborhood leaders are expressing frustration.
"Harlem has been ignored up until now," said Carolyn Kent, co-chairwoman of the parks and landmarks committee of Community Board 9, which covers West Harlem. "It has been ignored by its own residents, by downtown advocacy, by the commission, by elected officials. It's a tragedy because we've lost all these places that are of great international importance."
The president of the Hamilton Heights-West Harlem Community Preservation Organization, Ron Melichar, said that many architecturally significant buildings have been ignored. "The concern we feel is that as you look generally at the housing stock in Harlem, you see a deterioration and an increasing disregard for the historic value of what is there," he said. "It has had a big impact on our community, because it doesn't allow for us to move ahead with the revitalization that should happen."
Michael Henry Adams, a preservationist who is writing a book about historic Harlem, has become one of the area's most vocal advocates of landmarking. He argues that the Landmarks Preservation Commission has neglected buildings above 96th Street, thus erasing "the heritage and history and culture of so many people."
"It is not the kind of racism where someone calls you a name," Mr. Adams said. "It's the worst kind, where they just ignore you." He added: "It is an utter scandal that the incredible architectural and cultural heritage here can be destroyed when we have a law in place to protect it. But it is being used in an inequitable way."
The chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, Jennifer J. Raab, said that protecting Harlem was one of her top priorities, along with lower Manhattan and Douglaston, Queens. When Ms. Raab was appointed by the Mayor in 1994, she said, no action had been taken on 12 of the 25 sites that had been nominated. Since then, she said, seven of those sites have been landmarked, including the 1933 Harlem Y.M.C.A. on 135th Street, near Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard, where many important black figures from Richard Wright to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. have lived, visited or spoken.
Mr. Adams was not impressed. "What is that?" he said. "Seven buildings compared to some 600 buildings in Douglaston, Queens, alone, and hundreds of buildings designated in TriBeCa and Greenwich Village. Fewer than 7.5 percent of the buildings that have been designated in New York have been above 96th Street."
Ms. Raab contested Mr. Adams's count, saying that the agency did not tally landmark designations that way. She said her own agenda for Harlem included landmarking more buildings in the Hamilton Heights Historic District, the area between 140th and 145th Streets and St. Nicholas and Amsterdam Avenues. Once that is done, she said, she would consider requests for a Sugar Hill Historic District between Edgecombe and Amsterdam Avenues from 145th to 155th Streets.
"We have been very active in Harlem, very active," Ms. Raab said. "I've been up, I've been out, we've been planning and we are trying to make good decisions. This is something we care about a lot."
But she also said that she tended to focus attention on neighborhoods where there was a strong outpouring of support for landmarking from residents, because she wanted them to understand that landmark status was a responsibility as well as an honor.
Yet as Yuien Chin, an organizer of the Hamilton Heights-Sugar Hill Historic District Committee, a group seeking expansion of the historic districts in western Harlem, pointed out, "The people who fight for landmarking do it in their free time, and there are just so many other quality-of-life issues in this neighborhood that the resources are spread thin." Nevertheless, she said: "We are organized. It just may not be in the traditional way the commission is used to."
But some community developers who want to revive Central Harlem say landmarking would hurt rather than help. Karen A. Phillips, chief executive officer of the nonprofit Abyssinian Development Corporation, said the cost of rehabilitating a historic building under the landmark law can be 20 to 25 percent higher than renovating an ordinary building. For example, she said, some landmarked buildings must have a special kind of wood-frame window that costs three times more than a modern aluminum window.
"If you landmark all of Harlem, you're preserving a ruin rather than preserving a community," Ms. Phillips said.
Even defining the boundaries of Harlem is tough. The landmarks commission contends that sites in Morningside Heights qualify as Harlem, for example, and some preservationists would like to see the neighborhood's borders extend above 155th Street, which is generally considered the beginning of Washington Heights.
In the area traditionally considered Harlem (between 96th and 155th Streets on the East Side and 110th and 155th Streets on the West Side, excluding Morningside Heights) there are now three historic districts: the Hamilton Heights Historic District, in the elevated western section of the city near City College; the Mount Morris Historic District, near Marcus Garvey Park in Central Harlem, and the St. Nicholas Historic District, the two blocks of 138th and 139th Streets commonly known as Striver's Row, because the elite of Harlem lived there.
The commission has also given landmark status to about four dozen individual buildings. Some of the best known are the Apollo Theater, on West 125th Street; the former home of Alexander Hamilton, known as the Grange, on Convent Avenue; the Abyssinian Baptist Church and Community House, on West 138th Street; the Harlem Courthouse, on East 121st Street, and Astor Row on 130th Street. These sites, the commission says, represent pre-Civil War Harlem, the ecclesiastical heritage and the social history of the area.
By way of comparison, however, almost all of Greenwich Village, from St. Luke's Place to West 13th Street and from Washington Street to Washington Square East, is an official historic district, complemented by some 30 individual landmarks in the West and East Villages. A large swath of the Upper West Side -- from Central Park West to Amsterdam Avenue beginning at 62d Street and ending at 85th Street -- is a landmark district, and 50 buildings in the area have landmark status.
Andrew S. Dolkart, an architectural historian who teaches at Columbia University and wrote "Touring Historic Harlem: Four Walks in Northern Manhattan" (New York Landmarks Conservancy, 1997) as well as a history of Morningside Heights published last year, said the city landmarks commission was off to a good start in Harlem. But, he said, "There are still a lot of things, many of them equally good, that have not been landmarked, so there is a pressing need to do more."
The Mount Morris Historic District, for example, was too narrowly defined when it was designated in 1971, Mr. Dolkart said. He said the district should include the Queen Anne row houses on 122d Street, which he said make up "one of the outstanding rows in New York." In 1996, the row was listed on the National Register of Historic Places, with the help of the New York Landmarks Conservancy, a nonprofit group that offers financial and technical help to save historic properties.
But a National Register listing is merely honorific, said Peg Breen, the Conservancy's president, and offers few protections for city buildings. Only the city landmarks law, which carries penalties of up to $5,000 for an initial violation that is not corrected after two warnings, can insure that historic homes are not torn down or altered beyond recognition, she said.
Debbie Wright, president and chief executive officer of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, said that historic preservation is crucial for Harlem because it can help promote tourism. If important sites are preserved, she said, more tourists will visit and spend money in local restaurants, shops and clubs.
In 1924, the writer Arna Bontemps said that the hub of Harlem, near 135th Street, was "like a foretaste of paradise," adding, "A blue haze descended at night and with it strings of fairy lights on the broad avenues."
But that paradise is barely recognizable today. The home of Florence Mills, perhaps the most famous stage performer of the Harlem Renaissance, is one example. The building where she lived, at 220 West 135th Street, is boarded up and so untended that the limbs of a tree reach out of the windows from within the building's husk.
The scholar James Weldon Johnson, who at the turn of the century wrote the poem "Lift Every Voice and Sing," as well as "Black Manhattan," the first historical account of African-Americans in New York City, lived at 187 West 135th Street, next door to the jazz pianist Fats Waller. James Van Der Zee, an important photographer whose work chronicled life in northern Manhattan from the 20's through the late 60's, had his first studio at No. 107.
At the corner of 135th and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard is Small's Paradise, which Lana Turner once called "the home of the happy feet," where waiters wore roller skates or danced the Charleston as they served black and white customers in the 20's. Near the opposite corner was the headquarters of the United Negro Improvement Organization, founded by Marcus Garvey, the first major black pan-African philosopher. Though these buildings still stand, they are unmarked and in various stages of disrepair.
Around the corner on 136th Street, the home of the New York Urban League, founded in 1911 to help Southern blacks who had moved to the city, also still stands, although it has been modernized. But the house on the block with the greatest cultural significance, according to Mr. Dolkart, is gone. That was the rooming house run by Iolanthe Sydney, at No. 267, which Mr. Dolkart wrote, was "the headquarters of the Harlem Renaissance's vanguard wing" and a temporary home to the writers Langston Hughes, Wallace Thurman and Zora Neale Hurston.
And though the intersection of 135th Street and Seventh Avenue (now Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard) was known the Campus of the Harlem Renaissance, according to David Levering Lewis, a historian, only two major historic sites on these two critical blocks have been designated as city landmarks.
Some who live in the existing Harlem historic districts argue that landmarking is uplifting for neighborhoods. The president of the Hamilton Heights Homeowners Association, John Cardwell, said he wanted to see his district expanded because he believed the landmark designation enhanced community pride.
"This neighborhood is changing from a war zone where there's been an active drug war going on to an historic district that is interpreting Alexander Hamilton's time and bringing attention back to the architecture and the streetscape," he said.
When Mrs. Jones began her crusade to expand the Mount Morris Historic District, she had the support of Landmarks Harlem, an advocacy group founded by State Senator David A. Paterson to lobby for preservation in the district. In 1994, the group helped get the National Register of Historic Places to pick Harlem as one of its top 11 most endangered places in the United States. But Landmarks Harlem collapsed in 1996 after a controversy involving one of its officials and allegations of misappropriated funds.
Since then, Mrs. Jones said, she has not been able to garner the kind of community support for landmarking in Central Harlem that the commission seems to want. She said she declined an offer to have just her house designated because she wants the Mount Morris Historic District expanded to include it and many more houses.
Yet Mr. Adams said he worried about the perception that broad community support was needed for landmarking. The law, he said, does not require neighborhood lobbying. If that were the case, he added, only people in wealthy communities would be able to preserve their pasts.
"To contend that only if you have the leisure and the time to advocate on behalf of your community will you be able to get attention, then it's a foregone conclusion that people who live in poor neighborhoods will not get preservation," Mr. Adams said. "The dynamic is that poor people and minorities are shortchanged over and over again by government because people say they aren't organized."
 
A Glance at the Past That Has Been Lost
 
 BLACKS were originally restricted to the balcony of the 1912 Lafayette Theater, near right, on Seventh Avenue between 131st and 132d Streets. In 1936, Orson Welles staged the first all-black production of "Macbeth" at the theater, where Bessie Smith, Duke Ellington and other legends had also performed. A church bought the building in 1951 and had the facade demolished during renovations in 1990.
In 1965, Malcolm X was assassinated at the Audubon Ballroom, center, on Broadway between 165th and 166th Streets. The 1912 building, with lavish terra-cotta details, was gutted in the early 90's for a Columbia University science center, but the facade was preserved.
The Harlem Opera House, far right, at 209 West 125th Street, was opened by Oscar Hammerstein in 1889. In the 30's it featured swing bands and then became a cinema, but it was torn down in 1959 for a bowling alley.

HEADLINE: The World;
How to Curb Borrowing: Make Lending Riskier

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
EVER since the global financial crisis began in East Asia 19 months ago, public debate has focused on the mistake made by the damaged countries: too much borrowing. Now the flip side of that problem is coming into focus: too much lending.
The latest thinking about how to stop new outbreaks of global financial distress features proposals to slow down lending by making it riskier and more expensive. The plans, coming from academics and public officials, would rein in the banks, mutual funds, hedge funds, pension funds and wealthy individuals in industrial countries who in the 1990's poured tens of billions of dollars in short-term loans into East Asia's booming economies. 
 These loans played a huge part in precipitating bankruptcies, bank failures, plunging currencies and recessions, first in Asia, then in Russia and now in Brazil. When trouble came, the lenders canceled the loans, withdrawing their money and leaving whole countries in ruins.
"The fact is that in this particular crisis, private sector lenders have not emerged well," Stanley Fischer, first deputy managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said a week ago at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, an annual gathering of world leaders, corporate executives, economists and other movers and shakers.
The lenders, naturally enough, aren't happy about the attempts to alter their behavior. Rising from his seat in the audience, Deryck C. Maughan, vice chairman of Citigroup Inc., responded to Mr. Fischer by noting that lenders had already lost considerable sums in the current crisis -- a curb in itself on overly risky lending in the future.
In Washington, William Cline, chief economist at the Institute for International Finance, which represents lenders, said new rules that make lending riskier would only inhibit the flow of capital that emerging countries will need to expand their economies once the current global crisis ends.
"It will take some time for a really strong, resurgent lending market to revive," Mr. Cline said. "It is asking for trouble to put up impediments now to this future lending."
But that is the very goal of the new proposals. They seek to avoid flooding a country with too much short-term lending that can be quickly withdrawn. Already some nations are restricting such lending by taxing short-term loans as they enter the country, thus making them more expensive for the borrowers.
The new approaches would strike at the lenders, preventing them, for example, from pulling out their money in the event of crisis conditions -- a weakening currency, shrinking economic growth -- that threaten to devastate an economy. Other proposals would give debtor countries the legal right to reschedule and postpone payments owed to foreign banks and bondholders.
Restricting lenders would solve another problem. It would deflect criticism that the Clinton Administration and the I.M.F., in pushing through huge bailout loans for countries in crisis, are using public money to repay lenders for risky credits they should not have extended in the first place, or at least not in such quantities. Such bailouts will only encourage excessive lending in the future, this argument goes.
"If lenders don't take a hit, they won't price their loans correctly," said Robert Litan, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. "They will set interest rates too low, and they will shovel too much money into questionable markets."
THE proposals to curb lending are coming increasingly from international organizations, most of which bring together representatives from industrial countries where the lenders are located. One proposal, for example, would require or encourage lenders to put aside, say, 9 cents or 10 cents for every dollar lent to banks and businesses in high-risk countries. These are amounts larger than the sums that are required to be put aside today. With that extra money sitting idle, lenders would have to increase their interest rates to earn as much as before -- and the higher rates would inhibit lending.
Another change would make it easier to renegotiate debt, much of which is in the form of bonds sold to mutual funds, hedge funds, wealthy investors and the like. Through a majority vote, for example, these bondholders could agree to stretch out payments from hard-pressed debtors in emerging countries. Currently, most bonds agreements require a unanimous vote to do this.
Still other proposals would put ceilings on short-term lending in risky markets, or require lenders to take a loss on their loans in the event of a crisis -- a "haircut" that Mr. Litan is pushing.
Are any of these changes likely to be adopted and enforced? Probably not, if the global crisis ends soon. Besides, there are few mechanisms to enforce these rules across borders.
Even if the global crisis endures, overcoming the resistance of lenders will not be easy. Borrowers may also object, given the likelihood that the various restrictions will require them to pay higher interest rates.
"The problem is," Mr. Litan said, "that no one wants to be the first to make the necessary commitment."
